webTitle: No apologies from the captains for contrived finale

fields.headline: No apologies from the captains for contrived finale
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje may have lost the final Test of the series and seen his 14-match unbeaten run come to an end, but South Africa's captain was unrepentant at the contrived finish yesterday and threatened to quit if the International Cricket Council intervenes.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje may have lost the final Test of the series and seen his 14-match unbeaten run come to an end, but South Africa's captain was unrepentant at the contrived finish yesterday and threatened to quit if the International Cricket Council intervenes.

"If the ICC are unhappy then I want to get out of the game," he said. "What cricket is all about is having a full house and guys playing and entertaining. This was Test cricket at its best in my opinion.

"I spent a lot of time last night thinking about it. It needs to be seen that 22 players want to play Test cricket and this morning when I arrived at the ground the feeling I got was that all the players wanted to play. Both sides could have won the Test match right at the end and that's what it's all about."

England's captain Nasser Hussain was delighted with the victory but insisted that he did not want to set a precedent for future matches. "The last thing I want to do is devalue Test cricket. We don't want any lob-ups or false declarations, things like that," he said.

"We just wanted one declaration and a good ending, and I think we got that. We're not hiding the fact we still have a lot of work to do. We've lost another series and certainly won't be cracking open the champagne. But I think a lot of people out here will agree there are a few England people who can play some cricket.

"We've got areas to improve and areas we must look elsewhere in, but we also have areas I'm very pleased with. Now we need to be more consistent."

webTitle: One-off deal sets up Hussain Test victory

fields.headline: One-off deal sets up Hussain Test victory
fields.standfirst: South Africa win series 2-1 but Vaughan serves up a finish to remember
fields.trailText: After four days first of skirmishing and then singing in the rain, South Africa and England broke new ground on the final day of the series yesterday, Alec Stewart and Michael Vaughan giving England victory by two wickets in Test cricket's first contrived match. The winning runs to round off a controversial day came when Darren Gough laced the first ball of the final over to the midwicket boundary.
fields.body:
After four days first of skirmishing and then singing in the rain, South Africa and England broke new ground on the final day of the series yesterday, Alec Stewart and Michael Vaughan giving England victory by two wickets in Test cricket's first contrived match. The winning runs to round off a controversial day came when Darren Gough laced the first ball of the final over to the midwicket boundary.

With a total of 360 overs or the best part of 1,500 minutes' play lost to the elements since play was suspended late on Friday evening, the fifth Test had been destined to drift to the dullest of inevitable draws.

However, in a move familiar to followers of county cricket but unprecedented in Tests (of which this was No1483), the captains agreed to a deal by which South Africa would declare their first innings closed at 248 for eight, both sides would then forfeit innings - England their first and South Africa their second - leaving England to chase 249 in 76 overs to achieve an exciting and welcome, if largely meaningless, win. However, in making a game of it, Hansie Cronje ended a run of 14 matches unbeaten since England's win at Headingley 18 months ago.

The ramifications of the tinkering were immediate. In Bombay the bookmakers cried "foul" and "fix" and suspended their betting. Traditionalists muttered about interfering with the natural course of a Test match and scoured Law 14.2 for evidence that a first innings cannot be forfeited, only declared, and therefore the day should be invalidated, for the purposes of records.

Technically they are right but the MCC, which remains the custodian of the laws, says that common sense should prevail as all that had happened was a saving of the 10 minutes between innings and of the need to bowl one delivery before they all trooped off again.

In any case, the point was that a dead match at the end of a series had been resurrected as an offering to spectators who hitherto had had precious little to cheer.

Nevertheless the captains had only reached agreement midway into the morning session when it became apparent that a pitch which Nasser Hussain feared would be bowler-besotted after four days coddled in plastic sheeting, turned out to be less aggressive than it had been on the first day.

"I had to first decline Hansie's offer because I didn't know what the wicket was going to do after four days under the covers," Hussain said. "After 10 overs I sent a message out with the 12th man that we were open to offers."

Cronje's subsequent declaration, with Lance Klusener unbeaten on 61, left England 25 minutes before lunch and two more sessions to chase the target at a rate of 3.26 runs an over.

So generous was this offering in Test-match terms that it conjured up images of Garry Sobers' declaration at 92 for two against England in the fourth Test in Port of Spain 32 years ago, leaving England only 215 to win. They duly did so by eight wickets, held on in the last Test to take the series, and Sobers was vilified. Cronje, and indeed Hussain, should take nothing but plaudits.

"Looking at how it went, with the game going into the last over, I think it was a fairly perfect declaration," Hussain said. "I hope Hansie gets the credit he deserves because a lot of teams would simply have batted out the day."

South Africa were hampered by the loss of their spinner Paul Adams, who fractured a finger in a collision with a boundary board, but England paced their chase well. Key to this was the fifth-wicket partnership of 126 in 31 overs between Stewart and Vaughan, the man of the match, after Mike Atherton and Hussain had been caught off Shaun Pollock, Mark Butcher had been lbw to Klusener's inswinger and Chris Adams had been caught spectacularly by Mark Boucher during a fine spell from Nantie Hayward.

Stewart drove and pulled powerfully for his 10 boundaries, and once slog-sweeped Pieter Strydom's left-arm spin over wide long-on for six. He was caught at the wicket off Hayward with 21 still needed, his 73 making a total nonsense of his absence from the one-day squad, forward planning notwithstanding.

Vaughan, moved down the order to accommodate both Stewart and Adams, had a tough time early on, with Hayward snaking the ball repeatedly past his bat. But he is rock solid in temperament, survived and began to flourish, bringing up his first Test half-century and the hundred partnership with his eighth boundary.

Having lost Stewart, Vaughan then also lost Darren Maddy run out, and Andy Caddick caught at the wicket off Pollock, before he himself was bowled by Hayward, making room to hit through the off side with only nine needed. Gough and Chris Silverwood now scampered and Silverwood hit Pollock through the off side for four, leaving only two needed from the final over bowled by Hayward. Gough's ebullient pull did it.

webTitle: Old Trafford in talks to reduce Yorke's national service

fields.headline: Old Trafford in talks to reduce Yorke's national service
fields.trailText: Manchester United are trying to negotiate a compromise with Trinidad and Tobago to avoid losing their striker Dwight Yorke on international duty for up to seven weeks.
fields.body:
Manchester United are trying to negotiate a compromise with Trinidad and Tobago to avoid losing their striker Dwight Yorke on international duty for up to seven weeks.

Yorke may miss as many as 10 Premiership matches if Trinidad and Tobago invoke Fifa regulations to secure his services for next month's Gold Cup and their six World Cup qualifiers before the end of the season.

The national manager Richard Braithwaite has the right to demand Yorke's release, but Sir Alex Ferguson is hoping to reach a compromise acceptable to both club and country.

"We know Dwight will definitely miss the game at Newcastle [February 12]. Then it is a case of waiting to see what happens after that," said the Old Trafford manager.

United may request that Yorke be allowed to remain in England until the latter stages of the Gold Cup, a biennial tournament for the Caribbean and Central and North America. However, Ferguson will be powerless if Braithwaite insists on Yorke's availability.

"The guidelines state that Manchester United must release Yorke," a spokesman for the Trinidad & Tobago Football Association said. "Talks are ongoing with Ferguson and if we can reach a sensible compromise we will."

Others likely to be affected when the squad is announced on Friday week are West Ham's Shaka Hislop, Nottingham Forest's Stern John and Chester City's Kamu Laird and Angus Eve.

Faltering Middlesbrough's £4m defender Christian Ziege, who has been out for four weeks with what was thought to be medial ligament damage but which has turned out to be severe bruising, has a chance of being involved in Saturday's game at Liverpool.

Yesterday, moreover, the German international offered his support to the Boro manager Bryan Robson, who has implied that he may leave in May unless results improve.

"He is doing a good job here and his position should not be under question; it is the players who have let him down," Ziege said.

"We have to put that right, starting from now. The fans are upset and I know things have not been so good recently, but it is the same everywhere in the world."

 The entire squad and staff of the Dutch second division club Volendam will be tested for TB after the defender Rene Binken was taken ill and sent home for three weeks.

webTitle: Draper sets out his stall in Madrid

fields.headline: Draper sets out his stall in Madrid
fields.trailText: Aston Villa's out-of-favour Mark Draper has joined Rayo Vallecano on loan until the end of the season and may make the move permanent.
fields.body:
Aston Villa's out-of-favour Mark Draper has joined Rayo Vallecano on loan until the end of the season and may make the move permanent.

Vallecano registered the former England Under-21 midfielder before the Spanish league transfer window closed last night. "We have taken him on loan with an option to buy at the end of that period," said a spokesman for the Madrid club.

The 29-year-old has made only one appearance for Villa this season, as a substitute, and recently turned down an opportunity to join First Division Wolves on loan.

Draper joined Villa from Leicester for £3.25m in 1995 and was on the bench for Glenn Hoddle's first match as England coach, the World Cup qualifier in Moldova in September 1996.

He will now team up with a former Filbert Street club-mate, the goalkeeper Kasey Keller, who arrived at the Spanish club on a Bosman-inspired free transfer last summer.

Vallecano are still in contention for a place in next season's Uefa Cup, lying fifth in the Primera Division seven points behind the leaders Deportivo La Coruna, and may well give Draper a debut at Real Mallorca on Sunday.

fields.headline: Forest giant still standing
fields.standfirst: Dave Beasant at 40 will be back on familiar ground at Stamford Bridge tonight
fields.trailText: Dave Beasant at 40 will be back on familiar ground when Nottingham Forest play Chelsea at Stamford Bridge tonight.
fields.body:
When you have played in four different decades, you are in your 41st year and your sons are learning the trade at which you have excelled, retirement and relaxation would seem the obvious career move. For Dave Beasant though, as long as the body's willing so is he - and besides he's having far too much fun to pack it in just yet.

Beasant travels with Nottingham Forest to Chelsea tonight in the FA Cup fourth round and the route is a familiar one to the goalkeeper who has regularly returned to Stamford Bridge, the scene of some of his most glorious, and humiliating, moments since his turbulent playing spell there ended in 1993.

Sons Nick, 14, and Sam, 11, attend Chelsea's academy, and Beasant, who still lives in Buckinghamshire, trains with the first-team goalkeeping coach Eddie Niedzwiecki whenever possible. It is a close relationship which has restored Beasant's respect for the club who almost ended his career.

"The club has changed enormously since I was there and that's the disappointing thing," he says. "I would have liked to have been at Chelsea during the transitional period where it has gone from being a big clubby name, living on what had happened during the 70s, to an incredibly professionally run club which has had huge amounts of money pumped into it."

Oh for such a transformation at Forest. David Platt's side have struggled since they dropped out of the Premiership last year and currently lie 18th in the First Division; they were leapfrogged by Grimsby on Saturday after a 4-3 defeat at Blundell Park during which Beasant was sent off. The FA Cup is their last target of the season, other than staving off a further relegation.

"I don't think the players at the club realised how negative the effect of relegation would be," Beasant explains. "I think everyone thought that we were going to go straight back up, but suddenly it wasn't clicking together and we couldn't put our finger on what was happening. We were lacking confidence and couldn't put a run together. Lately we've had a more settled team and have raised our game against the better teams."

Forest must do that to stand a chance tonight, and Beasant will have an extra incentive to prove himself in front of the Stamford Bridge crowd. After a successful start to his Chelsea career, events took a dramatic turn for the worse when, without his knowledge, Chelsea's then manager Ian Porterfield effectively gave him the sack after a match against Norwich on September 12 1992 when the goalkeeper had made two dreadful errors to cost his side the game.

"I'd had a stinker," he continues, "and I went into the dressing room and apologised to the lads. The manager said nothing to me; I had a bath and went home. Then I was sitting watching the television later that night and the Nine O'Clock News came on. It went through the headlines and then it said, 'And in sport, Dave Beasant has been sacked from Chelsea.' I was stunned."

Beasant recovered from this most public of executions to rebuild his career at Southampton before moving to the City Ground in August 1997. His resilience against those who link him more with blunders than the form which brought him two caps for England was, he says, learnt at Wimbledon, where his professional career began in 1979.

The Dons' ultimate response to the knockers and doubters was to cap a remarkable six years, during which they climbed from the old Fourth to the First Division, by beating Liverpool to win the FA Cup in 1988.

Beasant was the hero, becoming the first goalkeeper to save a penalty in a FA Cup final, a moment he still views as the highlight of his career. He remembers the events clearly, from having a drink with shocked Wimbledon fans the night before the match, to having to persuade Vinnie Jones that he couldn't give Princess Diana a bouquet when the teams were presented to her before the kick-off; from the vital saves in the first half to the celebrations in a marquee on the Plough Lane pitch.

Yet he has also been on the wrong end of a few Cup shocks during his career, and would love to put one over Chelsea, not least for bragging rights when he next attends training. But whatever happens tonight the desire to go on playing will be undimmed.

"I just love playing the game," he says. "I go into training and I know that there will always be something there that will make me smile and laugh and you can't beat it. I can't imagine missing out on that."

webTitle: Adams stays on Arsenal injury roll

fields.headline: Adams stays on Arsenal injury roll
fields.trailText: Tony Adams will not be fit to return to the Arsenal team tonight for the FA Cup fourth-round replay at Leicester between two of the Premiership's most injury-ravaged teams. The England central defender is expected to have to sit out up to two more weeks resting a stress fracture in his foot and will therefore also miss next Monday's crucial Premiership game at Manchester United.
fields.body:
Tony Adams will not be fit to return to the Arsenal team tonight for the FA Cup fourth-round replay at Leicester between two of the Premiership's most injury-ravaged teams. The England central defender is expected to have to sit out up to two more weeks resting a stress fracture in his foot and will therefore also miss next Monday's crucial Premiership game at Manchester United.

"Tony has not even kicked a ball in training since the inflammation in his foot became a problem," Arsenal's manager Arsène Wenger said yesterday. "He has had to fight against a lot of injuries in his career and it is important now that he does not come back too soon."

Arsenal are also heavily depleted up front and on the flanks. With Dennis Bergkamp still injured, Nwankwo Kanu away on African Nations Cup duty with Nigeria and Davor Suker suspended, Thierry Henry is the only experienced striker available for the Leicester and United games.

Marc Overmars and Fredrik Ljungberg are injured too, which means Arsenal will also have an unfamiliar look on the wings, although Silvinho and Ray Parlour have both appeared there this season.

Gilles Grimandi, a late withdrawal with flu against Sunderland, is fit to return as Adams' deputy tonight.

"We should still have good enough players to win anywhere," Wenger said. "And what we have to do is show we can fight against a physical side like Leicester and then think about United afterwards.

"This is a cup tie and I certainly don't consider it just a warm-up for the United game. I will pick my best-balanced, strongest side for one of the most important games of the season because it would be terrible to go out of the FA Cup."

Despite their problems, Arsenal remain favourites to progress to a fifth-round tie against Chelsea or Nottingham Forest. Leicester, who have not won any of their past 11 games in regular time, are missing seven of their first-team players, including the key midfielders Neil Lennon and Muzzy Izzet.

 Roberto di Matteo has been ruled out of the Chelsea team for the next six weeks with a broken arm. The Italian midfielder played on with the injury for the final 10 minutes of Saturday's game at home to Leicester as he did not realise that he had suffered the break in a collision with Emile Heskey.

The Italian midfielder played on with the injury for the final 10 minutes of Saturday's game at home to Leicester as he did not realise that he had suffered the break in a collision with Emile Heskey.

fields.headline: The young and the witless
fields.trailText: The England Under-19s were humiliated at the P Saravanamuttu Stadium yesterday. Totally outclassed, they lost their World Youth Cup tie to Sri Lanka by seven wickets with more than 25 overs remaining.
fields.body:
The England Under-19s were humiliated at the P Saravanamuttu Stadium yesterday. Totally outclassed, they lost their World Youth Cup tie to Sri Lanka by seven wickets with more than 25 overs remaining.

England's leaden-footed batsmen never settled against the exceptional spin bowling of Ranil Dhammika, Muthumudalige Pushpakumara and Kaushal Lokuarachchi, and were bowled out for 123.

"We have been outplayed by a very exciting team who I believe will go on to win the tournament," said the England coach Tim Boon. "Unfortunately our batting lacked mental resilience and there were far too many unforced errors."

The unlucky Ian Bell was clean bowled in the first over by a perfect leg-cutter from Prabath Nissanka, who then had Jimmy Adams caught at short leg.

Michael Carberry and Mark Wallace put together a 56-run partnership before the spinners got to work, and Alex Loudon and Gary Pratt added 37 for the sixth wicket before a unsightly run-out undermined all their hard work.

The Sri Lankans replied forthrightly. The English seamers regularly over-pitched and, to the delight of a vocal crowd, were repeatedly driven to the boundary.

England will have to beat India tomorrow and Nepal on Saturday if they are to qualify for the semi-finals.

fields.headline: Indian outing for Donald
fields.trailText: Allan Donald has made himself available for the two Test matches South Africa will play on their tour of India starting next month.
fields.body:
Allan Donald has made himself available for the two Test matches South Africa will play on their tour of India starting next month.

The fast bowler, who has taken 290 wickets in Tests, had announced at the weekend that he would take a six-month break from international cricket, with the rider that he had yet to decide whether to go to India.

"I got a call from Donald last night, regarding India, and he told me he is available for selection for the Test matches," the South Africa team manager Goolam Rajah said yesterday. "He won't play in the one-dayers.

"He sounded very enthusiastic and committed to the tour, and we as a team are looking forward to having him on board."

 The West Indies paceman Curtly Ambrose says he is fit and ready to resume his Test career after being omitted from the squad for the disastrous tour of New Zealand.

The 36-year-old said he was pleased with his bowling so far in this year's Busta Cup after taking four wickets against Barbados. "I am feeling much better than when we played in Trinidad. My rhythm is good and once I have my rhythm going well I'm happy," he said.

Ambrose, who has taken 369 wickets in 88 Tests at an average of 21.31, said he was feeling no pain from the elbow injury that led to his omission from the New Zealand tour.

webTitle: At last the health service has something to celebrate

fields.headline: At last the health service has something to celebrate
fields.standfirst: Mr Blair's pledge on NHS spending is an unbreakable commitment
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's commitment to massively increase the NHS budget is not a step change but a revolution in NHS policy, says Polly Toynbee.
fields.body:
This is not another old sticking plaster. This is something never seen before. It is the first commitment ever to give the health service what it needs and deserves. Just as Tony Blair astounded his critics last year with his pledge to abolish child poverty, so he has knocked the wind out of every health critic with his pledge on NHS spending. Gobsmacked, said one. The BMA is demanding a precise interpretation of Blair's words, but even the lowest figure suggests a real increase of one quarter more. That's not a step-change, it's a revolution - and no amount of finessing the fine print will ever let Labour off: they must now hit EU average health spending in five years.

Ever since Attlee savagely cut Aneurin Bevan's money to launch the service, the NHS started out on the back foot. Bevan even promised NHS needs would shrink as the backlog of ill-health was cured. But soaring costs and demands kept the service struggling to keep up with an ageing population, new technology and now a new generation of drugs. Despite above inflation money every year, it hasn't had enough to show visible, tangible improvement, to prove what good value voters get for the low taxes they pay.

How sick is the NHS? Nothing like as bad as the past two weeks' news would have you believe. It is difficult to take the pulse of this huge, patchy beast, but almost any measure shows continuous improvement, treating more people more reliably with more transparent medical results. Tory health reforms improved accountability, while their patients' charter cut waiting times and made the NHS more consumer-aware. Labour has improved on the best elements of these. Best of all, the new National Institute of Clinical Effectiveness is screening drugs and treatments to spread the most effective practice evenly across the NHS. League tables now help weed out black spots where treatments fall below average.

But all this underlying improvement was too slow and too invisible. The NHS never kept up with public demand. Low tax decades left it trailing behind private affluence, shabby and slow compared with a trip to Ikea or Disneyland. That is why Tony Blair rightly demands the best in those things patients notice most - booked appointments, walk-in GP services, NHS Direct and refurbished A and E departments with no waits and no trolleys. Misled by most of what they read, or by scary documentaries empty of analysis (BBC just as guilty), how is the public to know how good or bad the NHS really is?

There will never be a time under any system in the world where health does not provide journalists with plentiful horror stories, true or false. Interestingly, the polls show how the most fit who rarely use the NHS rate it lowest, while frequent users rate it highest: rumour is stronger than reality.

The anatomy of an NHS panic is a curious thing. As a veteran of many outbreaks, this is how they work: they start in the post-new year news vacuum, coinciding with the annual "flu crisis" - usually an artifact, also conveniently close to the end of the financial year when traditionally hospitals used ostentatiously to close down wards to protest about running out of money. This time, on January 7, it was the man in Hereford shunted round several hospitals who died 24 hours later. His outspoken surgeon protested publicly and sent up the news flares. Never mind that it later turned out to be human error and not NHS shortage (the ambulance failed to take him to the nearest hospital where a bed was waiting for him).

Certainly the woman who had her operation cancelled four times was monstrously treated (yet experts murmur under their breath that her cancer was almost certainly non-survivable anyway). Never mind the subtleties, these cases fly like the wind. The timely words of Lord Winston gave added kick to the usual cacophony of NHS winter shroud waving (though an IVF specialist may not really know about winter crises among the old).

However these regular outbursts of NHS embarrassment for the government of the day don't take root or force government action unless there is an element of truth in them. In 1987, when deaths at a Birmingham heart hospital sparked a furore, the NHS was indeed in genuine trouble. John Moore's disastrous cuts had lead the heads of the mighty royal colleges to call on Downing Street in a formidable delegation. That led to the great Tory reforms - and more money. So now, again, Labour's two-year financial squeeze, though far less severe, lends a dose of truth to the partly fanciful reporting of the present state of the NHS.

There were plenty who warned Labour back in 1997 that a two-year freeze would inevitably lead to a public explosion. NHS staff are under intolerable pressure from too many years of forcing them to work harder through "productivity" cuts: they easily can and do walk with their feet to get better paid jobs elsewhere. Most doctors work very long, hard hours, with many committees and much paperwork. Beds are too full all year round, so any slight crisis means trolleys in corridors. If patients have to wait a week to see GPs, we need more doctors. Some services, like mental health, have always been calamitously underfunded.

What now? Not all NHS problems spring from lack of money - but money will make all the difference. There may be enough beds, but many are blocked with old people for lack of good (and far cheaper) nursing home beds or care at home. Better community care will matter as much as better hospitals. Will managers make sure doctors cut waiting lists, when private practice is such an incentive to keep them long? The unions need to be fought on local pay rates: it does cost more to hire a nurse in London than in Blackburn. The unions need to be listened to on conditions and hours to make NHS careers flexible, attractive and progressive.

But the main lesson of this last scare - and why Tony Blair was right to intervene so dramatically - is that the NHS has new and more ferocious enemies barking at its door. The private health lobbies and many in their pay are among them. It was essential that Tony Blair should send the whole Tory press, with their scares and campaigns about "Britain's third world wards" creeping away with their tails between their legs. There never was any problem about the NHS funding mechanism. All it required was the political will. The NHS, for all its miserly frugality, is rated the best value for money in the world. Paying for it out of general taxation is the most economical, fair and least bureaucratic way. All it needed was a lot more money, which it now has. Labour cannot backslide on this, whatever the future economic circumstances, whatever its equally strong promises on poverty, education and transport. And it might take raising more tax.

fields.headline: Transatlantic warning
fields.standfirst: In the US, social housing has been 'residualised' into ghettos for the  poorest. John Perry urges the government to stop it happening here
fields.trailText: In the US, social housing has been 'residualised' into ghettos for the poorest. John Perry urges the government to stop it happening here.
fields.body:
The mix of income groups living in social housing in the 1970s meant that a council tenant with a Jaguar was much more likely to warrant a headline than neighbours from hell are today. But in two decades social housing has changed so radically that now nearly two-thirds of heads of households are not working.

Two more recent factors have been added to the picture. One is falling demand in many areas in the northern half of England, so that unpopular estates become more so as people are able to choose to live elsewhere. The second is that, whereas in the past many new tenants expected to spend their lives in social housing, today they are much more likely to see it as a staging post to buying their own house. Of course, in areas with high house prices that may remain an unfulfilled ambition. But the halt in the decline of the private rented sector means that, for half the tenants who leave social housing, that too is a choice they can make.

If these trends continue, the fate of social housing seems inevitably to be what has happened in the US - the "residualisation" that has created ghettos for the poorest households who have no other option.

The Institute of Public Policy Research inquiry (IPPR), launched last July and now at the halfway stage, is looking to shape a vision that takes us in another direction, rather than the current situation in which most council and housing association tenants are not working, and where the likely choice for those who find a job is to move out - either to buy or to rent privately.

One policy objective should be that, whoever is building them, new developments should be mixed wherever possible. But new development adds less than 1% annually to the total number of homes. Defeating residualisation will mean tackling the estates we already have.

Councils and housing associations must move away from "need" as the only criterion for allocating housing, and try to ensure that estates have a balance of people in work, and that child densities and proportions of vulnerable tenants are not too high. This will obviously be easier in areas under less pressure. As far as possible, people should be given a choice about where they live, rather than being "allocated". Measures such as Dundee's property shop, which looks like an estate agents, will become the normal way of marketing homes.

Social landlords will look for new clients. Already, many associations let to nurses and students. Other groups who have traditionally used the private rented sector, or have bought a home without really wanting to, might be encouraged too.

In the best estates, the right-to buy has already done the job of getting a mix of residents. But should it now be curbed in some areas in order to keep a proportion of popular houses for tenants? In any case, tenants might be able to "staircase up" to home ownership in the same house, and later in life "staircase down" if keeping it in good repair is too much for them.

Many councils are stuck with a high proportion of poor houses on unpopular estates. Refurbishment and transfer to a community-based organisation might not lead to social mix in the short term but may revive commitment to the estate's future and pave the way for greater mix in the longer term. In the worst cases, though, demolition may be the only option. Social landlords might also improve the mix of dwellings in their portfolio by building ordinary homes on the market, so that fewer houses have the stigma of being "on an estate".

Neither the existing finance mechanisms nor the existing regime of social landlords can stay as it is if these changes are to be achieved. Ways of subsidising housing must be changed to act against residualisation, not reinforce it. Investment must be brought in - private as well as public - so that the product on offer is a much better one.

This is the kind of vision the IPPR inquiry is developing and which is supported by housing professionals. Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, has already shown his own inclination in this direction. The key question is whether the inquiry, and the minister, can force the issue up the government's agenda. Will Tony Blair and Gordon Brown see that the fight against social exclusion is as much about how and where people live as it is about welfare reform, jobs and schools? And can they persuade the middle classes that less, not more, segregation of where we live is necessary if we are to avoid the worst of what is happening across the Atlantic?

 John Perry is policy director at the Chartered Institute of Housing and is a member of the IPPR forum on social housing.

webTitle: Hick and the England VIII flourish in obscurity

fields.headline: Hick and the England VIII flourish in obscurity
fields.trailText: If you think the goings-on at Centurion yesterday were distinctly odd, this most richly eccentric of games threw up another little oddity here, a four-hour drive south of Johannesburg.
fields.body:
If you think the goings-on at Centurion yesterday were distinctly odd, this most richly eccentric of games threw up another little oddity here, a four-hour drive south of Johannesburg.

There were no spectators - not at the start anyway - and no scoreboard. When a few bewildered souls drifted in later in the day they could follow the match only by stalking the gruff and furiously nomadic scorer.

Eight players wore blue uniforms and the other 14 traditional whites. The sightscreen was black and the ball white. There was a solitary reporter.

This was England's first and penultimate one-day warm-up game before the Standard Bank Triangular Series against South Africa and Zimbabwe gets under way at the weekend.

Nick Knight, Chris Read, Graeme Hick, Vikram Solanki, Mark Alleyne, Craig White, Mark Ealham and Gavin Hamilton all played, in that batting order, against a local XI made up of Free State B side players and some university cricketers, who also made up the missing three in the England team.

England, captained by Hick, won with some comfort, scoring 298 for six from their 50 overs before bowling out their opponents for exactly half that score, 149, in 47.2 overs.

This bunch of players will be reinforced by Nasser Hussain, Darren Maddy, Chris Adams, Alan Mullally, Andy Caddick, Darren Gough and, if he has recovered from his back spasms, Ashley Giles for the more serious matches ahead.

Tomorrow there is another warm-up game in Potchefstroom and on Sunday they return here to play South Africa under lights.

After a grimly unremitting Test series the one-day games are unlikely to be any less competitive. England have lost nine of their past 10 one-day internationals against South Africa and five out of seven against Zimbabwe.

England's best one-day side, as with the Test team, is still a matter of conjecture but they look likely to go into this series with a top five of Knight, Hussain, Hick, Adams and Solanki.

After that it gets more complicated. Only two of the three specialist fast bowlers are likely to play, to shorten the tail. The other four will be the wicketkeeper Read plus, probably, three all-rounders from Ealham, Alleyne, Hamilton and White.

Bob Cottam, England's assistant coach, said yesterday: "We have had a training camp here for a week and it has been an exceptional success.

"The net facilities at Goodyear Park have been superb. We have also had plenty of fitness and fielding work. We just wanted to round it off in the middle."

The England innings was built around a stand of 94 in 68 minutes and 107 balls between Knight (63) and Hick (53), who both retired unbeaten. These are likely to be England's key batsmen in the series. Hick was especially fluent, his runs coming from 45 deliveries with six fours.

Their opponents never recovered from losing their first three wickets for 12 runs to Hamilton and Ealham.

The funny part of it was England's three white-flannelled guests who did not join in the high-fives at the fall of each wicket but patted the successful bowler, rather self-consciously, on the shoulder.

 Tim Munton ended his long association with Warwickshire yesterday to sign a two-year contract with Derbyshire.

The former England paceman, now 34, had spent more than a decade with Warwickshire, albeit a period blighted by a series of injury problems, but he insists he is fit enough to make an impact.

The former England paceman, now 34, had spent more than a decade with Warwickshire, albeit a period blighted by a series of injury problems, but he insists he is fit enough to make an impact.

webTitle: Defiant Banks insists Wembley could host athletics

fields.headline: Defiant Banks insists Wembley could host athletics
fields.trailText: Tony Banks, the former sports minister, yesterday vigorously defended himself against accusations that he was to blame for the fiasco over the new National Stadium at Wembley.
fields.body:
Tony Banks, the former sports minister, yesterday vigorously defended himself against accusations that he was to blame for the fiasco over the new National Stadium at Wembley.

Giving evidence before a Commons select committee, he hit back at claims by Jarvis Astaire, the former deputy chairman of Wembley plc, that he wanted to destroy the £475m project by deliberately keeping athletics out.

"It's a lie, a straightforward lie," said Banks. "If I were to have that agenda it would make me a liar in front of the House. I made it quite clear that a national stadium should be capable of staging football, rugby league and athletics."

Banks was the sports minister between July 1997 and July 1999 and oversaw the critical phase of the project. When he stepped down to become the government's special ambassador for the England 2006 World Cup bid and was replaced by Kate Hoey the proposal collapsed amid doubts whether Wembley could stage the Olympic Games.

The culture secretary Chris Smith sent the plans back to the drawing board before scrapping them last month and announcing that Wembley would stage only football and rugby league. Athletics is searching for an alternative venue capable of hosting the 2005 world championships.

As a result of Smith's decision the Football Association has to return £20m of the £120m it received in national lottery funding. But Banks said that when he left he believed everything was on track. "I was convinced we had a done deal," he said. "I remain convinced that deal was OK."

Banks admitted that Smith had expressed concern over plans to install a temporary track. "We had a meeting with the designers and he reluctantly accepted that the platform was the one to go forward with," he said.

The project was radically altered after Hoey took office, and Banks believes he has been made a scapegoat by the media. He remains committed to the original plan. "There have been a lot of people working very hard to poke a sharp stick in my eye," he said.

"But as a humble minister I could see no reason why the compromise which the architects came up with did not work. It was a stunning design and the solution for staging athletics was novel."

Banks, a friend of Ken Bates, the chairman of Wembley National Stadium Ltd, said he believed football had fulfilled its contract by coming up with a workable plan for a multi-purpose arena and should not have to return any money.

"Football could, in my opinion, say we've done this in good faith, we are not going to give any money back; why should we, what have we done wrong? I think it's a very generous offer football is making."

The committee, which is due to report next month, also heard evidence from David Moorcroft and Simon Clegg, chief executives of UK Athletics and the British Olympic Association respectively.

Banks made it clear that he believed the project would have gone through if the BOA had not tried to gain a greater input into the project after his departure. "I spoke to Simon and told him, 'Hang on to what you've got for you might end up with nothing'.

"I was concerned that athletics was going to be the loser in this situation. As one of the ministers responsible for the National Stadium it is a matter of great disappointment to me that athletics won't be there."

webTitle: Why Straw plans to ditch defendants' right to choose

fields.headline: Why Straw plans to ditch defendants' right to choose
fields.standfirst: Guardian legal correspondent Clare Dyer explains how cost-cutting measures will give magistrates the power to decide mode of trial
fields.trailText: Guardian legal correspondent Clare Dyer (left) explains how cost-cutting measures will give magistrates the power to decide mode of trial
fields.body:
The government wants to scrap the right defendants currently have to decide whether they should be tried by a jury or by magistrates in a range of middle-ranking offences.

Minor crimes such as common assault may only be tried in magistrates' courts whereas serious offences, such as murder, arson or rape, are always tried by a jury. But a substantial number of offences - including theft and burglary - may, under current laws, be tried either way.

It is in these "either way" cases that the government's bill will remove the defendant's right to choose; a right not guaranteed by Magna Carta - as some critics claim - but introduced as a cost-cutting measure in England and Wales in 1855. (In Scotland, the prosecution decides where a case should be tried.)

Instead, magistrates will decide whether a defendant charged with one of these offences will be tried by them or be sent to the crown court for trial by jury.

In a deal to secure the support of the Lord Chief Justice, the government has agreed to allow defendants the right to appeal against magistrates' decisions to a crown court judge.

Ministers believe the current system causes delays and adds to costs. They say the change will save £40 million in court costs and also save on prison costs because more cases will be heard by magistrates, who usually impose lower sentences.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, argues that the present system increases costs by encouraging defendants to "play" the system, only to plead guilty at the last minute. Many of the 18,500 defendants a year who initially say they want a jury trial later plead guilty. Mr Straw claims many try to spin out their cases, hoping witnesses will disappear or the prosecution will drop its charges.

The move is strongly opposed by lawyers, along with a number of Labour peers and civil liberties groups. They argue that guidance to magistrates - to take account of the reputation of the defendant in choosing the venue - will create a "two-tier" justice system, one for middle-class defendants and another for the working class, the unemployed and those with previous convictions.

They also claim that black people, who are more likely to opt for jury trial because they have less faith in the predominantly white magistracy, will be the hardest hit by the measure.

The government argues that research shows no difference in the treatment of black people between Crown and magistrates' courts.

The measure was recommended by the royal commission on criminal justice in 1993 and again by a review of delays in the criminal justice system in 1997.

Before Labour came to power, Mr Straw had attacked plans for a similar change by the Tory government as "shortsighted and wrong" but has since changed his mind.

The more he looked at the evidence, the more "overwhelming" the case for change was, he said.

fields.headline: Intensive farms threaten wildlife
fields.standfirst: Lords urges payment to farmers to save habitat
fields.trailText: Too many sheep in the hills and too much intensive agriculture in the lowlands would continue to destroy Britain's wildlife unless the government changed policy, according to the House of Lords select committee on the European communities.
fields.body:
Too many sheep in the hills and too much intensive agriculture in the lowlands would continue to destroy Britain's wildlife unless the government changed policy, according to the House of Lords select committee on the European communities.

The committee, which reviews the prospect of wildlife across Europe, said farmers must be paid to manage their land so that wildlife could survive. Currently the UK's support for agriculture/environment schemes is £6 a hectare - four times below the European average.

The committee said that Ireland planned to reduce its sheep population by 1.5m to protect rare plants and other wildlife and said similar density reductions were essential in the UK.

The committee has brought forward the publication of its report so the government could include its recommendations in the new countryside, amenity and conservation bill to be published next month.

Among items the Lords would like to see in the bill is statutory backing for Britain's biodiversity action plan which seeks to save rare species from extinction by protecting their habitat.

The report said devolving powers to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland to protect their environment meant that different rules might apply and some parts of the country could fail to comply with European legislation.

The committee wanted greater protection for sites of special scientific interest and powers for management orders requiring owners to look after them if neglected. These orders would enable conservation agencies like English Nature to take charge if endangered species were being lost through mismanagement.

The committee also called for a wider area around SSSIs to be notified as of "favourable conservation status". This would allow birds or plants which rely on sometimes tiny SSSIs for survival to spread out into the surrounding countryside. Farmers should be paid extra subsidy for providing this wider area where nesting birds might feed.

Large areas of Britain's coastline needed greater protection for wildlife and the committee urged greater co-operation between bodies responsible to make this happen.

Lord Cranbrook, the committee chairman, said: "The environment we live in is made up of innumerable and variable forms of life. This is what biodiversity means. We have a duty to protect it and it is as important a part of the global agenda as the control of climate change."

Craig Bennett, a wildife campaigner for Friends of the Earth, said: "The report confirms our view that Britain's precious wildlife has been repeatedly shortchanged by the UK government and deprived of the level of protection it deserves under EU law. We need stronger measures in the maritime environment, and a big shift in agricultural spending away from production, and towards conservation."

To underline the damage that changed agricultural practices cause to wildlife the RSPB released data yesterday showing that skylark numbers had declined rapidly as a result of sowing cereals in the autumn rather than spring.

A study over the past three years across 24 farms in East Anglia, Oxfordshire and Dorest found twice as many skylark nests on spring cereals as autumn cereals. Skylarks need the food supply left over winter in the unploughed stubble to survive. In the past 30 years the area of spring sown cereals has dropped from 73% to 16% of the total, while the skylark population has dropped 75%.

fields.headline: Agent provocateur
fields.standfirst: Harrison Ford's high profile change of agent last week highlights who is really making the decisions in Hollywood. Boyd Farrow explains
fields.trailText: Harrison Ford's high profile change of agent last week highlights who is really making the decisions in Hollywood. Boyd Farrow explains
fields.body:
Hollywood is buzzing, as only Hollywood can buzz, with the news that Harrison Ford has changed agents, and is now signed up with United Talent Agency, marking his first relationship with a major agency in 15 years. The increasingly craggy star, who has recently accepted the People's Choice award for favourite movie actor, has long been represented exclusively by his manager Patricia McQueeney. But although he may be the People's Choice, Ford's own choice of movies recently - Random Hearts, Six Days, Seven Nights - has not exactly set his accountant doing somersaults.

As McQueeney explains it, Ford realised that he needs better access to both hotter scripts and hipper film-makers. In other words, to lengthen his career span he needs to be more aware of those career-enhancing indie flicks that other megastars occasionally shoehorn into their saving-the-world itineraries (think Tom Cruise in Magnolia). Ford's decision triggered a predictable scramble among the top Hollywood agents to land him.

However, this feeding frenzy has come at a time when the whole concept of agenting in Hollywood is changing rapidly.

The distinction between agents and managers is a subtle but crucial one. Both cater to the whims of their 'talent', but under Californian law, agents must be licensed, and are prohibited from producing films. Managers, on the other hand, can produce, but are barred from negotiating contracts. So one hand washes the other. Agents (whose traditional job has been to seek out and negotiate deals for their clients) can collect no more than 10% of a star's fee. Managers (whose traditional role is to strategise an actor's career moves) routinely charge 15% or more.

Hollywood's proto-agent was Lew Wasserman. A protégé and partner of Jules Stein, Wasserman founded the original MCA, a talent-booking agency which by the 1930s had effectively wiped out its rivals. Jules Stein was an old-fashioned agent with manners to match. He once famously turned away from his door a casually dressed Cary Grant who was his most important client at that time: "No dinner jacket, no dinner."

Wasserman, on the other hand, was more likely to negotiate the shirt off somebody's back. As an agent, Wasserman was the first to secure a million-dollar deal for an actor - Ronald Reagan, no less. He even forced studio heads to renegotiate contracts even after all parties had signed.

MCA's impact is hard to understate. MGM head Louis B. Mayer held the company directly responsible for the erosion of the studios' control. Wasserman would persuade actors to buy out their existing studio contracts and sign with him. He then sold those new clients back to the same studios for inflated fees that quickly repaid the buyout, and which executives found themselves powerless to refuse. After all, the public demands its stars.

For Wasserman, it was a question of supply and demand. Create a sellers' market, control the commodity supply, cream off that 10%. Eventually, MCA realised that it could boost income from its less popular talent if it refused to let its A-list actors work without B-list support. Thus a lowly director on MCA's books might come as part and parcel of a deal that secured an A-list star.

Stories about brutal agents have long been Hollywood folklore. But in a town where the greeting "hello" is considered a bare-faced lie, Wasserman ran way ahead of the pack. His outbursts, usually directed at his hapless staff, are as legendary as his business skills. This is the man who unceremoniously fired Shirley Temple when her career fizzled out.

Once Wasserman had mastered the balance of kid-glove client control with iron-fist contract negotiation, MCA's dominance was all but assured. In 1962 the Justice Dept. under Bobby Kennedy was so alarmed by the concentration of power in Hollywood that it filed a suit against MCA to restrain Wasserman from controlling what had become the town's biggest agency.

Wasserman managed to ward off the relentless Kennedy only by pledging to steer MCA away from the agency business. The following decades saw the corporation in its various incarnations diversify into production, until it came to dominate almost every aspect of the entertainment business: music, radio, television and cinema.

Of course, MCA's dominance couldn't last forever. The company was eventually taken over by Japan's Matsushita Electric and then sold, in secret, to the Seagram Company in 1995. Wasserman famously first learned of the deal when it appeared on the front page of the Wall Street Journal. The entire take-over was orchestrated by his spiritual son, Mike Ovitz.

When Dustin Hoffman, in his 1989 Oscar acceptance speech (Best Actor for Rain Man), said: "I thank my agent, Mike Ovitz," he effectively outed Ovitz as a major Hollywood power broker. Indeed, Hoffman's proclamation was a community-wide acknowledgement that Ovitz and Creative Artists Agency (the agency he co-founded with Ron Meyer) had come to exercise an incredible influence over what films got made in the Hollywood of the 1980s and early 1990s.

As well as representing the biggest names in Tinseltown (Stallone and Schwarzenegger among them), Ovitz adopted Wasserman's practice of packaging his directing clients and his movie stars together. The faltering Brian De Palma (still burnt by The Bonfire of the Vanities and Carlito's Way) received a career boost when he got to direct Cruise in Mission: Impossible, and, in the case of Rain Man, Ovitz famously paired ageing client Hoffman with upcoming CAA new boy Tom Cruise, and provided the Graduate star with a whole new following. Hell, Ovitz even turned his aikido instructor, Steven Seagal, into a movie star.

Ovitz eventually left CAA to join Disney as President, an ill-fated move that was followed by a brief fling with the now-bankrupt Broadway company Livent, and he now heads another Hollywood company, Artists Management Group (AMG), which he formed with partners Julie and Rick Yorn.

AMG is something new yet again. The central ambition of Ovitz's new organisation is to merge the role of agents and managers. AMG insists it is a management company; agents insist it is also a talent agency. Some AMG clients also have an outside agent. Some have two managers.

Ovitz has already upset the natural order by targeting rival management firm Industry Entertainment and luring away some of their hottest clients (Leonardo DiCaprio, Cameron Diaz, Matt Dillon).

But Ovitz's plans range far beyond simply poaching clients. AMG (which boasts that most telling of Hollywood affectations, an unlisted phone number) is clearly designed to transform Ovitz from super-agent to super-manager, representing top stars and creating a portfolio of outfits that produce in every medium: movies, television, records, concerts and the internet. AMG is propelling the agency business into uncharted new territory; it is poised to transform the management business from a cash cow into a veritable golden fleece.

And where Ovitz goes, others follow. Before last Christmas, representatives from Hollywood's top agencies - Endeavor, United Talent Agency, Creative Artists Agency, William Morris and International Creative Management - met with representatives from the Screen Actors Guild to outline a new set of demands. To put it bluntly, they all want to become wheelers and dealers. They want the freedom to buy companies, even production companies, or - in these mega-merger days - to sell their businesses to bigger entities. They also want the opportunity to produce movies and TV shows. Basically, they want to do everything that managers can do.

Many in Hollywood believe that such a sweeping change to the natural order is as inevitable as it is overdue. After all, in nearly every sector of the business landscape multi-billion media mergers routinely sail past the regulators. Yet agents - arguably the most entrepreneurial players in town - remain the most tightly regulated under federal restrictions.

Nevertheless, whatever agents metamorphose into and whatever new name they dream up for themselves, they are still completely reliant on their clients; still live or die by the talent they land. And that, in short, is why Indiana Jones is currently cracking the bullwhip.

AMG is propelling the agency business into uncharted new territory; it is poised to transform the management business from a cash cow into a veritable golden fleece. And where Ovitz goes, others follow. Before last Christmas, representatives from Hollywood's top agencies - Endeavor, United Talent Agency, Creative Artists Agency, William Morris and International Creative Management - met with representatives from the Screen Actors Guild to outline a new set of demands. To put it bluntly, they all want to become wheelers and dealers. They want the freedom to buy companies, even production companies, or - in these mega-merger days - to sell their businesses to bigger entities. They also want the opportunity to produce movies and TV shows. Basically, they want to do everything that managers can do. Many in Hollywood believe that such a sweeping change to the natural order is as inevitable as it is overdue. After all, in nearly every sector of the business landscape multi-billion media mergers routinely sail past the regulators. Yet agents - arguably the most entrepreneurial players in town - remain the most tightly regulated under federal restrictions. Nevertheless, whatever agents metamorphose into and whatever new name they dream up for themselves, they are still completely reliant on their clients; still live or die by the talent they land. And that, in short, is why Indiana Jones is currently cracking the bullwhip.

fields.headline: The case against Ken Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
For months now there has been an official whispering campaign against Ken Livingstone, designed to block his attempt to be London's first mayor. We deliberately sought out his detractors and asked them to set out the case against Mr Livingstone - on one condition: it was all on the record and verifiable. This is the result.
The London mayor: special report
