fields.body:
Livingstone...at the GLC
"We were determined to do in the GLC anyway, but by his conduct he made it easier for us to do it" [Kenneth Baker, Tory architect of abolition]

"A great deal of ratepayers' money was spent on the personal whims of the people running the council" [Andrew McIntosh, deposed by Livingstone as GLC leader]

and plotting...
"He's a dodgy politician, an opportunist. He's got his own agenda." [Bernie Grant, fomer ally of Livingstone]

"During the selection interview he was making it impossible for us, flipping all over the place" [Clive Soley, on trying to pin Livingstone down to backing Labour's manifesto]

in parliament...
"It was because he was left outside that he established an alternative agenda. There was nowhere else for him to go". [Margaret Hodge, Labour minister]

"You know he would exploit it and it would end in grief and there was no point in doing it". [Neil Kinnock on why he did not give Livingstone a job]

and Labour leadership...
"Ken believed that the party would turn to him. He's never understood that the party and the country have moved on". [David Blunkett, Labour minister]

"I don't see why London has to suffer because he hasn't fulfilled his ambition to be party leader." [Brian Sedgemore, Labour MP]

There can seldom have been a political figure in recent political history who so divided opinion, even amongst his colleagues. He is hugely ahead in the opinion polls while spurned by most of his fellow MPs. To many who have never met or worked with him he is charismatic, popular, cheeky and personable. To many who have, he is difficult and manipulative. To Millbank and Downing Street he is anathema.

The prime minister has made no secret of his loathing for Ken Livingstone and has expended considerable personal effort to snuff out his chances of ever becoming mayor - to the extent where many wondered whether this was becoming an unhealthy obsession.

More surprising has been the extent to which people formerly or currently on the left have pointedly refused to support Mr Livingstone or have positively attacked him. Only this week the international development seretary, Clare Short, attacked Mr Livingstone in print, with the active encouragement of senior figures in government.

But more often the campaign against Mr Livingstone has been more covert. A word here, a piece of "helpful guidance" there. Journalists would be approached and told that Ken was charming but "a liar". He was "a Trot", an unreformed and incorrigible "oppositionist". He was out for himself, not a team player.

The problem with most such comments were that they were off the record, uncheckable and often defamatory. Over nearly a month we contacted many of Mr Livingstone's known detractors and invited them to put the case against him publicly - so long as they were prepared to do so attributably. Some refused these conditions. Many did not.

The picture that emerged of Ken Livingstone - with some unexpected exceptions - was that of a self-obsessed, vain and manipulative opportunist who is temperamentally unable to deliver for London. Opponents ranging from members of the cabinet to former colleagues on the Greater London council warn that Mr Livingstone as mayor would become the de facto opposition to Tony Blair's government.

"He's a dodgy politician, an opportunist," said Bernie Grant, who once stood for Labour's deputy leadership with Mr Livingstone as leader."He's got his own agenda and he's not going to follow the party's policy in relation to London. I think there is going to be a big row with the leadership of the party and Londoners are going to lose out by it."

Brian Sedgemore, the leftwing MP for Hackney South and Shoreditch, said: "Ken is a sad and lonely figure. He continually portrays himself as a victim when he is in fact a destructive manipulator. If you slice him through the middle what you see is a man whose heart does not pump for the Labour party but who is completely obsessed with himself."

Opponents of Mr Livingstone concede there is no single action by the former GLC leader which demonstrates his unsuitability for office. But they argue that his style, and what Terry Ashton, former general secretary of the London Labour party, calls "the drip, drip, drip - really splash, splash, splash - of unhelpful comments and criticisms" would be disastrous. To his critics, comments widely reported yesterday allying himself with anarchist rioters in Seattle and London, are just a taster of things to come.

Neil Kinnock, the last Labour leader to deal with Mr Livingstone running London, said he would be "an absolute answer to a prayer" for Tory-supporting papers. "I've got no reason to believe that if he found himself in the mayor's chair he wouldn't continue to extrude half-arsed ideas. When it's a Labour backbencher it doesn't matter all that much. When it's the mayor of London - picked up, examined and splattered across every tabloid front page - the only person envious of him would be William Hague, because of the coverage he got in embarrassing the Labour party. It comes down to the inclination of Labour party members to poke the Labour government in the eye with a sharp stick. It's got nothing to do with Ken and everything to do with the assertion of independence of the Labour rank and file. I completely, totally understand that, but its just not sensible ... you can't afford to mess about."

Mr Sedgemore told the Guardian that Mr Livingstone's call for the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to go "belongs to the Alice-in-Wonderland world of politics. One wonders why he wants the post when Ken clearly can't work with the prime minister. He keeps saying that he gets on with Tony Blair - it's a preposterous allegation. To get on with somebody takes two people."

David Blunkett, now education secretary but also leader of Sheffield metropolitan council in the 1980s, has called the mayoral selection a "defining moment" for Labour members. He said: "Everything that he's done has always been antagonistic to the Labour leadership, it's always been about confrontation, exposing and dividing, not about healing and uniting. His great talent is in fact to present himself and to spin a case but that's not the same thing as being able to do deals and provide answers."

Clive Soley, who chaired the panel which eventually allowed Ken to compete in the ballot to become Labour's candidate, said: "He is in his way a classic individualist - a bit like David Owen, or Enoch [Powell], or Tony Benn. In Ken's case it's the cheeky chappie who says, 'I'm thumbing my nose at the government'. That's fun, you know. But what we in the Labour party have to say is if we want someone to do that, why don't we vote for [Tory hopeful] Steve Norris, who will do it rather better?"

Interview

Mr Soley said that in advance of Mr Livingstone's interview with the panel in November, he had been uncertain about whether he should be allowed to contest the party's primary. "On that first five minutes or so of the interview he was making it impossible for us.

"I was quite prepared - much more so than others - to say, he actually is saying I'm not going to sign up to the manifesto. As that day wore on it actually got much more messy, and you got the other side of Ken which is this bit of him which is what makes him popular - the guy in the pub who says, 'I think this, and I think this, and have another pint', and before too long you're clutching your head ... he seemed to be flipping all over the place." Mr Soley added: "I have to say anybody else who had been refusing to sign up to the manifesto wouldn't have got through. The only reason he got through was he's Ken Livingstone and a lot of party members wanted him."

Margaret Hodge, one-time Islington council leader and now, as a junior employment minister, a fully paid-up member of the Blairite project, said: "Ken's such a loner. Because he's after the very quick headline ... he'll focus on the wrong things, he won't facilitate partnerships. The great prize of the mayor is the political voice it gives you. That's why he wants it. He will use that political voice destructively for Labour, to be even more vocal in attacking Gordon and attacking Tony."

Mr Livingstone used the pages of Labour Left Briefing to declare last month: "I intend to fight a clean fight - there will be no negative campaigning from my supporters." Yet there is strong evidence that he was behind the spate of reports that the Labour mayoral candidate backed by Downing Street, Frank Dobson, was "depressed". The journalist John Lloyd said he clearly remembered Mr Livingstone saying so in an interview in October, but asked for it not to be attributed to him. Other journalists claim to have heard Mr Livingstone use the term "clinically depressed" about Mr Dobson.

To his critics, such unattributable briefing fitted a pattern with Mr Livingstone's tactics both during his attempt to wrest the Labour nomination for Brent East from sitting MP Reg Freeson, and during his assaults on Neil Kinnock's leadership in the 1980s. Mr Livingstone once said: "Poor Kevin Barron [Mr Kinnock's PPS]. Even he is in total despair with Kinnock. He says privately it would have been good to have a leadership contest with an alternative candidate." Mr Barron fiercely denies making any such remark.

For some like the now-Blairite John Carr, the former chair of the GLC staff committee, Mr Livingstone becoming Labour's candidate would be a political disaster not because of what he does, but what he is. "People voted Labour for the first time or came back to Labour in 1997 because Blair implicitly or explicitly said that people like Ken Livingstone and the politics of the 80s were dead, buried and gone forever. How would we ever explain to those people ... how a man like Ken now ends up in perhaps the second most important political job in Britain?"

The GLC record

Among Ken Livingstone's opponents there is uncertainty about the line of attack on - or whether to attack at all - his record in running the Greater London council from 1981 to 1986.

Several people close to Tony Blair are keen to turn away from a debate about the GLC, preferring instead to focus on what they perceive as Mr Livingstone's record of almost unremitting hostility to the Labour leadership since entering parliament in 1987. Members or former members of the government - Paul Boateng, Tony Banks, Margaret Hodge - were in the GLC or associated with GLC controversy. "They've changed, he hasn't," is the Downing Street refrain.

But if, as they argue, Mr Livingstone has achieved little since the GLC, what are Labour members to make of his record the last time he did do something?

In early 1984, polls indicated half of all Londoners opposed abolition of the GLC; by late 1984, that figure had risen to three-quarters. The GLC spent £25m on advertising and public relations between October 1983 and March 1985, of which £14m was directly about abolition. Aggressive, clever and funny assaults on the Tories - including displaying London's unemployment figures on a huge banner along County Hall, opposite parliament - boosted Mr Livingstone's popularity and frequently contrasted with the feebleness of the attack on the Tories by Labour at Westminster.

Some metropolitan councillors blamed Mr Livingstone for provoking Mrs Thatcher into abolition. Lord (Kenneth) Baker, the minister appointed by Mrs Thatcher to take on Mr Livingstone, told the Guardian: "We were determined to do in the GLC anyway but I think that by his conduct of the GLC he made it easier for us to do it ... at the end of the day, when the GLC was abolished in 1986, there were not many tears. It had ceased to be an effective local government agency."

As leader of the GLC, Mr Livingstone made good Labour's promise to bring in a massive cut in bus and tube fares. Labour promised a 25% cut in its manifesto and delivered a 32% cut. The policy, under the banner Fares Fair, was popular and reduced car numbers in London by 15%. But it was overturned by a law lords ruling in December 1981, triggered by a protest from the outer london council of Bromley, which complained it was being asked to fund cheap fares when its ratepayers were miles from the nearest tube station.

"They [the GLC] were actually copying what was taking place in South Yorkshire - and they implemented it so badly that it allowed the Bromley challenge," said Mr Blunkett. "The way it was introduced virtually guaranteed that it would live only for months," said Mr Kinnock. "A very good idea was effectively destroyed." But the former Labour GLC leader, Lord McIntosh, in a rare concession to Mr Livingstone, who deposed him, and his supporters, exempts them from blame.

The GLC precept on the rates almost doubled in London under Mr Livingstone, from 21p under the Tories in 1980 to 39.7p in 1983, and 36.9p in 1984 - in line, says Mr Livingstone, with Labour's election promises. Overall, it increased the GLC's budget of roughly £1bn under the Tories to £1.534bn by 1984, though this was brought down by rate-capping and the courts to £1.34bn by the time of abolition. Clashes with the government over money culminated in March 1985, when the GLC went to the wire in refusing to set a rate and produce a budget. Mr Livingstone eventually agreed to a budget that was, at a rate of 33.8p, considerably lower than the limits prescribed by the government of 36.5p.

The crisis was, both in policy and tactical terms, a disaster. Mr Livingstone fell out bitterly with leftwing colleagues in cluding John McDonnell, now MP for Hayes and Harlington and once again his ally. Mr Livingstone accused Mr McDonnell, chairman of the finance committee, of concealing the GLC's true financial position; Mr McDonnell, who joined nine other Labour members including Tony Banks and Paul Boateng in refusing to set a rate, accused Mr Livingstone of "bottling out".

Minority groups

Lord Baker says there was "a real danger" that the GLC would refuse to set a rate. But he adds: "I always felt Livingstone wouldn't go right over the wire - he'd take it up to the wire and make it as grim as possible but never actually go over. The consequences would have played into our hands which is why Livingstone was very careful not to do it. There would have been old people's homes that weren't maintained, schools that would have closed, everything would have collapsed."

The GLC devoted substantial funds to community and minority groups, the so-called rainbow coalition. Mr Livingstone, according to Mr Kinnock, "became quickly and widely-known as an enthusiast for, sponsor of, spender of public money on, an assortment of zany ultra-left fads that obscured good work that the GLC did - and it also got a national reputation which had repercussions and political returns just about everywhere. Everywhere in the country, where we had a byelection or local election we could distinguish what became known as the London Livingstone effect - the loony left - and he never made any attempt to counteract it. And of course it was a burden that we carried with us. That was Ken's main and lasting contribution."

Cash for organisations such as Babies Against The Bomb - a creche for the children of peace protesters - won huge and adverse publicity. The GLC's equality and anti-racism policies are regarded even by some Livingstone critics as farsighted then and mainstream now. But Mr Kinnock said: "The way in which they did it completely alienated potential support ... there was a certain arrogance in the enthusiasm, the idea that there shouldn't be any compromise with the electorate. It's difficult to think of Babies Against The Bomb as mainstream. Ordinary Labour voters of all classes in society just looked at it and thought, what the bloody hell is going on?"

How much credit, or blame, should Mr Livingstone take? Colleagues and critics portray a relaxed, confident leader, prepared to share praise and responsibility, strong on the big picture but weak on detail and, above all, a sucker for publicity.

Mr Blunkett said: "Our objection to Ken was that he never delivered. It [ the mayor] has got to be somebody who is prepared to do business with government rather than constantly saying it wasn't me guv, I wanted to do this, they stopped me ... that was the style all the way along."

On the other hand Bill Bush, chief of staff at the GLC and now a Downing Street adviser, told Mr Livingstone's biographer, Guardian journalist John Carvel: "On the big issues I don't remember him ever being bounced by officials into an ill-considered decision." Mr Livingstone, he said, was "good at delegating, phenomenally productive", and because of his willingness to take public responsibility for mistakes, inspired people to "die in the last ditch for him".

John Carr says Mr Livingstone was "a very good leader". But he said his work in the council was often overshadowed by his rent-a-quote, grandstanding style. Mr Livingstone famously refused an invitation to the Charles-Diana royal wedding and made a series of controversial stands on Northern Ireland, inviting Sinn Fein to County Hall and commenting that the bombers who killed a woman at the Chelsea barracks were "not criminals or lunatics" in 1981.

Lord McIntosh, now Labour's deputy chief whip in the Lords, said : "His term of office apart from Fares Fair ... was not only undistinguished and unsuccessful in policy terms but actually offensive in the sense that a great deal of ratepayers money was spent on the personal whims of the people who were running the council."

Illtyd Harrington said: "I don't underestimate his popularity ... he's got a determination which I think is good, he's got a ruthlessness that would make him a success, but he doesn't believe in anything. His weakness is his incredible vanity. The only consistency Ken has is to himself. That sounds critical: he's always very friendly to me ... I can see why London likes him. I always remember one of my extended family saying to me, 'you know why we like Ken?' in the 80s. 'It's because we go home and our parents hate him' ... Tony Blair is like the parents."

Livingstone and plotting

With an inimitable mixture of humour and faint menace, Ken Livingstone once said: "I love meetings and plottings. I didn't get where I am today without plotting."

He earned a reputation as an opportunist and carpetbagger by moving swiftly through spells on Lambeth and Camden councils, and on the GLC in Norwood, Hackney and Paddington. But he won a respect and fear in equal measure from his most famous plot, unseating Andrew (now Lord) McIntosh as leader of the GLC the day after Labour took power in the 1981 council elections.

"He came to power as a complete machine politician, spending his time on internal battles within the Labour party rather than fighting the Conservative party," Lord McIntosh said. "Whenever he was asked whether he would stand against me he equivocated. He's been doing exactly the same thing now ... [about] whether he would stand as an independent if he were not to be a Labour candidate.

"A few people, a few leftwingers, some of them Trotskyite - not Ken, he never had the ideological commitment to be a Trotskyite - they met together, they decided a common line. They then got into larger groups and decided a common line. They then got into the Greater London Labour party and by having a common line they often outvoted the trade unions and more moderate people."

Mr Livingstone's links with leftwing groups outside the Labour party date back to 1978 and his connection with the Socialist Campaign for a Labour Victory and its newspaper, Socialist Organiser, which once backed Mr Livingstone, then fell out with him, and is now defunct.

The SCLV argued for socialists to campaign against the "pro-capitalist record" of the then Labour government. Mr Livingstone was enthusiastically supported by London Labour Briefing. In its current guise, Labour Left Briefing, it supports Livingstone for the mayoralty and continues to assault the Labour leadership.

Lady (Glenys) Thornton, former chair of the London Labour party (and John Carr's wife) said: "His record during that period was one of damning these people that didn't agree with his kind of 'politics of the people' and making life miserable for them. One of the worst characteristics of the London Labour party in the 80s was his treatment of some of the people that wished to challenge the hegemony. It wasn't about wider democratic politics - it was about who controls the left; in that sense it's classic Trotskyist politics."

Mr Livingstone, Lambeth leader Ted Knight, and another Lambeth councillor, Matthew Warburton, set up the newspaper Labour Herald. He withdrew from the board as he was condemned for finally agreeing to set a budget in the capping row which split Mr Livingstone from many of his colleagues in 1985. Labour Herald was printed by Astmoor Litho, a publishing company owned by the Workers' Revolutionary Party, the vehicle of his friend, the leader Gerry Healy. "He [Livingstone] is not a dinosaur, not a kind of stick in the mud Trotskyite... fundamentally he's an old fashioned Keynesian tax-and-spend socialist who doesn't agree with the whole drift of Labour policy these days," said John Carr. "Ken did get very embroiled - inexplicably to some - in some of the internal disputes that were in the WRP over Gerry Healy and Vanessa Redgrave and all of that."

Last year Ken Livingstone said of Mr Healy: "I never met the man until I was 36 years old and I am far too independent-minded ever to submit myself to Marxist discipline." But in the foreword to a book, Gerry Healy: A Revolutionary Life, Mr Livingstone painted a different gloss. Though the men had "fundamental differences", he wrote, "it was a privilege to have worked with Gerry Healy". Healy's paper, News Line, was "thorough and objective" in its coverage of the GLC. Mr Livingstone still attracts support from left groups outside the Labour party. "Organise for Livingstone! Break free from Millbank mafia," calls Socialist Outlook, a monthly Marxist review. Last month's Socialist Review reported: "Millions betrayed by Labour: The campaign by Livingstone for mayor can become a rallying point for all those who oppose the Blair agenda in a way which goes beyond Livingstone's actual politics, which is why those on the left support him against Blair."

After Socialist Workers Party supporters picketed Mr Sedgemore's surgery in his support, Mr Livingstone said it was a "very serious falsehood" to suggest he was being funded by the SWP. Socialist Action, formerly the International Marxist Group, has also given him strong support. "The truth is that I am prepared to work for people when there is political agreement," he said, but denied being their "tool".

John Ross, a former leading light of Socialist Action, was appointed as his researcher in 1987, helped compile his extensive economic database and, now working for the Russian trade union movement based in Moscow, is still employed part-time by Livingstone to help produce his Socialist Economic Bulletin, a periodical funded by the MP's outside earnings through his company LocalAction. His chief of staff, Simon Fletcher, has links with Socialist Action and Mr Livingstone is close to another Socialist Action mainstay, Redmond O'Neill. "I just always operated within the Labour party and was prepared to work with any left groupings inside or outside it on a series of policy issues," Mr Livingstone told John Carvel. "The relationship goes hot and cold."

Mr Kinnock said of Mr Livingstone's supporters: "If you are relying on people to do your footslogging who are from the ultra left they do have a certain temperament. Politics is their whole life, they've got no hinterland, they are obsessive and really the siege troops came from that element ... despite, frequently, their intellectual intelligence, they're the daftest sods, so they must be easy to manipulate."

But Mr Kinnock exempts Mr Livingstone from the charge of being a Trotskyist. "He's a Kennist. He really is. 'Red Ken' was always a bit of a joke. I don't think he's even a Red."

According to John Carr, Mr Livingstone as GLC leader was always focused on becoming an MP. He was foiled in his attempt to take Brent East in 1983 but eventually succeeded in forcing out Reg Freeson in 1987 as part of a sustained campaign by leftwingers working through a group, Target 87. The GLC set up an Irish centre in Brent during Mr Livingstone's tenure, which went through a series of crises and overspends. "He indulged the Irish people there, and they indulged him by voting for him," said Illtyd Harrington. Mr Freeson said Mr Livingstone's supporters made life so difficult for him that "in effect I was being excluded, and quite consciously excluded from doing my job as an MP".

In parliament

By any standards, Ken Livingstone's 12-year parliamentary career has been undistinguished, proof, critics say, of his inability to forge alliances and work with colleagues. For the mayoral race he has the support of eight of London's 57 Labour MPs, including himself; Mr Dobson has 43. Initially coldshouldered by members of the leftwing Campaign group, angry with him for what they saw as his cave-in over capping, Mr Livingstone has failed, as some expected, to take over from Tony Benn as leader of the parliamentary left.

Though Mr Livingstone was the Campaign group's choice to run for leader in 1992 - he won the support of only 13 MPs when he needed 55 to make it through to the final ballot - it did not consolidate his position. He shared the ticket with Bernie Grant but, says Mr Grant, "there was no working together. The Campaign group felt that somebody should put up, make a token gesture - I pulled the short straw - we never went on television together."

As even his opponents concede, he was given a rude introduction to parliament. The whips ensured he was the last MP to be given an office. He admits detesting Neil Kinnock. But according to some loyalists, attempts were made to take Mr Livingstone on board. "In 1988 we were planning the local elections and I said we should use Ken," said Mrs Hodge. "[But] he was so hated by all the other people ... I am still of the view that if we had used him then ... I think Ken would have come in board. It was just because he was left outside that he established an alternative agenda ... out of pique and [because] there was nowhere else he could go."

Both Mr Livingstone and his opponents say the crucial event in his estrangement from the leadership was in 1987, when he joined an attempt to deliver a joint slate for the shadow cabinet elections from the soft left Tribune group and the hard left Campaign group. Tribune group members Gordon Brown and, with an impassioned speech, Jack Straw, repelled the effort.

Mr Kinnock said he never considered bringing Mr Livingstone in. "You knew with Ken that he wouldn't say, 'I recognise the gesture, I'm interested in constructing and therefore I'll get on with it', like a lot of other people did. You knew very well that he would take such an opportunity as a sign of concession, he would exploit it and it would end in grief and there was no point in doing it."

The Labour leadership

"When we were on the GLC together he did say at various points that he had an ambition to be leader of the Labour party," John Carr said. "He's still got the same glint in his eye, he's still got the same agenda ... Ken believes that in the end the rightwing project as he would call it, the Blairites will fail ... and the rank and file of the party will turn once again to the left and look for a new leader, and Tony Benn's mantle will be resting on Ken's shoulders and he'll be waiting for the call."

During the 1980s, said David Blunkett, "Ken did believe at the time, seriously, that the party would turn to him to replace Neil Kinnock. He believed that when we lost the 1987 election, and he believed it again in 1992, that the party would turn to him, and he's never understood yet why that wasn't the case, that the party and the country had moved on."

Brian Sedgemore offered an alternative take. "He wanted to be leader of the party. That's an unfulfilled ambition. I don't see, because he hasn't fulfilled his ambition, why London should have to suffer."

Neil Kinnock, the last Labour leader to deal with Mr Livingstone running London, said he would be "an absolute answer to a prayer" for Tory-supporting papers. "I've got no reason to believe that if he found himself in the mayor's chair he wouldn't continue to extrude half-arsed ideas. When it's a Labour backbencher it doesn't matter all that much. When it's the mayor of London - picked up, examined and splattered across every tabloid front page - the only person envious of him would be William Hague, because of the coverage he got in embarrassing the Labour party. It comes down to the inclination of Labour party members to poke the Labour government in the eye with a sharp stick. It's got nothing to do with Ken and everything to do with the assertion of independence of the Labour rank and file. I completely, totally understand that, but its just not sensible ... you can't afford to mess about." Mr Sedgemore told the Guardian that Mr Livingstone's call for the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to go "belongs to the Alice-in-Wonderland world of politics. One wonders why he wants the post when Ken clearly can't work with the prime minister. He keeps saying that he gets on with Tony Blair - it's a preposterous allegation. To get on with somebody takes two people." David Blunkett, now education secretary but also leader of Sheffield metropolitan council in the 1980s, has called the mayoral selection a "defining moment" for Labour members. He said: "Everything that he's done has always been antagonistic to the Labour leadership, it's always been about confrontation, exposing and dividing, not about healing and uniting. His great talent is in fact to present himself and to spin a case but that's not the same thing as being able to do deals and provide answers." Clive Soley, who chaired the panel which eventually allowed Ken to compete in the ballot to become Labour's candidate, said: "He is in his way a classic individualist - a bit like David Owen, or Enoch [Powell], or Tony Benn. In Ken's case it's the cheeky chappie who says, 'I'm thumbing my nose at the government'. That's fun, you know. But what we in the Labour party have to say is if we want someone to do that, why don't we vote for [Tory hopeful] Steve Norris, who will do it rather better?" Interview Mr Soley said that in advance of Mr Livingstone's interview with the panel in November, he had been uncertain about whether he should be allowed to contest the party's primary. "On that first five minutes or so of the interview he was making it impossible for us. "I was quite prepared - much more so than others - to say, he actually is saying I'm not going to sign up to the manifesto. As that day wore on it actually got much more messy, and you got the other side of Ken which is this bit of him which is what makes him popular - the guy in the pub who says, 'I think this, and I think this, and have another pint', and before too long you're clutching your head ... he seemed to be flipping all over the place." Mr Soley added: "I have to say anybody else who had been refusing to sign up to the manifesto wouldn't have got through. The only reason he got through was he's Ken Livingstone and a lot of party members wanted him." Margaret Hodge, one-time Islington council leader and now, as a junior employment minister, a fully paid-up member of the Blairite project, said: "Ken's such a loner. Because he's after the very quick headline ... he'll focus on the wrong things, he won't facilitate partnerships. The great prize of the mayor is the political voice it gives you. That's why he wants it. He will use that political voice destructively for Labour, to be even more vocal in attacking Gordon and attacking Tony." Mr Livingstone used the pages of Labour Left Briefing to declare last month: "I intend to fight a clean fight - there will be no negative campaigning from my supporters." Yet there is strong evidence that he was behind the spate of reports that the Labour mayoral candidate backed by Downing Street, Frank Dobson, was "depressed". The journalist John Lloyd said he clearly remembered Mr Livingstone saying so in an interview in October, but asked for it not to be attributed to him. Other journalists claim to have heard Mr Livingstone use the term "clinically depressed" about Mr Dobson. To his critics, such unattributable briefing fitted a pattern with Mr Livingstone's tactics both during his attempt to wrest the Labour nomination for Brent East from sitting MP Reg Freeson, and during his assaults on Neil Kinnock's leadership in the 1980s. Mr Livingstone once said: "Poor Kevin Barron [Mr Kinnock's PPS]. Even he is in total despair with Kinnock. He says privately it would have been good to have a leadership contest with an alternative candidate." Mr Barron fiercely denies making any such remark. For some like the now-Blairite John Carr, the former chair of the GLC staff committee, Mr Livingstone becoming Labour's candidate would be a political disaster not because of what he does, but what he is. "People voted Labour for the first time or came back to Labour in 1997 because Blair implicitly or explicitly said that people like Ken Livingstone and the politics of the 80s were dead, buried and gone forever. How would we ever explain to those people ... how a man like Ken now ends up in perhaps the second most important political job in Britain?" The GLC record Among Ken Livingstone's opponents there is uncertainty about the line of attack on - or whether to attack at all - his record in running the Greater London council from 1981 to 1986. Several people close to Tony Blair are keen to turn away from a debate about the GLC, preferring instead to focus on what they perceive as Mr Livingstone's record of almost unremitting hostility to the Labour leadership since entering parliament in 1987. Members or former members of the government - Paul Boateng, Tony Banks, Margaret Hodge - were in the GLC or associated with GLC controversy. "They've changed, he hasn't," is the Downing Street refrain. But if, as they argue, Mr Livingstone has achieved little since the GLC, what are Labour members to make of his record the last time he did do something? In early 1984, polls indicated half of all Londoners opposed abolition of the GLC; by late 1984, that figure had risen to three-quarters. The GLC spent £25m on advertising and public relations between October 1983 and March 1985, of which £14m was directly about abolition. Aggressive, clever and funny assaults on the Tories - including displaying London's unemployment figures on a huge banner along County Hall, opposite parliament - boosted Mr Livingstone's popularity and frequently contrasted with the feebleness of the attack on the Tories by Labour at Westminster. Some metropolitan councillors blamed Mr Livingstone for provoking Mrs Thatcher into abolition. Lord (Kenneth) Baker, the minister appointed by Mrs Thatcher to take on Mr Livingstone, told the Guardian: "We were determined to do in the GLC anyway but I think that by his conduct of the GLC he made it easier for us to do it ... at the end of the day, when the GLC was abolished in 1986, there were not many tears. It had ceased to be an effective local government agency." As leader of the GLC, Mr Livingstone made good Labour's promise to bring in a massive cut in bus and tube fares. Labour promised a 25% cut in its manifesto and delivered a 32% cut. The policy, under the banner Fares Fair, was popular and reduced car numbers in London by 15%. But it was overturned by a law lords ruling in December 1981, triggered by a protest from the outer london council of Bromley, which complained it was being asked to fund cheap fares when its ratepayers were miles from the nearest tube station. "They [the GLC] were actually copying what was taking place in South Yorkshire - and they implemented it so badly that it allowed the Bromley challenge," said Mr Blunkett. "The way it was introduced virtually guaranteed that it would live only for months," said Mr Kinnock. "A very good idea was effectively destroyed." But the former Labour GLC leader, Lord McIntosh, in a rare concession to Mr Livingstone, who deposed him, and his supporters, exempts them from blame. The GLC precept on the rates almost doubled in London under Mr Livingstone, from 21p under the Tories in 1980 to 39.7p in 1983, and 36.9p in 1984 - in line, says Mr Livingstone, with Labour's election promises. Overall, it increased the GLC's budget of roughly £1bn under the Tories to £1.534bn by 1984, though this was brought down by rate-capping and the courts to £1.34bn by the time of abolition. Clashes with the government over money culminated in March 1985, when the GLC went to the wire in refusing to set a rate and produce a budget. Mr Livingstone eventually agreed to a budget that was, at a rate of 33.8p, considerably lower than the limits prescribed by the government of 36.5p. The crisis was, both in policy and tactical terms, a disaster. Mr Livingstone fell out bitterly with leftwing colleagues in cluding John McDonnell, now MP for Hayes and Harlington and once again his ally. Mr Livingstone accused Mr McDonnell, chairman of the finance committee, of concealing the GLC's true financial position; Mr McDonnell, who joined nine other Labour members including Tony Banks and Paul Boateng in refusing to set a rate, accused Mr Livingstone of "bottling out". Minority groups Lord Baker says there was "a real danger" that the GLC would refuse to set a rate. But he adds: "I always felt Livingstone wouldn't go right over the wire - he'd take it up to the wire and make it as grim as possible but never actually go over. The consequences would have played into our hands which is why Livingstone was very careful not to do it. There would have been old people's homes that weren't maintained, schools that would have closed, everything would have collapsed." The GLC devoted substantial funds to community and minority groups, the so-called rainbow coalition. Mr Livingstone, according to Mr Kinnock, "became quickly and widely-known as an enthusiast for, sponsor of, spender of public money on, an assortment of zany ultra-left fads that obscured good work that the GLC did - and it also got a national reputation which had repercussions and political returns just about everywhere. Everywhere in the country, where we had a byelection or local election we could distinguish what became known as the London Livingstone effect - the loony left - and he never made any attempt to counteract it. And of course it was a burden that we carried with us. That was Ken's main and lasting contribution." Cash for organisations such as Babies Against The Bomb - a creche for the children of peace protesters - won huge and adverse publicity. The GLC's equality and anti-racism policies are regarded even by some Livingstone critics as farsighted then and mainstream now. But Mr Kinnock said: "The way in which they did it completely alienated potential support ... there was a certain arrogance in the enthusiasm, the idea that there shouldn't be any compromise with the electorate. It's difficult to think of Babies Against The Bomb as mainstream. Ordinary Labour voters of all classes in society just looked at it and thought, what the bloody hell is going on?" How much credit, or blame, should Mr Livingstone take? Colleagues and critics portray a relaxed, confident leader, prepared to share praise and responsibility, strong on the big picture but weak on detail and, above all, a sucker for publicity. Mr Blunkett said: "Our objection to Ken was that he never delivered. It [ the mayor] has got to be somebody who is prepared to do business with government rather than constantly saying it wasn't me guv, I wanted to do this, they stopped me ... that was the style all the way along." On the other hand Bill Bush, chief of staff at the GLC and now a Downing Street adviser, told Mr Livingstone's biographer, Guardian journalist John Carvel: "On the big issues I don't remember him ever being bounced by officials into an ill-considered decision." Mr Livingstone, he said, was "good at delegating, phenomenally productive", and because of his willingness to take public responsibility for mistakes, inspired people to "die in the last ditch for him". John Carr says Mr Livingstone was "a very good leader". But he said his work in the council was often overshadowed by his rent-a-quote, grandstanding style. Mr Livingstone famously refused an invitation to the Charles-Diana royal wedding and made a series of controversial stands on Northern Ireland, inviting Sinn Fein to County Hall and commenting that the bombers who killed a woman at the Chelsea barracks were "not criminals or lunatics" in 1981. Lord McIntosh, now Labour's deputy chief whip in the Lords, said : "His term of office apart from Fares Fair ... was not only undistinguished and unsuccessful in policy terms but actually offensive in the sense that a great deal of ratepayers money was spent on the personal whims of the people who were running the council." Illtyd Harrington said: "I don't underestimate his popularity ... he's got a determination which I think is good, he's got a ruthlessness that would make him a success, but he doesn't believe in anything. His weakness is his incredible vanity. The only consistency Ken has is to himself. That sounds critical: he's always very friendly to me ... I can see why London likes him. I always remember one of my extended family saying to me, 'you know why we like Ken?' in the 80s. 'It's because we go home and our parents hate him' ... Tony Blair is like the parents." Livingstone and plotting With an inimitable mixture of humour and faint menace, Ken Livingstone once said: "I love meetings and plottings. I didn't get where I am today without plotting." He earned a reputation as an opportunist and carpetbagger by moving swiftly through spells on Lambeth and Camden councils, and on the GLC in Norwood, Hackney and Paddington. But he won a respect and fear in equal measure from his most famous plot, unseating Andrew (now Lord) McIntosh as leader of the GLC the day after Labour took power in the 1981 council elections. "He came to power as a complete machine politician, spending his time on internal battles within the Labour party rather than fighting the Conservative party," Lord McIntosh said. "Whenever he was asked whether he would stand against me he equivocated. He's been doing exactly the same thing now ... [about] whether he would stand as an independent if he were not to be a Labour candidate. "A few people, a few leftwingers, some of them Trotskyite - not Ken, he never had the ideological commitment to be a Trotskyite - they met together, they decided a common line. They then got into larger groups and decided a common line. They then got into the Greater London Labour party and by having a common line they often outvoted the trade unions and more moderate people." Mr Livingstone's links with leftwing groups outside the Labour party date back to 1978 and his connection with the Socialist Campaign for a Labour Victory and its newspaper, Socialist Organiser, which once backed Mr Livingstone, then fell out with him, and is now defunct. The SCLV argued for socialists to campaign against the "pro-capitalist record" of the then Labour government. Mr Livingstone was enthusiastically supported by London Labour Briefing. In its current guise, Labour Left Briefing, it supports Livingstone for the mayoralty and continues to assault the Labour leadership. Lady (Glenys) Thornton, former chair of the London Labour party (and John Carr's wife) said: "His record during that period was one of damning these people that didn't agree with his kind of 'politics of the people' and making life miserable for them. One of the worst characteristics of the London Labour party in the 80s was his treatment of some of the people that wished to challenge the hegemony. It wasn't about wider democratic politics - it was about who controls the left; in that sense it's classic Trotskyist politics." Mr Livingstone, Lambeth leader Ted Knight, and another Lambeth councillor, Matthew Warburton, set up the newspaper Labour Herald. He withdrew from the board as he was condemned for finally agreeing to set a budget in the capping row which split Mr Livingstone from many of his colleagues in 1985. Labour Herald was printed by Astmoor Litho, a publishing company owned by the Workers' Revolutionary Party, the vehicle of his friend, the leader Gerry Healy. "He [Livingstone] is not a dinosaur, not a kind of stick in the mud Trotskyite... fundamentally he's an old fashioned Keynesian tax-and-spend socialist who doesn't agree with the whole drift of Labour policy these days," said John Carr. "Ken did get very embroiled - inexplicably to some - in some of the internal disputes that were in the WRP over Gerry Healy and Vanessa Redgrave and all of that." Last year Ken Livingstone said of Mr Healy: "I never met the man until I was 36 years old and I am far too independent-minded ever to submit myself to Marxist discipline." But in the foreword to a book, Gerry Healy: A Revolutionary Life, Mr Livingstone painted a different gloss. Though the men had "fundamental differences", he wrote, "it was a privilege to have worked with Gerry Healy". Healy's paper, News Line, was "thorough and objective" in its coverage of the GLC. Mr Livingstone still attracts support from left groups outside the Labour party. "Organise for Livingstone! Break free from Millbank mafia," calls Socialist Outlook, a monthly Marxist review. Last month's Socialist Review reported: "Millions betrayed by Labour: The campaign by Livingstone for mayor can become a rallying point for all those who oppose the Blair agenda in a way which goes beyond Livingstone's actual politics, which is why those on the left support him against Blair." After Socialist Workers Party supporters picketed Mr Sedgemore's surgery in his support, Mr Livingstone said it was a "very serious falsehood" to suggest he was being funded by the SWP. Socialist Action, formerly the International Marxist Group, has also given him strong support. "The truth is that I am prepared to work for people when there is political agreement," he said, but denied being their "tool". John Ross, a former leading light of Socialist Action, was appointed as his researcher in 1987, helped compile his extensive economic database and, now working for the Russian trade union movement based in Moscow, is still employed part-time by Livingstone to help produce his Socialist Economic Bulletin, a periodical funded by the MP's outside earnings through his company LocalAction. His chief of staff, Simon Fletcher, has links with Socialist Action and Mr Livingstone is close to another Socialist Action mainstay, Redmond O'Neill. "I just always operated within the Labour party and was prepared to work with any left groupings inside or outside it on a series of policy issues," Mr Livingstone told John Carvel. "The relationship goes hot and cold." Mr Kinnock said of Mr Livingstone's supporters: "If you are relying on people to do your footslogging who are from the ultra left they do have a certain temperament. Politics is their whole life, they've got no hinterland, they are obsessive and really the siege troops came from that element ... despite, frequently, their intellectual intelligence, they're the daftest sods, so they must be easy to manipulate." But Mr Kinnock exempts Mr Livingstone from the charge of being a Trotskyist. "He's a Kennist. He really is. 'Red Ken' was always a bit of a joke. I don't think he's even a Red." According to John Carr, Mr Livingstone as GLC leader was always focused on becoming an MP. He was foiled in his attempt to take Brent East in 1983 but eventually succeeded in forcing out Reg Freeson in 1987 as part of a sustained campaign by leftwingers working through a group, Target 87. The GLC set up an Irish centre in Brent during Mr Livingstone's tenure, which went through a series of crises and overspends. "He indulged the Irish people there, and they indulged him by voting for him," said Illtyd Harrington. Mr Freeson said Mr Livingstone's supporters made life so difficult for him that "in effect I was being excluded, and quite consciously excluded from doing my job as an MP". In parliament By any standards, Ken Livingstone's 12-year parliamentary career has been undistinguished, proof, critics say, of his inability to forge alliances and work with colleagues. For the mayoral race he has the support of eight of London's 57 Labour MPs, including himself; Mr Dobson has 43. Initially coldshouldered by members of the leftwing Campaign group, angry with him for what they saw as his cave-in over capping, Mr Livingstone has failed, as some expected, to take over from Tony Benn as leader of the parliamentary left. Though Mr Livingstone was the Campaign group's choice to run for leader in 1992 - he won the support of only 13 MPs when he needed 55 to make it through to the final ballot - it did not consolidate his position. He shared the ticket with Bernie Grant but, says Mr Grant, "there was no working together. The Campaign group felt that somebody should put up, make a token gesture - I pulled the short straw - we never went on television together." As even his opponents concede, he was given a rude introduction to parliament. The whips ensured he was the last MP to be given an office. He admits detesting Neil Kinnock. But according to some loyalists, attempts were made to take Mr Livingstone on board. "In 1988 we were planning the local elections and I said we should use Ken," said Mrs Hodge. "[But] he was so hated by all the other people ... I am still of the view that if we had used him then ... I think Ken would have come in board. It was just because he was left outside that he established an alternative agenda ... out of pique and [because] there was nowhere else he could go." Both Mr Livingstone and his opponents say the crucial event in his estrangement from the leadership was in 1987, when he joined an attempt to deliver a joint slate for the shadow cabinet elections from the soft left Tribune group and the hard left Campaign group. Tribune group members Gordon Brown and, with an impassioned speech, Jack Straw, repelled the effort. Mr Kinnock said he never considered bringing Mr Livingstone in. "You knew with Ken that he wouldn't say, 'I recognise the gesture, I'm interested in constructing and therefore I'll get on with it', like a lot of other people did. You knew very well that he would take such an opportunity as a sign of concession, he would exploit it and it would end in grief and there was no point in doing it." The Labour leadership "When we were on the GLC together he did say at various points that he had an ambition to be leader of the Labour party," John Carr said. "He's still got the same glint in his eye, he's still got the same agenda ... Ken believes that in the end the rightwing project as he would call it, the Blairites will fail ... and the rank and file of the party will turn once again to the left and look for a new leader, and Tony Benn's mantle will be resting on Ken's shoulders and he'll be waiting for the call." During the 1980s, said David Blunkett, "Ken did believe at the time, seriously, that the party would turn to him to replace Neil Kinnock. He believed that when we lost the 1987 election, and he believed it again in 1992, that the party would turn to him, and he's never understood yet why that wasn't the case, that the party and the country had moved on." Brian Sedgemore offered an alternative take. "He wanted to be leader of the party. That's an unfulfilled ambition. I don't see, because he hasn't fulfilled his ambition, why London should have to suffer."

webTitle: Rumours of talks as Russians continue Chechen assault

fields.headline: Rumours of talks as Russians continue Chechen assault
fields.trailText: Chechen rebel commanders were reportedly holding talks in Moscow today with the Russian government as street battles raged in the centre of Grozny.
fields.body:
Chechen rebel commanders were reportedly holding talks in Moscow today with the Russian government as street battles raged in the centre of Grozny.

Russia's Itar-Tass news agency said the talks were taking place under the mediation of a pro-Moscow Chechen body. The agency quoted Malik Saidullayev, a Moscow-based Chechen businessman who heads the Chechnya state council, as saying the group included "the best known and authoritative field commanders".

He said the talks were progressing "with difficulty" and that it was too soon to identify participants. Those reports add an intriguing twist to the Chechnya war, raising the possibility of a political settlement after weeks of intense fighting.

For now, the fighting continues unabated, with Russian commanders reporting that Grozny, already reduced to a charred and ruined shell, could fall within days. Lieutenant-general Gennady Troshev told Interfax news agency he believed the military operation could be wrapped up by February 26, although "nobody is giving the forces any firm deadlines for ending the operation".

Russian predictions, however, have proved notoriously unreliable. Last year, Moscow forecast that the campaign would end at Christmas.

Russian forces also said they had captured a bridge across the Sunzha river and Minutka square. Rebel commanders have described the bridge as "the most strategically important" site in Grozny as it forms a major transit route for militants moving about the city.

But a statement by Chechen fighters on a rebel website insisted that there had been no Russian breakthrough. "The news regarding Russian troops entering Grozny is not true and the capital remains under our control," said Shamil Basayev, commander of the mujahideen, according to Jihad in Chechnya.

Another Chechen rebel website, www.kavkaz.org, claims: "The Chechens are permitting the Russian units to move deeper into the town in order to wipe them out subsequently." It adds: "During the last 24 hours, the Russians lost about 300 men and eight armoured vehicles. The situation in the Chechen capital is under the control of the Chechen government forces."

Both sides have given conflicting reports of the military successes and casualties since Russia's assault on Chechnya began last autumn.

Estimates of the number of civilians still left in the city range from 10,000 to 40,000. Many are feared trapped in Grozny's cellars with little or no food. Russia's emergency situations ministry said only 59 civilians had managed to leave the city since midday yesterday because of the heavy fighting.

One Russian commander, major general Vadim Timchenko, paid tribute to the rebels' ingenuity in defending the capital. "You have to give them their due," he said. "They have prepared excellently the city for defence in engineering terms, turning it into a many-layered fortress."

fields.headline: Your millennium poems
fields.standfirst:
When poet laureate Andrew Motion sold the millennium poem to a Sunday newspaper, we invited site users to send in their own Y2K odes. Here are some of the ones we received

2000: Zero Gravity by Andrew Motion
Killing Time by Simon Armitage
fields.trailText: A Thousand Years A Thousand Words
fields.body:
A Thousand Years A Thousand Words

Extracts from a poem written to accompany the Royal Mail's Millennium Stamps. It was published by the Camberwell Press on 15 December 1999

"This is a tale about time
A tale that time alone can tell
Trouble is
You don't tell time
Time tells you
Tocktocking its tales
Making things old
Making things new
[...]
This millennium
This garlanded, pilloried thing
Waits
Tales all told
Slouched in night silence
Time ticktocks to dawn
O brave new world
This is the beginning
And this is the end."

By Michael Benson

Untitled

Future's life is exploration
Happiness its dream
Each day a pool of fascination
With change in every scene
But Love itself must have no change,
Its Truth must always be
The foil to evil selfishness
And rampant misery
So
The time has come for each to know
How all the world does live
And find in exploration
That Love, itself, must give

By Michael Goodman

A Song for the Millennium

As words give arbitrary meaning
millennia make sense of centuries
centuries structure years
years: months
months: days
days: hours
framing
this chaos of seconds wrapped in minutes.

A mega thousand lines
might fix those
countless wars, plagues, explorations
inventions, descriptions, obfuscations.

I'd swap it all
for one bare lyric moment.

By Derek Summers

By John O'Donoghue

Untitled

Yesterday is history,
Tomorrow a mystery,
Today is God's gift,
that's why it's called the present.

By Jon Gardener

Untitled

Festive holly draped on the hearth,
Wistful mistletoe is hanging from the frame.
Angels on the tree dance in the lights of Christmas,
Your lonely soul expires like a candle in its flame.
The Ale warms your blood through,
Vodka lights your soul and dims your mind.
Once more the old question haunts you,
Can you afford to be kind?
Are you worthy of those who love you?
To yourself have you been true?
Your life has something missing,
And the missing piece is you.
New year, new century and a new millennium,
yet the old slavery remains the same.

So stand up for yourself and be counted,
refuse to play the profit game.

By Fawaz

Untitled

Dans les clapotements furieux des marées,
Moi, l'autre hiver, plus sourd que les cerveaux d'enfants,
Je courrus! Et les Péninsules démarrées
N'ont pas subi tohu-bohus plus triomphants.

By Foinchem

Millennium Countdown

Empires built by the craftsmen's hand, monuments forever across the land.
Memories of events that last and last, heroes and legends from the past.
Art, science, inventions and sound, all the stars the world has found.
Men of vision, who had a dream, sporting giants - stars of screen.
Songs that will never fade away, The Beatles, love and yesterday,
History, medicine, space and time, all the worlds' clocks are waiting to chime.
A new dawn - has begun, racing toward the Millennium.

By Nicholas Fletcher

panic in grozny

pokemon everywhere

Ship of Fools

I'm dreaming of the Mandledome in all its glorious splendour
all our tinsel town politicians heading off to another bender
the emperor dresses in new clothes he found on tracey emin's bed
Michaelangelo is pissing himself looking at a dead sheep in a jar while Buster 'one take' Keaton smiles and shakes his head
false prophets on the take with jam on new Jerusalem scones and lager cans littering the streets
In the age of enlightement Bill the conqueror yields to Ronald the burger king
roll over Rule Britannia move over cool Britannia
daffy duck rules the airwaves
poet laureates do as they must
knighthoods await
backhanders
heroes and villians call a truce
El Harrod and Hamilton bury the hatchet
and the saviour has come as the messiah with the mercedes courtesy of Lottery UK plc

By Miscreant

Retrograde Motion?

As calendar cogs whirl and 99 turns to 00
The Millennium Mall's open for 24 hour trading
And the Big Bugaboo's got it all in his sack for grabs:
Rent-a-womb services, albums of cute kiddie porn pics,
Court perjury on demand, personalised airbrushing,
Made-to-measure spin-doctoring,
All-purpose ethnic cleansing lotion, even hack poetry -
Each at a specially inflated neo-capitalistic seasonal price.
Yes folks, the muse girls have recently had a Sunday Magazine makeover:
Calliope, ex-epic leader, is a latterday tawdry tinsel whirligig.
Clio, once in charge of heroic verse, has become a compact car.
Thalia's pastoral poems have been cut back to green belt rhymes.
Erato, doyenne of erotic poetry, has sunk to dealing in dirty limericks.
Polyhymnia, lyricist supreme, is currently writing advertising jingles.
In this stripped-pine kitchen-sink school of poetasting
Our word-defying world is bathetically reduced to
A cabbage boiling in a pan of beaded green water,
Or a glazed christmas pudding revolving in the microwave's glare.
Where once Shakespearosaurus and Miltoniraptor roamed the hills
Now cockroach feet patter round crumbs in the pantry.

By Bill Bowler

Extracts from For Millennium Night

Down the snow-covered Hill of Allegory
(Vivaldi's Four Seasons on the CD player
and in our laps the Pictorial Anthology of
The Century's Most Memorable Images
which we received as a Christmas present)
who comes towards us but Time, scythed,
hourglassed, and a little unsteadily tracking
the slope of the last few hours that take him
towards midnight and his extinction;
his two daughters, Falsehood and Truth
(Truth the elder), attentive with medicinal
phials of laudanum, aloe vera, wormwood,
and in his wake the footprints of history
whose images captured by photo-realists
in the same street where they happened, or
dreamed and schemed in the skin and paint
textures of the artist's studio, we may examine
more closely and much more conveniently
in the warmth and comfort of our own homes
by referring to the same Pictorial Anthology
open at this very moment in our own laps.
[...]
Let's drink to youth then, while the year's young, and a third
millennium's still in its infancy; we have a long way to travel.
It's early. Stars fleck the millennium sky with faint pinpoints
of light. They will fade soon, before we are in bed. There'll be
a red sky in the east, and the sound of the dawn birds singing
the sweetest of all dawn songs for this next thousand years.

By John Gohorry

fields.headline: Deeper into the mire
fields.standfirst: The CDU's troubles are likely to grow
fields.trailText: Germany's galloping sleaze scandal, which has irredeemably damaged the reputation of former chancellor Helmut Kohl, is now rapidly consuming the man who wants to follow him. Wolfgang Schäuble's survival of a confidence vote at a crisis meeting of his Christian Democrats yesterday looks like a reprieve, not a pardon.
fields.body:
Germany's galloping sleaze scandal, which has irredeemably damaged the reputation of former chancellor Helmut Kohl, is now rapidly consuming the man who wants to follow him. Wolfgang Schäuble's survival of a confidence vote at a crisis meeting of his Christian Democrats yesterday looks like a reprieve, not a pardon. His defiance of calls to resign will only add fuel to the political funding row which erupted around Dr Kohl last November. The affair has already split the CDU along generational lines. There have been resignations at national and state level, and more may follow. The party's standing with the electorate has been seriously affected, with last autumn's long opinion poll lead over Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrats now nothing more than a fond memory.

As matters stand, the CDU could pay a heavy price in state elections in Schleswig-Holstein next month and North-Rhine Westphalia in May - elections which until recently, many commentators had portrayed as a possibly fatal obstacle to Mr Schröder's vacillating chancellorship. Yesterday's apparent CDU attempt to pin the blame for the scandal wholly on Dr Kohl, with the implication that he should quit parliament as well as his post as honorary CDU chairman, looks doomed to failure. Mr Schäuble's refusal to take responsibility, particularly given his belated and incomplete admission of personal involvement, will not impress the voters or younger party members. He may not, technically, have broken the law. But how much longer he can survive as a credible force is very much open to question.

The funding scandal now looks set to run and run. The CDU's apparently routine and systematic abuse of laws concerning the origin and disclosure of campaign cash donations, over a period of many years, makes it likely that the official inquiries launched into its finances in Bonn and Frankfurt will extend elsewhere. It is possible political parties other than the CDU may also become enmeshed in this dragnet. The tax authorities will be keen to discover just how much of the $17m so far linked to the scams was money which was rightfully the state's. But it is the upcoming parliamentary inquiry into the affair which promises to produce the real fireworks. It will inevitably raise issues about the transparency and accountability of a political system which has changed little since the post-war settlement. But if it is thoroughly conducted, the inquiry should also be able to provide answers to the key questions which Dr Kohl and others have so far ignored: who were the CDU's mystery money-men, and did their cash influence government policies and decisions? In short, was the Kohl government, which held power for 16 consecutive years, up for sale?

Concern has already been expressed about cash payments to the party and the former government's approval of an arms sale to Saudi Arabia; about a property company which made donations to the CDU and which bought government-privatised housing stock at bargain basement prices; and about the controversial sale of an east German oil refinery to the French oil giant, Elf Aquitaine. These transactions may represent merely the tip of the proverbial iceberg - and, with Mr Schäuble unrepentant, the hunt is on in earnest for more evidence. Karlheinz Schreiber, the millionaire businessman whose bundles of used banknotes lie at the heart of the scandal, predicted last November that "it will become very nasty" before it is finished. As the CDU's treasurers might have said, you can bet your bottom deutschmark on that.

webTitle: Kohl forced out as Schäuble clings on

fields.headline: Kohl forced out as Schäuble clings on
fields.trailText: The former German chancellor Helmut Kohl last night resigned in disgrace from the honorary leadership of the party he headed for a quarter of a century.
fields.body:
The former German chancellor Helmut Kohl last night resigned in disgrace from the honorary leadership of the party he headed for a quarter of a century.

As he stepped down, reports circulated that prosecutors investigating him on suspicion of financial impropriety had raided the house of one of his closest associates.

Mr Kohl was responding to an ultimatum from his successor as head of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). Wolfgang Schäuble had warned him that he should either collaborate with the prosecutors or step aside.

The former chancellor, who had stayed on as honorary chairman, has refused to identify the source of some DM2m (£635,000) which he kept secret and funnelled into party coffers through a network of clandestine accounts.

He took barely two hours to reach his decision to resign. In a statement he said it had not been an easy choice, but added: "I do not see myself in a position to break my promise to several people who supported financially my work in the CDU."

Mr Kohl's refusal to name names put him on a collision course with the judiciary and raised the likelihood of an even more tangled, protracted and emotionally charged crisis. But, in forcing his hand, his successor has succeeded - however temporarily - in switching the focus of the affair away from the party's present leaders. But it is not yet clear whether his ploy will backfire, widening a breach between Kohl loyalists in the CDU and members seeking a clean break with the past.

The Christian Democrats' leadership had earlier confounded expectations of a blood-letting session by rallying behind Mr Schäuble at a crisis meeting in Berlin.

The CDU chairman said afterwards that he had asked his executive whether he should go. "The executive said that if I resigned then the entire executive would resign."

But differences of opinion were apparent among senior figures going into the meeting, and when Mr Schäuble was asked if there had been a power struggle among other CDU politicians he was evasive. "What there was has been decided," he said.

Since Mr Kohl's confession, the scandal has spread like a bushfire through the party, singeing Mr Schäuble and burning its way into the regional leadership. Most recently, party bosses in Hesse acknowledged that far greater sums than those taken by either Mr Kohl or Mr Schäuble were disguised. Some were falsely explained as bequests from Jewish Holocaust survivors with accounts in offshore tax havens.

Mr Schäuble yesterday offered an apology to Germany's Jews for a ploy that has outraged community leaders.

The disclosures of irregularities in Hesse caused the first political casualty of the affair. On Monday Manfred Kanther, the regional party chairman and Mr Kohl's former interior minister, gave up his seat in parliament. He had previously admitted that local officials had channelled DM13m into campaign funds through a Swiss account.

A key figure in the Hesse affair and in the investigation of Mr Kohl is one of the former chancellor's confidants and advisers, Hans Terlinden. According to a report to be published in today's edition of the mass-circulation Bild Zeitung, Mr Terlinden's home in Mainz was raided yesterday by officials from the prosecutors' offices in Bonn and Wiesbaden.

It is likely that the Christian Democrats' opponents will redouble their efforts to get senior party figures to accept responsibility for their self-confessed misdemeanours.

The speaker of the lower house of parliament, Wolfgang Thierse, a member of the governing Social Democrats, has rejected the CDU's revised party accounts as unsatisfactory and called for them to be resubmitted. If the newly reshaped figures fail to convince him, the Christian Democrats may risk losing state funding.

And next week an all-party committee opens its inquiry into the question underlying the whole scandal - whether the Christian Democrats kept the contributions secret because they were, in fact, bribes or rewards for government decisions.

webTitle: My life on the net: David Long, Reclaim the Streets activist

fields.headline: My life on the net: David Long, Reclaim the Streets activist
fields.trailText: An activist's favourite sites
fields.body:
®TMark
This site produces spoof versions of the enemy's websites. While retaining a graphic similarity, real information is given instead of the office propaganda of the organisation - but with a sense of humour, instead of dry politics. Subversive humour is about making corporations look ridiculous. There's an added advantage when those being subverted become apoplectic about these spoof sites, as they did before the World Trade Organisation's Seattle conference when its director-general called this site underhand.

A similar thing took place with a spoof Shell website which was established at the beginning of '99. What's so good when you search for a company website, for example in Shell's case, is that our subverted website appears directly next to the official address.

On the other hand, Etoys is a huge corporation that does mail order e-toys, and they took to court a European group dedicated to subversive art who used the same name. The corporation was getting very upset that its customers were getting diverted. That was quite interesting - the law, politics, virtual territory and how businesses colonised the net.

www.oilcompanies.org
Exposes the sophisticated green-wash employed by corporations with huge public relations budgets and returns the web to what it should be - access for all. It makes our message as accessible as that of the corporations, regardless of how powerful they are.

agp.org
A very good way to find out about global resistance is by looking at Peoples' Global Action (PGA). It's a global network of groups and people resisting capitalism. Our own Reclaim the Streets site is good for more local resistance. I think it explains a lot, and it's witty, and it gives information - where and when a particular event or action takes place. There tends to be a generic way websites are laid out and Reclaim The Streets breaks the mould.

 Interview by Andy Ajiz

webTitle: Tips on getting more efficiency out of women employees

fields.headline: Tips on getting more efficiency out of women employees
fields.standfirst: Advice from a 1943 issue of the US magazine Transportation on women in the workforce
fields.trailText: • Pick young married women. They usually have more of a sense of responsibility than their unmarried sisters, they're less likely to be flirtatious, they need the work or they wouldn't be doing it, they still have the pep and interest to work hard and to deal with the public efficiently.
fields.body:
 Pick young married women. They usually have more of a sense of responsibility than their unmarried sisters, they're less likely to be flirtatious, they need the work or they wouldn't be doing it, they still have the pep and interest to work hard and to deal with the public efficiently.

 When you have to use older women, try to get ones who have worked outside the home at some time in their lives. Older women who have never contacted the public have a hard time adapting themselves and are inclined to be cantankerous and fussy. It's always well to impress upon older women the importance of friendliness and courtesy.

 General experience indicates that "husky" girls - those who are just a little on the heavy side - are more even tempered and efficient than their underweight sisters.

 Retain a physician to give each woman you hire a special physical examination - one covering female conditions. This step not only protects the property against the possibilities of lawsuit, but reveals whether the employee-to-be has any female weaknesses which would make her mentally or physically unfit for the job.

 Stress at the outset the importance of time - the fact that a minute or two lost here and there makes serious inroads on schedules. Until this point is gotten across, service is likely to be slowed up.

 Give the female employee a definite day-long schedule of duties so that they'll keep busy without bothering the management for instructions every few minutes. Numerous properties say that women make excellent workers when they have their jobs cut out for them, but that they lack initiative in finding work themselves.

 Whenever possible, let the inside employee change from one job to another at some time during the day. Women are inclined to beless nervous and happier with change.

 Give every girl an adequate number of rest periods during the day. You have to make some allowances for feminine psychology. A girl has more confidence and is more efficient if she can keep her hair tidied, apply fresh lipstick and wash her hands several times a day.

 Be tactful when issuing instructions or in making criticisms. Women are often sensitive; they can't shrug off harsh words the way men do.

 Never ridicule a woman - it breaks her spirit and cuts off her efficiency.

 Be reasonably considerate about using strong language around women. Even though a girl's husband or father may swear vociferously, she'll grow to dislike a place of business where she hears too much of this.

 Get enough size variety in operator's uniforms so that each girl can have a proper fit. This point can't be stressed too much in keeping women happy.
