fields.headline: Stop and think
fields.standfirst: What is the truth about 'stop and  search'? Does it prevent crime? Does it  discriminate against black people?  Denis O'Connor at the Met has been  monitoring what happens on the streets  of London
fields.trailText: What is the truth about 'stop and search'? Does it prevent crime? Does it discriminate against black people? Denis O'Connor at the Met has been monitoring what happens on the streets of London.
fields.body:
Stop and search has, at best, had a mixed press, but it's had a bad press for a long time. To move forward, we need to bear in mind the old adage: "Seek simplicity and then distrust it."

Reduced to their simplest, we are faced with two opposing arguments: on the left, the power is regarded as unfair, almost to the point of being sinister, while on the right it's seen as something of a panacea for dealing with all crime.

Yet a narrow concern for fairness based on superficial assumptions about how "fairness" is to be measured risks undermining the effective use of the power to tackle crime. And the impact of this will be unfair in real terms - more victims will come from the poorer sections of communities living in high crime areas and this, in turn, means that the consequence will disproportionately affect ethnic minorities.

Until now, the test of fairness has rested on the notion of "disproportionality". The fact that ethnic minorities nationally are six times more likely to be searched than whites has been assumed to measure the scale of unfairness.

The approach we've adopted at the Metropolitan Police in London is to seek improvements in the use of the tactic but to be led by the evidence, acknowledging that we need to base our action on facts rather than assumptions - whether we like the facts or not.

Since April 1998, on seven sites in London we have piloted an intelligence-led approach to establish how much more effective stop and search could be in qualitative and quantitative terms without encouraging officers to fiddle the figures. As reported in August 1999, with the touchstone "quality not quantity", additional training, briefing of officers and accountability for their efforts produced real improvements.

We increased the searches which resulted in an arrest from 10% to 18% while we reduced the ratio of black people searched relative to whites from 4.4 to 3.3 to 1.

However, these promising results left a number of thorny questions. Since the publication of the Lawrence report in February last year, the use of the power has declined by about 50% in London; and an important factor in the reduction of searches has been officers' concerns about being accused of racism. At the same time, crime has increased across the board. Some of the police and the press claimed that the reduction in searches has increased crime.

Rather than rush into this speculative and polarised debate, I insisted on pursuing our evidence- based approach, believing that our commitment to the safety of vulnerable communities required us to delve deeper into the issues. We therefore expanded our evaluation of the work on the pilot sites into what we believe is the first major study of its kind in this country. It looks in depth at searches in general, including the link with crime, disproportionality, the reduction in searches and the potential for improvement.

The study was undertaken independently by Dr Marian FitzGerald. Among the findings of her report, published in December, was that the apparent disproportionality associated with the tactic was significantly less when allowances were made for demographic factors.

For example, once comparisons were limited to the age group most likely to be searched (between 13 and 37) the black: white ratio reduced from 3.3 to 1.6. And the disproportionality reduced even more dramatically if further account was taken of victims' reports of crime suspects.

The report also produced some surprising results with regard to t he impact of searches on crime. Forty-seven per cent of arrests for possession of drugs came from searches in 1998/99, rising to 84% in the case of offensive weapons and 95% of going equipped to steal. And analysis undertaken separately by the London School of Economics confirmed that there was a statistical correlation between the fall in searches and the rise in crime at the beginning of 1999.

Worryingly, but predictably, this rise in crime has been most severe in inner city areas. Within London, crime rose on average by 24% in five inner city boroughs, compared to only 7% in the suburbs.

We cannot afford to withdraw from using the tactic if it penalises the communities most in need of protection - that is, those people (a disproportionate number of whom are from ethnic minorities) who must share the space on streets with those in possession of weapons, drugs, etc. If we do, they will increasingly feel unsafe to use the streets at all. Indeed, stripped of its negative connotations, the theory of broken windows has much to offer in terms of understanding how neighbourhoods decay as minor crime and incivility go unchecked.

Stop and search is not a cure-all and it can only be one tool in our armoury for halting this decline. For me, the most powerful messages of the report is that all groups support the police use of the power, provided they use it with respect.

The two most salient features of this issue - and indeed in race relations and the criminal justice system more widely - are, first, the complexity of assessing fairness and, second, the dilemmas involved in trying to achieve it.

What should be done? First, I believe we need to agree common ground on how we measure fairness, based on more refined notions of proportionality. Meanwhile, the human rights act, which will apply from October, itself enshrines a new concept of proportionality which will require increased vigilance on the part of the police but which may yet prove to be a useful basis for achieving fairness.

Second, the Lawrence report recommends providing documentation of the reasons to anyone stopped by the police. This documentation of "stop and talk" is currently being tested; and it may prove a less intrusive, more acceptable way for officers to re-engage - and to re-engage with respect - rather than disengage.

Third, and this will upset some people, we should consider challenging the low use of searches in crime prone areas. Working with the communities in these areas, we need to work out where the tactic could be used most beneficially on their behalf and this could be included in local crime and disorder plans. Taken together, these approaches may enable us to balance concerns of fairness for people who are searched with fairness to the community as a whole.

webTitle: 'A police service that can enjoy widespread support from the community as a whole'

fields.headline: 'A police service that can enjoy widespread support from the community as a whole'
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson's statement to the Commons
fields.trailText: Full text: Peter Mandelson's statement to the Commons
fields.body:
With permission, Madam Speaker, I would like to make a statement on the Government's decisions on the report of the Independent Commission on Policing in Northern Ireland, known as the Patten Report after its Chairman, Chris Patten.

Of all the issues that have divided society in Northern Ireland, policing is probably the most controversial. In the last 30 years the Royal Ulster Constabulary has faced demands completely unlike those faced by any other force in the United Kingdom or elsewhere in the developed world. I would like to place on record the Government's deep admiration for the courage, resilience and professionalism with which the RUC has met these challenges. The accounts I have heard of personal tragedy, pain and loss in the RUC family are profoundly moving and humbling. 302 officers have been killed, and many thousands injured. We all owe the RUC a huge debt of gratitude. The George Cross is a fitting acknowledgement of their sacrifice.

But in rising to the challenge, the RUC has inevitably, if unfairly, become identified more with one side of the community than the other. It finds it hard to recruit from the nationalist community and - with 88% of its members Protestant and only 8% Catholic - is not representative of all sides of the community.

This is not a desirable state of affairs. The RUC itself is forward-looking and accepts the need for change. It is eager to police a normal society in a normal professional way, but it is held back by the burden of history.

The talks which led to the Good Friday Agreement addressed but did not resolve these problems. Instead, Chris Patten and his colleagues were asked to design arrangements for, and I quote:

"a police service that can enjoy widespread support from, and is seen to be an integral part of, the community as a whole."

The Patten Commission rose to this challenge and I pay tribute to them. Their report covers, among other things, composition, training, culture, ethos and symbols. My Rt Hon friend the Member for Redcar accepted the report in principle, and launched a period of consultation about the details. Since my own appointment, I have met all the interested parties and police groups and have listened carefully to what they had to say.

The decisions which I am announcing today will be reflected in legislation which we will bring forward later in this session. In reaching them, I have been driven by, and have tried to keep in balance, three distinct but interdependent considerations:

 representativeness;

 effectiveness;

 respect for the sacrifices of the past.

I say "interdependent", because only a police service that is accepted and draws members from both traditions and is therefore accepted across the community can hope to be fully effective. And it is only by recognising the sacrifices of the past that we can move forward together to meet the challenges of the future. I am determined that the police in Northern Ireland should be modern, representative and effective, and no longer the fulcrum of antagonistic debate.

However, Patten also points out that the implementation of some recommendations will, and again I quote, 'depend to a greater or lesser degree on how the security situation develops', and that judgements will need to be made on how and when they should be introduced. That is advice which the Government will, rightly, keep firmly in mind as we take this process forward.

Human Rights

Patten rightly places much emphasis on human rights. The Chief Constable and the new Policing Board together will be made responsible for developing and implementing a comprehensive programme of action - including an audit to ensure full compliance with human rights requirements. We also accept a new police oath as proposed by Patten, which will be taken by all new recruits to the police service. I do not believe it appropriate for already attested officers to take the new oath, which would in any case raise significant legal difficulties. All officers will, however, receive human rights training, and will be required to behave in accordance with a Code of Ethics. This Code will be provided for in legislation, and will, like the new Oath, emphasise the priority to be given to human rights.

Accountability

The Government accepts Patten's recommendation for the creation of a new Policing Board, composed as the Report recommends, to replace the current Police Authority. The new Policing Board will be responsible for securing the maintenance of an efficient and effective police service and holding the Chief Constable and the police service to account.

I am sure the House will wish to join with me in paying tribute to the work of the Police Authority over the last 30 years. Many have served with distinction on the Authority, and were prepared to come forward even when there was a direct terrorist threat against them. Two members of the Authority were murdered by terrorists. The contribution of the Authority, members and staff, will not be forgotten.

Police planning process

The Report recommends clarifying the roles of the Secretary of State, the Chief Constable and the Policing Board. The broad thrust of the recommendations is that the Policing Board should play a more developed role - setting objectives, priorities and performance targets while leaving operational control and direction of the police firmly in the Chief Constable's hands.

I entirely agree with the Report that the new Policing Board "should be empowered and equipped to scrutinise the performance of the police effectively". I therefore accept the recommendations and will introduce legislation accordingly, subject to the Chief Constable continuing to answer to me on all matters involving national security and the work of relevant agencies.

DPPBs

Patten proposed the creation of District Policing Partnership Boards to provide an element of local accountability. He envisaged that they should have a primarily consultative role with an ability to monitor police delivery against an agreed local plan, and I endorse this. He also proposed an additional community safety role, with powers to purchase services on top of normal policing. This latter activity is currently a subject being considered by the Criminal Justice Review. Until decisions are taken on this Review, which will be published shortly, I do not intend to extend their function in this way. It will be better, in any case, to concentrate initially on building up relationships at the local level in what I propose to call District Policing Partnerships. I also intend to consider further the arrangements proposed for Belfast, where I am not satisfied that it would be right to have four separate partnerships.

Style, structure, size and composition of the police service

Progress on the style of policing and the size of the police service will be critically dependent on the Chief Constable's assessment of the security threat and the public order situation. There will be no question of rushing forward with changes in the absence of a stable security environment. Subject to that overall proviso, in line with the Report, the Chief Constable has decided to re-organise the police service into District Commands based on District Council areas and geared towards policing in partnership with the community. District Commanders will have much higher levels of devolved authority under the overall command of the Chief Constable. The Chief Constable intends that this structural reorganisation will be underway by November this year.

The Chief Constable will also re-organise Police Headquarters to produce a slimmer structure. Headquarters will in future take a more strategic approach to management and Special Branch and CID will both be retained and placed under a single Assistant Chief Constable, as the Chief Constable believes is desirable, when the security situation permits.

The Government accepts Patten's recommendations on the future size of the police service - that is, a regular complement of 7,500 full-time officers - provided, as the Report says, that the security situation does not deteriorate significantly. We accept Patten's recommendation for the enlargement of the part-time Reserve and the discontinuation of the full-time Reserve - again, subject to the security situation.

The severance arrangements to enable serving police officers, whether regular or reservist, to leave the police service will be generous and sympathetic. The Government is committed to finding the necessary resources. Negotiations with the police staff associations are currently in progress. I hope that these discussions will help all sides to agree arrangements which will address the concern which officers understandably have about their future.

I attach particular importance to Patten's recommendations for action to transform the composition of the police service, which are essential to gaining widespread acceptability. I endorse the proposal for 50/50 recruitment of Protestants and Catholics, from a pool of candidates all of whom - I stress - will have qualified on merit. We propose that the requirement for this special measure should be kept under review on a triennial basis, with rigorous safeguards to ensure that the, rightly, challenging targets for recruitment do not diminish the standard required of recruits. There will be no question whatsoever of ex-terrorists joining the service.

Name and symbols

Madam Speaker, our aim is to develop a police service which is both effective and accepted throughout the community. This aim, as Patten recognises, also clearly bears on the name and symbols of the RUC.

The issue here is not whether the name of the RUC is wrong or something not to be proud of. I understand exactly why serving and former officers, their families and indeed widows are proud of the RUC and its name. The issue is whether a change in name, underlining a new start, is a necessary and indispensable part of attracting balance in recruits. Of course it is not the only barrier to recruitment. There has been at times disgraceful intimidation of nationalists who wished to join the RUC. But a change of name was in Patten's view essential, and I agree.

That change is needed to signal the new beginning which will, in particular, be symbolised by the arrival in the new training environment of the first recruits entering through the new independent procedures and selected on the new balanced basis. That point will come in the autumn of next year. At that point too, I will therefore bring into force the new title, which will be the Police Service of Northern Ireland, a name which I believe is preferable to that proposed by Patten.

At the same time, a service badge incorporating this title will be introduced, after the new Policing Board has had a chance to address the issue. In this context, the RUC will wish to consider how best permanently to record the award to them of the George Cross last autumn. And finally, existing police memorials will remain as they are, and the colour of the uniform will not change.

IT and Training

The Government also accepts Patten's important recommendation for IT improvements to put the police in Northern Ireland at the forefront of communications and information technology, and for police training. I am also delighted to tell the House that we have accepted the case for a new Police College, and appropriate resources will be provided. These are in addition to a range of other forward-looking recommendations on practical policing issues, which I will not detain the House by detailing here, which we will also be implementing.

Oversight Commissioner

Finally, Patten recommends the appointment of an Oversight Commissioner, to monitor the implementation of those changes agreed by the Government. This appointment will not in any way cut across the responsibilities of either the new Policing Board or the Chief Constable, and the accountability which I and my colleagues have to this House on policing issues will not diminish as a result. The Oversight Commissioner will help create a first rate police service for the future.

Conclusion

Madam Speaker, the implementation of these changes will entail a major and challenging programme of work for the Government, the Chief Constable, the Police Authority (and in due course the Policing Board) but, most of all, for police officers themselves. It is not an overnight event but a process of change which will extend over several years. I am confident that the police will meet the challenge of change positively and with commitment.

For those in the unionist community who have fears, I urge them to accept the need for significant change to create a police service in which all can feel they belong and with which all can identify. To nationalists who have for so long withheld their support from the police in Northern Ireland, I would ask them to reflect on the transformation that is planned and to reconsider their position. It is now time for them to support this programme of change; unambiguously to support the police; and to encourage young men and women from their community to join the police. The prize is a modern, effective police service drawing support and strength from all parts of the community. It is within our grasp. The proposals I have announced today should enable us to achieve it.

I am also delighted to tell the House that we have accepted the case for a new Police College, and appropriate resources will be provided. These are in addition to a range of other forward-looking recommendations on practical policing issues, which I will not detain the House by detailing here, which we will also be implementing. Oversight Commissioner Finally, Patten recommends the appointment of an Oversight Commissioner, to monitor the implementation of those changes agreed by the Government. This appointment will not in any way cut across the responsibilities of either the new Policing Board or the Chief Constable, and the accountability which I and my colleagues have to this House on policing issues will not diminish as a result. The Oversight Commissioner will help create a first rate police service for the future. Conclusion Madam Speaker, the implementation of these changes will entail a major and challenging programme of work for the Government, the Chief Constable, the Police Authority (and in due course the Policing Board) but, most of all, for police officers themselves. It is not an overnight event but a process of change which will extend over several years. I am confident that the police will meet the challenge of change positively and with commitment. For those in the unionist community who have fears, I urge them to accept the need for significant change to create a police service in which all can feel they belong and with which all can identify. To nationalists who have for so long withheld their support from the police in Northern Ireland, I would ask them to reflect on the transformation that is planned and to reconsider their position. It is now time for them to support this programme of change; unambiguously to support the police; and to encourage young men and women from their community to join the police. The prize is a modern, effective police service drawing support and strength from all parts of the community. It is within our grasp. The proposals I have announced today should enable us to achieve it.

webTitle: Blair rebukes Hague on crime and health

fields.headline: Blair rebukes Hague on crime and health
fields.standfirst: Prime minister's questions
fields.trailText: William Hague came under attack today in a prime minister's question time dominated by rising crime figures and the NHS crisis.
fields.body:
William Hague came under attack today in a prime minister's question time dominated by rising crime figures and the NHS crisis.

The Tory leader came unstuck as he told the house that Labour's "failure to be tough on a crime is a cause of crime" and Mr Blair's promises to increase health spending were fiction.

Mr Hague said that there are 1,000 less police officers today than there were at the election, police morale had dropped and crime was rising.

"His pledges to be tough on crime turned out to be worthless pledges turned out to be a worthless aspiration. Is the 5% increase on health a pledge or aspiration?" he asked Mr Blair.

Mr Blair told the Commons that police numbers had fallen under the last government and that crime had doubled.

He added that he was "entirely confident" that the government would be able to increase spending on the NHS by 5% in real terms over the next five years. Pay rises to nurses last year had led to a 24% increase in recruitment, he said.

"I stand by what I said on the Frost programme," Mr Blair said to Tory heckles.

Mr Hague accused Mr Blair of failing to clarify whether the government would be giving extra money to the health service or not, and said that Downing Street spokesmen had been giving out different messages.

"Frost on Sunday, panic on Monday, u-turn on Tuesday and waffle on Wednesday," he said.

He dismissed the prime minister's promise of extra funding for the NHS as a "piece of rhetoric to get him through the next five days."

As the row raged on, Mr Blair angrily hit back, accusing the opposition leader of having "zero judgment" on health policy.

To loud Labour cheers, he added: "Your policies are a joke. Your party is divided and that is one reason why this country will never trust the Tories with the health service again."

Mr Blair turned on the Tory plans to make private medical insurance compulsory for non-urgent operations. He said it was a "ludicrous notion" for the Tories to claim that the problems of the NHS could be resolved through private medical insurance.

The Tories made a promise to cut tax irrespective of economic growth, he said, and were now forced to find a policy to accommodate it.

Mr Blair quoted the previous prime minister, John Major, who had said that it was impossible to cut tax as a proportion of GDP without a cut in spending on the health service.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy called on Mr Blair to halt the 1p income tax cut due in April and spend the £2bn thus saved on the NHS.

Mr Blair accused the Liberal Democrats of asking him both to reduce the tax burden and to raise taxes.

In other questions, the prime minister told the Commons that the repeal of section 28, which prohibits the promotion of homosexuality in schools, would "free school teachers and others to be able to explain to children properly the facts of life". He said it was "a sensible change and a right change".

fields.headline: Method in his movies
fields.standfirst: Kenneth Branagh is our greatest living Shakespearean - and that's official.  Michael Billington  on why he won the Golden Quill
fields.trailText: Kenneth Branagh is our greatest living Shakespearean - and that's official. Michael Billington on why he won the Golden Quill
fields.body:
On Sunday Kenneth Branagh won the Golden Quill, established by the Washington-based Shakespeare Guild to honour the "greatest Shakespearean of our day". Clearly the guild's founder, John F Andrews, has a wry sense of humour. After praising the 38-year-old Branagh for introducing Shakespeare to a new generation through his films, he goes on: "In the process Mr Branagh has revived the sagging fortunes of a 435-year-old has-been and turned him into today's hottest screenwriter."

It is significant that the award is American and is given to Branagh primarily for his movies. In blasé Britain, where Shakespeare is still theatrically available and where Branagh-bashing is a popular sport, we have no idea of the impact the Belfast boy's movies have made in the US. I was in Chicago when Branagh's Renaissance Theatre Company was playing King Lear and Midsummer Night's Dream. The theatre was packed with young people, and at a panel on playing Shakespeare, in which Branagh took part, people talked about the Henry V movie with a glowing gratitude you wouldn't find in Britain. Americans, quite simply, have a hunger for Shakespeare which their theatre cannot begin to satisfy.

But Branagh doesn't merely have three Shakespeare movies made, with Love's Labour's Lost and Macbeth still to come. He has, in at least two of those cases, created a film that is comparable in linguistic richness and density of texture to a theatrical experience. Praising Branagh for making a movie that is like a play may seem a backhanded compliment, but in a medium where adapting Shakespeare usually involves textual dilution, Branagh has shown you can preserve the values of the original and still make exciting cinema.

Filming Shakespeare is always difficult. The Russian director Grigori Kozintsev once summed up the orthodox cinematic view: "The problem is not one of finding means to speak the verse in front of the camera... The aural has to be made visual. The poetic texture itself has to be transformed into a visual poetry, into the dynamic organisation of film imagery." This is easier if you're working in a language other than English; it's what Kozintsev himself did in Hamlet, Kurosawa in Throne of Blood - and Orson Welles in his sequence of Shakespeare movies, by treating the text as if it were in another tongue.

Branagh, however, has found a way of preserving the text and yet keeping the film visually alive. In Henry V, Derek Jacobi's Chorus, wandering through the battle-scenes like an ironic commentator, keeps the language constantly in front of us. Contrast the Olivier version, in which the Chorus is gradually reduced to an off-screen voice. Even more remarkable is the Branagh Hamlet, where we get a powerful image of Elsinore as a vast hall of mirrors and a place of imprisoning confinement, and the full four-hour text, which reminds us that the prince is part of a larger pattern.

Branagh has preserved the Shakespearean experience and yet produced popular cinema. What we forget, however, is that the Branagh movies, which triggered off a whole new cycle and made Shakespeare cinematically sexy, owe their exis tence to the Renaissance Theatre Company. Read Branagh's premature biography, Beginning, and you discover that, even as he was planning a Renaissance theatre season comprising Hamlet, Much Ado About Nothing and As You Like It, he was insisting that filming on Henry V start the second it was finished. The momentum created by the theatre project carried through into the movie. It also helped that Branagh had already played Henry V for Adrian Noble at the RSC and understood the rhythm of the role.

In short, Shakespeare on screen often depends on a pre-existing theatrical culture: both Branagh and Olivier used their regular team of actors and even Baz Luhrmann's high-concept Romeo + Juliet was the product of a group who had grown up together at drama school in Sydney. As ever, cinema feeds off theatre. But if Branagh amply deserves his Golden Quill, it is not just for his remarkable chutzpah and energy. It is for showing that you can do Shakespeare on screen without sacrificing his density and richness and without relentlessly transforming the aural into the visual. Imaginatively handled, the aural becomes the visual.

fields.standfirst: Could you have won a million? Try our interactive quiz
fields.trailText: The £1m question was unveiled last night, even if it was not actually answered. To win the jackpot on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? all that was needed was the answer to the question: which county cricket side is based at Chester-le-Street?
fields.body:
The £1m question was unveiled last night, even if it was not actually answered. To win the jackpot on ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? all that was needed was the answer to the question: which county cricket side is based at Chester-le-Street?

The answer, Durham, evaded Peter Lee, a 65-year-old retired naval officer from west Wales, who was consoled by becoming the first person to win £500,000 on the British version of the hit game show.

ITV sources last night predicted record viewing figures for the edition as Mr Lee correctly answered 14 of the 15 questions. He had earlier told the programme's host, Chris Tarrant, that he would be pleased to go home with £4,000 to cover the cost of his new car.

Mr Lee, who first appeared on Monday night's show, reached £8,000 using one of his lifelines, ask the audience, to ascertain the answer to the £4,000 question: "Corgi means 'dwarf dog' in which language?", correctly answering "Welsh".

He used his remaining two lifelines, phone a friend and 50-50, on the £250,000 question, but answered without help the £500,000 question: "What does the Japanese word 'kamikaze' literally mean?" with "divine wind".

The path to £500,000 was:

 £16,000: Bhutan is a small country situated in which range of mountains? a. Alps; b. Pyrenees; c. Andes; d. Himalayas (answer: d)

 £32,000: Which of these is made from beef? a. prosciutto; b. pastrami; c. pumpernickel; d. panettone (answer: b)

 £64,000: Which of these actresses has not appeared in Coronation Street? a. Patricia Routledge; b. Maureen Lipman; c. Prunella Scales; d. Joanna Lumley (answer: b)

 £125,000: Which John Osborne play features the character Archie Rice? a. The Entertainer; b. West of Suez; c. Look Back in Anger; d. Time Present (answer: a)

 £250,000: Which French impressionist painter had a son who became a successful film director? a. Pissarro; b. Degas; c. Sisley; d. Renoir (answer: d)

 £500,000: What does the Japanese word "kamikaze" literally mean? a. sacred venture; b. divine wind; c. self-destruction; d. final attack (answer: b)

webTitle: Mandelson confirms sweeping changes and new name for RUC

fields.headline: Mandelson confirms sweeping changes and new name for RUC
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson today moved to dampen Unionist fury over plans to overhaul the Royal Ulster Constabulary after confirming that the force will be renamed the Police Service of Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson today moved to dampen Unionist fury over plans to overhaul the Royal Ulster Constabulary after confirming that the force will be renamed the Police Service of Northern Ireland.

Mr Mandelson told the Commons that most of the 175 reforms proposed by the Patten Commission last year will be implemented. As well as the name change, there will be a cut in size from 13,500 officers to 7,500 is envisaged, and an equal number of Catholic and Protestants.

All RUC officers will receive human rights training, accept a new police oath and follow a new code of ethics. A new policing board will replace the current police authority, along with new district policing partnership boards, he announced.

"For those in the Unionist community who have fears, I urge them to accept the need for significant change to create a police service in which all can feel they belong and with which all can identify," he said.

In an angry prime minister's question time Northern Ireland first minister David Trimble asked Tony Blair why the Royal Ulster Constabulary had been forced to loose its name.

Mr Trimble said there were only a few police forces with the right to call themselves Royal. "What precedent is there for removing such an award and is it not regarded as a sign of dishonour?" he demanded.

Mr Blair stressed: "There is no dishonour intended to the RUC. Their officers have given their lives in outstanding bravery over many, many years. "What we are trying to do is ensure we have a police service in Northern Ireland that is capable of attracting support from all sides of the community so that it can police better."

This morning Mr Mandelson had tried to assuage Unionists by arguing that change was inevitable. "These changes are going to involve pain for the whole RUC family," He told the BBC's Today programme.

"I don't want to seem to add insult to injury but I don't believe it is possible to avoid making all these changes, including to the name, if we are going to get the sort of policing we want in Northern Ireland."

The implementation of the recommendations by former Hong Kong governor Chris Patten is likely to end the honeymoon between Mr Mandelson and the Ulster Unionists. It will also heighten pressure on Ulster Unionist Party leader David Trimble as he prepares for a crucial meeting of his party's ruling council on 12 February. The council will meet to consider whether the IRA is meeting its commitment to disarm; Mr Trimble has offered to resign if this is not the case.

A senior Ulster Unionist warned today that if his party was unable to prevent the Patten report from being implemented, it would call Mr Trimble's leadership into question.

David Burnside declared: "I find what is about to be announced absolutely revolting and I expect the Unionist Party to act accordingly. If David Trimble, John Taylor, Ken Maginnis are not capable as Unionist leaders in defending the name and reputation of the RUC, I think the whole question of their leadership is in doubt."

The Police Service of Northern Ireland name was agreed after Mr Patten's suggested name of Northern Ireland Police Service was rejected because the government disliked the NIPS acronym.

webTitle: Towering colossus who fell to earth

fields.headline: Towering colossus who fell to earth
fields.trailText: If a tragedy is the story of a great man brought to  ruin by his inner weaknesses, then - in the strict  and literary sense of the word - the fate of Helmut  Kohl is truly a tragedy.
fields.body:
If a tragedy is the story of a great man brought to ruin by his inner weaknesses, then - in the strict and literary sense of the word - the fate of Helmut Kohl is truly a tragedy.

His resignation last night from the honorary chairmanship of the Christian Democrats is highly significant for a country he reunited by the sheer power of his personality.

It is not, arguably, the end of the "Kohl era". In one sense, that ended when he was voted out of office in the 1998 general election. In another, it is far from over, for Mr Kohl remains a prominent figure on the German political landscape.

His decision to step down rather than name the donors whose contributions he secretly channeled into party accounts has set the scene for a potentially titanic court struggle.

But what last night's announcement has done is to reduce him definitively from the status of a feted hero to that of an ordinary mortal. And that is a role to which Helmut Kohl, the "reunification chancellor" and godfather of monetary union, has long since ceased to be accustomed.

The same qualities which made him great also brought him to the ground. "In Helmut Kohl's politics there was never much room for concepts or systems, let alone rules," a German journalist said. "It was always people. If he could get through to the person, then he felt that he had the key to a deal or a solution".

And he was right. Magnificently so. It was Mr Kohl's "touchy-feely" politics that enabled him to forge a relationship with François Mitterrand that was the bedrock of the German-French axis within the European Union and which enabled the swift reunification of Germany. It also that which made it difficult for him to establish an effective relationship with the more ideologically-motivated Margaret Thatcher.

But applied to the mundane business of party finances - quintessentially an area of rules - it proved disastrous. Yet from the start of this scandal, Mr Kohl has seemed at a loss to understand that he too was meant to abide by them.

In a disastrous television interview following his admission that he had used undisclosed contributions, Mr Kohl sought to justify himself on the grounds that the funds were needed to strengthen his party's standing among the East German electorate.

In refusing to reveal the identity of his benefactors, he claims he gave his word not to do so. People, once again, come first. But unfortunately, in this case, the philosophy conflicts with the law.

Yesterday's ultimatum from his successor was more than just a shrewd political manoeuvre - it was also an attempt to make him realise that the pragmatism on which he built his career has limits.

His reaction suggests that he remains heedless, and that the tragedy of Helmut Kohl may not have reached its final act.

fields.headline: A parent's directory
fields.standfirst: Joanna Moorhead picks the best sites for parents
fields.trailText:
Conception and pregnancy advice
If you have worries about your fertility, try the website at ReproMED, run by the Centre for Reproductive Medicine in Bristol. Conception and pregnancy advice
If you have worries about your fertility, try the website at ReproMED, run by the Centre for Reproductive Medicine in Bristol. It's invaluable as a first stop on the road to finding out what, if anything, might be wrong. Go to Fertility Information on the homepage to test your fertility awareness and find information on topics from egg donation to fertility options for the over-40s. The site also includes the Infertility Patients Directory, a useful next-stage tool.

If you want to maximise your chances of conceiving naturally, try FertilityUK, a natural family-planning site. It's a back-up to properly taught fertility awareness, and urges that you get individual training in how to diagnose your fertile days, but the basic information is all here. You can even download a blank chart to help you check the relevant symptoms that pinpoint ovulation. If you're already embroiled in, or about to become embroiled in, the assisted conception maze, you'll get loads of help from the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority, which goes through the practical and legal issues behind treatment and lists the clinics offering different treatments.

The Women's Health Information pages are excellent for information on conditions related to pregnancy and fertility. If your doctor or midwife throws out a name and you want to find out more, you probably will here. For example, if you're told you're one of the 15% of women who has a retroverted uterus, this site will show you a cross-section of what it looks like.

Finally, if you're pregnant, or just easily moved, go to First 9 Months. You'll love it.

Information sharing with other parents
Babyworld is a friendly magazine-format website with lots of chatty information about pregnancy as well as life after birth. Articles currently trailed on the front page include an excellent piece about the causes of choking in young children and how to avoid them. Pregnant users are invited to start their own pregnancy diary, which they can put online. Enter your due date, and the site comes up with facts on what's going on inside your body right now. Best of all are the notes posted up by other users giving useful tips - for example, apparently you can get McCalls patterns for maternity wear and baby outfits on special offer, two for £5, until January 22.

Set up by a mother for other mothers (and fathers), UKparents describes itself as "a virtual coffee morning". And it's true - browse there for a few minutes and chances are you'll find a soulmate. Whether you hanker after talking to other parents who are in the forces, or other mothers who are themselves motherless, this is the site to meet them. Need to chat to someone else with a bossy baby like yours? Want to swap stories with another parent who's got a big age gap between kids? Drop in here.

Children's health, parenting issues, childcare and more
ParentTime
Subtitled Your Personal Parenting and Pregnancy Advisor, this is an American site with information ranging from hot topics of the moment (articles on the new flu and how to avoid it) to a vast baby medical encyclopedia. Possibly best to steer clear of the "What's my baby got?" self-diagnosis section if you're prone to panic - when I told it my baby had abdominal pain, vomiting and no appetite it came up with pneumonia and lead poisoning. Colour-coded pages are a big help in negotiating the site, and for information on toddler behaviour it's excellent.

If it's help with older children you're after, don't be put off browsing the pages of The Site when you're welcomed to "the guide to surviving and enjoying life in the 90s". Fortunately, the information is as relevant to the noughts as to the nineties, and is written to appeal to the teenager you've all but given up on. Send her here if she wants to be virtually understood, and use the comprehensive list of organisations and contacts yourself to deal with almost anything family life can throw at you.

Need a nanny? Want to know how to invest your baby's christening cheques? Try nannyjob.co.uk and the Motley Fool. The first gives information on childcare and the chance to search would-be caregivers' CVs, the second gives easy-to-understand, even entertaining, information on personal finance.

Help with relationships
The Relate website can point you in the direction of your nearest centre if you think relationship guidance counselling could help, but it isn't in itself a source of practical information.

Not so divorce.co.uk, which explains divorce in a straightforward and easy-to-digest way. Relationship specialists Janet Reibstein and Jeannette Josse give lots of information on how to limit the damage, and there's an excellent section on what divorce is like from a child's viewpoint.

What to do, where to go
Parents Online has pages and pages on activities, from making a millennium time capsule to how to do leaf printing. You can also download pages from Letts educational books, a boon for quiet days in the school holidays when you realise you haven't done anything remotely improving with them for ages.

Kidsnet lists places to go. It bills itself as "the family guide to the best days out all over the UK", but displays a southeast bias. Good if you live in that area, though.

More comprehensive is VisitBritain - you can search for places to go by area.

Help with buying books
Ever gone into a bookshop with your child and been baffled by the range of titles on offer? It won't happen next time if you print out a relevant book list from the Book Trust site - lists run from first baby books through reluctant readers to teenage fiction.

For a bit of peace (and fun for the kids)
Children's entertainment is a hugely well-developed area of the internet. The problem isn't finding quality sites, it's deciding which quality site to opt for. Because of the nature of kids' entertainment, the US sites are as relevant as the UK ones - and there are lots of both. But if you thought the internet for kids would mean hours of them staring into a screen, think again. You can use the net to download and print out all sorts of fun and educational worksheets and exercises to do around the kitchen table. It's a godsend when you need something to do and don't fancy traipsing down to Woolworth's first - in fact, you may never need to buy another colouring book again. The BBC website comes up trumps with things to do for kids. At www.bbc.co.uk/littlekids/colouring/ you can print out pictures of all your children's favourite TV characters to colour in, and at www.bbc.co.uk/cbbc/write/ there's a brilliant page at which your budding young author can read the beginning of a story by a children's author, and then finish it and send it in.

Enchanted Learning is a US site with masses of craft ideas - I printed out a three-page step-by-step guide to how to make a Valentine's Day pop-up card, and my seven-year-old is working feverishly on it now.

Of the plethora of other excellent sites, the US Women.com section on family play has a brilliant search facility. You enter your child's age range, interests and whether you want to play inside or out, and it comes up with a list of game ideas.

Younger kids will enjoy funschool.com, which has lots of well-designed, easy-to-play games.

Education issues
Schools Online is a site still being developed which offers information on schools throughout Britain. From the end of this year, when every school in the country will be listed with an in-depth profile, it will be an invaluable tool for parents thinking of relocating - as well as all you need to know about a particular school and the chance to look at an aerial photo of it, you'll be able to read a detailed neighbourhood profile of the surrounding area.

Ofsted carries inspection reports for 24,000 schools in England, although there is a delay between general publication and posting on the site.

Need to understand the national curriculum or have a query about the way your school is governed? The DfEE parent centre features many topics, from what to do if your child doesn't get into your chosen school to how to get the most out of parents' evening.

For help with choosing a holiday
A bit of a gap in the market here - I've been unable to find a decent website devoted to the not inconsiderable needs faced by parents trying to find a summer holiday. families.co.uk is developing pages on family holidays, and its family skiing pages, which are up and running, suggest it's getting the formula right: it includes the top-10 resorts for families, plus relevant operators. If it's an activity holiday you're after, you'll fare better at the British Activity Holiday Association - a good starting point for whole-family or kids-only breaks.

fields.headline: The diligent pupil
fields.trailText: The question: Examine Jean Piaget's contribution to the scientific understanding of child development.
fields.body:
The question: Examine Jean Piaget's contribution to the scientific understanding of child development.

The research method: Averagely diligent. Ask Jeeves, at www.ask.com, purports to trawl the web in response to questions in plain English, but asking "Where can I learn about the child psychologist Jean Piaget?" took us to sites offering advice on buying children's shoes. Leading search engine Excite fared somewhat better, pointing to two reliable-looking sites at universities in Alberta and Washington DC, which proved sufficient for the basic theory. A message posted on Student-UK.com - where school and college students swap work tips and chat-up lines - brought a friendly response within hours recommending that "egocentrism is a good one to focus on - go to the cognitive science page at Arizona uni - I think that's where I copied most of my stuff from!" Armed with this information and assistance from the Jean Piaget Society webpage (www.piaget.org), we fleshed out an essay and handed it in.

Essay extract: "Jean Piaget posited that children progress through four stages and they all do so in the same order. The sensorimotor period lasts from birth to two years old... It is possible to make several criticisms of the work of Piaget... he did not consider how the social world of the child might affect its development... but his work is still a very useful guide for understanding how children develop."

The verdict: "It's a mixture of good information in some places and misinformation in others," said Chrissie Lawler, course leader in psychology at Park College in Eastbourne. "Its language varies, giving the impression of a capable student, but there is the odd glimpse of a pupil who struggles a little that makes me suspicious that the candidate did not produce this by him or herself. I would consider it fine as a piece of personal note-taking."

The grade: C

fields.headline: The lazy teenager
fields.trailText: The question: Imagery is important in Macbeth. In what ways is it used?
fields.body:
The question: Imagery is important in Macbeth. In what ways is it used?

The research method: Somewhat plagiaristic. The meat of our answer to this timeless classic was downloaded free from GCSE World (www.gcseworld.cjb.net), where it had been posted by an anonymous student. We reproduced it verbatim, spelling errors, unsubstantiated assertions and all.

Essay extract: "In all Shakespeare's plays he uses many forms of imagery. Imagery, the art of making images, the products of imagination... the imagery of clothing portrays that Macbeth is seeking to hide his 'disgraceful self' from his eyes and others... The second form used to add to the atmosphere, the imagery of darkness... Within the whole drama, the sun seems to shine only twice... Shakespeare uses the imagery of blood to represent treason, guilt, murder and death... we see the imagery of blood change from honor to treachery and then to guilt... this essay weighs [sic] blood to be the most important imagery of Macbeth."

The verdict: Geoff Barton, deputy head at Thurston Community College, Suffolk and author of several English textbooks, was unimpressed. "It's an odd mixture of windy rhetoric and textual detail," he says. "The opening is pretty awful, with its pretentious non-sentence about imagery being the art of making images - I hope none of my students ever quacks that kind of guff. I worry about the expression, which smacks of someone pontificating without detailed knowledge of the text, perhaps even churning out second-hand opinions from critical works. If a student of mine wrote this, I'd say, get on and answer the question. I'd suspect plagiarism; it's hard to grade because it's so inconsistent - some moments of textual insight scattered among grand generalisations. I'd probably give it a C+ but add an ominous 'See me' in red ink at the end."

The grade: C+

fields.headline: Shady grades
fields.standfirst: The net - a wonderful investment for your child's education. But what does it actually offer them?  Oliver Burkeman  writes up three cyber-essays and gets his efforts marked by teachers
fields.trailText: The net - a wonderful investment for your child's education. But what does it actually offer them? Oliver Burkeman writes up three cyber-essays and gets his efforts marked by teachers
fields.body:
Some people would say - many people, indeed, already have said - that what Kenny Sahr does ought to be illegal. Like many a thrustingly ambitious internet entrepreneur, Sahr is a rebellious twentysomething who's grown rich by thinking against the grain. Unlike most of the others, though, he's done it in a supremely controversial manner: by offering schoolchildren pre-prepared answers to their homework assignments.

At his website, SchoolSucks.com - motto: "download your workload" - overworked pupils can access over 3,800 essays posted on the site by other students, on subjects from history and English to film studies and botany. And he's not unique: another site, freeessay.com, provides links to 100 similar services, with names like Essays Galore and Evil House of Cheat, a handful of which will even write essays to order for a fee of around £15 per page.

Sahr, 28, prefers to think of himself less as the cheater's friend than as an educational revolutionary. "Most of the net content for teenagers is fed to them by adults with teaspoons, and I know that when I was a teenager I sure didn't like being fed anything by adults," Sahr says, speaking from his home in Israel where, by his own admission, the advertising revenues from SchoolSucks allow him "to get up at 12 every day and head for the beach". His site, he argues, permits pupils to communicate with each other, rather than being talked down to; he insists that the essays are only intended as a starting point, and that no student in their right mind would turn one in as their own. "Most of the papers are awful, which is reflective of the end product of the work of teachers," he says. "And if there are any teachers out there giving these papers good grades, that makes me even more scared about our school systems."

SchoolSucks epitomises some of the manifold contradictions of the internet as a homework tool. You may have purchased your PC and connected it to the web in order to provide your children with an unparalleled educational resource - but even when they're not downloading hardcore pornography or learning how to make pipe bombs, the homework-burdened pupil faces a myriad of hazards online. There are all too many temptations to cheat, and, even for the most conscientious students, often few clues to distinguish the reliable information from the nonsense.

There are one or two rules of thumb, though. "At a very simplistic level, if the publisher of the site has a good reputation - the BBC, for example - then you know you're on fairly safe ground," says Jacquie Disney, director of the Parents Information Network, an organisation established to help parents use computers in their children's education.

"You should be aware of the fact that just because a site looks reputable, that's not necessarily a means of judging the content. Also, many parents don't realise that adverts are interspersed within the information; they don't look like the sort of adverts we're used to seeing. Site developers do need advertising to pay for sites, but parents need an awareness that the adverts are there and of where they might lead children."

But there was only one true way to put the net to the test. Using a variety of web-based research techniques - from the diligent to the blatantly plagiaristic - we concocted three GCSE-level essays, in history, English literature and psychology, and asked three teachers to mark them. One was prepared using reputable search engines and academic websites; one was largely borrowed from the work of another pupil who'd posted it on the web; and a third was custom-written for a £45 fee by a company in California. We thought we'd got the hang of this cyber-homework thing: the essays certainly looked pretty convincing to us. But then we handed them in...

The outright cheat

The lazy teenager

The diligent pupil

fields.headline: The outright cheat
fields.trailText: The question: Did the Cuban missile crisis change the relationship between the superpowers?
fields.body:
The question: Did the Cuban missile crisis change the relationship between the superpowers?

The research method: Abjectly fraudulent. Armed with a credit card we took advantage of the services of Junglepage (www.junglepage.com), a company in Irvine, California whose sales pitch runs: "We know you have a busy schedule - our full-time staff of expert writers will ensure you a well thought-out, well written essay for your research or school assignment." Two days later, bang on time, it arrived by email, accompanied by a somewhat disingenuous warning that "you must never turn in an assignment received from Junglepage. These papers are to be used for research purposes only... using one of our papers as your own is plagiarism." Not that they need worry: most pupils would feel uneasy about handing in Junglepage's work, which read as if it had been lifted from a basic and somewhat biased textbook, with the addition of countless spelling errors (including, inexcusably, the word "missile").

Essay extract: "The United States and Russia had different political systems. Each believed that theirs was the best... The Cuban Missile Crisis was a period in the United States history during October 1961. The Cuban Missile crisis taught the United States two things, one old, one new. The first, 'speak softly but carry a big stick.' The second was the best way to destroy a nation's ability to wage physical war is to wage economic war."

The verdict: "The information is accurate in parts, but it doesn't answer the question and seems lifted from other sources," said Paula Mountford, head of history at Huntington School in York. fields.headline: Have they got you mouse-trained?
fields.standfirst: Do your children think you're a steam-driven old has-been who's still too scared of the net to have any fun with it? Don't be put off, says  Maureen Freely - go online and family life won't be the same again
fields.trailText: Do your children think you're a steam-driven old has-been who's still too scared of the net to have any fun with it? Don't be put off, says Maureen Freely - go online and family life won't be the same again.
fields.body:
When I think back to my son Matthew's efforts to teach me to use the internet - this time last year - what I remember best is his tone of voice. It was the same strained, careful tone I take with him when trying to explain why it's not a great idea to wear a stained, wrinkled South Park T-shirt to a job interview, or why many people think it wise to check their account balance before withdrawing money from a hole in the wall.

He couldn't believe I didn't know what an icon was, or what you were supposed to do with this icon once you had deciphered it. He paused - was it to count to 10? - when I revealed that I did not know what a home page was, and when I expressed alarm about this hand that kept jumping up at me when I moved the cursor around it. He seemed to age 10 years with every question I asked him. In the end - I think it was just after I had asked him to explain what the two squares at the top labelled Back and Forward were for - his patience snapped.

"What is it with your generation? Why is this so hard for you to accept?" It took me back to 1972, when I said much the same thing to my mother during a conversation about Bob Dylan's singing voice in Lay Lady Lay.

A year later, he and his sister still insist that the internet is the main thing that divides my generation from theirs. "You're all so afraid of it," is how Matthew puts it. "You treat it like bone china, as if it's going to break if you press the wrong button. But even if you do press the wrong button, what's the big deal?"

He told me about the big deal his father had made a few months ago, after he found out that Matthew had been using his computer to go on the internet without his permission and - possibly because he had pressed the wrong button - crashed the hard disk. "He wouldn't let me anywhere near it after that. It was so frustrating because if he had, I could have fixed it."

Of course, when I ask where he acquired all his expert knowledge, he says he can't tell me. "It's intuitive, I guess. For people of my age, it's second nature."

He and his sister Emma tell me that the weirdest thing about people my age and the internet, is our reluctance to go off the beaten path. "You're always telling people how useful it is," is how Emma puts it. "Like, who cares?"

I do have an idea how exasperating I must be to them now that I have tried to explain a few internet functions to my mother and a number of her uncomprehending contemporaries. They get stuck inside riddles like: "Why is a search engine called a search engine when there is no engine?" If I treat the internet like bone china, they treat it like a hand grenade. When they click on an icon, they grimace as if they expect the screen to explode in their face. There are supposed to be so many people their age going online that in the US they've started calling them Silver Surfers. But I have yet to meet a single silver surfer who can get an email address right. The typical thing is for them to send an email and then ring right away to see if it's arrived. If it hasn't, they ask, "So where is it?".

To believe in cyberspace you have to get to know it as a child when you're still comfortable with magical thinking. When I ask Helen and Pandora, my 8- and 6-year-olds, if they understand how an email we've just written to their cousin got from us to Turkey in less than a second, their respond is: "Why shouldn't it?"

The point of the internet, according to them and my older kids, is just to have fun - leave the house without leaving the house, explore forbidden territory, play elaborate practical jokes on their friends. I can't say I agree. If I look back over the bookmarks I've accumulated during the past year, what I notice first is the good use I've made of it - and how it's changed my life. For example, I used to have a terrible time finding time to research. Also, I would have to leave home to do it, and this meant finding babysitters. Now I can order books and get into newspaper archives all over the world without leaving my office.

My office is a much quieter place because the phone isn't always ringing now that I communicate mostly by email. I have more free time at weekends because I do not have to go into town every Saturday, because I buy so much online. And if I have an anxiety about anything at all I use the internet to quell it.

My Damascus moment came late last winter when my eight-year-old woke me in the middle of the night with a fever and another symptom that made me worry that she had contracted meningitis. I was frightened enough to want to ring the doctor. At the same time I dreaded waking him for a false alarm. So instead I got on the internet and found the site for the Meningitis Research Foundation. This furnished me not just with lists of symptoms but also with photographs which answered all but one of my questions. It also gave me the number of a 24-hour hotline which I used to clear up the remaining question. It was the first time in 20 years of child-rearing that I was able to find out everything I needed to know about a disease without worrying that my doctor would think I was neurotic.

So I am very sorry, that the internet wasn't invented sooner. I really could have used sites like this when I was starting out and knew nothing. It would have done a lot to mitigate my sense of isolation. I moved house a great deal when Matthew and Emma were little and often went for months before I was able to track down people in my new area with children the same age. It took longer still to make friends. But if you know how to play the internet, you can become part of a parent network almost overnight.

By exchanging emails, you can work out which are most likely to laugh at your jokes and which most likely to bristle at them. As vetting techniques go, this seems a lot better to me than four months of stiff coffee mornings and abominable playdates.

That said, my old social networks have a lot in common with the new networks that have opened up to me on the internet. In fact, a lot of the new networks are old ones brought back to life. For example, I'm back in touch with a group of friends who did Latin American literature with me at university. We used to make life bearable during boring lectures by writing bad poems in Spanish, in which every other line contained the word paloma (dove). Now we've revived the game. As an antidote to boredom, it works better than ever. In the same way, I've been able to revive so many other friendships that had become dry and formal over the years, either because I'd moved, or was too tired by the time I'd put the children to bed to call them, or so much time had passed by the time I got round to ringing that I had nothing to say to them. Thanks to email, I can talk to them at length, and everyday, about absolutely nothing.

The best thing is that I can engage in all this fluff without anyone in my family having the faintest suspicion that I am not in the middle of something deadeningly useful. If they thought I was typing for my own amusement, they would, I am sure, find a reason to interrupt. But because I can type the most amazing things while still looking grimly maternal, they leave me to it. What's the internet done for me? It's given me my life back.

fields.headline: The world@war
fields.standfirst:
Continuing the Guardian series on electronic life, John Vidal hears how dictators, democracies and transnational capitalism are all vulnerable to global subversive coalitions using the internet
Get the most out of the net with Guardian Unlimited's guide to Life online
fields.trailText: Continuing the Guardian series on electronic life, John Vidal hears how dictators, democracies and transnational capitalism are all vulnerable to global subversive coalitions using the internet.
fields.body:
We are at war. Not the sort that pits army against army, that sheds blood, destroys economies and bankrupts governments, but what is being called by the US military "social netwars". Little noticed and less analysed, they are being taken seriously as the possible style of future conflicts. Already they are beginning to shape the new international and national political agendas.

In a series of papers commissioned by the world's most powerful army, the Rand Institute - a leading US government-funded think tank with close links to the White House - has argued that the information revolution now sweeping through most countries is migrating power away from nation states towards new non-governmental alliances and networks of civil organisations. The implications for the way societies develop and the foreign policy of governments may be huge, say the authors, and the threat to established, but particularly authoritarian, regimes may be significant.

"Netwar refers to information-related conflict at a grand level between nations or societies," says John Arquilla, one of the report's authors. "It means trying to disrupt or damage what a target population knows, or thinks it knows, about itself and the world around it. A social netwar may focus on changing public or elite opinion, or both... It may involve diplomacy, propaganda and psychological campaigns, battles for public opinion and for media access and coverage."

The tone is militaristic, and the report includes the activities of terrorists, criminals and militias, all of whom are using the latest communications to operate, but the broad analysis of the new battle lines between entrenched government and social activism is pretty close to what many in non-governmental organisations are saying.

The past 50 years have seen the rise and rise of two new major forces on the world stage: the non-governmental group and the media. The power of the two to change public perceptions is undisputed, but the electronic revolution is now able to bring them together in ways that were inconceivable just a decade ago. The globalisation of capital, business and governanace is being matched by the globalisation of opposition.

Huge networks of public interest, environment, human rights, consumer development, religious and umbrella civil society groups, drawing in local, national and international organisations, are beginning to emerge. For the first time they are able to respond immediately to international events, counter state propaganda or bring concerted pressure to bear on governments, companies or international bodies.

The most recent netwar was the Seattle world trade talks, where hundreds of diverse groups - often not even present in the city - massively opposed an organisation which very few people in the world had ever heard of, let alone thought about. Through a concerted "information" campaign and public protest, they raised a global debate questioning the very legitimacy of the World Trade Organisation.

They set an agenda of public disquiet which shocked many western governments and strengthened the arguments of many poor countries who had been prepared to be sidelined.

Opposition to the multilateral agreement on investment (MAI), an OECD initiative that sought to rewrite the rules of international investment, is another example of recent netwar. A coalition of several hundred groups sowed confusion and outflanked the governments by picking holes in the arguments, alerting interest groups and demanding accountability.

Other netwar arenas include the global grassroots campaign against world debt, started by Jubilee 2000 but picked up across the world; the massive campaign against landmines - the first netwar, the authors note, to have won a Nobel prize; and the international opposition to genetically modified foods.

All the issues have very quickly moved on to the international agenda in the past few years, taking governments and industries by surprise. All three have forced climbdowns, new laws and safeguards and caused governments deep embarrassment. The authors anticipate a new global peace and disarmament movement arising "from a grand alliance among diverse NGO and other civil society actors attuned to netwar".

It is not just governments at risk. Corporations, especially in contentious areas such as oil, mining, banking, chemicals and new biological technologies, are all liable to be "hit" - and can do very little to counter the threats posed.

The social netwar may also be a fundamental threat to capitalism and neo-liberal economies, the US army has been warned. "A new generation of revolutionaries, radicals and activists are beginning to create information-age ideologies in which identities and loyalties may shift from the nation state to the transnational level of global civic society. New kinds of actors, such as anarchistic and nihilistic leagues of computer-hacking 'cyboteurs', may also partake of netwar".

The US military, like the British police, has always tended to overstate the case to further its own agendas, but the difficulty they face countering coordinated opposition coming at them from many direct ions is real. "Old hierarchies have a difficult time fighting networks," says the report. "The Zapatista movement in Mexico, with its legions of supporters and sympathisers among local and transnational NGOs, shows that social netwar can put a democratising autocracy on the defensive and pressure it to continue adopting reforms."

The report's authors believe that it takes networks to fight networks. "Governments will have to adopt designs and strategies like those of their adversaries... they must draw on the same principles and [adopt] a willingness to innovate doctrinally." And they suggest that the scenes of future social netwars could include Cuba, Nigeria, Russia and Saudi Arabia.

Cuban grassroots groups are connecting to outside NGOs. What could emerge before long are the conditions for a fully-fledged social netwar if Cuba becomes more open. In Saudi, the ruling family keeps tight control, but an underground exists and people's access to modern telecommunications is improving. "Opportunities may grow for an indigenous dissident movement to emerge and gain links to outside fundamentalist and even secular democratic forces," says the report. Even a country as closed as Burma may, say the authors, be vulnerable to a social netwar. "Free Burma" exile groups have organised into a network to promote the downfall of the junta and to support internal pro-democracy activists. The authors predict that authoritarian regimes may try to harass, control, arrest and expel activists, and regulate the formation and behaviour of NGOs through judicial methods, even creating "dummy NGOs".

They do not include countries like the US and Britain, which are well-advanced in trying to counter environmental and other activism through all these methods.

"Social netwar is fundamentally anti-establishment," say the authors. "It may be used by leftists, rightists or anyone else with an anti-establishment agenda." It is, they conclude, "more likely to be used against states rather than by them".

How the net was tightened

Seattle: The World Trade Organisation meeting in Seattle was the subject of one of the most intense social netwars yet. Trade unions, indigenous peoples, environmental, human rights, protest, consumer and new democracy groups targeted the ministerial meeting last month, creating an international debate that questioned the legitimacy of the body that oversees world trade. Most worrying to governments was the undermining of one of the cornerstones of free trade.

Zapatistas: Recognised as the first netwar. Within hours of the January 1994 armed uprising by revolutionaries in the desperately poor Mexican state of Chiapas, local, national and international support groups were being set up to counter the government's propaganda war and further the cause of the rebellion. The government was put on the back foot, tried to respond, but has been forced to make substantial reforms.

Landmines: The international campaign to ban landmines was a social netwar that rocked governments and military establishments. A populist peace movement, led by NGOs, grouped together to force governments to change their military policies. They succeeded in getting an international convention to ban landmines (although not all countries signed up) and won, in the process, a Nobel prize.
