fields.headline: Praise indeed
fields.standfirst: As a group of workers, they are so  often attacked in headlines about poor  practice. But a new national awards  scheme will at last start to spread the  good news. David Brindle reports
fields.trailText: As a group of workers, they are so often attacked in headlines about poor practice. But a new national awards scheme will at last start to spread the good news. David Brindle reports.
fields.body:
About time too, some may say. Nevertheless, there has been a broad welcome for the government's initiative in launching the annual social care awards, the first of which will be presented today.

Unlike more glamorous professions, or those better placed to attract sponsorship, social care has not had many opportunities to pat itself on the back. And recent events on the national stage have reawakened concern in the statutory social services that ministers may be more interested in highlighting poor practice than in lauding good.

John Hutton, social care minister, is anxious to set the record straight on this. "We want to tell the whole story - the good as well as the bad," he says. "I hope these awards will allow us to do what we have always said we would do, which is to pay tribute to the outstanding work which many people in social care up and down the country do day in, day out."

The awards are by no means limited to the statutory sector, however. Of 24 shortlisted projects in nine categories, 12 are voluntary sector led and one is from the private sector. Indeed, a common theme of many of the most impressive schemes is truly joined up working, just as the government prescribes.

Take the project in the name of Charnwood borough council, Leicestershire, whereby the authority's housing department has appointed a specialist occupational therapist, funded jointly with social services and the NHS, to advise directly on provision for people with particular needs. Although she took up the post only last March, Helen Blakeman can already see attitudes shifting among the housing professionals.

"I have actually watched the change in people who have never thought about disability before," she says. "Our surveyors go out and come back and say: 'By the way, Helen, that house has got a low level shower in it.'"

Or take the project attributed to Nottingham social services, but in fact a joint venture with local police, that has drawn in a raft of charities and street-based organisations to mount a remarkably succcessful drive against juvenile prostitution. No fewer than 89 girls and 36 boys, aged 12-19, have been identified as being involved in prostitution. More than 85% have been steered away from the criminal justice system and a majority have changed their lifestyles.

"Our emphasis now is on moving into preventive work," says Sue Gregory, lead officer for the scheme and service manager for child protection with Nottingham city council. "Children will always be vulnerable and there will always be adults who prey on them."

Representatives of the short listed projects - whittled down from more than 700 initial expressions of interest - will today attend a reception and lunch at Lancaster House in London. One winner in each category will receive £5,000 and an overall winner will get an additional £5,000, the money to be invested in further service development.

The story will not end there, however. A key part of the awards scheme is to spread the good practice being acclaimed, so there will be a special conference in the early spring, supported by the Guardian, at which the winners will present their work to social care profession als from across England. Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, says: "We want people to come and celebrate the success of these projects; to listen, discuss and learn from them."

At least one project would find no problem with that. Full Body and the Voice, a West Yorkshire theatre group comprising 10 performers with learning disabilities, is well used to going on the road with its drama workshops and shows. It has just returned from France.

Formed a year ago, with training and employment money from the European social fund, the group performs without using the spoken word. "Because it's a form of theatre governed by the group's abilities, it's very accessible, very visual, very sensory," says Jon Palmer, artistic director. "The arts are such an appropriate environment for people with learning disabilities to express themselves."

The group's success has brought considerable reflected glory for its backers, notably the local branch of learning disability charity Mencap and Kirklees council, which put in £20,000 start-up funding. "I think," says Palmer, "that we have already manoeuvred ourselves into a position where other people need us as much as we need them."

The awards shortlist

 Promoting independence

The Clive Project, Oxford: providing specialist support for younger people with dementia and their families.

Drugs and Homeless Initiative, Bath: helping people with problems of drug misuse and homelessness to overcome addiction through outreach work and a care programme.

The Young People's Centre, Brighton : enabling young people to design and operate a snack bar, learning about food preparation and running a business.

 Improving protection

Children's services inspectors, London: joint task force has developed common standards, now widely adopted in the capital and by several other local authorities, for assessing suitability of applicants seeking to open new children's provision.

Sunderland social services: a scheme providing extra community support and care for people with severe mental illness, beyond the usual nine-to-five service.

 Cross boundary working

Charnwood borough council: appointment of occupational therapist to advise housing department on appropriate housing and living aids for people with disabilities and special needs.

Nottingham social services: establishment of multi-agency team to divert young people from prostitution.

Sandwell social services: a project to promote integrated working in primary care, delivering fast and responsive services tailored to individual needs.

 Promoting social inclusion

Full Body and the Voice: Huddersfield based theatre company of performers with learning disabilities, touring with shows, leading drama workshops and providing professional training for staff in the arts and care sectors.

Old Trafford Family Centre, Manchester: a safe community centre providing day care, play sessions and a literacy scheme in an inner-city area.

 Increasing life chances

Brighton Housing Trust: a project run by recovering drug addicts and alcoholics, aimed at engaging with people with drug and drink problems whom other services cannot reach.

Link Mental Health, north Devon: providing help and services, ranging from education to healthy living advice, for people with mental health problems.

The Riverwood Project, London: a scheme devised by charity Mencap to help people with learning disabilities into employment, based on the idea of making furniture from driftwood washed up by the Thames.

 Carers' schemes

Careshare, Gloucestershire: providing home based respite care for carers of people with physical disabilities and dementia in the south Cotswolds.

Esmi Weekend Day Centre, Cheshire: bridging the weekend gap in support and entertainment for people with Alzheimer's disease and their carers.

Wilf Ward Family Trust, York: offering help for people with learning disabilities and their carers.

 Family placement schemes

Bristol social services: a scheme giving deaf children the chance to spend time away from their families with deaf carers, who share their culture and sign language.

Parents for Children: London based group finding adoptive or foster families for children with multiple difficulties, who have often been badly abused.

 User participation

Herefordshire social services: the St Owen's centre student council, run by and for people with learning disabilities, with the help of a facilitator.

Wiltshire social services: a project giving children and young people in care the opportunity to share their experiences with decision makers through a performance they write, direct and act.

Total care management: a private sector initiative, based in Lancashire, to give people with mental health needs the chance to speak out about services provided for them.

 Consultation with service users

Asian Disability Network, Bradford: working at the grass roots to make disability services more accessible for Asian families.

Kensington and Chelsea social services: a project by the dementia team to "map" patterns of care in residential homes over a full working day, gauging how each resident fares and how services could improve.

fields.headline: Keeping it clean
fields.standfirst: Michael Meacher on the air we breathe
fields.trailText: Michael Meacher on the air we breathe.
fields.body:
There was a considerable reduction in 1998 in the average number of days when urban air pollution levels were above the health-based standards. The initial indications are that 1999 will be the second best year on record for urban air quality, although weather conditions led to an increase in ozone episodes caused by pollution from mainland Europe.

Air pollution in the UK is responsible for bringing forward the deaths of between 12,000 and 24,000 people each year, as well as many hospital admissions and considerable illness and discomfort. It can bring on asthma attacks among Britain's 3 million sufferers.

Air pollution hits hardest the most vulnerable. It also tends to be worse in heavily congested inner city areas, where it exacerbates a poorer quality of life and increases social deprivation. But it even affects healthy adults.

Today, we publish our new air quality strategy. It sets tougher objectives for five pollutants: benzene and 1,3-butadiene, which are carcinogens; carbon monoxide and nitrogen dioxide, which exacerbate heart and lung problems; and lead, which is thought to damage children's brains. The objectives for sulphur dioxide and ozone are unchanged.

We have had to introduce, for the time being, a less stringent objective for the small particles which come from exhausts, primarily from diesel vehicles. I am disappointed, because there is no doubt that these are serious pollutants with potentially significant impacts.

But, in effect, we had no choice. The original strategy objective for particles was set on the basis of the best available knowledge at the time. It is now clear that this objective is quite simply not achievable, at least in the short term. This is in part due to pollution from mainland Europe. Even if we took every single vehicle off the road, we could not guarantee that the objective would be met.

I have decided that, in the short-term, the objective should be simply to meet EU standards. But this is a staging post, not the final outcome. So we are going now to consider further the health effects of particles, the costs and benefits of reducing them. This will allow us to consider a new objective for particles towards the end of the year.

This is a national strategy, but much of the delivery will be at local level. Local authorities are assessing local air quality and drawing up plans to tackle local air pollution hotspots, through traffic management schemes, low emission zones and if necessary, more radical schemes, such as pedestrianisation.

 Michael Meacher is the environment minister.

fields.headline: No end to pain
fields.standfirst: Dee Rose on a woman who 'won' a review of  her treatment - but is still suffering
fields.trailText: Dee Rose on a woman who 'won' a review of her treatment - but is still suffering.
fields.body:
Nicole couldn't believe her ears. She had telephoned her consultant's secretary to find out about her progress on the surgical waiting list. Although at her last consultation she had been told that she would be sent a date in a month, she waited until seven weeks had passed before telephoning. After all, she didn't want to be diagnosed a nuisance.

"Mr X, your consultant, retired yesterday," she was told. Yes, he had given the requisite three months' notice. Yes, he was still working privately. No, he had not made arrangements for someone else to take over her care. Why hadn't they told her? What would happen now?

Although Nicole's hospital is a renowned London teaching hospital, it does not have another consultant who performs the spinal surgery she was awaiting. Moreover, she was told that his replacement would probably not perform spinal surgery and, in any event, would not take up his post for about five months. "Your best bet would be to get your GP to refer you somewhere else," Nicole was told. "Where would you suggest?" she asked. Nicole discounted the only suggestion she was given - to contact her now ex-consultant through his private secretary for some advice.

She decided to make a formal complaint. She hoped that this might help in obtaining the treatment her ex-consultant had originally deemed "urgent" when she was placed on his waiting list. She also wanted to highlight the unacceptability of what had happened to her.

She received a formal reply from the chief executive of the hospital trust. It was obvious that he had read the newspapers and seen the TV exposés - the ones that say patients want apologies and want acknowledgement of wrongdoings."

Yes, it was quite nice for Nicole to receive an apology, a validation of her argument. But what she really needed was action to remedy the situation. She needs treatment. Her physical problem completely compromises her quality of life; she has been unable to work for 14 months, has no social life and is totally dependent on family and friends for her day-to-day survival.

The chief executive's response to Nicole's complaint included a plan for her to be reviewed by a senior orthopaedic consultant three-and-a-half months later.

She received no response to her question about what the purpose was of a review by someone who did not perform spinal surgery. Did it indicate a questioning of her original consultant's clinical judgment? If such a review were necessary, why must she wait so long for it?

Finally, the time had dragged by. The consultant chosen to review Nicole's case was a knee specialist. He told Nicole that she needed to be seen by someone who specialises in her problem. Surely this should have been obvious from her notes? Undoubtedly, some other poor patient with a knee problem has had their appointment delayed while the consultant and his registrar took time to tell her that. Nicole was told that they would refer her to another hospital and ask the specialist there to see her as quickly as possible: a month on and she has not yet received an appointment letter.

N ot surprisingly, Nicole was dissatisfied. So she asked for an independent review, which is the next stage of the complaints procedure. For this, a convenor - employed by the hospital against which she is complaining - reviews her case with a lay person, who is appointed by the health authority. Together, they decide whether her case merits an independent review, and, if so, convene a committee to consider the complaint.

Nicole received the convenor's response today. Her complaints are justified.

Her delight was short-lived. The letter states that the action necessary to remedy matters is not within the powers of the review process. Hence, there is no point in having an independent review.

Without any remedy, this is a meaningless victory. Sure, Nicole is pleased that significant recommendations have been made to ensure that no one is "unfairly condemned", as the convenor put it, to her situation again.

But what about the treatment she needs? What point is there in having a complaints procedure that has no power to take the action that it rightly identifies would rectify a situation?

fields.headline: History in the breaking
fields.standfirst: The west has often been accused of ignoring diseases that  blight poorer nations, but a powerful coalition of interests is  showing the way forward for eradication programmes.  Malcolm Deanon the all-out bid to kill off elephantiasis
fields.trailText: The west has often been accused of ignoring diseases that blight poorer nations, but a powerful coalition of interests is showing the way forward for eradication programmes. Malcolm Deanon the all-out bid to kill off elephantiasis.
fields.body:
How do you eradicate a disease? Just two years ago, a joint campaign to eliminate elephantiasis, the grossly disfiguring disease which is the second leading cause of permanent disability worldwide, was announced by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and SmithKline Beecham (SB), the multinational pharmaceutical company. Long since eradicated from affluent countries, the infection affects more than 120 million people in 80 poor tropical states, with another billion people at risk. Big foot - or big leg, as it is known in many states - produces huge swellings in the arms, breasts and male genital organs too.

In the history of man, only one disease has ever been eradicated: smallpox in 1977. Earlier this month in Delhi, WHO launched its final push against polio. It hopes to have eliminated the disease, which has paralysed millions, by the end of this year. A third disease, guinea worm (the "fiery serpent"), is on the brink of extinction. Its victims pick up minute crustaceans from contaminated water that grow into thread-like worms slowly and painfully emerging through blisters on the skin.

The fourth target, elephantiasis - or lymphatic filariasis (LF) as it is medically known - sounds an easy enough task. Just two drugs, in tablet form, taken once a year for four or five years, would break the transmission. SB is donating up to 5 billion tablets in the next 20 years. The other is a generic drug, DEC, which costs less than $0.01 a tablet. It can't be used in Africa, but Merck, the US pharmaceutical company, has agreed to donate a substitute for that continent, ivermectin, which it is already donating by the million in its river blindness mectizan control programme.

If only it was simple. I have been following the people putting the programme together since it was first announced in 1998. Like previous eradication campaigns, it has been a bumpy ride. But tomorrow, at the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene in London, the key people in the campaign will be assembled to finally set out their jointly agreed global strategy for this fourth eradication target.

It is a daunting task. First is its scale. Smallpox began as a mass immunisation programme but quickly adopted a targeted approach, isolating victims and ensuring just those at risk from contact were vaccinated. Polio only involves vaccination of the under fives. Elephantiasis will need to treat both children and adults - not just the 120 million infected but also the 1 billion at risk.

These are among the poorest people in the world. Most are illiterate and many instinctively turn to soothsayers or witchdoctors, not western medicine, for what they perceive to be an affliction of an evil spirit or angry god. Unlike smallpox, it does not threaten the west. More complicated still, people are unaware they have the disease for several years. Until recently, there was only one way of checking: a blood test in the middle of the night - unpopular with health workers as well as communities, many of whom have no electricity.

The disease's complicated transmission process was first identified by a British general medical officer, Patrick Manson, serving in the Chinese imperial maritime customs service in the remote port of Amoy in 1877. Manson not only helped in a local Chinese hospital but became fascinated with the pathology of local diseases including elephantiasis. He discovered it was the blood-sucking mosquito which was spreading LF, winning him international aclaim as "the father of modern tropical medicine". It led to the identification of a succession of similar transmission cycles: malaria (1898), yellow fever (1900) and dengue (1903).

LF is caused by thread-like, parasitic filarial worms, which lodge in the lymphatic system, producing millions of immature microfilaria (minute larvae) that circulate in the blood, but only at night. Mosquitoes feed at night, ingest the larvae with the blood, and proceed to pass them on to new victims at a later feeding session. The new two-drug treatment programme would kill over 99%of the microfilaria within hours, thus breaking the transmission chain.

Even before the recent successful combined drug trials, elephantiasis had been identified as potentially eradicable. The International Task Force for Disease Eradication evaluated 94 infectious diseases and, in 1993, selected elephantiasis as one of only six that could be eliminated. There were three main reasons: humans were the only hosts; there was no multiplication of the parasite in the mosquito; the disease's poor transmission system.

In May 1997, the World Health Assembly passed a resolution making elimination of LF a public health priority. Later that year, Jan Leschly, SB chief executive, was at a celebration dinner in Washington, sitting next to former US president Jimmy Carter, who had his own foundation campaigning to eliminate diseases. Leschly, whose company had turned down an invitation to take part in London's Dome, was looking for a bigger millennium philanthropic project. He asked Carter if he had any ideas.

Next day, Carter called William Foege, the biggest name in global public health, who helped spearhead the smallpox, polio and guinea worm campaigns. Foege was at a scientific meeting of the mectizan programme in France, where news of the success of the first combined drug trial was circulating. There could not have been a more obvious project for SB: their drug was the key player. The single biggest act of corporate philanthropy was underway: a 20-year $1bn commitment from SB.

Pharmaceutical companies are currently under attack for the way they are run - driven by share prices, earnings ratios and high drug prices beyond the reach of developing nations. The critics make a powerful case, but so far as SB's philanthropic team are concerned, I have not met a more dedicated or impressive group of professionals. The delay in the launch of the elephantiasis programme has not been caused by SB, which has been straining to get going, but by the bureaucracy of WHO and its reorganisation. Reorganisation was needed, but in abolishing the old tropical disease control division, almost a year was lost.

Foege is unequivocal about future eradication programmes: they will only succeed if they can create large coalitions of international organisations, private pharmaceutical companies, voluntary groups and research institutes.

In the last two years the elephantiasis team has brought together just such a coalition: three international organisations (WHO, World Bank, Unicef); three private companies (SB, Merck and Amrad, Australia); three national aid agencies (UK, Japan, Italy), plus the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development; eight non-governmental organisations, including the Carter Centre; and nine academic and research organisations, including the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, which is hosting today's launch.

What is inspiring is the opportunity opening up to the tiny group of dedicated scientists, who doggedly continued with their research into what was the most unfashionable of diseases, and who now have a chance to launch pioneering eradication programmes. They have limped along on the smallest of grants, in some of the most inhospitable climates, with seemingly little chance of international recognition. At several points, the two biggest research institutions - CDC, the huge Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, and NIH, the National Institute for Health in Washington - came near to cutting off funding. Now all that has changed.

Most important of all are the people who it will help. I've met victims in Ghana, Haiti and India. They remain incredibly stoic. They've all suffered grievously: shame, stigma and extreme social exclusion.

The psychological consequences of the disease are horrendous: losing its victims jobs, preventing both men and women from marrying, causing severe social isolation through sexual dysfunction and the gross disfigurement of the limbs. Left untreated, the disease produces massive skin folds, fissures and a weeping cauliflower surface that produces a terrible odour.

I met young farmers in Haiti, unable to work during acute attacks, and seriously handicapped by the chronic condition.

Initially, she turned to a native herbal healer, who cut her swollen feet with razor blades to insert herbs, only making them worse. She left college and now sells maize, grown by her mother, at a road junction. But she is attending an elephantiasis clinic, where she has learned new techniques to control the swellings.

Just two years ago, a joint campaign to eliminate elephantiasis, the grossly disfiguring disease which is the second leading cause of permanent disability worldwide, was announced by the World Health Organisation (WHO) and SmithKline Beecham (SB), the multinational pharmaceutical company. Long since eradicated from affluent countries, the infection affects more than 120 million people in 80 poor tropical states, with another billion people at risk. Its victims pick up minute crustaceans from contaminated water that grow into thread-like worms slowly and painfully emerging through blisters on the skin. The fourth target, elephantiasis - or lymphatic filariasis (LF) as it is medically known - sounds an easy enough task. Just two drugs, in tablet form, taken once a year for four or five years, would break the transmission. SB is donating up to 5 billion tablets in the next 20 years. He discovered it was the blood-sucking mosquito which was spreading LF, winning him international aclaim as "the father of modern tropical medicine". LF is caused by thread-like, parasitic filarial worms, which lodge in the lymphatic system, producing millions of immature microfilaria (minute larvae) that circulate in the blood, but only at night. The International Task Force for Disease Eradication evaluated 94 infectious diseases and, in 1993, selected elephantiasis as one of only six that could be eliminated. There were three main reasons: humans were the only hosts; there was no multiplication of the parasite in the mosquito; the disease's poor transmission system. Later that year, Jan Leschly, SB chief executive, was at a celebration dinner in Washington, sitting next to former US president Jimmy Carter, who had his own foundation campaigning to eliminate diseases. fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Back in the 60s, there were many occasions during my time teaching drama in a London comprehensive when I'd have welcomed an effective sanction against all those pupils who'd come to the conclusion that reading Hamlet aloud was considerably less engaging than a bout of Sumo wrestling.

Nowadays, teachers labouring under the ever more insistent requirement to deliver academic results which will lift their schools up the league table have understandably responded by making more and more use of an ultimate sanction which was rarely, if ever, invoked during my teaching days: the decision that the troublemaker should be permanently excluded from school. In 1994, the number of such exclusions stood at 11,084. By 1997 this had increased to 12,678.

This escalating trend has led the social exclusion unit to take active steps to reduce school exclusions by a third by 2002, but this policy has been labelled colour-blind in that it takes no account of the disproportionate number of male Afro-Caribbean students who are currently excluded from school.

In a book to be published tomorrow, Race, Class And Gender In Exclusion From School (Falmer Press), Dr Cecile Wright, of Nottingham Trent University, produces figures to show that black pupils, who make up 9% of the school population, account for 19% of all exclusions. In some areas, Afro-Caribbean boys were up to 15 times more likely to be excluded from school than their white classmates.

Her research, carried out in five selected schools with varying proportions of African and Afro-Caribbean pupils, suggests that the reason for this imbalance lies in the white teachers' tendency to respond to misbehaviour by black children in a more aggressive manner than to similar conduct exhibited by non-black children. Even fellow pupils from other ethnic groups told her that they thought the treatment of their Afro-Caribbean classmates was "unequal and unfairly harsh".

Wright argues, on the basis of her interviews, that the teachers' aggression is prompted by their underlying belief that Afro-Caribbean pupils are not merely difficult but constitutionally "anti-authority". In such circumstances, she insists, conflict between white teachers and black pupils becomes inevitable.

 Laurie Taylor will be discussing racism and school exclusion with Dr Cecile Wright at 4pm today in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Enviromently plastered | Waste Capital of Britain
fields.body:
 Environment journalists seldom thank government and the NGOs and spend all their time making everyone jump through hoops. But once a year, in a moment of altruism, they invite their meat for a drink. So it was last week that Messrs Prescott, Meacher and Morley among government ministers, Lords de Ramsay and Melchett, the new head of English Nature, and almost everyone in the green NGO establishment descended on the Wig and Pen club in Fleet Street to exact their revenge.

It was, indeed, a terrible sight to see the bar bill veer towards £2,000 and so many serious policy analysts, strategists and activists utterly plastered and in each other's arms. Even worse were some of the hangovers the next morning, which might explain a slight pause late last week in the info-babble emanating from government departments, Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth, the RSPB, among others.

 If the department of the environment has recovered, perhaps someone could investigate what is happening in Flintshire, where Castle Cement proposes to spend £48m on a new toxic waste plant to secure that area of north Wales the title of Waste Capital of Britain. The intention is to burn tyres and other dangerous toxic materials, drawn from all over the Midlands and Lancashire, using a 350-foot chimney to disperse any pollution back over an area about 50 miles to the east.

The company, of course, says that no one will be adversely affected, but this is not impressing the people of Chester, just 11 miles away, or any of the nearby communities who have spent years on the receiving end of pollution of the worst order from different industries. With a supine Welsh Assembly, it may be up to Mr Prescott to call the application in as soon as possible.

 The influence Newcastle United football club has exerted on the city council over the years is staggering and so, too, has been the cynicism of the club's directors. Not content with trying to take over a central park to rebuild their football ground, the club now wants to wreck Waverdale Fields, the last green lung in the east of the city. Their plan for a footie "school of excellence" - which will benefit only themselves and a few lads who have no lack of places to play anyway - involves dozens of new football pitches being rolled out in a monolithic swathe over a superb area of grasslands and wildflower meadows, which are home to hundreds of species.

The city and the club say Waverdale is "run-down" and a "derelict former waste tip", when in fact it is an extraordinary industrial landscape extremely popular with the locals - not least because it is the centre of a culture of horseriding that stretches back generations. The £6m cost of the football fields will be borne mainly by the city council, or rather the taxpayers, but so hostile are the Toon Army and the council to critics that few people dare to raise the matter. Perhaps someone - Tony Blair, Nick Brown, Alan Milburn, or some other fawning New Labour MP who still thinks football is about goals and league tables? - should note that a poll done by the local LibDems suggests that two in three people asked about Waverdale are appalled at the club's plan and everyone feels that there has been little consultation.

 All is truly weird in the world of bananas, especially Fairtrade ones. Six weeks ago, before the Guardian backed the Fairtrade Foundation as its environmental charity of the year, all supermarkets were saying that Fairtrade - an alternative system which gives small producers a guaranteed price, cuts out middlemen and provides a bonus for social works - was a nice idea but that it was all far too complicated to bring bananas grown this way into Britain. Then, glory be, the Co-op last week shipped in two containerloads from Costa Rica and have been selling them since Monday in hundreds of its stores.

Not to be outdone, on Friday, Sainsbury's announced that it, too, would be selling fairly traded bananas, from the same Costa Rica cooperative, from the same date in 30 of its stores. Just like that. It's all a tremendous coincidence, says Sainsbury's, who rushed to import them via Holland. What bets that all supermarkets will be selling Fairtrade bananas within the year? Meanwhile, they're now in the shops after 10 years of trying to get them there, so let's buy them, and be glad a lot of very disadvantaged people will really benefit.

 How far have we come? The excellent Environment Health Journal records from its predecessor, the Sanitarian, that in British industrial towns in 1950, between 50 and 60% of available daylight and sunlight was usually obscured by the presence of smoke in the air. "The housewife finds cleaning, dusting and washing duties occupy far more of her time as compared to others."

webTitle: Sexual orientation: Everybody needs some body

fields.headline: Everybody needs some body
fields.standfirst: Until recently, most transsexuals were too scared to come out. But attitudes are changing and many are now standing up to the bigots and 'body fascists'. Adam James reports
fields.trailText: Until recently, most transsexuals were too scared to come out. But attitudes are changing and many are now standing up to the bigots and 'body fascists'. Adam James reports.
fields.body:
When Anne Ring was a man she had, for 20 years, enjoyed a pint with friends in her favourite pub. So, after coming out as a transsexual and walking into the pub for the first time dressed as a woman, she fully expected a few raised eyebrows. But she was totally taken aback when the landlady glared at her and ordered her never to set foot in her pub dressed as she was. Anne, 56, was forced to leave, feeling angry and humiliated.

Most "trans" people are all too familiar with such prejudice and bigotry. Some get petrol bombs through their letter boxes, others are attacked by gangs of thugs. Some find it impossible to get promotion at work, others cannot get a job at all.

Trans people - who, as opposed to transvestites, believe they have been born into the wrong body - have been cast as silent victims of such hatred, stereotyped as timid loners hiding from a hostile world.

Although support groups for UK trans people first appeared in the 1950s, and the most politically active subsequently allied with the gay movement, there was no distinct political voice for trans people. But, in 1992, this all changed when six men and women met at a London cafe to form Press for Change, trans people's first political campaigning organisation.

Since then, huge steps have been made in the fight against "body fascism". Dynamic activists such as Stephen Whittle, a Manchester lawyer, helped Press for Change to launch the first concerted campaign via the courts to fight discrimination against trans people.

After four years, the first important milestone was reached when the European court of justice ruled that discrimination against anyone who had undergone "gender reassignment" surgery contravened the 1975 sex discrimination act.

This victory opened up challenges to be made against discrimination in employment, and when, in 1998, airline pilot Kristina Sheffield won a case for unfair dismissal, it was followed by a string of similar victories.

Christine Burns, Press for Change vice-president, says such a step-up of campaigning activity represents trans people's willingness to become more vocal in resisting prejudice.

"When Press for Change started five years ago, it was regarded as being exceedingly brave even to come out as trans," she says. "You could count the names on one hand of those who had. People feared coming out would lead to further discrimination and trouble - such as someone turning up at your doorstep with malicious intent. But now more trans people are prepared to publicly challenge injustice."

Activists have tended to use the courts as a platform as opposed to direct action because, with only 5,000 UK trans people, it has been difficult to rally mass support.

Activists also readily admit that many still fear the consequences of becoming militant - such as appearing in court, where previous names are made public, and facing the ignominy of having their personal lives splashed on tabloid front pages.

Yet, in 1997, trans people united publicly for the first time when 50 protesters marched to Downing Street and handed over a 10,000-name petition protesting against Britain's law that their birth certificates cannot be altered once a person changes sex or has "gender reassignment" surgery.

"It represented tremendous progress to have got all these trans people on to the streets," says Burns. "Characteristically, trans people have been afraid of public attention."

In the same year, activists had their first direct confrontation with "body fascists".

Some neighbours of Stephen Whittle were trying to eject him and his family from the neighbourhood and had organised a "public meeting" in a pub to discuss how to get rid of them. But Whittle turned up at the pub accompanied by dozens of supportive neighbours, work colleagues, activists and a TV reporter.

"The bigots had moved on and were nowhere to be seen," Burns recalls. "So we decided not to waste the opportunity and had a jolly good party instead. We challenged unashamed prejudice head-on and we won."

Despite such progress, Britain remains one of four out of 39 Council of Europe countries which prohibit trans people's birth certificates from being changed. This stems from a 1970 decree of nullity case brought by Arthur Corbett, the heir of Lord Rowallen.

Corbett wanted to separate from his wife, the trans model April Ashley, and his family was desperate to avoid handing over any inheritance to her. The court ruled the marriage void because Ashley's birth certificate, which acts as proof of identity, stated that she was a man.

"In effect, the judgment means that, once a person has undergone gender reassignment, they no longer officially exist," says Burns. "The court's decision became the touchstone upon which virtually every aspect of our lives came to be judged. Whether it be claiming benefits or applying for insurance, trans people can end up in all sorts of difficulties if they do not give the name stated on their birth certificate."

Activists doggedly continue to press the government's interdepartmental working group on trans issues for the right to have their birth certificate changed.

And, while the court triumphs have done their bit to reverse discrimination, activists have found an unexpected, but powerful, ally in Coronation Street. Its own male-to-female trans character, Hayley Patterson, presents the first enduring positive image of a trans person to a mass audience and helps erode the idea of trans people as somehow shockingly aberrant.

Hayley's marriage and employment problems also mirror those that trans people face in real life, largely because a Press for Change member acts as a personal adviser to actress Julie Hesmondhalgh and the Street's scriptwriters.

Granada, the producer of the programme, had first planned to use Hayley as a character for just eight weeks. But such was her popularity that the contract was increased to two years.

"Let's not forget that 18 million people watch Coronation Street," says Burns. "The day-to-day experience of a trans person's life is coming into the living-room of all these viewers, and Hayley's popularity flies in the face of some who even thought that the life of a trans person should not be shown until after 9pm."

Meanwhile, Anne is well into her life as a woman. She planned to take the pub which barred her to court for contravening the sex discrimination act. But, last October, the landlady apologised and handed Anne £1,000 compensation in an out-of-court settlement.

"It seems the law was on my side," said Anne. "But I did want the case to go to court to reveal the kind of suffering and prejudice people like me still have to go through."

It is such resistance which symbolises trans people's stronger united voice. As Whittle says: "Being trans has been a privilege because I have met wonderful people and have done wonderful things. And I have also been at the forefront of a new political movement that has really challenged the issue of body fascism.

"If we can win the one about trans bodies, then we can win in on all the other battlegrounds surrounding the body - whether it is to do with being fat or thin, able or disabled, black or brown, male or female."

But, in 1992, this all changed when six men and women met at a London cafe to form Press for Change, trans people's first political campaigning organisation. Since then, huge steps have been made in the fight against "body fascism". Dynamic activists such as Stephen Whittle, a Manchester lawyer, helped Press for Change to launch the first concerted campaign via the courts to fight discrimination against trans people. After four years, the first important milestone was reached when the European court of justice ruled that discrimination against anyone who had undergone "gender reassignment" surgery contravened the 1975 sex discrimination act. This victory opened up challenges to be made against discrimination in employment, and when, in 1998, airline pilot Kristina Sheffield won a case for unfair dismissal, it was followed by a string of similar victories. Christine Burns, Press for Change vice-president, says such a step-up of campaigning activity represents trans people's willingness to become more vocal in resisting prejudice. "When Press for Change started five years ago, it was regarded as being exceedingly brave even to come out as trans," she says. "You could count the names on one hand of those who had. People feared coming out would lead to further discrimination and trouble - such as someone turning up at your doorstep with malicious intent. But now more trans people are prepared to publicly challenge injustice." Activists have tended to use the courts as a platform as opposed to direct action because, with only 5,000 UK trans people, it has been difficult to rally mass support. Activists also readily admit that many still fear the consequences of becoming militant - such as appearing in court, where previous names are made public, and facing the ignominy of having their personal lives splashed on tabloid front pages. Yet, in 1997, trans people united publicly for the first time when 50 protesters marched to Downing Street and handed over a 10,000-name petition protesting against Britain's law that their birth certificates cannot be altered once a person changes sex or has "gender reassignment" surgery. "It represented tremendous progress to have got all these trans people on to the streets," says Burns. "Characteristically, trans people have been afraid of public attention." In the same year, activists had their first direct confrontation with "body fascists". Some neighbours of Stephen Whittle were trying to eject him and his family from the neighbourhood and had organised a "public meeting" in a pub to discuss how to get rid of them. But Whittle turned up at the pub accompanied by dozens of supportive neighbours, work colleagues, activists and a TV reporter. "The bigots had moved on and were nowhere to be seen," Burns recalls. "So we decided not to waste the opportunity and had a jolly good party instead. We challenged unashamed prejudice head-on and we won." Despite such progress, Britain remains one of four out of 39 Council of Europe countries which prohibit trans people's birth certificates from being changed. This stems from a 1970 decree of nullity case brought by Arthur Corbett, the heir of Lord Rowallen. Corbett wanted to separate from his wife, the trans model April Ashley, and his family was desperate to avoid handing over any inheritance to her. The court ruled the marriage void because Ashley's birth certificate, which acts as proof of identity, stated that she was a man. "In effect, the judgment means that, once a person has undergone gender reassignment, they no longer officially exist," says Burns. "The court's decision became the touchstone upon which virtually every aspect of our lives came to be judged. Whether it be claiming benefits or applying for insurance, trans people can end up in all sorts of difficulties if they do not give the name stated on their birth certificate." Activists doggedly continue to press the government's interdepartmental working group on trans issues for the right to have their birth certificate changed. And, while the court triumphs have done their bit to reverse discrimination, activists have found an unexpected, but powerful, ally in Coronation Street. Its own male-to-female trans character, Hayley Patterson, presents the first enduring positive image of a trans person to a mass audience and helps erode the idea of trans people as somehow shockingly aberrant. Hayley's marriage and employment problems also mirror those that trans people face in real life, largely because a Press for Change member acts as a personal adviser to actress Julie Hesmondhalgh and the Street's scriptwriters. Granada, the producer of the programme, had first planned to use Hayley as a character for just eight weeks. But such was her popularity that the contract was increased to two years. "Let's not forget that 18 million people watch Coronation Street," says Burns. "The day-to-day experience of a trans person's life is coming into the living-room of all these viewers, and Hayley's popularity flies in the face of some who even thought that the life of a trans person should not be shown until after 9pm." Meanwhile, Anne is well into her life as a woman. She planned to take the pub which barred her to court for contravening the sex discrimination act. But, last October, the landlady apologised and handed Anne £1,000 compensation in an out-of-court settlement. "It seems the law was on my side," said Anne. "But I did want the case to go to court to reveal the kind of suffering and prejudice people like me still have to go through." It is such resistance which symbolises trans people's stronger united voice. As Whittle says: "Being trans has been a privilege because I have met wonderful people and have done wonderful things. And I have also been at the forefront of a new political movement that has really challenged the issue of body fascism. "If we can win the one about trans bodies, then we can win in on all the other battlegrounds surrounding the body - whether it is to do with being fat or thin, able or disabled, black or brown, male or female."

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A businessman in Swansea, who thought the millennium bug had struck when his computer exploded, discovered that a mouse had been inside and left droppings on the circuit board.
fields.body:
Dicky mouse: A businessman in Swansea, who thought the millennium bug had struck when his computer exploded, discovered that a mouse had been inside and left droppings on the circuit board.

Meat slogger: A Manchester City fan has been banned from watching any domestic football games for 18 months after being found guilty of hitting a rival fan with a meat pie.

Thirst degree: Students at Edinburgh University are to be paid to drink seven shots of vodka daily as part of a study into the effects of alcohol on speed and coordination.

Scarborough scare: The town hall and surrounding area in Scarborough, Yorkshire, were sealed off for two hours after a bomb alert over a suspicious package, which turned out to contain a bundle of electricity bills.

Miaow, miaOW! An RSPCA supporter in Norwich is helping to raise awareness about the charity's cat neutering campaign by getting people to sponsor his vasectomy operation.

Pane gain: An elderly couple in Sunderland were so pleased with the new windows fitted in their conservatory that they have bequeathed the house to the workman.

Curse reverse: A Belgian tourist who claims his family has been struck by a curse has returned a stone he took from a neolithic burial site near Inverness.

Rush jobs: Pagers are to be given to long-term unemployed people on Merseyside so they can be sent up-to-date 'job alerts'.

Sneaky move: Detectives in Eastbourne are to place adverts in their local newspaper in a bid to recruit more informers.

April fooled: A Sussex market trader has sent back a consignment of diaries made in Taiwan because they included two Aprils but no May.

Social gaffe: Police in Derby arrested a burglar at a social club when he returned to look for a wallet he dropped at the scene of the crime.

Private view: The coil worn by a teacher for 25 years will form the centrepiece of a Bristol GP's exhibition of art and fashion wear created from contraceptives discarded by her patients.

Dopey idea: Thieves who stole Dopey, one of the Seven Dwarfs in the garden of a house in Maidstone, Kent, have sent a ransom note to the owner.

webTitle: Unita leader ordered UN planes to be shot down, videotape shows

fields.headline: Unita leader ordered UN planes to be shot down, videotape shows
fields.standfirst: A videotape supplied by Canadian ambassador Robert Fowler, chairman of the  UN sanctions committee on Angola, to the UN's security council last night shows Unita rebel leader Jonas Savimbi ordering the shooting down of two UN planes in Angola last year
fields.trailText: The United Nations security council last night saw stunning videotape evidence from senior former military leaders of the Unita rebel movement in Angola that the movement's leader, Jonas Savimbi, personally ordered the shooting down of two UN planes in Angola last year, which killed all 22 people on board.
fields.body:
The United Nations security council last night saw stunning videotape evidence from senior former military leaders of the Unita rebel movement in Angola that the movement's leader, Jonas Savimbi, personally ordered the shooting down of two UN planes in Angola last year, which killed all 22 people on board.

The evidence given to the council with a report from Canadian ambassador Robert Fowler, chairman of the UN sanctions committee on Angola, besides revealing Savimbi's personal responsibility in the UN officials' deaths, details Unita's trade of arms for diamonds which has kept the war going since the rebel movement rejected the results of the UN-supervised elections in 1992. Mr Fowler promised a fuller report in March which would name people, countries and companies involved in breaking UN sanctions on selling arms to Unita.

The report finally nails any chance of a political future for Savimbi, once the protege of successive US presidents, the CIA and their allies in various west European governments, including Britain. Savimbi is now widely regarded as a war criminal.

The ambassador explained how the arms trade was done. Unita would put out tenders to the international arms market, and brokers would fly into Savimbi's headquarters at Andulo in the central highlands to negotiate prices, Mr Fowler said.

"The supplier would offer the whole package, delivered to Andulo. They would settle the price in diamonds, with the arms merchant's expert in diamonds and Unita's expert in diamonds agreeing on what the diamonds were worth," he said.

The arms were from eastern Europe. "There is a huge volume of information out there indicating - crystal clear - that Unita's arsenal is essentially east European," Mr Fowler said.

The video shows six separate interviews between Mr Fowler and Unita defectors, including General Jacinto Bandua who was in charge of Unita's logistics for three years.

The evidence given to the UN is the first authoritative report on the scale of the Unita resupply operation during the last two years when the rebel movement showed a surprising strength in resisting more than one major government offensive. One of the witnesses said that the airport at Andulo was receiving 15 to 20 flights a day, including Illushin 76 and Antonov 72s carrying T74 tanks.

Andulo is now in government hands, and there have been numerous significant defections to the government side, but military officials in Luanda have warned that the war is not over. Tens of thousands of refugees have been pouring into eastern Zambia to escape fighting in recent days, while northern Namibia has also seen incursions of Unita troops in recent weeks.

fields.headline: Goodbye and good riddance
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet may escape justice, but at least Chileans had a year of peace
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has promised to give the "most careful consideration" to yesterday's submissions on the Pinochet case. The general's final departure from these shores, then, is delayed, but perhaps not for long: the likelihood of his return to Chile remains high enough for Chile to have dispatched a plane, due in Britain today, to collect him.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has promised to give the "most careful consideration" to yesterday's submissions on the Pinochet case. The general's final departure from these shores, then, is delayed, but perhaps not for long: the likelihood of his return to Chile remains high enough for Chile to have dispatched a plane, due in Britain today, to collect him. It is a disappointment, obviously, for Judge Baltasar Garzon and for the families of Pinochet's victims. Whatever the merits of Jack Straw's decision, it would certainly have been courteous - and, prudent - had he offered the Spanish courts access to the contested medical evidence to judge for themselves whether Pinochet was fit to stand trial.

But as the old dictator sits on his suitcase, it would be wrong to see this result as a defeat for those who wished to see the crimes of the dictatorship accounted for - or those who wish Chilean democracy well. Fifteen months ago, in the wake of Pinochet's arrest, the main chant of Norman Lamont's bizarre chorus was that Chilean democracy was so fragile that an act of justice of this kind would bring it crashing to the ground. The subtext of Lord Lamont's remarks appeared to be that Chilean democracy was just a pretence that the Chilean right and the Chilean armed forces were ready to end at a moment's notice.

Fifteen months on, those opinions seem even more contemptible than they did at the time. As it turned out, a year and a half without Pinochet was just the tonic Chilean democracy needed. Chileans of the left and the right have been able to go about the political business of remembering that democracy used to flourish in their country before Pinochet tried to destroy it.

Pinochet's era, despite the rump of appointed senators, is over. The bulk of his support on the right has melted away or transferred its allegiance to the next generation. Joaquin Lavin, the leader of that new generation, is treading a path similar to that taken by the Spanish prime minister Jose Maria Aznar, when he steered his rightwing party away from its associations with the past dictatorship and towards democratic terra firma. Lavin has made it clear that if Pinochet comes home, he will be expected to stay decently indoors.

There is no mileage any more in being a Pinochet groupie. The pragmatic component has decamped, leaving only the retired military die-hards of the Pinochet Foundation and those elements of the security services who fear ending up in the dock themselves. Pinochet will return to a country that has just elected Ricardo Lagos as president, a man he once imprisoned and exiled, a man who had been nominated ambassador to Moscow, of all places, by Salvador Allende.

The Pinochet issue was refreshingly absent for much of the election and, when it did become important just before the final vote at the weekend, it seems to have tipped the vote in favour of the left. If Lord Lamont wanted any clearer view of what the people of Chile (in whose name he claims to have been speaking all these months) really think about their retired dictator, he has only to ask himself why the prospect of the general's return should so have galvanised the vote for his arch opponent.

It is not just Chilean politics, though, that have benefited. Chilean judges, who have ignored the pleas for justice, the requests for habeas corpus and the dossiers of evidence for the best part of a quarter of a century, have found a little courage after Pinochet's arrest. Even if only from a sense of wounded national pride, Chilean judges have begun to recover their sense of shame and with it, a capacity for action. Judge Jaime Guzman, for instance, has now accepted more than 50 cases against General Pinochet, many of which he has been pursuing with a certain diligence. He may never get anywhere and even if he did, he is likely to be led a dance as he tries to prosecute the general in person. But it is no longer considered outlandish or suicidal in Chile to try for justice, just as it is no longer thought eccentric or mad to insist on the right to truth. Fifteen months ago, the widows and orphans of Pinochet's victims were outcasts. All had lost loved ones. Some had also lost their homes and their livelihoods. For them Pinochet's arrest and detention has been a liberating event.

Even if there will be no court verdict, Chilean society has lost enough of its fear to have recovered a measure of its conscience; the least the victims are owed is a frank account of their fate.

Pinochet and his admirers will never again be able to impose their view of history on their country and never again be able to force the lie that the general is a hero to his people down the throats of his victims. The general has found his true place in history. For that, we should all thank Baltasar Garzon.

fields.headline: The name's Bean ... Mr Bean
fields.standfirst: Also today, Dave Stewart makes an Honest man of Clinton | Cruise's woman-hating turn alarms fans but delights critics | Security tightened around Lord of the Rings set | Bond goes back to basics
fields.trailText: Also today, Dave Stewart makes an Honest man of Clinton | Cruise's woman-hating turn alarms fans but delights critics | Security tightened around Lord of the Rings set | Bond goes back to basics
fields.body:
Mr Bean as James Bond? It's on the cards - sort of. A secret movie project is being hatched for Rowan Atkinson by Robert Wade and Neal Purvis, the hotshot writers of The World Is Not Enough, as part of a deal the duo recently struck with Working Title, the company behind the Bean movie.

The so-far untitled movie being written for Atkinson will be a blend of action and slapstick comedy. It is envisaged that Atkinson's character will be a cross between James Bond and Inspector Clouseau.

The notoriously picky Atkinson, who has so far resisted overtures for him to reprise his money-spinning Bean role on the big screen, is known to be a big Bond fan: he took a cameo as a hapless government official in the 1983 caper Never Say Never Again in which Sean Connery played 007. Atkinson has just completed a co-starring turn in Maybe Baby, the movie adaptation of Ben Elton's novel that marks Elton's movie directorial debut. Later this year, he is hotly tipped to take the part of the bug-eyed horn-parping Harpo Marx in Universal's biopic of manic 1930s entertainers, the Marx Brothers.

Wade and Purvis recently delivered a script for a $50m studio remake of The Italian Job. They are now working on the screenplay for Bond 20, which will be released in 2002. Pierce Brosnan will reprise his role as Bond although no director has yet been confirmed for the project.

The screenwriters are developing several other projects for Working Title, for whom they wrote last year's 18th-century highwaymen romp Plunkett & Macleane. Wade says that the deal even offers them a chance to direct a movie. Clearly, the world is not enough.

Dave Stewart makes an Honest man of Clinton

Eurythmics star-turned-director Dave Stewart has cut a scene portraying Bill Clinton smoking a joint from his upcoming All Saints-starring film, Honest.

According to reports in this week's Heat magazine, the producers pulled the scene because of concerns that it could hinder the film's success in the US.

The Clinton lookalike is apparently shown smoking the joint in a scene set at Oxford university, where the future US president was a Rhodes scholar.

The movie is no stranger to drugs controversy. In July, the Sun ran the story saying that Stewart had handed fake drugs as props to eight-year-old children and told them to behave as if they were "off their heads" (see our news story). It turned out that the children in question were Stewart's, and they were not indulging in any illegal activity.

Cruise's woman-hating turn alarms fans but delights critics

Tom Cruise's decision to dump his clean-cut, wholesome image in his new film Magnolia has dismayed his female fans. Cruise plays misogynist self-help TV evangelist, Frank TJ Mackey, who encourages spurned men to exact revenge with a "humping then dumping" policy.

Says one female fan: "He plays such a woman hater it's scary. I really hope he's just acting." The critics however are delighted by Cruise's change of direction, and the actor's performance in Magnolia is tipped for an Oscar nomination. An insider says: "Cruise has been overly cautious in his choice of roles - now with Magnolia he goes wild. He's finally liberated himself."

Ring of steel around Tolkien set

A spy on Ain't it Cool News reveals the latest Lord of the Rings (LOTR) developments. Some of the sets, "which look absolutely amazing", have been shown on a New Zealand TV report, which also ran an interview with the associate producer. He revealed that set security is tighter than any other movie in history, because "we want everything to be a surprise when you see the movie".

Meanwhile, Harry Knowles reports that LOTR spy site theonering.net has been hit with a two-year trespassing warning, forbidding them to go near the land where the Tolkien saga is being filmed.

In brief

James Bond will soon be back behind the wheel of his signature Aston Martin after driving a BMW for the last two Bond movies. American carmaker Ford is reported to have signed a £1m deal to ensure that Bond drives an Aston Martin in his next two movies. The deal is expected to see the company quadrupling production of its latest model.

Michael J Fox has finally been forced to end his acting career due to Parkinson's disease. The 38-year-old star has been suffering from the incurable degenerative brain disorder for over 10 years. He hopes to devote himself to his family and to raise awareness of the disease.

It seems that Monday's story linking Steven Spielberg with the Harry Potter film may have been somewhat premature. Spielberg's camp will neither confirm or deny the rumour, saying only that the director has yet to decide officially on his next film.

Woody Allen meanwhile sets the record straight in this week's Time Out over his future living arrangements. Despite reports that the director and family would be coming to London, he apparently has no intention of leaving New York, but is however in early negotiations to direct a couple of new one-acters which would involve him coming to London, briefly.

Casting couch

 Tim Curry has signed on to join Sam Rockwell as the villainous element in Charlie's Angels.

 Drew Barrymore will both star in and produce an adaptation of Robert Nathan's 1958 novel So Love Returns, about a young writer whose world is shattered by the death of his wife.

An insider says: "Cruise has been overly cautious in his choice of roles - now with Magnolia he goes wild. He's finally liberated himself." Ring of steel around Tolkien set A spy on Ain't it Cool News reveals the latest Lord of the Rings (LOTR) developments. Some of the sets, "which look absolutely amazing", have been shown on a New Zealand TV report, which also ran an interview with the associate producer. He revealed that set security is tighter than any other movie in history, because "we want everything to be a surprise when you see the movie". Meanwhile, Harry Knowles reports that LOTR spy site theonering.net has been hit with a two-year trespassing warning, forbidding them to go near the land where the Tolkien saga is being filmed. In brief James Bond will soon be back behind the wheel of his signature Aston Martin after driving a BMW for the last two Bond movies. American carmaker Ford is reported to have signed a £1m deal to ensure that Bond drives an Aston Martin in his next two movies. The deal is expected to see the company quadrupling production of its latest model. Michael J Fox has finally been forced to end his acting career due to Parkinson's disease. The 38-year-old star has been suffering from the incurable degenerative brain disorder for over 10 years. He hopes to devote himself to his family and to raise awareness of the disease. It seems that Monday's story linking Steven Spielberg with the Harry Potter film may have been somewhat premature. Spielberg's camp will neither confirm or deny the rumour, saying only that the director has yet to decide officially on his next film. Woody Allen meanwhile sets the record straight in this week's Time Out over his future living arrangements. Despite reports that the director and family would be coming to London, he apparently has no intention of leaving New York, but is however in early negotiations to direct a couple of new one-acters which would involve him coming to London, briefly. Casting couch  Tim Curry has signed on to join Sam Rockwell as the villainous element in Charlie's Angels.  Drew Barrymore will both star in and produce an adaptation of Robert Nathan's 1958 novel So Love Returns, about a young writer whose world is shattered by the death of his wife.

fields.headline: What's in a name?
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on the renaming of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, announced today by Northern Ireland secretary of state Peter Mandelson
Plus: Cherie lays down the law
fields.trailText: The Royal Ulster Constabulary is bigger than its name, Peter Mandelson declared today. He will soon find out the truth of this doubtful assertion.
fields.body:
The Royal Ulster Constabulary is bigger than its name, Peter Mandelson declared today. He will soon find out the truth of this doubtful assertion.

The Northern Ireland secretary has, in effect, adopted the radical recommendations of last year's report by Chris Patten into policing in the province. The strength of the force will be sliced down from 13,500 to around 7,500. New recruits will be drawn equally from the Protestant and Roman Catholic communities. The anti-paramilitary cutting edge of the force, the special branch, will be absorbed into a new anti-crime division.

But the key change, in a land obsessed by symbols, will be symbolic. The name Royal Ulster Constabulary is to be replaced by the anodyne new title of "police service of Northern Ireland". Mandelson suggests that this is a relatively minor aspect of the reforms. But he is a shrewd operator, and must know that what he is proposing is not just the refettling of the RUC, but its destruction.

Ever since it was resurrected from the ashes of the old Royal Irish Constabulary in the early 20s, the RUC's function has been to protect and perpetuate unionist hegemony in the six counties of Northern Ireland. In the old days, it did so crudely as an all but solidly Protestant tribal force. Since the introduction of direct rule by Westminster nearly 30 years ago, it has been more an instrument of the crown than of Stormont. But to an overwhelming majority of the Catholic nationalist community, it is at best unloved and distrusted.

At the same time, to the Protestant unionist community, which has seen its political authority steadily eroded, it remains the only effective locally raised and (to a large extent) locally controlled bulwark against republican violence.

The "Royal" in the title RUC was a reassuring if somewhat notional reminder that the force stood for the continuing union with the rest of the kingdom. Much more reassuring, of course, was the bias of a force which successive British secretaries of state have failed to make more representative: the RUC remains more than 90% Protestant.

That statistic illustrates the depth of Catholic hostility to the force. It also reflects the ruthlessness of the various republican gangs who discouraged police recruitment in "their" community by executing the few brave souls who dared to join up.

There is now a real chance that Catholics will feel free to take part in the impartial policing of the province. That is a huge gain. But against it must be set the real sense of disillusion within the loyalist community which wants peace, but perceives it to be coming at a bitter price.

After all, more than 300 RUC officers have been murdered, and some 13,000 wounded, in defence of the concept embodied in the simple, potent word "Royal". In the end, the name may prove bigger than Mandelson supposes.

Related documentary
Northern Ireland: special report

Cherie lays down the law

The government is breaking EU law by denying millions of parents the right to take extra leave from work. So says Cherie Booth QC, aka Mrs Tony Blair.

Wearing her wig as a leading authority on employment law, Booth has advised the TUC that the EU's parental leave directive is not being implemented properly in Britain. The directive allows mothers, fathers and adoptive parents to take up to 13 weeks' unpaid leave, to care for children under the age of five. The government has decreed that the rule will apply to parents of children born on or after December 15 last year. That excludes some existing 3.3m parents of children under five.

Trade unionists are delighted with the Booth interpretation of the directive. They say they will step up their campaign to end what they call "nursery apartheid". Mrs Blair, meanwhile, says she would be happy to assist the TUC if it wanted to take legal action.

All parties, naturally, dismiss any notion of embarrassment in Downing Street. But it is comforting, somehow, to know that when the Blair babe is born around May, both Tony and Cherie will be fully entitled to take themselves out of public view for 13 weeks.

Work Unlimited
TUC

fields.headline: US anti-missile test fails
fields.trailText: A US missile today missed a dummy warhead in a test of the Pentagon's mini Star Wars programme designed to protect America from intercontinental attacks by "rogue" states.
fields.body:
A US missile today missed a dummy warhead in a test of the Pentagon's mini Star Wars programme designed to protect America from intercontinental attacks by "rogue" states.

The "kill vehicle" failed to find and destroy its target fired into space from Vandenberg Air Force base in California. Defence officials said the interceptor, fired from Kwajalein atoll in the Marshall Islands, missed the target as the two missiles streaked through the skies in opposite directions 140 miles above the Pacific.

"We did not have an intercept," said lieutenant colonel Rick Lehner from the Pentagon's ballistic missile defence organisation. "We don't know what happened when it got into space."

The botched test will come as a relief to America's allies as well as Russia and China. All have strenuously opposed the creation of the scaled-down version of Ronald Reagan's strategic defence initiative, better known as Star Wars, on the grounds that it would undermine the global nuclear balance. Russia and Europe have argued that a mini Star Wars system would violate the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty.

The Pentagon has been racing to develop a system to counter a potential nuclear threat from America's designated bogeymen such as Iraq and North Korea, although recent private spy satellites indicated that the latter's missile capability was virtually non-existent.

Pentagon officials have drafted plans to deploy a system of 100 interceptors, perhaps as early as 2005. The proposed system would be the most complex weapon ever developed. Defence officials said before today's test that they would find it difficult to recommend deployment unless it succeeded in at least one of the two flight tests scheduled before President Bill Clinton takes a decision in the late summer.

The anti-missile defence system has already emerged as a US presidential election issue. All the Republican presidential candidates want to proceed with the system, while vice-president Al Gore and former senator Bill Bradley are more cautious.

The previous test in October was officially judged a success. While some critics disputed this assessment, it was hailed by missile-defence advocates as proof that the system can be effectively deployed by 2005. But this morning's failure suggests that the system is not ready despite a breakneck development schedule.

Projected to cost $12.7bn, the system would be expected to protect against only up to 30 fairly simple missiles. Even if the full shield is deployed in 2011 - with more than 200 interceptors at two or more sites - it would only be able to handle "tens, not hundreds" of enemy missiles.

Under the rules of the Pentagon's development programme, the system must score two kills to be judged ready for continued work towards the 2005 deadline. The first test, in October, achieved a successful interception, and so now the Pentagon must score a kill in the next test, scheduled for April or May.

webTitle: As dusk falls, the dogmas track a demented meerkat

fields.headline: As dusk falls, the dogmas track a demented meerkat
fields.standfirst: Life in Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: The house of Commons debated the crisis in the health service yesterday. It was parliament at its best. In a calm, rational discussion, MPs agreed that the problems were deep-seated and could not be solved overnight. A balance had to be found between efficient administration and funding frontline care for the sick.
fields.body:
The house of Commons debated the crisis in the health service yesterday. It was parliament at its best. In a calm, rational discussion, MPs agreed that the problems were deep-seated and could not be solved overnight. A balance had to be found between efficient administration and funding frontline care for the sick.

Neither the present nor the last government could be blamed entirely for the crisis, but it might be solved by goodwill and with a rational approach by all sides.

Oh no, they didn't! Just my little joke! They were as bad as ever. All of them. I assume there were some doctors and nurses in the public gallery, attending a debate about their future, and they must have been close to despair.

Liam Fox, the Conservative spokesman, who had spent the flu crisis skiing, solemnly declared that it was time to "drop the dogma, to drop the soundbites and to drop deception."

He then offered the house a feast of all three. He started by shroud waving. When he began with the words "Mr Jones of Portishead", Labour MPs groaned, because naming a poorly constituent is the parliamentary equivalent of a force-field. You are simply not allowed to be rude about Mr Jones (nor about Mr Duncan Shepherd of Staffs, nor Colonel Bruce Owen of Bucks, nor any of the other patients whose ghostly forms stalked the benches yesterday like Marley's various ghosts). It's like children in a playground shouting "pax".

Dr Fox blamed it all on the government's spin doctors (as in "we need more real doctors than spin doctors".)

"In the twilight world of new Labour spin, the dark shadow of Alastair Campbell is fast approaching," he said , as if tracking a vulture's flight towards a limping kudu, who'd just been turned away from A & E.

"If information is inconvenient," he went on, "they corrupt it, they change it, or they deny it. Even better, they withhold it."

Labour MPs kept rising to read out from a script provided for them. The Tories, they allege, wanted to privatise all health care.

Dr Fox ignored them. "There is no such thing as truth and lies in this government's views, merely what suits them at the moment."

Jean Corston of Bristol kept trying to intervene. "You mustn't jump up and down like a demented meerkat," said Dr Fox, adding to the Wildlife On Two air of the entire debate. We needed David Attenborough's hushed voice. "The fox is trying to soundbite the meerkat's head off. The other meerkats rush to its support..."

Finally, Dr Fox declared that people did not want the NHS to be used as a political football, while he simultaneously thumped damp leather spheres all over the place.

"The secretary of state," he said of Alan Milburn, "is no doubt being lined up as the fall guy - before he is lined up to be mayor of Darlington."

This cutting reference to Frank Dobson (Mr Milburn is the MP for Darlington) did not encourage the health secretary to be any more sane and constructive.

"Any time the Tories talk about health care there is an epidemic - an epidemic of hypocrisy and an outbreak of selective amnesia," he said, before launching into a smorgasbord of hypocrisy and selective amnesia.

It was, he said repeatedly, "fatuous" to suggest that all the NHS's problems had begun on May 2, 1997, before going on to imply that they all stemmed from events which occurred in the 18 years before that date.

He even essayed some false candour. "If we thought that there was nothing wrong," he said. "We wouldn't be working so hard to put things right!" A wonderfully circular argument, which, no doubt, can excuse any of a government's failings.

I wondered vaguely whether you can get the parliamentary cable channel from a hospital trolley.
