webTitle: UK minister defends arms sales to Indonesia

fields.headline: UK minister defends arms sales to Indonesia
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign office minister John Battle yesterday defended the resumption of British arms sales to Indonesia in spite of the rapidly escalating social unrest, a divided military and warnings from other countries.
fields.body:
The foreign office minister John Battle yesterday defended the resumption of British arms sales to Indonesia in spite of the rapidly escalating social unrest, a divided military and warnings from other countries.

He urged the world to dispel its long-held view of Indonesia as an unstable, military-controlled state and to welcome the emerging democracy into the international fold.

Mr Battle said after two days of talks with Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid and government officials in Jakarta that it was time to get rid of outdated and antiquated views on Indonesia.

"It is not commonly understood internationally that there is a new president elected, that there are new ministers, that there's a programme of reform, and my view is that the government needs to be underpinned in that programme of reform," he said.

In such circumstances, and in the light of Indonesia's withdrawal from East Timor, he said, there was no reason to reimpose the European Union arms embargo against Jakarta.

"The situation in East Timor has changed massively," he said, referring to circumstances four months ago, when the embargo was imposed. "The TNI [Indonesian military] are not in East Timor, thankfully, and the situation is different. What we're talking about now is a new government that has to cope with the legacy of what went on there."

However, he stressed that there would be "no free flow through of arms and no questions asked tomorrow", because both the EU and Britain had strict codes of conduct regarding arms exports to Indonesia.

"The international community is not going to go away," he said. "It's going to watch the situation and see how the government handles it. It's going to be a case by case basis."

Britain is one of the biggest arms suppliers to Indonesia. In 1998 Britain exported arms worth £73m to Indonesia. In order not to lose future busi ness, British diplomats and arms dealers have regularly courted Indonesian dealers and generals during the embargo period when all links were supposed to have been broken.

The Dutch foreign minister, Jozias van Aartsen, who is also in Jakarta, said that when he reports on Indonesia to the EU council of foreign ministers next Monday, "without any doubt there will be a very positive outlook".

Neither referred to the current state of the military which, after decades as the country's most powerful political force, is now deeply divided over its future role. There is speculation that some generals, particularly those threatened with prosecution over their involvement in East Timor, are plotting a coup.

It is widely accepted that barely half of the armed forces support President Abdurrahman and his reform programme.

Mr Battle met only one general in Jakarta, the mines and energy minister, Bambang Yudoyhono, who no longer has hands-on control of any troops. Mr Van Aartsen sidestepped questions about whether he trusted the military to respect the civilian government's reform programme.

However, with more than a quarter of the country affected by social unrest that the military appears unable to control, Washington is still worried about the situation and refuses to lift its arms embargo until the generals are brought completely to heel. Many other western diplomatic missions in Jakarta share their concern.

One diplomat said it was "pretty irresponsible" of Mr Battle and Mr Van Aartsen to make judgments without consulting the military high command or considering many other factors.

"The place is in a mess and what is more frightening is that we don't know how bad a mess it is," he said. "The military is even more splintered than it was a year ago, access to this cabinet is worse than to the last cabinet and ministers are running scared and keeping their heads down because they don't know what the president is going to say next."

webTitle: Serbia in fear after Arkan's murder

fields.headline: Serbia in fear after Arkan's murder
fields.trailText: The assassination of the notorious warlord and mobster Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic has thrown Serbia into political uproar, amid mounting allegations that the murder was sanctioned by President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite, who were alarmed at his growing power.
fields.body:
The assassination of the notorious warlord and mobster Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic has thrown Serbia into political uproar, amid mounting allegations that the murder was sanctioned by President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling elite, who were alarmed at his growing power.

The gunning down of the indicted war criminal and two bodyguards in Belgrade's Intercontinental hotel last Saturday provided "confirmation that we are living in a country of state terrorism", said the opposition politician Vuk Draskovic. "These liquidations have the aim of spreading fear," said Mr Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement.

Arkan seemed unassailable, the commander of his own private army of several thousand experienced fighters. "I am not afraid of anything, remember this," he said only last year.

The head of the United Nations mission to Bosnia described him last Sunday as a psychopath and coward. "Crying for Arkan is like crying for [Nazi war criminal Adolf] Eichmann," said Jacques Klein, a United States diplomat.

Mr Klein said his only regret was that Arkan had not been brought to justice at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague, which had indicted him for crimes against humanity, including alleged atrocities in Croatia in 1991 and in the 1992-95 Bosnia war.

Arkan led the feared Serbian "Tigers" paramilitary unit that took part in the brutal three-month siege of the city of Vukovar in eastern Croatia in 1991. A year later he helped the Bosnian Serbs to overrun northern and eastern Bosnia, where he was considered one of the pioneers of "ethnic cleansing", his fighters spreading terror among Muslims.

He had become an independent force in Serbia through his control of most criminal and black market activities. But he had also gained many enemies. Even his ownership of the top Serbian football club, Obilic, was marked by gangland violence. The Serbian football federation concluded recently that the results of last season's championship should be declared void, following threats made to referees and opposition teams.

But Arkan's most dangerous enemies were those in the ruling elite. Once reputed to be close to President Milosevic, he had of late moved further away from governing circles.

Analysts in Belgrade say Arkan was disenchanted with the growing influence of the small Yugoslav United Left (JUL) party led by Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. Key government positions have increasingly been filled by JUL officials, prompting thoughts of defection by some old-guard members of Mr Milosevic's Socialist party.

Local journalists say Arkan may have come into conflict with Mr Milosevic's son, Marko, over fuel smuggling into Serbia in violation of international sanctions. They say Arkan had been making inroads into this profitable business which, they claim, was hitherto dominated by Marko.

webTitle: Now the Pompidou looks a picture

fields.headline: Now the Pompidou looks a picture
fields.standfirst: Uplifting, stylish, even cheap - no, it's not the Dome. Jonathan Glancey admires an inspired makeover
fields.trailText: The signs are silly, the staff surly, some of the new displays potty, the lavatories unspeakably filthy . . . At this point, criticism begins to trail off. The refitted and repainted Pompidou Centre is a wonder. Here you can see how the broadest possible public can be offered culture without compromise in a building that remains as striking, if not quite as controversial, as it was in 1977, when Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano's original design was attacked for looking too much like a gasworks.
fields.body:
The signs are silly, the staff surly, some of the new displays potty, the lavatories unspeakably filthy . . . At this point, criticism begins to trail off. The refitted and repainted Pompidou Centre is a wonder. Here you can see how the broadest possible public can be offered culture without compromise in a building that remains as striking, if not quite as controversial, as it was in 1977, when Richard Rogers and Renzo Piano's original design was attacked for looking too much like a gasworks.

Unlike some overhyped cultural attractions that have opened this past year, visitors would be lying if they said they were disappointed by the exhibits, or thought that 30 francs (less than $5) was too much to pay to see as much Picasso, Braque, Ernst, Tinguely, Klein and Calder as you can manage without suffering visual indigestion. And these are before attempting to tackle the delightful displays of modern architecture, graphics, photography and design. Stuff all this nonsense about "virtual" exhibitions, the decline of the "object" and cyberspace: people from all walks of life, all ages and all corners of the world love to see the range and quality of the very real things - paintings, sculpture, furniture, architectural models - that the Pompidou has on display.

The centre had been closed until January 1 for 27 long months. Under the direction of Piano, but without Rogers on a formal basis, other firms of architects have been involved in bringing the Pompidou up to date.

Since it opened in 1977, 145m visitors have come to ride the external escalators with their cinematic views of central Paris, and to see great exhibitions of Dali, Matisse and Derain. That's an average of 23,000 a day, and this for a cultural centre designed for an optimistic capacity of 5,000 a day. No wonder the Pompidou was looking shabby and threadbare by the mid-90s. Now it looks and feels light, airy, almost elegant. The west front has been painted a convincing shade of white (with subtle yellow bands behind windows, and the undersides of the escalator tubes painted a handsome red), leaving the less-visited east front in the toy-like reds and blues which, fashionable among architects in the 70s, seem hard on the retina today.

The building has been much modified internally. The admin offices have gone, clearing a whole floor for more art. The vast lobby is lighter and more welcoming. On opposed mezzanines Piano has added an open cafe, and, more controversially, an open shop, the first museum shop of its kind, in fact - no doors, no windows and best of all, no tat. In this franchise from the department store Printemps, the "designer" merchandise is arranged like a street market. Below the shop and cafe are a children's rumpus room (the sort of mimsy you expect to find in Ikea) and a bookshop twice as big as before.

At the centre of this space is a stunted tree growing from a huge cube of earth rising from the basement (where four new performance and lecture spaces, including a second cinema, have been shaped) and a shoulder-shrugging information desk. (Don't try to speak a foreign language, and, whatever you do, don't attempt your school French; this will only make matters all the more degrading for you, rosbif.)

External escalators lead up to a new library designed by Jean-Franois Bodin, who has also re-dressed the Museum of Modern Art above it. The museum is on two levels, connected by a temporary-looking stair. The sub-John Pawson, white-painted minimalist joinery here is scarcely a match for the breathtaking collection of 20th-century art on the upper level, nor does it come anywhere near matching the superb exterior lake terraces that Piano has added to punctuate the generously spaced, if near-relentless sequence of masterpieces.

These terraces are an inspiring touch. From inside the museum, surrounded by the works of Giacometti, Picabia and Delaunay, visitors can gaze over watery terraces animated by Miro, Ernst and Calder sculptures and through the cat's cradle of Piano + Rogers' structure to monuments of earlier heroic moments. At one point they can see the mount of Montmartre and its crown, the Sacr Coeur basilica, framed by the legs of a hefty Calder sculpture: the art world caught in the leghold of a major artwork.

The museum has paintings and sculpture housed in pavilions leading off a main internal "street" on both levels. On both of these, pre- and post-1950, the pavilions lead into others displaying design and architecture. This is a controversial decision in curatorial circles, but it works well, because the selection of architectural drawings and models, of chairs and cameras and even computers (it's fun to see one of those faddish iMacs, dated 1998, already preserved in a display case) has been rigorous.

Above the museum is a gallery of contemporary art. The interior architecture, by Bodin, is much as the museum below. On level six there's a zooty, curvy 350-seater terrace restaurant (not open on my visit).

There is truly something for everyone in the new-look Pompidou.

fields.headline: Anglo-Caribbean View
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon on the Windies' woes
fields.trailText: Hansie Cronje hates losing, but at least he can console himself with the thought that these visitors were better than the lot of a year ago. The West Indies won only a single one-day match out of seven, and lost all five Tests. Yet that tour was successful compared to the one they have just completed, on which they lost every single international - two Tests and five one-day internationals against New Zealand. Normally, the people of the West Indies are near inconsolable when they lose a Test match. Imagine the mood now.
fields.body:
Hansie Cronje hates losing, but at least he can console himself with the thought that these visitors were better than the lot of a year ago. The West Indies won only a single one-day match out of seven, and lost all five Tests. Yet that tour was successful compared to the one they have just completed, on which they lost every single international - two Tests and five one-day internationals against New Zealand. Normally, the people of the West Indies are near inconsolable when they lose a Test match. Imagine the mood now.

The chairman of the selectors, Mike Findlay, released a statement that was unusually harsh for such a mild-mannered man. "Embarrassing" was how he described the result. He detected inconsistencies in the batting, bowling and fielding, which made the team pretty useless in any language. He said that "each member carries a great burden of guilt for having let down [the Caribbean], and subjecting West Indies cricket to tremendous humiliation."

Greg Kite, the big ponderous basketball forward for the outstanding Boston Celtics team of the 1980s, was once described by a sportswriter as "five fouls in a uniform". A West Indian batsman at the crease these days is a slip catch waiting to happen.

Chris Cairns certainly thinks so. Much-improved allrounder though he is, he could not have expected 17 wickets in a couple of Tests, to go with a batting average of 51. Nathan Astle's 74 per innings was more than twice his Test career average (36 plus), and the captain Stephen Fleming who averaged 66 in the series, also played well above himself (Test average 38). Even Courtney Walsh suffered. BBC Sport for one stood ready with the phone numbers of everyone from the Jamaican prime minister down, if, as expected, he broke Kapil Dev's bowling record in New Zealand. Those calls are on hold. Walsh fell well short of the 11 wickets he needed, taking only three very expensive ones. Of the Caribbean bowlers, only Reon King had a good series, taking eight wickets. King, whose style has been compared to Michael Holding, is the only one who seems ready to take over from those amazing old men, Walsh and Ambrose. Mervyn Dillon and Franklin Rose, once The highly regarded, have gone backwards.

The batting? Lara's once-stratospheric average could slip below 50 by year's end. It's now just above 51 and fast heading south. That's still an astonishing record, but it's not if you're Brian Lara. On the plus side, they seem to have found a gutsy, spirited player in the left-handed opener Adrian Griffith. Shivnarine Chanderpaul, who answered to that description a year ago, has become unreliable and his game is riddled with error. Another previously dependable leftie, Jimmy Adams, now looks shot.

The next Test series is against Zimbabwe, ranked ninth out of nine in the Wisden World Championship. Lara admits that even they must now fancy their chances against the Windies. No Zimbabwe series has ever held as much interest as this one: it will be a measure of how far the mighty have fallen, and how much the lowly have progressed. For West Indies, who have still only lost at home once in recent memory (to Mark Taylor's Aussies in 1994-95), there is hardly anything to gain, and a frightening amount to lose.

After Zimbabwe, West Indies entertain Pakistan, and then come to England. Anglo-Caribbeans who are unsure of how they score in the Tebbit test will at least have had some of their disappointment lifted with England's win in Pretoria. The majority who happily fail the test had better be prepared to think the unthinkable this summer - an England series win. The last two series between the sides in England, in 1991 and 1995, were both 2 -2 draws, and West Indies were much stronger then than now. Phil Tufnell squared the '91 series with a fabulous performance at The Oval, taking six for 25. The Cat's reputation may have been dented in South Africa, but on that day he was at his brilliant bounding best.

But back to the Windies. The '95 team included a Brian Lara who had not long ago set two new world batting records. Lara 2000 is looking and sounding like a man with a broken spirit. I make England the favourites.

webTitle: What to do if you want to jump ship

fields.headline: What to do if you want to jump ship
fields.trailText: Our step-by-step guide to swapping your mortgage.
fields.body:
1 Ask your lender what it will cost to repay early redemption penalties.

2 Ask if the bank or building society can switch you into a better deal.

3 Look at what is available elsewhere. If you are looking to another special deal, seek one with penalties that last no longer than the period on which you would have paid penalties anyway. Note all set-up fees with the new lender, including arrangement fees, solicitors' costs, valuation fees and any other charges.

4 Work out your total payments over what remains of the fixed period.

5 Calculate payments on the new deal over the same period. Deduct these from total payments on your existing deal.

webTitle: A sea of choices for those who switch

fields.headline: A sea of choices for those who switch
fields.trailText: Discounts offer a reduction on a lender's standard loan rates. They rise and fall with rates generally. There is some uncertainty over how much further variable rates will fall and, therefore, the level to which a discount will take your payments. But the general trend is still expected to be downwards, although broker Clive Miers thinks there will be a gentle drift over three years, rather than a thud over two.
fields.body:
Discounts offer a reduction on a lender's standard loan rates. They rise and fall with rates generally. There is some uncertainty over how much further variable rates will fall and, therefore, the level to which a discount will take your payments. But the general trend is still expected to be downwards, although broker Clive Miers thinks there will be a gentle drift over three years, rather than a thud over two.

Some analysts believe variable rates will reach 5 per cent within two years. If this is the case, borrowers should do well from discounts.

Fixed rates offer certainty in monthly payments and rates of less than 5 per cent are available, although not for much longer. If the standard variable rate comes down to 5 per cent in that time, fixes may not look so good.

But Patrick Bunton of broker London & Country says the variable rate still has a long way to go to fall below today's better fixes. And borrowers will have saved money in the meantime. Fixes suit people who want or need certainty.

Capped rates can fall but not rise above their 'cap'. But even though rates may fall generally, don't expect your capped mortgage to come down until your lender's standard rate is below the cap.

Flexiloans such as those from Virgin, Woolwich, Legal & General and Standard Life are designed less for their rate benefits than for the option to increase or decrease the debt at will or take payment holidays. You can repay chunks as you like without penalty, whereas fixes, discounts and caps will usually penalise you.

Rates on flexiloans are not quite as keen as on special rate deals. But Standard Life's product, at 6.05 per cent, discounted to 4.55 per cent for the first six months, has been earning it a place in best buy tables.

Euro loans are only for people whose pay comes in euros, and even then only for the risk-aware. Even if you pay and borrow in euros, you could end up with a loan that swells if the pound falls. Abbey National's new euro loan has a rate of 4.57 per cent which, though attractive, is not that wide of the better sterling deals available now. So don't get carried away with the idea that a euro loan will always be cheaper.

fields.headline: The best maternal scene
fields.standfirst: Mystery Men
fields.trailText: As aspirant world saviour and deadly cutlery thrower The Blue Raja (Hank Azaria) rummages in the drawers for spare silverware, his mother (Louise Lasser) peers around the kitchen door. Her faces registers deep and profound shock.
fields.body:
As aspirant world saviour and deadly cutlery thrower The Blue Raja (Hank Azaria) rummages in the drawers for spare silverware, his mother (Louise Lasser) peers around the kitchen door. Her faces registers deep and profound shock.

"Jeffrey?" she stammers. "What are you doing?"

The Raja turns to face her, stoicism etched into his face: it's time to come clean.

"I'm a superhero, mother", he begins. "An effete British superhero, to be precise. And I'm pilfering your silverware because I hurl it. I hurl it with deadly accuracy. The Blue Raja is my name and, yes, I know I don't wear much blue, and I speak with a British accent, but if you know your history, it really does make sense..."

He trails off; his mother stands before him, her jaw hanging open.

"Anyway, the point, mother, is that your son's a limey fork-flinger. Ha! Hard cheese to swallow I know, but there it is."

The Raja feigns indifference to the gravity of the situation.

"What will the bridge club think, eh mother?"

The shock begins to fade from his mother's eyes, to be replaced by a warm glow of maternal warmth. Finally she speaks.

"You need more forks?"

See also: Psycho, The Manchurian Candidate, Carrie

Don't see also: Stop! Or My Mom Will Shoot

Pointless trivia: As a regular contributor to The Simpsons, Hank Azaria has provided the voices for (among others) Apu, Moe, Chief Wiggum, the Comic Book Guy, Lou, Carl, Dr Nick Riviera, Snake, Professor Frink, Kirk Van Houten and the Bumblebee Man.

webTitle: Agile Pope defies retirement rumour at unity ceremony

fields.headline: Agile Pope defies retirement rumour at unity ceremony
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II exuded a spontaneity, agility and joy not seen for years yesterday at a ceremony of Christian unity in Rome which helped to dispel rumours of his imminent retirement.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II exuded a spontaneity, agility and joy not seen for years yesterday at a ceremony of Christian unity in Rome which helped to dispel rumours of his imminent retirement.

The Pope clinched the first triumph of the Vatican's holy year with a bravura performance which astonished observers, who had expected a shuffling, ailing pontiff.

Looking down at the Archbishop of Canterbury, George Carey, and Orthodox church leaders, the 79-year-old electrified his audience with an unscripted shout of "Unity! Thank you!"

He arrived at the basilica of St Paul's Outside the Walls with a brisk step instead of being wheeled on the mobile platform he is normally forced to use because of his difficulty in walking.

Speculation that the Pope might step down was revived when the National Catholic Reporter, a US magazine, published a long-standing rumour that he had written a resignation letter to be activated if he became senile.

But papal aides were jubilant at having scored a "double whammy" by demonstrating John Paul's robustness during one of the holy year's most significant events.

John Paul symbolised his dream of healing division among Christians by pushing open the door of St Paul's with the help of Dr Carey and Metropolitan Athanasios, who represented Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I, the spiritual leader of the world's Orthodox Christians.

"It was a total triumph for the Pope. He was like the man we used to know," said Marco Tosatti, the Vatican correspondent for La Stampa. "It showed what the Pope has been saying privately - that he has no plans to retire, at least not until after the holy year."

Speculation over an imminent vacancy and a race for succession would be cooled, at least in the short term, said Mr Tosatti. Karl Lehmann, the head of the German bishops, last week unleashed a frenzy of speculation after suggesting the Pope should resign if he felt too ill to continue.

A consensus is emerging that for a variety of reasons, the Pope's successor is likely to be either an Italian or a Latin American.

But the growing ambition of John Paul's travel plans confirms the Vatican's confidence: trips to Egypt, Israel and Portugal, plus an invitation to Brazil under consideration.

Margaret Hebblethwaite, a theologian and Vatican expert, said yesterday's performance would bolster those advising the Pope to cling on - despite his pain and the suspected Parkinson's disease which is thought to cause his trembling and slurred voice.

"The advisers are sycophants and they will never tell him to retire. They all tell him how wonderful he is doing. It's like an old-fashioned court."

The Pope's sense of mission and enjoyment of his job - at which even critics admit he excels - would reinforce the advice, said Ms Hebblethwaite.

"In any case, it would be a nightmare scenario for any successor if he did retire, because he wouldn't be able to let go. It would be like Margaret Thatcher to the power of 10."

The Vatican's success in enticing non-Catholic leaders to attend a holy year (or jubilee) ceremony, was unexpected because jubilee excesses, such as the sale of privileges, are regarded as having contributed to the break-up of Christianity.

Only one cushion for kneeling was provided at the basilica door because officials did not expect the Anglican and Orthodox representatives to get down on their knees. But they did, in a gesture of unity.

A series of Orthodox figures in black robes each offered John Paul a double-cheeked kiss of peace. An American woman, Frances Alguire, greeted him as president of the World Methodist Council.

The participants, which included Lutherans and Pentecostals, symbolically asked each other pardon for the sins committed against Christian unity in the past millennium.

The Pope said: "We know we are brothers still divided, but we have placed ourselves with decisive conviction on the path that leads to full unity."

webTitle: Net fuels huge growth in fraud

fields.headline: Net fuels huge growth in fraud
fields.standfirst: Fastest growing crime is online in England and WalesE-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Crime on the internet is driving the biggest growth area in illegal activity in England and Wales, fraud and forgery, which has risen by 29% or 70,000 offences in the past year, according to the latest official crime figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Crime on the internet is driving the biggest growth area in illegal activity in England and Wales, fraud and forgery, which has risen by 29% or 70,000 offences in the past year, according to the latest official crime figures published yesterday.

Apart from the 19% rise in street robberies in inner cities, the increasing volume of credit card fraud on the internet has pushed crime figures up for the first time in six years.

The head of home office research, Paul Wiles, said yesterday that although some of the 29% increase was due to increased reporting and changes in the counting rules, cyber-crime was increasing.

This marked the first official acknowledgement that credit card fraud was a significant emerging problem after months in which the banks, credit companies and eletronic retailers have scorned media "scare stories" and insisted that fraud on the net was a minor problem.

The banking industry's credit card research group has shown that although the internet was only responsible for 2% of all credit and debit card transactions it now generated 50% of all complaints.

Most cover cases where people have ordered the wrong goods by accident or where retailers do not put their publicly recognised names on credit card statements, but they also involve genuine cases of fraud. They ranged from be ing charged for goods or services never received to the worst cases when credit card numbers are sold to other fraudsters.

Anthony Abrahams of the Canadian-based Fraud Watch, said the problem was that credit cards were designed to be used for face to face transactions not for deals over the net or telephone.

Safeguards - such as signatures, magnetic strips and holograms - were of little help in cyberspace. He suggested that their best virtue was probably the £50 limit on an individual's liability if caught up in fraud.

But the British banking industry is hoping that the introduction of "smart" credit cards with microchips over the next two years will go some way to solving this new crime problem.

The Consumer's Association said it believed the use of credit cards on the internet was safe as long as strict guidelines were followed.

New home
The worldwide web address sky.com has been bought by BSkyB from Sky Computers of Massachusetts for an undisclosed sum. The existing web addresses will default to the new location.

Hard copy
Online travel company ebookers.com plans Britain's biggest outdoor advertising campaign with 3,200 posters and is planning similar campaigns in Germany, France and Scandinavia.

fields.headline: Spare the child
fields.standfirst:
It's a pity that the government won't give our children a straightforward right not to be hit

• Child groups fight right to smack
• More about the Children are unbeatable! campaign
fields.trailText: Asked if we love our children, few of us would be backward in coming forward. Asked which of us would sacrifice our legal right to hit our own children, a swingeing 70% of parents would apparently put their hands down.
fields.body:
Asked if we love our children, few of us would be backward in coming forward. Asked which of us would sacrifice our legal right to hit our own children, a swingeing 70% of parents would apparently put their hands down.

A friend told me the story of taking his five-year-old daughter up to bed. She immediately came downstairs, so he smacked her and took her back up. Down she came again, so he smacked her harder, and took her up again. Within minutes she was downstairs. At this point he knew he would literally have to beat her into submission or think of something else. Luckily for her - for both of them - he realised there must be another way.

The British Medical Journal recently reported a large-scale Canadian survey in which adults who had been slapped or spanked as children were twice as likely as those who had not to have alcohol or drug problems and to show antisocial behaviour. The point is this: even if it were only the teeniest, hardly measurable bit harmful, why would we want to take the risk with those we love most?

The United Nations convention on the rights of the child, ratified by the UK in l991, says: "State parties shall take all appropriate legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to protect the child from all forms of physical or mental violence..."

It is puzzling, therefore, that freshly into the 21st century we still sanction violence towards children and even plead for its continuance. It is a very simple question: "should children have the same right not to be hit as adults have?" And yet it is a proposition that throws us into immediate panic. Partly, it seems, from reluctance to condemn ourselves or our parents for actions that appeared absolutely correct at the time. But we can move forward. Many grandparents I know who did hit their children wouldn't dream of hitting their grandchildren.

Children's rights have always proceeded very slowly. It was the factories act of l833 which stopped children having to work more than 10 hours a day. Next they were prevented from having to go up chimneys - no doubt to choruses of "but how will we clean the chimneys". Amazingly it wasn't until l944 that all children got the statutory right to education, but it still took until l986 - barely 15 years ago - to stop them being physically punished in schools.

I remember my brother being beaten in boarding school with a ferule - a piece of leather containing a whale bone - at the age of eight, and although we children were gleefully appalled by this, it did not occur to any of us that it was barbaric.

Eight European countries now have a law against smacking. In Sweden, before they introduced the ban 20 years ago, attitudes were similar to those in Britain. Now only 6% of people under 35 support smacking. Ask a young Swede if they would hit their child and it would be like asking someone here if they would burn their child with a cigarette.

So what is the point of having a law that would be difficult to enforce? In order to state unequivocally that hitting children is wrong. And to change attitudes, as a no-smacking law has done, dramatically, in Sweden. Even people who slightly exceed the speed limit still agree that there should be a law which saves countless lives on the road.

Children Are Unbeatable is an alliance of 250 organisations including the royal colleges of GPs, paediatricians, psychiatrists and midwives, Dr Barnados, Save the Children, chief constables, the NSPCC and National Children's Bureau, as well as hundreds of individuals who want a total ban on smacking. They do not want grey areas. They believe that it would benefit both children and parents if a clear message were given.

For the last 140 years we have had a law which confirmed parents' right, "for the purposes of correcting what is evil in a child", to use "reasonable chastisement"; this has included the use of canes, electric flexes, horsewhips, belts, hairbrushes and slippers. The government may be about to change that. It has a golden opportunity to take the rational and logical step of giving children the same protection under the law as adults. But it probably won't. Instead it seems to have fallen into the idiocy of trying to define how often, at what age, on which parts of the body and with what severity you may hit a child. A minefield if ever there was one.

The most recent government research from the department of health says that over 90% of children studied were physically punished and that three-quarters of babies were smacked in their first year. Almost a quarter of seven-year-olds had experienced "severe" punishment by mothers (defined as involving "intention or potential to cause injury or psychological damage").

The most serious aspect of smacking children is that in a substantial number of cases this escalates to something worse. Parents readily admit to hitting harder if a child does not obey. Children can be both brave and stubborn; we all know what happens next to the child who says: "That didn't hurt".

People are seriously concerned about the level of violence in society and yet persistently refuse to see any connection between this and violence inflicted on children in the home.

It is uncivilised to use violence towards children. So what's the alternative? Positive discipline focuses on good behaviour and approval, so that children are motivated to go on trying. Making children feel confident and good about themselves is far more effective than humiliating and hurting them.

To put it in perspective, imagine yourself at a smart dinner party with your spouse who, in the course of the evening, contradicts you. You respond with a quick clip round the ear or possibly a sharp rap over the knuckles with a knife-handle. A frisson of horror ripples round the table, yet we think nothing of men and women perhaps four or five times the bodyweight of the average two-year-old hitting them around the head and body, sometimes on a daily basis, for no greater crime.

Most of us with children can understand the frustration of a parent, driven beyond endurance, who hits out. The responsibility should, nevertheless, be placed squarely on the shoulders of the adult and not on the child, however provoking. The law should not exist for the benefit of the parent who loses control, it should be there to protect the countless children who are brutalised on a daily basis. Parents don't need the right to smack their children.

People are preoccupied with the idea that their children or their neighbours' might take them to court if the law changed, but trivial smacks on children are unlikely to be prosecuted any more than adults are currently prosecuted for trivial assaults on each other. There is a protocol for pursuing such actions and minor assaults are not usually permitted to waste police time or money.

A no-smacking ban will not produce rude or anarchic children. Children learn respect for others through example. Were I to hit my eight-year-old I would so instantly cede the moral high ground, the gesture would be worthless. As for my five-year-old, hitting her would exponentially increase any rebelliousness I was trying to quell.

With a strong public education campaign most parents would adjust rapidly to a ban on smacking. The majority of parents don't want to hit their children and would welcome the clarity such a law entails. I'm confident people would quickly begin to find more effective ways of encouraging good behaviour in their children, and that has to be progress.

I profoundly hope that in 20 years time we won't have to look back and admit we were the generation that fought for the right to carry on hitting children.

fields.bodyText: Asked if we love our children, few of us would be backward in coming forward. Asked which of us would sacrifice our legal right to hit our own children, a swingeing 70% of parents would apparently put their hands down. A friend told me the story of taking his five-year-old daughter up to bed. She immediately came downstairs, so he smacked her and took her back up. Down she came again, so he smacked her harder, and took her up again. Within minutes she was downstairs. At this point he knew he would literally have to beat her into submission or think of something else. Luckily for her - for both of them - he realised there must be another way. The British Medical Journal recently reported a large-scale Canadian survey in which adults who had been slapped or spanked as children were twice as likely as those who had not to have alcohol or drug problems and to show antisocial behaviour. The point is this: even if it were only the teeniest, hardly measurable bit harmful, why would we want to take the risk with those we love most? The United Nations convention on the rights of the child, ratified by the UK in l991, says: "State parties shall take all appropriate legislative, administrative, social and educational measures to protect the child from all forms of physical or mental violence..." It is puzzling, therefore, that freshly into the 21st century we still sanction violence towards children and even plead for its continuance. It is a very simple question: "should children have the same right not to be hit as adults have?" And yet it is a proposition that throws us into immediate panic. Partly, it seems, from reluctance to condemn ourselves or our parents for actions that appeared absolutely correct at the time. But we can move forward. Many grandparents I know who did hit their children wouldn't dream of hitting their grandchildren. Children's rights have always proceeded very slowly. It was the factories act of l833 which stopped children having to work more than 10 hours a day. Next they were prevented from having to go up chimneys - no doubt to choruses of "but how will we clean the chimneys". Amazingly it wasn't until l944 that all children got the statutory right to education, but it still took until l986 - barely 15 years ago - to stop them being physically punished in schools. I remember my brother being beaten in boarding school with a ferule - a piece of leather containing a whale bone - at the age of eight, and although we children were gleefully appalled by this, it did not occur to any of us that it was barbaric. Eight European countries now have a law against smacking. In Sweden, before they introduced the ban 20 years ago, attitudes were similar to those in Britain. Now only 6% of people under 35 support smacking. Ask a young Swede if they would hit their child and it would be like asking someone here if they would burn their child with a cigarette. So what is the point of having a law that would be difficult to enforce? In order to state unequivocally that hitting children is wrong. And to change attitudes, as a no-smacking law has done, dramatically, in Sweden. Even people who slightly exceed the speed limit still agree that there should be a law which saves countless lives on the road. Children Are Unbeatable is an alliance of 250 organisations including the royal colleges of GPs, paediatricians, psychiatrists and midwives, Dr Barnados, Save the Children, chief constables, the NSPCC and National Children's Bureau, as well as hundreds of individuals who want a total ban on smacking. They do not want grey areas. They believe that it would benefit both children and parents if a clear message were given. For the last 140 years we have had a law which confirmed parents' right, "for the purposes of correcting what is evil in a child", to use "reasonable chastisement"; this has included the use of canes, electric flexes, horsewhips, belts, hairbrushes and slippers. The government may be about to change that. It has a golden opportunity to take the rational and logical step of giving children the same protection under the law as adults. But it probably won't. Instead it seems to have fallen into the idiocy of trying to define how often, at what age, on which parts of the body and with what severity you may hit a child. A minefield if ever there was one. The most recent government research from the department of health says that over 90% of children studied were physically punished and that three-quarters of babies were smacked in their first year. Almost a quarter of seven-year-olds had experienced "severe" punishment by mothers (defined as involving "intention or potential to cause injury or psychological damage"). The most serious aspect of smacking children is that in a substantial number of cases this escalates to something worse. Parents readily admit to hitting harder if a child does not obey. Children can be both brave and stubborn; we all know what happens next to the child who says: "That didn't hurt". People are seriously concerned about the level of violence in society and yet persistently refuse to see any connection between this and violence inflicted on children in the home. It is uncivilised to use violence towards children. So what's the alternative? Positive discipline focuses on good behaviour and approval, so that children are motivated to go on trying. Making children feel confident and good about themselves is far more effective than humiliating and hurting them. To put it in perspective, imagine yourself at a smart dinner party with your spouse who, in the course of the evening, contradicts you. You respond with a quick clip round the ear or possibly a sharp rap over the knuckles with a knife-handle. A frisson of horror ripples round the table, yet we think nothing of men and women perhaps four or five times the bodyweight of the average two-year-old hitting them around the head and body, sometimes on a daily basis, for no greater crime. Most of us with children can understand the frustration of a parent, driven beyond endurance, who hits out. The responsibility should, nevertheless, be placed squarely on the shoulders of the adult and not on the child, however provoking. The law should not exist for the benefit of the parent who loses control, it should be there to protect the countless children who are brutalised on a daily basis. Parents don't need the right to smack their children. People are preoccupied with the idea that their children or their neighbours' might take them to court if the law changed, but trivial smacks on children are unlikely to be prosecuted any more than adults are currently prosecuted for trivial assaults on each other. There is a protocol for pursuing such actions and minor assaults are not usually permitted to waste police time or money. A no-smacking ban will not produce rude or anarchic children. Children learn respect for others through example. Were I to hit my eight-year-old I would so instantly cede the moral high ground, the gesture would be worthless. As for my five-year-old, hitting her would exponentially increase any rebelliousness I was trying to quell. With a strong public education campaign most parents would adjust rapidly to a ban on smacking. The majority of parents don't want to hit their children and would welcome the clarity such a law entails. webTitle: Child groups fight right to smack

fields.headline: Child groups fight right to smack
fields.standfirst: More about the Children are unbeatable! campaign
fields.trailText: Children's rights campaigners last night accused the government of failing to protect youngsters and hiding behind the legal system after refusing to abolish parents' right to smack under new legislation.
fields.body:
Children's rights campaigners last night accused the government of failing to protect youngsters and hiding behind the legal system after refusing to abolish parents' right to smack under new legislation.

Save the Children accused ministers of passing the buck by suggesting courts use a checklist to determine if a beating was legally justifiable.

The NSPCC spoke of its "huge disappointment" at a missed opportunity. "Playing around with legal definitions of how and in what circumstances children can be hit is a recipe for confusion and fear for parents and keeps children at risk," said a spokesman.

The condemnation followed the launch of a department of health consultation document, Protecting Children; Supporting Parents, which proposes tightening the law in relation to assaults on children.

As the Guardian revealed yesterday, the document proposes banning parents from hitting children around the head, eyes and ears and from using any implements such as canes, belts or slippers.

Parents could receive jail sentences of up to five years - but such punishments would be at the judge's discretion, with courts being asked to consider the age and sex of the child, the severity of the beating, why it occurred, and its duration.

Launching the document - which will be circulated among leading children's organisations, libraries, parents' groups, local authorities and social services until the end of April - John Hutton, the health minister, stressed its aim was "to strengthen the protection of children against abuse".

He insisted banning smacking was not an option. "We accept and protect the rights of parents to discipline children within the proper framework of the criminal law and we are trying to do that in a way that is not intrusive and wouldn't criminalise perfectly ordinary parents who are doing a very difficult job," he said.

"The majority of parents know the difference between a mild physical rebuke and an abusive assault. We don't in any way wish this to be seen as a nanny state restricting the rights of parents."

The government is being forced to change the existing 140 year old law after a European court of human rights ruling on the case of a nine-year-old beaten with a 3ft pole by his stepfather.

fields.headline: Mandelson agrees makeover for RUC
fields.trailText:
Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, will today announce
the Royal Ulster Constabulary is to be renamed when he tells the
Commons he is rubber-stamping almost all Chris Patten's
controversial recommendations for reforming the 78-year-old
force.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, will today announce the Royal Ulster Constabulary is to be renamed when he tells the Commons he is rubber-stamping almost all Chris Patten's controversial recommendations for reforming the 78-year-old force.

The RUC, at the forefront of fighting terrorism for 30 years, is to be renamed the Police Service of Northern Ireland. There is now expected to be no move to allow the name RUC to stand alongside the new description.

The force's crown and harp badge, supported among officers' widows, will also change. But, in a rare departure from Mr Patten's 175 recommendations, it is thought the emblems of the British and Irish traditions will remain in a re-designed badge.

Mr Mandelson will also recognise unionist reservations about a key aspect of Mr Patten's report. He will unveil proposals to cut the powers of the proposed local policing boards, aiming to limit the chance for paramilitaries to seize influence on these bodies.

The Police Association yesterday began talks with civil servants at Stormont on the likely severance package as Mr Mandelson seeks to cut the 13,000 strong force almost in half through voluntary redundancies.

The policing authority is expected to be abolished and replaced with a new policing board for Northern Ireland. It will include 19 members, 10 of them politicians appointed under the d'Hondt system, giving Sinn Fein at least two places on it.

There will also be changes in recruitment, designed to ensure new intakes are drawn equally from the Protestant and Catholic communities. That will mean the introduction of a qualifying standard in entrance tests, rather than simply as now taking the best scoring applicants.

Mr Mandelson's aim is to secure a force which is one-third Catholic within 10 years, a development which will depend on Sinn Fein's approach to the Patten report. Catholics make up just over 40% of the population in Northern Ireland.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, said it was too soon to say whether he could recommend young republicans to join the new force. He would wait for the legislation before announcing Sinn Fein's approach. The SDLP is strongly in favour.

Mr Mandelson is today expected to underline the sacrifices of the RUC, which he believes was underplayed in Mr Patten's report. Since Constable Victor Arbuckle died in Belfast in October 1969, another 301 police officers have been murdered. Almost 9,000 have been injured.

webTitle: Ex-spin doctor tells almost all about Blair's euro embarrassment

fields.headline: Ex-spin doctor tells almost all about Blair's euro embarrassment
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The secret of the Red Lion affair that rocked the new Labour government and shook the stock market was disclosed last night.
fields.body:
The secret of the Red Lion affair that rocked the new Labour government and shook the stock market was disclosed last night.

Charlie Whelan, then treasury press secretary, admitted it was not only journalists he spoke to from the Whitehall pub to announce that Britain would not join the single currency in this parliament. He also took a call on his mobile phone from a very senior - and very angry - member of the government trying to discover what was happening.

Tony Blair, marooned in Chequers on that frantic Friday night in the late autumn of 1997, was desperate to discover what was being briefed to newspapers about the euro.

Unable to get hold of Gordon Brown, the chancellor, or Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's official spokesman, Mr Blair tracked down Mr Whelan. The chancellor's spin doctor, in a show of respect for the PM, put down his white wine spritzer and left the Red Lion to speak in privacy.

Mr Blair had been tipped off by Peter Mandelson, then minister without portfolio in the cabinet office, that an interview with the chancellor in the next day's Times would harden the existing "wait and see" line. His decision to call Mr Whelan suggests that he was in the dark about the timing of the shift and possibly even the precise line.

Mr Whelan, overheard briefing reporters in the Red Lion by a Liberal Democrat researcher, let slip the secret call in a speech to a Royal Bank of Scotland dinner in London. "Blair couldn't get hold of anybody. Campbell had gone awol and Gordon Brown was doing his constituency surgery," said Mr Whelan, who is now co-presenter of Radio 5 Live's Sunday Service programme.

"One day I might tell exactly what he said. Someone at GCHQ will have a tape of it. He was not a happy bunny. The only person I spoke to on my mobile phone that night out side the Red Lion was the PM."

Mr Whelan may have been unusually reticent about what was discussed, but a former minister was more forthcoming: "Charlie told Blair: 'Sorry, mate, it's too late'. The PM will never forget how he heard his government's European policy had been announced to the world."

webTitle: Euro: Sceptics winning battle over currency as Cook and Brown argue

fields.headline: Euro: Sceptics winning battle over currency as Cook and Brown argue
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Opposition to Britain's entry to the European single currency has reached a record 63% of the electorate according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll with the eurosceptics opening up a massive 38 point lead over the 25% of voters who say they would vote to join.
fields.body:
Opposition to Britain's entry to the European single currency has reached a record 63% of the electorate according to the latest Guardian/ICM opinion poll with the eurosceptics opening up a massive 38 point lead over the 25% of voters who say they would vote to join.

The monthly Guardian/ICM euro referendum tracking index for January shows that the absence of any government campaign to persuade voters of the benefits of the euro and the fall in the value of single currency since its launch a year ago have combined to consolidate the level of opposition to entry firmly above the 60% mark.

The eurosceptics appeared to have filled the political vacuum left by the government and are simply walking away with the argument.

The details of the poll on the euro show that women are more hostile to the idea than men. The results show that 64% of women are against the single currency and 22% are in favour while 62% of men are against and 29% are in favour.

While, as expected Conservative voters are the most hostile splitting 84% to 12%, even a majority of Labour (56% to 33%) and Liberal Democrats (57% to 34%) voters say they would vote against entry in a referendum.

The poll findings add to the government's dilemma over British entry to the European single currency: Tony Blair must decide whether to wait until public opinion changes or else lead a campaign to try to turn it around.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, has become the government's cheerleader for the euro. The foreign office is worried that Britain will lose foreign investors such as Toyota, which hinted on Monday it might move elsewhere if Britain does not join up.

Mr Cook also believes that tactically Labour will be vulnerable unless it has a clear line on the euro going into the next general election. But the chancellor, Gordon Brown, though in favour of a single currency, sees no need for a headlong rush, arguing that Britain should not consider entry until the stability of the euro is assured.

The treasury claims to be confident that, in spite of the poll findings, public opinion will begin to switch in favour of the euro once it becomes clear it is a success.

Mr Blair is caught in the middle, fearful that a strong commitment to the euro or an indication of the timing for the referendum will see the rightwing press engage in a relent less campaign that will cost important seats at the general election.

The poll provides ammunition for both sides of the argument: those who advocate a cautious approach and those who say that British hostility will become ingrained unless the government begins campaigning.

The ICM results also show that while Labour has been shaken by the row over standards in the national health service in the past week it has had little impact on the party's opinion poll rating.

The Conservatives appear to be in the early stages of a slow recovery after a damaging month dominated by the memories of Jeffrey Archer, Jonathan Aitken and Neil Hamilton but appear to be as far away as ever from being seen as an electable force. The figures show Labour down one on 47%; the Conservatives up one on 30%, and the Liberal Democrats unchanged at 17%.

ICM interviewed a random sample of 1,155 adults aged over 18 by telephone between 14-17 January 2000. Interviews were conducted across the country and the results have been weighted to the profile of all adults.

webTitle: Cuban exiles thank God for their saviour from the sea

fields.headline: Cuban exiles thank God for their saviour from the sea
fields.standfirst: A boy's rescue is seen as a heaven-sent miracle by US rightwingers, writes Julian Borger in Miami
fields.trailText: It is a humble home compared with some of the stucco palaces in Miami's Little Havana - and in the eyes of the faithful gathered around the fence, its modesty is fitting. For them, it is a shrine to a Cuban miracle.
fields.body:
It is a humble home compared with some of the stucco palaces in Miami's Little Havana - and in the eyes of the faithful gathered around the fence, its modesty is fitting. For them, it is a shrine to a Cuban miracle.

It is difficult to understand the ferocity of the movement to keep six-year-old Elian Gonzalez in Miami without witnessing the religious fervour with which he has been embraced by devout Catholic conservatives among the Cuban exile community here.

Outside the house, owned by Elian's great-uncle, Lazaro, a trio of one-metre figures have been planted like latterday saints: Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse and Santa Claus. They are just a few of the lorryful of gaudy gifts unloaded on the little boy since he was plucked out of the Straits of Florida on November 25 after seeing his mother and 12 other Cubans drown while trying to reach the United States. At night the plastic trinity is illuminated by fairy lights.

The spiritual imagery is no accident. The rightwing activists who have surrounded Elian and now bask in the media glow emphasise the religious significance of his appearance at every turn. "There is something mythical about him," said Jose Basulto, an exile leader. "He has come to us as a sign sent from God . . . the child has united the Cuba community in exile."

Whatever other miracles he is being credited with, Elian has certainly come to the salvation of the Cuban right. His presence has provided a rallying cry and a shot of adrenalin at a time when the hardliners' influence among young Cuban Americans was dwindling, along with their absolutist influence on US foreign policy.

Before Elian was found bobbing on the waves clinging to an inner tube, Washington had begun to lose its fear of the electoral clout wielded by the hardliners. In 1994 the US started returning refugees found on the open water back to Cuba, much to the disgust of Brothers to the Rescue, Mr Basulto's radical group, which patrolled the seas to guide them to an American haven.

The change in policy meant that Cubans were no longer a special case. They were no longer exiles waiting to return at any moment, but just another immigrant community.

Then, in November 1997, Jorge Mas Canosa, the patriarchal boss of Cuban exile politics, died, leaving a vacuum that has been filled by new moderate groups, almost as resentful of the dominance of Mas Canosa's Cuban-American National Foundation in south Florida as they were of Fidel Castro's alleged tyranny across the straits.

Meanwhile the embargo has been eroding at an accelerating rate. Last year the US allowed charter flights to Havana for the first time in 40 years and permitted social and cultural links between Americans and Cubans.

For the diehards, Elian's arrival has reawakened the aggressive street-level activism that was once the hallmark of their political strength. The Yanqui politicians are once more beginning to take notice, and opposition to Elian's return to Cuba has become a touchstone for Republican presidential candidates. Even the vice-president, Al Gore, has been trying to distance himself from the immigration department, which is trying to reunite the child with his father in Havana.

"This child has been elevated to the level of a saint, and no one knows whether he has ever been baptised," complained Elena Freyre, a moderate Cuban-American leader. Her organisation, Cuban Committee for Democracy, believes, like a significant minority of Cuban exiles, that Elian should be reunited with his father. But their voices have been unheard, so strong are the emotions being whipped up around Elian.

Max Castro, a Cuban-American analyst at Miami university, sees the quasi-religious Elian-mania as the last gasp of the Batista generation. "They find they cannot control the future of the Cuban nation," he said. "But they can control the future of one little boy."

Then, in November 1997, Jorge Mas Canosa, the patriarchal boss of Cuban exile politics, died, leaving a vacuum that has been filled by new moderate groups, almost as resentful of the dominance of Mas Canosa's Cuban-American National Foundation in south Florida as they were of Fidel Castro's alleged tyranny across the straits. Meanwhile the embargo has been eroding at an accelerating rate. Last year the US allowed charter flights to Havana for the first time in 40 years and permitted social and cultural links between Americans and Cubans. For the diehards, Elian's arrival has reawakened the aggressive street-level activism that was once the hallmark of their political strength. The Yanqui politicians are once more beginning to take notice, and opposition to Elian's return to Cuba has become a touchstone for Republican presidential candidates. Even the vice-president, Al Gore, has been trying to distance himself from the immigration department, which is trying to reunite the child with his father in Havana. "This child has been elevated to the level of a saint, and no one knows whether he has ever been baptised," complained Elena Freyre, a moderate Cuban-American leader. Her organisation, Cuban Committee for Democracy, believes, like a significant minority of Cuban exiles, that Elian should be reunited with his father. But their voices have been unheard, so strong are the emotions being whipped up around Elian. Max Castro, a Cuban-American analyst at Miami university, sees the quasi-religious Elian-mania as the last gasp of the Batista generation. "They find they cannot control the future of the Cuban nation," he said. "But they can control the future of one little boy."

webTitle: Opera gift book hits blue note

fields.headline: Opera gift book hits blue note
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: As opera fan Fred Harrop, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, approached his 80th birthday his friends clubbed together to buy him a special present: a book about a high-flying opera singer.
fields.body:
As opera fan Fred Harrop, of Stockport, Greater Manchester, approached his 80th birthday his friends clubbed together to buy him a special present: a book about a high-flying opera singer.

They ordered through the internet a copy of Cinderella and Company: Backstage at the Opera with Cecilia Bartoli, and the parcel was despatched direct from Amazon.com, complete with a message saying: "We hope you enjoy this book."

Mr Harrop opened the package and was taken aback by the title, Nerve: Literate Smut, Fiction, Essay and Photographs by Genevieve Field, astonished by the chapter headings, Diary of a Nude Girl, A Day in the Life of a Sex Addict, Yuppie Sex and Snapshots of a Lusty Lady, and gobsmacked by the illustrations, 35 pictures of homosexual and heterosexual sex.

Mr Harrop said: "I know the people who sent the present very well and I knew they wouldn't send me that kind of thing. I thought it could have been a joke but they are not the sort of people who would do that.

"In the last few years, I have had a couple of heart attacks so it's fortunate I'm broadminded. The photos are of a very explicit nature."

The friends were mortified. But when they complained to Amazon, they were told: "Well, if you think Mr Harrop is disappointed, imagine how the guy who got the opera book feels."

Amazon has since apologised for the "inappropriate" comment and the muddle and has sent Mr Harrop a £10 voucher.

webTitle: Israeli publication sparks war of words in Egypt

fields.headline: Israeli publication sparks war of words in Egypt
fields.standfirst:
The Arabic translation of Grossman book puts 'cold peace' to the test
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A decision by Egypt's ministry of culture to publish an Arabic translation of a book by the Israeli author David Grossman has sparked a war of words in a country that has officially been at peace with Israel for 20 years.
fields.body:
A decision by Egypt's ministry of culture to publish an Arabic translation of a book by the Israeli author David Grossman has sparked a war of words in a country that has officially been at peace with Israel for 20 years.

The "coldness" of that peace and the continuing debate in Egypt about the nature of ties with Israel have been highlighted by the objections to the book, even though Grossman is generally regarded as sympathetic to the plight of Palestinians.

Yellow Wind includes interviews with Palestinians in the West Bank in 1987 to mark the 20th anniversary of the 1967 Middle East war in which the Arabs lost the West Bank and Gaza Strip to Israeli occupation.

The fact that the book was translated into Arabic by a Palestinian who was commissioned by Beir Zeit university, a West Bank institute strongly associated with Palestinian nationalism, has also failed to silence the culture ministry's detractors.

They argue that publishing a book by an Israeli author constitutes premature normalisation - the term for practical matters such as trade, easy travel, diplomatic recognition, academic exchanges and individual contacts with Israel.

The book has now been handed over to an Egyptian researcher who has just published a weighty tome on Zionism. He has been given the task of deciding whether it is safe to unleash the book on the Egyptian public and may write an introduction aimed at uncovering whatever hidden Zionist ideology lurks within.

Esmat Kandeel, a managing editor at the culture ministry who gave the initial go-ahead for the Arabic translation to be published, said those who criticised her decision were missing the point.

"It's a beautiful book that paints a very painful picture of life under occupation for the Palestinians. I wish everyone would read it," she said.

"The people who have criticised the decision to publish the book haven't even read it. The only reason they object is because it's a book by an Israeli. It's a kind of terrorism. They want us to close our eyes and ears and stay ignorant forever."

Egypt became the first Arab country to sign peace with Israel in 1979 but its citizens remain wary of the Jewish state. Egyptians rarely visit Israel, professional unions forbid dealings with it and opposition parties repeatedly urge the government to suspend the peace treaty.

Organisers of the annual Cairo book fair and international film festival refuse to invite Israel, and opposition newspapers survive on a staple diet of Israeli conspiracy theories.

But Israel seems more eager to embrace Egyptian culture. The Friday evening Egyptian film on Israeli television has been a staple for many years and most Israeli bookshops carry Hebrew translations of the works of Egypt's Nobel prize-winning author Naguib Mahfouz.

Wahid Abdel-Meguid, a political analyst at the Ahram Centre for Political and Strategic Studies in Cairo, said: "The defeated side is always more sensitive than the victorious one.

"Egyptian cultural circles are still not used to dealing with Israeli culture. They feel the conflict is not over and that peace has not been realised and that whatever comes from Israel is loaded with the position and point of view of Israel and leads to furthering its interests, and this causes them to recoil."

Mohammed Madbouli Mohammed, the owner of Madbouli bookshop in central Cairo, sees nothing wrong with selling books by Israeli authors.

"What's wrong with knowing the enemy? They buy all our books. We must pay attention and read and see what this enemy is doing," Mr Mohammed said. "We are in a truce right now, we should take advantage of it by seeing how the enemy lives.

"We must congratulate whoever thought of translating this book. They are not collaborators, they wanted to give us an insight into these people's way of thinking."

fields.headline: Smacking stays legal
fields.standfirst: But the ground rules are still too vague
fields.trailText: True to our national tradition as the last country in Europe to ban corporal punishment in schools, ministers made a glacial move yesterday to providing children with more protection from their parents.
fields.body:
True to our national tradition as the last country in Europe to ban corporal punishment in schools, ministers made a glacial move yesterday to providing children with more protection from their parents. They were required to do so after the European Court of Human Rights ruling in 1998 on a stepfather who had severely and repeatedly beaten his stepson with a three-foot pole, but was found not guilty by a jury because of the old Victorian defence of "reasonable chastisement". The case could not have been a clearer breach of the European Convention on Human Rights, which outlaws inhuman and degrading treatment, but it moves the debate on to the politically more difficult ground of a parental right to smack. Labour ministers, already oversensitive to Tory charges of nanny state tendencies, reacted robustly to the Strasbourg ruling. Paul Boateng was as insistent as Virginia Bottomley, in a 1994 version of this debate, that "smacking has a place in parental discipline. Our law will do nothing to outlaw smacking."

When he issued a deeply unsatisfactory consultation document yesterday, the latest minister charged with handling the issue, John Hutton, did at least produce a more intelligent defence of parental rights. "We accept and protect the rights of parents to discipline children within the proper framework of the criminal law," he said, "and we are trying to do that in a way that is not intrusive and wouldn't criminalise perfectly ordinary parents who are doing a very difficult job in bringing up their children." The minister has ruled out the abolition of the "reasonable chastisement" defence as an impractical, unenforceable and unjustifiable intrusion into family life. This is a respectable position, but only if ministers are ready to produce a modern definition of the Victorian concept, which was set out by a chief justice in an era when parents were even more authoritarian in their approach to child rearing than Paul Boateng.

The problem with the document is that it leaves the definition to the courts. But it was the courts which found the stepfather in the 1998 case not guilty in the first place. It sets out four open ended criteria (context; duration; physical and mental effects; and sex, age and health of the victim) with no further definition. This is far too vague. What prosecutors - and parents - require is something far more specific. Good law requires certain and predictable boundaries.

webTitle: Flu epidemic perks up Boots' medicine sales

fields.headline: Flu epidemic perks up Boots' medicine sales
fields.standfirst:
Retailers' Christmas results fail to impress City
Flu epidemic: special report
fields.trailText: Medicines have been flying off the shelves at Boots as a result of the flu epidemic.
fields.body:
Medicines have been flying off the shelves at Boots as a result of the flu epidemic.

In a trading update yesterday Boots said underlying sales of over-the-counter medicines, which include branded cough and cold cures and painkillers, were up 6.4% while sales of prescribed medicines were up 10% in the three months to the end of December. "Increases of this order are continuing in January, helped by a high incidence of flu and colds", the company said.

Boots, which has had few fans among City investors in the past 12 months, was unveiling Christmas sales figures which analysts described as uninspiring. Overall like-for-like sales at the Boots the Chemists chain were up 2.6% in the six weeks to January 8, with health and beauty products driving that growth with a 4.1% improvement on 1998 levels.

The group's chain of opticians was ahead just 0.8% - and down 2.3% over three months - as a result of tough competition, while the jewel in the crown was its car accessory offshoot Halfords, which posted a like-for-like improvement of 10.5% on last Christmas.

The chairman, Lord Blyth, said the figures were "evidence of the strength of our health and beauty business in the face of heightened price-based competition".

But the City remained unimpressed, with some retail sector specialists saying Boots should have done better after its huge TV advertising campaign in the run-up to Christmas. The shares, which tumbled from 1,030p last year to a four-year low of 532p, closed down 1p yesterday at 540p.

Elsewhere, cheap and cheerful fashion chain New Look is beginning to have a touch of the Marks & Spencer about it and looks frayed at the edges. Its shares, which peaked at 249p last year, fell 12.5p to 117.5p after the company admitted its like-for-like Christmas sales were down 2.5%.

Debenhams also admitted to problems with clothing sales but made up for it with impressive sales of home goods. The department store chain said like-for-like sales in the three weeks before Christmas were up 7%. However, the shares ended down 15p at 177p.

Supermarket chain Budgens found no more City friends, despite a 4.5% improvement in Christmas sales. The chain reported six-month profits of £8.5m, compared to £6.4m a year ago. Like-for-like sales growth over the six months was 4%, compared to the 2.5% growth registered a year ago.

Chief executive John von Spreckelsen said: "We are very encouraged by these results which we believe further underpin our position in the convenience market." But the shares, which had been changing hands at a 12-month peak of 79p, lost 5.5p to 73p.

Distribution group John Menzies, whose only retail interest now is the Early Learning Centre, also disappointed investors. First-half profits were up £0.9m to £4.1m but chief executive David Mackay is desperate to unload ELC. "No one should underestimate the problems of turning around a troubled retailer," he said yesterday.

The group also has problems with its video and music wholesaling division. Its performance was poor in comparison with 1998, when it had the Titanic video to boost sales, and its exclusive Nintendo game distributorship has lost out to Sega's new Dreamcast. The company has £100m to spend on acquisitions but the shares lost 22.5p to finish at 395p.

webTitle: Flu comes from outer space, claim scientists

fields.headline: Flu comes from outer space, claim scientists
fields.standfirst: Flu epidemic: special report
fields.trailText: It made the festive season a misery for many and threw NHS policy into crisis. But the flu may have worse in store, according to scientists who claim to have discovered an alarming explanation for the epidemic - a virus from outer space.
fields.body:
It made the festive season a misery for many and threw NHS policy into crisis. But the flu may have worse in store, according to scientists who claim to have discovered an alarming explanation for the epidemic - a virus from outer space.

Dismissing as dogma the conventional medical wisdom that flu is a virus passed by human contact, the distinguished astrophysicist Sir Fred Hoyle, and his colleague at Cardiff university, Chandra Wickramasinghe, warn that we may be on the brink of a global epidemic.

In a report to be published in the journal Current Science, they claim the outbreak was caused by dust deposited high in the atmosphere by passing comets being forced down to earth by energy generated by cooler patches on the sun's surface, known as sunspots.

They reach the peak of their activity, the maxima, every 11 years, coinciding, the scientists say, with all major flu outbreaks since 1761, including the 1918 Spanish flu pandemic blamed for 20m deaths worldwide. The latest cycle began to peak in September and the maxima is due sometime this year.

fields.headline: Photo-Me chief in £28m moving story
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Serge Crasnianski, the Frenchman who turned the Photo-Me photo-booth business into a hot internet stock, yesterday banked more than £28m by selling less than one tenth of his stake in the company.
fields.body:
Serge Crasnianski, the Frenchman who turned the Photo-Me photo-booth business into a hot internet stock, yesterday banked more than £28m by selling less than one tenth of his stake in the company.

The Photo-Me chief executive sold 7m shares, equal to a 1.9% slice of the firm. A Photo-Me spokesman said he was using the cash to move house. "He has just moved from France to the UK and there are significant costs involved."

Mr Crasnasiaski, who trained as a nuclear physicist and has patented more than 100 inventions, moved in at Photo-Me after the British company bought out his Grenoble-based KIS group, a firm which had started life in the key-cutting business but evolved into digital technology for photo booths.

His masterstroke came with a deal to convert booths into multimedia service centres - offering internet and email facilities. The machines were developed with BT. Photo-Me shares rose from 68p to 470p last year, adding £250m to the value of Mr Crasnianski's 75m shares.

The first 10 new machines, called PhotoPlanet, will be unveiled in London next month.

Mr Crasnianski's move to cash in some of his shares came as Photo-Me unveiled half-year profits up 35.1% to £20.5m. The dividend was hoisted 13.6% to 0.5p and the shares dipped 4p to 401p.
