webTitle: Eidos sheds a third on profits warning

fields.headline: Eidos sheds a third on profits warning
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Eidos, the computer games publisher behind the Tomb Raider series, plunged by almost a third yesterday after the company warned of weak sales among some of its newer titles.
fields.body:
Shares in Eidos, the computer games publisher behind the Tomb Raider series, plunged by almost a third yesterday after the company warned of weak sales among some of its newer titles.

Delays in release dates during the pre-Christmas period and the poor reception given to a number of games would cause full-year profits to be "significantly below" last year the company said. Eidos shares, which reached a high of £66 at the end of last year continued their recent collapse, falling a further £12.17 to £27.08.

"We made the wrong call on a number of titles," admitted Eidos chief executive Charles Cornwall.

The business shipped 5.9m units in the three months to the end of December against 6.2m in 1998 and some of the biggest disappointments, including F1 World Grand Prix will be discontinued.

The warning will raise fears that Eidos continues to be too dependent on the success of its Tomb Raider franchise featuring action hero Lara Croft. The company said that following the disappointment of its other titles, Tomb Raider would account for 40% of revenues this year.

"It would be great if we had half a dozen Tomb Raider lookalikes but we still believe we have a fantastic line up of games," Mr Cornwall said.

webTitle: Hague olive branch on NHS rebuffed

fields.headline: Hague olive branch on NHS rebuffed
fields.standfirst:
Tory call to stop using health as political football backfires as Labour admits pledge of extra cash has strings attached
Tories in opposition: special report

Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and William Hague last night locked horns over the future funding of the health service after the Conservative leader offered "cross-party agreement" and Downing Street admitted that its new NHS spending pledge could not happen without strong economic growth.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and William Hague last night locked horns over the future funding of the health service after the Conservative leader offered "cross-party agreement" and Downing Street admitted that its new NHS spending pledge could not happen without strong economic growth.

Mr Blair's promise to spend 5% more each year on health - to catch up the European average by around 2006 - prompted a Tory attack on what Mr Hague called the "collapse in public confidence" in Labour solutions.

Stung by the criticisms last week by the country's leading fertility expert, Lord Winston, of continuing NHS problems under Labour, Mr Blair signalled on Sunday that his government would make health its number one priority in the second comprehensive spending review, CSR 2000, which the chancellor, Gordon Brown, is now completing.

Amid speculation that ministers may ringfence NHS taxes - the "hypothecation" option which the then Labour leader, Neil Kinnock, embraced before 1992 - Mr Blair's spokesman rejected that course.

He also stressed that a "substantial increase" in health spending was an aspiration, not a pledge.

"I cannot sit here and tell you what the outcome of the CRS for the next six years is going to be. What he [Mr Blair] was clearly doing was signalling a substantial increase in health spending to get us to that [European average] level, allied to the modernisation and reform agenda," he said.

The spokesman stressed: "Everything depends on the competent and efficient management of the economy." Asked about transport and educational needs, he added: "We have always said that education remains the number one priority and that remains the case."

That appeared to water down Mr Blair's apparent commitment to increase extra NHS spending from 3% a year to 5% and gradually raise Britain's total health budget from 6.4% to 8% - roughly what France and Germany spend - by 2006.

Mr Hague and his health spokesman, Liam Fox, poured scorn on that. Labour complacency had brought the NHS to its knees, kept going only by the "Herculean effort" of its staff, Dr Fox told an opposition-initiated Commons debate on the service.

But the Tory leader's offer to both the prime minister and Charles Kennedy, the Lib Dem leader, for them all to stop using the NHS as a political football backfired because his proposed remedy included a commitment to "expanding both the public and the private health sectors".

That is anathema to Mr Blair. His spokesman, Alastair Campbell, told reporters last night that the prime minister "genuinely believes that the Tory right wants to undermine the NHS and move towards a American form of insurance which will be both costly and socially divisive".

Mr Hague and Dr Fox, who say they and their families use the NHS, called such claims an "offensive caricature". But Labour repeated it last night and ruled out any insurance-based solution to the NHS's cash problem.

Mr Hague repeated that he did not wish to privatise the NHS or end the "free at the point of use" principle that has guided it for 50 years. He also dusted off last autumn's "common sense" policy, which would guarantee that patients would be treated according to medical need, and that, if the NHS could not perform an operation in time, it would have to pay the private sector to do so. The Tories argue that the new social security bill will ensure that people with personal medical insurance will be hit by national insurance contributions on such benefits in kind.

By 2006, 300,000 more Britons will die of coronary heart illnesses than die in France, they said.

 The government could potentially save money and provide a better service for patients by handing medical care over to the private sector, according to the Confederation of British Industry.

Firms are already involved in running cleaning and other non-medical services in many hospitals under the controver sial private finance initiative, and the CBI believes there is no reason why the private firms should not employ medical staff as well.

Until now the government has drawn a clear line between contracting out medical and non-medical services and has rejected allowing companies to provide medical care.

But David Metter, a member of the CBI's committee on public procurement, told MPs on the treasury select committee that the line between medical and non-medical services was essentially an arbitrary one and that it would therefore be perfectly feasible for companies to run the entire hospital system.

webTitle: Hospital infections cost NHS £1bn a year

fields.headline: Hospital infections cost NHS £1bn a year
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The cash-strapped NHS is spending nearly £1bn a year to treat patients for infections they have picked up in hospitals, and the cost is likely to rise if the so-called superbug, MRSA, continues to spread.
fields.body:
The cash-strapped NHS is spending nearly £1bn a year to treat patients for infections they have picked up in hospitals, and the cost is likely to rise if the so-called superbug, MRSA, continues to spread.

Yesterday's revelation of the huge cost of infection, which hospitals have been fighting to control without great success since 1959, will add to the pressure on them to improve hospital hygiene. The figures come from a study carried out by the public health laboratory service and the London school of hygiene and tropical medicine, which was commissioned by the department of health.

Infections are spread through hospitals in a variety of ways. Patients are transferred from one bed and one ward to another because of staff shortages. Doctors and nurses have been accused of failing to wash their hands before and after examining patients. A member of the British Medical Association's occupational health committee, Jo Kearns, told the BMA conference 18 months ago that operating theatre staff went to the canteen in their theatre clothing for lack of proper changing facilities. "Even in the theatre, nostrils above masks spray infection into the wound before our very eyes," he said.

Nurses who tried to remind doctors of the need for hygiene were put in their place, he said. "It is my experience that nurses who have asked doctors of any grade to wash their hands are steamrollered."

Dr Kearns blamed hygiene problems on lack of resources. Yesterday's report suggested substantial savings could be made with a little more investment in measures to control and prevent infections.

Rosalind Plowman from the London school, one of the authors, said that if infections were reduced by just 10%, it would release resources worth £93.1m. It could save 364,056 bed days, "equivalent to an estimated 467,902 finished consultant episodes".

"It wouldn't take much of a reduction to start reaping these benefits," said Nicholas Graves, of the London school.

"Staff hand hygiene before and after contact with patients is the single most important thing," said Barry Cookson, director of the laboratory of hospital infection at the PHLS. Other measures to combat in fection include careful cleaning and sterilisation of instruments and use of antibiotics to prevent infection in some patients undergoing surgery.

There are costs for the hospital, costs for the GP if the patient's infection develops after he or she is sent home, and costs for the patient. The report shows that patients who pick up infections spend two and a half times longer in hospital on average than they would have done otherwise, and cost £3,000 more to treat.

The study looked at 4,000 patients from one district general hospital, of whom 7.8% picked up an infection during their stay. In this particular hospital, which is unnamed, only 5% developed MRSA (multi-drug resistant staphylococcus aureus). This is well below the current rate in the UK.

Patients with MRSA are hard to treat, because the bacteria which may infect a wound have developed a resistance to most of the common antibiotics.

If MRSA continues to spread through hospitals at the present rate, the cost of treating infection is bound to rise still further, the report's authors agreed yesterday.

Bug that gets up the nose

MRSA stands for methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus.

It is a type of bacterium carried in the nose of 20%-40% of healthy people and is also commonly found on the skin and causes no harm. However, once it enters the body, under the skin or into the lungs, it causes infections such as boils or pneumonia, skin infections and blood poisoning.

Usually confined to hospitals, and patients in intensive care, burns units, surgical and orthopaedic wards are at greater risk.

Treatment involves antibiotics.

Handwashing before and after contact is the most effective control measure.

fields.headline: Russians close to taking Grozny
fields.standfirst:
Moscow launches fresh military onslaught on Chechen capital and predicts city will fall within a week
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russian troops geared up to seize Grozny yesterday, driving ground forces from three directions towards the centre of the Chechen capital for the first time and predicting that the city would fall this week.
fields.body:
Russian troops geared up to seize Grozny yesterday, driving ground forces from three directions towards the centre of the Chechen capital for the first time and predicting that the city would fall this week.

The ground assault was accompanied by one of the heaviest aerial and artillery poundings of the four-month war. While Russian forecasts about the city's imminent fall have repeatedly proved inaccurate, it appeared that failure would not be countenanced this time.

"The decisive phase of the liberation of Grozny has started," said Konstantin Kukharenko of the Russian defence ministry. Senior officers predicted they would be in control of the city within three to four days.

By last night, however, the confident Russian forecasts were becoming more guarded. At campaign headquarters in Mozdok, the three to four days became one week, while officers stressed they were in no hurry to take the city.

Commercial Russian television showed film of thick black smoke billowing over Grozny as high-rise flats were battered by Russian artillery. Hand-to-hand fighting was reported as the Russians sought to advance on a strategic bridge over the River Sunzha in central Grozny. It appeared the Russians were concentrating on mopping-up operations in areas already under their control rather than pressing on.

The commander of the Russian interior ministry troops fighting for Grozny, Vyacheslav Ovchinnikov, said the guerrillas were in a hopeless position. "There is no light and no heat in Grozny. The fighters are running out of food and ammunition. Reinforcements cannot get through. They can not hold out in the besieged city for long."

The fresh onslaught followed strategic shifts on both sides at the weekend. The previous ground offensive to take Grozny, launched on Christmas Eve, had to be aborted due to guerrilla successes.

Meanwhile the Chechens announced that they were abandoning attempts to hold territory in favour of hit-and-run tactics. Despite yesterday's fierce ground fighting, it may be that the Chechens are opting to leave the city to the Russians and will then harry the occupying army through ambushes and raids.

Yesterday's developments showed how little heed the Russians are paying to outside criticism - the drive to take Grozny coincided with a visit to the region of a delegation from the Council of Europe, led by Lord Russell-Johnston, which is to consider suspending Russian membership of the organisation at a special session next week.

The onslaught also coincided with the first public Russian appeal for a halt to the war. The Union of Committees of Soldiers' Mothers accused Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president and prime minister, of violating international conventions on the conduct of war by attacking civilians. They accuse Moscow of covering up the true number of Russian casualties.

Mikhail Gorbachev, yesterday contradicted the official line by stating that there would be no quick end to the war and that the situation could be much worse in six months.

 An artillery shell exploded yesterday outside the supreme court building in Nazran, the regional capital of Ingushetia, but it caused no casualties.

fields.headline: Puffed up and out
fields.trailText: Clare Short (Vote for Frank, January 17) is right. The GLC was not at all popular until it fell victim to a vendetta waged by the prime minister of the day. Has it occurred to her that the same might be true of Ken Livingstone?
fields.body:
Clare Short (Vote for Frank, January 17) is right. The GLC was not at all popular until it fell victim to a vendetta waged by the prime minister of the day. Has it occurred to her that the same might be true of Ken Livingstone?

Francis King
Wymondham, Norfolk

 Clare Short was wonderful. If I still lived in London this certainly would have swung it for Ken.

Margaret Downing
Cambridge 

 Now Chile has voted in a socialist president (Report, January 17), I'm worried in case Pinochet should undergo a miraculous recovery in Chile and stage another bloody coup.

Alex Melbourne
Bradford
alexmelbourne@hotmail.com

 Did anyone stop worrying about the Ali G/racism question (Letters, January 17) long enough to notice that Monday night's TV featured three programmes containing portrayals of black women as prostitutes (Eastenders, The Vice and Mona Lisa). It's cause I is a black woman, innit?

Ceri Mollard
Edinburgh
cerimollard@hotmail.com

 First Clinton, now Mo Mowlam (Letters, Janaury 18). We need just one more aging politician to admit to experimenting and the whole street cred of drugs will be shot.

Sally Winter
Merthyr Tydfil

 So "New Labour to reduce parents' right to smack" (January 18): does their right to charlie or wizz remain?

Simon Birnstingl
Upper Beeding, W Sussex

 Peter Jones (Letters, January 17) is right. We puffed our way up Okehampton Castle mount to be greeted by the largest collection of molehills we had ever seen.

Christopher Gadsden
Penryn, Cornwall
h25@dial.pipex.com

fields.headline: Seeds of drug cartels
fields.trailText: The use of patents to obtain control over medical techniques and practices is nothing new (US firm may double cost of UK cancer checks, January 17). Patents over broad-spectrum antibiotics provided the foundation for the cartels that pharmaceutical companies formed in the 1960s to drive up the cost of those antibiotics. The German chemical industry used patents to monopolise and cartelise key sectors of the world industry in the early part of the 20th century.
fields.body:
The use of patents to obtain control over medical techniques and practices is nothing new (US firm may double cost of UK cancer checks, January 17). Patents over broad-spectrum antibiotics provided the foundation for the cartels that pharmaceutical companies formed in the 1960s to drive up the cost of those antibiotics. The German chemical industry used patents to monopolise and cartelise key sectors of the world industry in the early part of the 20th century.

Assuming current trends in modern biotechnology patenting continue, two things will happen. First, more and more medical knowledge will leave the scientific commons and fall into private ownership. Second, private ownership of that knowledge will become more concentrated as the pharmaceutical industry rationalises itself through mergers and takeovers - more biotech patents in fewer hands in other words. The prospect of global knowledge cartels in the field of medicine raises important access and price issues for consumers everywhere.

Dr Peter Drahos
Queen Mary Intellectual Property Institute

 Worldwide, a massive "gene rush" is underway as corporations claim patent rights to the genetic building blocks of plant and animal life (Leader, Janaury 1). This privatisation of staple food crops such as rice and maize by giant corporations poses huge risks to global food security and poor farmers' rights. Publicly-held resources of vital benefit to the most needy are even now being passed into corporate hands. The patenting of life is all about putting private profit before public good, both here and in the developing world.

Eve Mitchell
ActionAid

fields.headline: Coptic state
fields.trailText: Following the recent massacre of Coptic Christians in Egypt by Muslim traditionalists (Kosheh clashes, January 17) Nabil Osman, head of the state information service, said: "A radical solution has to be found to address this distressing event."
fields.body:
Following the recent massacre of Coptic Christians in Egypt by Muslim traditionalists (Kosheh clashes, January 17) Nabil Osman, head of the state information service, said: "A radical solution has to be found to address this distressing event."

The Copts of Egypt welcome this. However, there could be no acceptable solution other than treating all Egyptians, regardless of their religion, as equal under the law and with the same respect to their natural rights; in other words to treat Copts as full citizens on the same footing as Muslims.

The Copts can accept either full equality and freedom in a united Egypt or secession and establishment of an independent state for the Copts. Assimilation and segregation are not acceptable any more, neither by the Copts nor by the international community.

Dr Imad Boles
British Coptic Association

fields.headline: Public pay revolt grows
fields.trailText: The extensive reporting of the pay awards for NHS staff (Pay rises will put squeeze on NHS, January 18), has overlooked skilled employees, such as laboratory scientists and technicians, who are not covered by the pay review body. While nurses and health visitors received a 3.4% pay rise, non-PRB staff gained a 3.25% award, increasing differentials. Many non-PRB staff have degrees, but start on salaries of a mere £9,000.
fields.body:
The extensive reporting of the pay awards for NHS staff (Pay rises will put squeeze on NHS, January 18), has overlooked skilled employees, such as laboratory scientists and technicians, who are not covered by the pay review body. While nurses and health visitors received a 3.4% pay rise, non-PRB staff gained a 3.25% award, increasing differentials. Many non-PRB staff have degrees, but start on salaries of a mere £9,000.

Much has been made of the 7.8% award to 60,000 E-grade nurses. There is no indication that any scientists, technicians and other professionals outside the PRB will receive any increase along these lines. Without the expertise of such employees, who are responsible, for example, for analysing tests for suspected breast cancer, the NHS could not function.

Roger Kline
MSF union
kliner@msf.org.uk

 We also need increased salaries for all the many good and dedicated NHS administrative staff - secretaries, clinic clerks, medical records staff, right down to porters, cleaners and caterers. Much of their work has been contracted out expensively. I am a medical secretary obliged to work in the NHS via an agency to have a take-home pay that will cover my mortgage repayments. If the extra money for the NHS was trickled down, more dedicated people could be employed and retained, and efficiency would begin to rise. I am writing this in my lunch half-hour. I am typing up letters for one consultant and five registrars and have a backlog of three weeks clinic letters piled on my table.

Name and address supplied

 The media forget that the majority of people in need are actually cared for by hard-pressed social-care professionals, often working for low wages in underfunded private, voluntary, and local authority services. The real angels of caring Britain are not nurses and doctors, but social workers and social-care staff providing 24-hour care, seven days a week, for as little as £3.50 an hour. The government needs to stop using social services as a scapegoat for an inadequate commitment to local authorities.

JAF Thomas
Impington, Cambs

 There is a connection between the debate about whether fathers should be present at the birth of their children (G2, January 17) and the underfunding of the NHS. The shortage of midwives effectively removes the choice for expectant couples. Has it occurred to the health economists that it might be more cost-effective to train and employ more midwives rather than the highly skilled and expensive doctors it requires to perform a caesarean?

Edward Dimbylow
London

 So housing officers and librarians earn £29,060, do they (Recruitment crisis may be caused by misconceptions on pay, January 18)? I can only speak as a librarian, but in my authority the vast bulk of qualified librarians earn between £13,000 and £18,000.

David Drewitt
Redditch, Warks

 As a senior lecturer I would gladly settle for either the New Earnings Survey estimated average earnings of £32,000pa or the Guardian/ICM poll rate the public think I'm worth of £33,000. Sadly I don't earn anything near either figure. As a lone parent, I would also like to qualify for help with my son's nursery fees (£4,800) and not to have to pay £1,020 tuition fees for my daughter's university education. Unfortunately I earn too much to qualify for help with either of these.

Marie Lebacq
Nantwich, Cheshire

Roger Kline MSF union kliner@msf.org.uk  We also need increased salaries for all the many good and dedicated NHS administrative staff - secretaries, clinic clerks, medical records staff, right down to porters, cleaners and caterers. Much of their work has been contracted out expensively. I am a medical secretary obliged to work in the NHS via an agency to have a take-home pay that will cover my mortgage repayments. If the extra money for the NHS was trickled down, more dedicated people could be employed and retained, and efficiency would begin to rise. I am writing this in my lunch half-hour. I am typing up letters for one consultant and five registrars and have a backlog of three weeks clinic letters piled on my table. Name and address supplied  The media forget that the majority of people in need are actually cared for by hard-pressed social-care professionals, often working for low wages in underfunded private, voluntary, and local authority services. The real angels of caring Britain are not nurses and doctors, but social workers and social-care staff providing 24-hour care, seven days a week, for as little as £3.50 an hour. The government needs to stop using social services as a scapegoat for an inadequate commitment to local authorities. JAF Thomas Impington, Cambs  There is a connection between the debate about whether fathers should be present at the birth of their children (G2, January 17) and the underfunding of the NHS. The shortage of midwives effectively removes the choice for expectant couples. Has it occurred to the health economists that it might be more cost-effective to train and employ more midwives rather than the highly skilled and expensive doctors it requires to perform a caesarean? Edward Dimbylow London  So housing officers and librarians earn £29,060, do they (Recruitment crisis may be caused by misconceptions on pay, January 18)? I can only speak as a librarian, but in my authority the vast bulk of qualified librarians earn between £13,000 and £18,000. David Drewitt Redditch, Warks  As a senior lecturer I would gladly settle for either the New Earnings Survey estimated average earnings of £32,000pa or the Guardian/ICM poll rate the public think I'm worth of £33,000. Sadly I don't earn anything near either figure. As a lone parent, I would also like to qualify for help with my son's nursery fees (£4,800) and not to have to pay £1,020 tuition fees for my daughter's university education. Unfortunately I earn too much to qualify for help with either of these. Marie Lebacq Nantwich, Cheshire

webTitle: It was the Wall Street Journal wot got it

fields.headline: It was the Wall Street Journal wot got it
fields.trailText: I must say I am enjoying myself this millennium. Piers has finally gone ga-ga. Alastair's not talking to me. The euro is sliding. All is right with the world. But, just for the record, the Financial Times Editor, Richard Lambert, was mistaken in Monday's Guardian. I refer, of course, to the Roy Greenslade piece about the Sun's attack on the FT (Oi! Mind your own business, Media, January 17). He told the excellent Mr Greenslade that the Wall Street Journal did not break the Time Warner-AOL story. He said it was a "Dow Jones wire story".
fields.body:
I must say I am enjoying myself this millennium. Piers has finally gone ga-ga. Alastair's not talking to me. The euro is sliding. All is right with the world. But, just for the record, the Financial Times Editor, Richard Lambert, was mistaken in Monday's Guardian. I refer, of course, to the Roy Greenslade piece about the Sun's attack on the FT (Oi! Mind your own business, Media, January 17). He told the excellent Mr Greenslade that the Wall Street Journal did not break the Time Warner-AOL story. He said it was a "Dow Jones wire story".

For the record, it was a Journal exclusive. The paper's LA bureau had the story and I believe the New York-based editors decided to put it out on their wire service (Dow Jones owns the WSJ) and online.

Surely in this digital cyber-era, Mr Lambert is not going to quibble about this? After all, these days a scoop is a scoop whether delivered in electronic or print form. Maybe the FT should have reacted quicker and bunged it on FT.com. Meanwhile, thanks for the coverage.

David Yelland
Editor, the Sun

 It was reported that what irked Richard Lambert, the FT's editor, was "the fact that the leader was based on a somewhat false premise in that it was Dow Jones Newswires rather than [its sister organisation] the Wall Street Journal which beat the world to the AOL story". This premise was not, in fact, false at all. Whilst the story did run on Dow Jones Newswires first, then on CNBC and wsj.com, the scoop was got by the Journal's Los Angeles bureau chief who, primarily for reasons of timing (it was midnight his time, 8am London time), decided to give the scoop to Dow Jones Newswires. By most people's judgement, this was, and remains, a Journal scoop.

It is not by any means the first time that a Journal scoop has run on Dow Jones Newswires, nor will it be the last. One of the advantages of having a truly global news gathering network of some 1,650 reporters and editors is that if a news story breaks at an "inconvenient" time in one part of the world, we at Dow Jones have other highly efficient ways through our various print, electronic and TV operations of getting the news out those parts of the world that are awake and trading.

Brigitte Trafford
Dow Jones

fields.headline: We have no secret agendas
fields.trailText: In its response to the consultation exercise, the government accepted that there was no reason for the exemption relating to communications with the royal household to apply for more than 30 years (Attack on Straw over extension of secrecy, January 17).
fields.body:
In its response to the consultation exercise, the government accepted that there was no reason for the exemption relating to communications with the royal household to apply for more than 30 years (Attack on Straw over extension of secrecy, January 17).

Honours records raise questions of confidentiality, and the freedom of information bill was drafted in recognition of this. In this area, the bill merely reflects the status quo. The home secretary has not extended current restrictions or introduced new ones. However, the government will consider this exemption afresh in the light of the comments of the select committee, the Royal Historical Society and the lord chancellor's advisory council on public records. Our aim is to provide access to as many honours records as possible, at the earliest possible date (after 30 years, instead of the 75 quoted), taking into account questions of confidentiality.

Mike O'Brien MP
Under secretary of state, Home office

 The government has no plans to introduce charging on trunk roads or motorways (Drivers face road tolls, January 18). That's why there is no provision for it in the transport bill, which began its passage through parliament this week. You selected just one of a number of illustrative scenarios and despite clearly stated caveats, turned it into government policy. Interesting perhaps but alarmist and utterly out of context. There was no mention of the remarkable progress made in reducing pollution from traffic, nor of investment plans to improve public transport and reduce the growth of congestion.

Lord Macdonald
Minister for transport

fields.headline: Name game
fields.trailText: Playing with people's names is a mug's game (Letters, January 17). The big Oxford English Dictionary gives for Jack Straw "A man of no substance, worth or consideration" and quotes Chaucer "...Iakke Straw he made neuere shoutes half so sh[r]ille". It also has "Elfayde: some kind of animal: Elfaydes and Arrabys" (ca 1400); and under "Derry - to have a derry on, to be prejudiced against"; and "Mandy, obs, form of maundy: almsgiving, bounty, largesse"; and "to tony, to make a fool of...". The Collins-Robert French Dictionary offers " je ne peux pas les blairer : he gives me the creeps; I can't stand him"; and the French Vocabula Amatoria baldly gives " fergier : to copulate".

webTitle: Accomplice in Arkan killing reported found

fields.headline: Accomplice in Arkan killing reported found
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Pro-government newspapers in Serbia are fuelling public hysteria surrounding the killing of the notorious warlord Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, with reports that police have tracked down one of his assailants.
fields.body:
Pro-government newspapers in Serbia are fuelling public hysteria surrounding the killing of the notorious warlord Zeljko "Arkan" Raznatovic, with reports that police have tracked down one of his assailants.

Newspapers yesterday said a man lying unconscious in hospital after emergency surgery was one of the assailants. According to witnesses, a man wounded in the shootout in Belgrade's Intercontinental hotel on Saturday evening had managed to crawl out of the hotel lobby and escape in a waiting car.

Arkan and two other men were killed. The principal assassin is reported to be still on the run.

Quoting "reliable sources", the newspapers say Arkan appeared to know his attackers because he was seen shaking hands and talking with them.

"Arkan was killed by a known hand," said one of the newspapers. "Only someone whom Raznatovic knew would be allowed to approach him with his hand concealed in a pocket."

The authorities often use the Belgrade press to circulate convenient theories, and analysts say the comatose henchman may serve as a scapegoat to bypass a more thorough investigation into the killing, which has frayed the usually steely nerves of many in Belgrade's murky underworld.

Arkan was the godfather of godfathers, the undisputed king of the Serbian underworld. His business empire was based on his control of some 90% of the black market and other criminal activities.

Strong, powerful and independent, Arkan presented too great a threat to the traditional power bases in Serbia. Most Serbians, especially opponents of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, do not see Arkan's murder as a crackdown by the authorities on the criminal class, but rather as an attempt to substitute new gangster bosses who will be more loyal to the police and state security.

The killing of this seemingly untouchable warlord in one of his regular haunts apparently had an additional purpose - to send a message to any enemies of Mr Milosevic.

It is a tried and tested theory. The assassination last April of the newspaper owner and publisher Slavko Curuvija sent shock waves through the independent media and guaranteed a subdued press during the Nato air strikes.

"This assassination will be a very clear message to people in the ruling Socialist party of Serbia, the police and state security who could have thought about eventual behaviour which was disloyal to Milosevic," said the Belgrade-based political analyst Bratislav Grubacic.

"I think this was intended to create fear among the ruling structures themselves."

Arkan, who was indicted by the Hague tribunal in 1997 for alleged war crimes in Bosnia and Croatia, presented the only real challenge to the rule of Mr Milosevic and the financial interest groups that surround him.

His influence was far greater than that of the political opposition which is divided and discredited among ordinary people.

Released from Arkan's iron grip, the criminal empire he controlled is expected to disintegrate, with the authorities reasserting control over the underworld.

fields.headline: Museums are not sexy
fields.standfirst: And some never will be. Good
fields.trailText: Four years ago James Boyle took over BBC Radio 4. Soon he was ordering changes which roused its devotees to rebellion. Mr Boyle was at first unmoved. One must not give in, he insisted, to the forces of conservatism. But in time, his first designs were sensibly amended. Some innovations stuck; others were quietly lost. Now Mr Boyle is going too, perhaps to apply a new broom to the British Library.
fields.body:
New brooms sometimes sweep more rigorously than those who put them to work intended. Four years ago James Boyle took over BBC Radio 4. Soon he was ordering changes which roused its devotees to rebellion. Mr Boyle was at first unmoved. One must not give in, he insisted, to the forces of conservatism. But in time, his first designs were sensibly amended. Some innovations stuck; others, like the dreadful quiz games which cropped up each lunchtime, were quietly lost. Now Mr Boyle is going too, perhaps to apply a new broom to the British Library.

Now another new broom has taken charge of the nation's musuems. Matthew Evans, formerly chairman of Faber and Faber, sees them as deeply in thrall to the forces of conservatism. In what would once have been a coveted accolade but is now a term of supreme disapproval, he likens their present state to that of Marks and Spencer. It almost seemed from his opening salvo last night that he hardly sees a place for conventional museums at all. The biggest and best of their treasures will always have to remain within museum walls - not least for security. But much of the rest should go out to meet the public - dispersed to places like schools and shops and even pubs where people who flinch at the word museum are likely to see them.

Such sweeping assertions may need to be tempered if the sort of consumer backlash which greets any attempt to shift the time of The Archers starts to set in. What he needs to champion is diversity. That may mean exporting exhibits now mouldering in dark corners to places where people can stumble on them by accident. And yet there must surely still be a place for the local museum with its sepia pictures of 19th-century worthies celebrating the town's new railway line. They may lack excitement; they may not relate to New Britain; but they are part of any community's history and sense of itself - which is one of the reasons museums are there.

webTitle: UN split over Iraq arms inspector

fields.headline: UN split over Iraq arms inspector
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: A British-inspired initiative aimed at ending the impasse with Iraq was in trouble last night after China and Russia formally objected to the proposed head of a new weapons inspectorate, Rolf Ekeus.
fields.body:
A British-inspired initiative aimed at ending the impasse with Iraq was in trouble last night after China and Russia formally objected to the proposed head of a new weapons inspectorate, Rolf Ekeus.

France also cast doubt on the ability of Mr Ekeus, a Swedish ambassador who was in charge of monitoring Iraq's weapons programme for six years after the Gulf war. Britain and the US back Mr Ekeus.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, spent yesterday trying to find a compromise candidate.

Both China and Russia opposed Mr Ekeus on the grounds that no progress would be made because he was unacceptable to Iraq.

The British foreign office was the driving force behind a UN resolution passed before Christmas to set up the new weapons body. The hope was that sanctions against Iraq could be lifted if President Saddam Hussein accepted the new body.

At worst, if the UN negotiations run into the ground, the British and US governments can accuse Iraq of having spurned an opportunity for a peaceful resolution of the conflict.

Arms inspectors have been barred from returning to Iraq since leaving in mid-December 1998, shortly before the US and Britain launched the four-day air campaign Desert Fox.

A foreign office source suggested Mr Annan may have used Mr Ekeus as a stalking horse and that he can now turn to China and Russia with an alternative candidate who has the same arms monitoring credentials but no past involvement in Iraq.

A possible alternative is Pasi Patokallio, the Finnish ambassador to Israel and Cyprus. Mr Annan has the power to nominate candidates but endorsement requires the approval of UN security council members.

China, which has a permanent seat on the council, sent a letter yesterday to the president of the security council saying Beijing had "difficulty going along with the nomination", and asking that other candidates be considered. Russia sent a similar letter on Monday.

The French foreign ministry spokesman, François Rivasseau, also questioned Mr Ekeus's suitability: "It is doubtful that someone who has presided over this special commission for six years can represent this will, this necessity for renewal and change."

Britain and the US believe that Iraq is harbouring chemical, biological and nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them, and wants to send a team into Iraq to check. Iraq denies having the arsenal of weapons of mass destruction, and wants the sanctions lifted, claiming they cause distress to ordinary civilians.

Iraq's deputy prime minister, Tariq Aziz, said: "How can they form a new commission and then name its former head to lead it?"

fields.headline: Patient attacks five in hospital
fields.trailText: Police were called in to a hospital yesterday after a man ran amok, clubbing five other patients with a broken chair leg and shouting abuse at nurses.
fields.body:
Police were called in to a hospital yesterday after a man ran amok, clubbing five other patients with a broken chair leg and shouting abuse at nurses.

Security men wrestled the man, 61, to the floor, but not before a pensioner aged 78 suffered a fractured cheekbone, one aged 82 a fractured jaw, and a third elderly man a broken collar bone. Two younger male patients were cut about the face.

Managers at Huddersfield Royal infirmary, which has many patients with flu-related conditions as well as routine medical and surgical cases, said the attack was sudden, unprovoked and unpredictable.

Security measures are being reviewed, but the attacker was described as a routine admission who appeared to have settled in to ward 15 without problems. He was under 24-hour police guard in a side room yesterday

The three elderly patients were sharing a six-bed bay in the ward with a teenager, 18, and another man when the new arrival allegedly went berserk at about 1.15am yesterday.

The alarm was raised by the teenager, one of 22 patients in the ward all suffering from conditions such as pneumonia or orthopaedic injuries which left many helpless. A nurse called security staff, who had restrained the man by the time police arrived.

The hospital's medical director, Tony Milling, said the man was not a psychiatric patient and his mental state had given no particular cause for concern when he was admitted after going to accident and emergency late on Monday with a medical complaint.

"He was still being assessed at the time by consultant physicians - he was quiet and he had settled in," he said.

Police are investigating any incidents that may have triggered the attack after the man was moved to the ward at 11.20pm.

The infirmary's chief executive, Diane Whittingham, said: "We will be looking at security as part of our full investigation, and we will see if there are any lessons that need to be learned.

"We have all the measures in place to deal with security matters, but it's difficult to protect against an incident which is totally unpredictable."

The nursing director, Helen Thomson, said the nurses were trained to deal with violence and in ways of calming the situation. "The staff are extremely distressed by such an event, and we are trying our best to support them. It's frightening that this can happen in a hospital."

fields.headline: Hunt for phantom Dando 'brother'
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: An obsessive "living in a fantasy world" posed as Jill Dando's brother in a determined effort to become involved in her life shortly before she was murdered, detectives revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
An obsessive "living in a fantasy world" posed as Jill Dando's brother in a determined effort to become involved in her life shortly before she was murdered, detectives revealed yesterday.

Calling himself James Dando and saying he lived at her house in Fulham, west London, the man telephoned the gas, electricity and water companies to try to have her bills transferred into his name.

He seemed to possess confidential details, including the 14-digit number of her electricity account.

A direct debit form from British Gas marked Mr J Dando was sent to the television star and she filled in the details without noticing anything was amiss.

The calls to the utilities were made between 6.31pm and 6.49pm on Sunday February 1 last year, the day after Ms Dando held a party at a restaurant in Chiswick to celebrate her engagement to gynaecologist Alan Farthing.

Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell, who is leading the murder hunt, described two other instances of stalking behaviour before Ms Dando was shot on the doorstep of her home in Gowan Avenue on April 26.

On November 22 1998, someone used an internet service, 192.com, to pinpoint exactly where she lived: 192.com is an online directory inquiries service, using data from the electoral roll to provide callers with details of addresses and maps of the area for a small fee.

Ms Dando's ex-directory telephone number was not on the website. However, a caller who rang British Telecom last April did have her private number and tried to persuade a BT operator to switch her account details into his name.

On this occasion, the caller did not pretend to be the presenter's brother, whose name is Nigel, but he said he lived with her. Detectives admit they have no evidence to link the three incidents at this stage. But even if they are not connected, they add weight to the theory that Ms Dando was targeted by an obsessive rather than a contract killer.

The murder squad is hoping that AOL, the service provider, might trace the subscriber who went to the 192.com site 14 months ago, but recognise it is a mammoth task.

The name and credit details of whoever logged on to the site were wiped from computer records within 14 days of the request.

Two detectives from the Dando murder squad yesterday returned from a fact-finding mission to the US. They spoke to officers with expertise in tracking down stalkers. A source said US investigators were baffled by the murder.

fields.headline: Paedophiles admit murder plot
fields.standfirst: Undercover police officer reveals plan to travel the country in search of young girls to kidnap and rape
fields.trailText: Two men described as Britain's most dangerous paedophiles were facing long jail sentences yesterday after admitting a plan to travel the country in search of young girls to kidnap, rape and murder.
fields.body:
Two men described as Britain's most dangerous paedophiles were facing long jail sentences yesterday after admitting a plan to travel the country in search of young girls to kidnap, rape and murder.

Michael Williams, 47, and Paul Elkington, 49, planned to buy a van which they would use to hunt for girls between the ages of two and 10, before taking them to a remote location in the west midlands where they would be assaulted and killed.

But a secret 18-month police operation uncovered their plans and both men were arrested before they could act out their fantasies.

Both were charged with conspiring with another to abduct, rape and murder a child between the age of two and 10. Williams, formerly of Bilston, Wolverhampton, pleaded guilty to the charge yesterday. Elkington, formerly of Coventry, admitted the same offence at Nottingham crown court on Monday.

Detective Inspector Cath Hannon, who led the inquiry, said: "These are two of the most dangerous sex offenders in the country. They had gone so far as buying items they would need to carry out their plan. The only thing left was for them was to carry it out."

An undercover police officer spent 10 months befriending the pair, and used hidden microphones and cameras to gather evidence. It was a harrowing task, since the men went to great lengths describing how they would restrain, rape and kill their victims.

Ms Hannon praised the officer yesterday. "He is a man for whom I have a great deal of respect. He was dedicated and spent a long time dealing with this case."

The officer first made contact with Elkington and Williams when they were still serving prison sentences for attacks on children. Williams served four and a half years for the abduction of a boy and a girl, while Elkington served five and a half years for assaulting a 13-year-old girl.

Police gathered more than 100 hours of audio and video recordings of the two men as they developed their plan. The men discussed how their van would have blacked-out windows and false number plates; aware of the possibility of detection by DNA evidence, they planned to take changes of clothes for them and their victims. They also planned to take sleeping pills and an instant camera.

They discussed disguises, and intended to ensure that their faces did not show in the photographs they planned to take of their victims.

The men went to great lengths to find suitable places to dispose of their victims' bodies. They inspected a country park in the midlands, where they knew of a number of deep holes which lead to underground caves. The pair believed that dumping a body down the holes would ensure it would never be found.

The pair were arrested on April 3 last year when police feared they were about to put their plan into action. Mobile phones, maps, a shopping list of items the men would use, and magazine articles showing pictures of young children were recovered from Williams's flat. When he was interviewed by police, Williams admitted planning the offence for between two and three years.

The case against the pair was adjourned yesterday by the judge, Mr Justice Holland. He ordered psychiatric reports to be prepared on both men before they are sentenced.

Ms Hannon said after the hearing: "This operation was the biggest we have ever carried out, and I think we have learned a lot about the way paedophiles operate."

webTitle: Half of GPs ignore need for early diagnosis of dementia

fields.headline: Half of GPs ignore need for early diagnosis of dementia
fields.trailText: One in two family doctors believes it unimportant to make an early diagnosis of dementia in elderly people because it is seen as untreatable and its diagnosis alone can cause great distress, the audit commission reports today.
fields.body:
One in two family doctors believes it unimportant to make an early diagnosis of dementia in elderly people because it is seen as untreatable and its diagnosis alone can cause great distress, the audit commission reports today.

Only half of all carers of people with dementia say they were told about the diagnosis soon after their relative or friend started to become confused, and fewer still were advised how it might affect them or asked if they needed any help.

Whether dementia is regarded as treatable or not, the commission says, carers deserve early information and support. A clear diagnosis can also trigger help from community services, sometimes deferring or even preventing admission to residential care.

Andrew Foster, the commission's controller, said: "It is unacceptable that carers, who are so essential to vulnerable older people, can find themselves forgotten by the system."

A report by the commission, based on study of 12 areas of the country, says mental health services for elderly people are "patchy and inconsistent". Spending on specialist services for problems such as dementia and depression varies from area to area by as much as eight to one and is too heavily skewed towards residential care, it says.

Calling for urgent action to make services more consistent and comprehensive, the commission is warning that the over-80s are one of the fastest growing groups of the population and that one in four of those over 85 will develop dementia.

In the first move its kind, the commission is to send auditors into every district in England and Wales during this year and next to check on the level and quality of services, and, specifically, how different health and welfare agencies liaise in their provision.

Mr Foster said: "GPs and primary care teams could give far better information and support if they were getting more help from specialist mental health professionals." Research for the report, Forget Me Not, included a survey of more than 1,000 GPs. Although nine in 10 said it was important to look for early signs of depression in their elderly patients, only 54% said the same for dementia, while 52% believed it beneficial to make an early diagnosis of the condition.

One GP commented: "What is the point in looking for an untreatable illness?" Another said: "Diagnosing dementia can be difficult, uncertain and create unnecessary anxiety."

A second survey, of 850 carers of people with dementia, found that barely 50% reported early diagnosis by a doctor. In one area, fewer than 30% said they had been asked if they needed any help coping with their relative's or friend's condition.The report describes these findings as "rather worrying".

The report was welcomed by groups working with elderly people and with those with mental health problems.

Gil Hitchon, chief executive of mental health charity Maca, said it was imperative that patients and carers were fully involved in decision making.

webTitle: UK resists ban on child soldiers

fields.headline: UK resists ban on child soldiers
fields.trailText: Britain is holding out against international moves to raise the minimum age limit for the recruitment and deployment of soldiers to 18 despite strong pressure from the UN and a consensus among developing and developed countries.
fields.body:
Britain is holding out against international moves to raise the minimum age limit for the recruitment and deployment of soldiers to 18 despite strong pressure from the UN and a consensus among developing and developed countries.

A UN proposal on the rights of the child, being negotiated in private in Geneva this week, is seen as an important signal, with an estimated 300,000 child soldiers, mainly in African conflicts, recruited or kidnapped by governments as well as rebel groups.

An existing UN convention sets 18 as the age of transition to adulthood with one exception - participation in war, where the age limit is 15.

The government is sticking to existing British rules with 16 as the minimum age for voluntary recruitment and 17 for deployment, though it says an age limit of 18 should be set for recruitment by rebels or "non-state actors", and all forcible recruitment or conscription of children should be outlawed.

A coalition of non-governmental organisations, including Amnesty International and Human Rights Watch, is accusing Britain and the US of double standards.

Both countries are also opposed to bringing the ban under the remit of the proposed international criminal court. A deal expected this week is likely to allow countries to opt out of the agreement.

webTitle: Galley leak froze BA jet controls

fields.headline: Galley leak froze BA jet controls
fields.trailText: Controls on a British Airways jumbo jet with 300 passengers were jammed after a leak from the galley caused cables to freeze, an accident report said.
fields.body:
Controls on a British Airways jumbo jet with 300 passengers were jammed after a leak from the galley caused cables to freeze, an accident report said.

Force had to be used to free the roll flight controls, but the problem recurred before they returned to normal and the flight from Detroit landed at Heathrow, said the report by the air accidents investigation branch.

A similar leak had occurred on the same 1970-built Boeing 747-136 five days before the reported incident over the Irish Sea on the morning of August 22 last year.

BA had experienced the water accumulation problem on 14 previous occasions. It had used a Boeing service bulletin on the problem to develop an engineering order which led to more drains being installed in galleys than the bulletin required.

But the report said BA "decided not to embody the engineering order on their Boeing 747-136 aircraft as their retirement was anticipated". BA has since retired all its 747-136s.

In the Detroit to London incident, the controls appeared normal after "extreme force" was used, the report said, but the problem recurred near the English coast.

Worried about ice on the controls, the captain asked to fly at a lower level. The problem got worse. The crew put in a PAN call, one stage down from mayday, to London air traffic controllers, who gave the plane priority, and at 11,000ft the problem eased and it landed normally.

Two gallons of water that had leaked from a galley drain were drained from a section of the plane.

A BA spokeswoman said yesterday: "No emergency was declared, and there was never any danger of having to make a landing with a control problem. The crew had complete control of the aircraft because the rudder could provide steering and roll control. We are not required to act on service bulletins: they are advisory."

webTitle: Chilean jet on standby to fly Pinochet out as human rights groups say medical tests flawed

fields.headline: Chilean jet on standby to fly Pinochet out as human rights groups say medical tests flawed
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A Chilean air force jet was last night on standby at an airfield 1,000 miles north of Santiago ready to extract the former dictator Augusto Pinochet from his 15-month enforced exile in Britain.
fields.body:
A Chilean air force jet was last night on standby at an airfield 1,000 miles north of Santiago ready to extract the former dictator Augusto Pinochet from his 15-month enforced exile in Britain.

Pinochet and his supporters, and human rights groups around the world, are facing an anxious wait after the deadline for submitting objections to Jack Straw's announcement that he was minded to halt extradition proceedings on medical grounds expired at 5pm yesterday.

The home secretary is expected to make his final decision in the next seven days. "Once we've seen the size of the representations and the nature of the arguments then we'll give an indication of when it is likely that I'll announce a decision," Mr Straw told BBC radio's The World At One.

In London Amnesty International and the other human rights groups protesting at Mr Straw's provisional announcement delivered their submissions to the home office yesterday morning.

The representations include claims that the general could have been faking dementia during his medical tests and that the team which examined the general did not include anyone with specific expertise in dementia.

In letters accompanying the submissions, Robert Howard, of the Institute of Psychiatry at the Maudsley Hospital in London, and Nori Graham, president of the International Alzheimer's Society - both eminent old-age psychiatrists - stated that the medical tests to which Pinochet was apparently subjected were insufficient to arrive at a diagnosis of dementia.

Dr Howard said the medical team "cannot be considered to have established beyond doubt that he is unfit to stand trial".

"If Pinochet recovers it will not be an indictment of the doctors who examined him, but it will be an indictment of Jack Straw," Pierre Sané, Secretary General of Amnesty, said at a press conference in London.

In Strasbourg the European Court of Human Rights rejected a request by seven Chileans, now living in Spain, that Britain be stopped from sending General Pinochet home. They argued that they or their families suffered under his rule.

The court gave no reason for the decision but an official in Strasbourg said an injunction would have been granted had the plaintiffs managed to convince the tribunal that release "would have caused grave and irreparable harm" to their lives.

Switzerland said yesterday it had decided against requesting a new British medical examination for Pinochet but added that it did not consider health grounds a legal reason to decide against extradition.

The Swiss extradition request for the former Chilean dictator followed a criminal complaint filed in Geneva by the widow of Alexis Jaccard, a student of Swiss-Chilean dual nationality who disappeared in Argentina in May 1977.

fields.headline: Hunger striker 'weakening'
fields.trailText: Barry Horne, the jailed animal rights campaigner, is seriously weak after again refusing solid food following a 68-day hunger strike over government policy on animals.
fields.body:
Barry Horne, the jailed animal rights campaigner, is seriously weak after again refusing solid food following a 68-day hunger strike over government policy on animals.

Horne, 47, has been drinking only fruit juice and glucose drinks since August 5 and has signed a living will stating that he does not want treatment if he goes into a coma.

He has been moved to the health care centre at Full Sutton prison, near York, and reportedly weighs five stone.

Friends in the animal rights movement said that, unlike his previous three hunger strikes, this action was not connected to any particular animal rights issue.

A prison service spokesman said yesterday: "His condition is serious and he's very weak. We have offered him medical treatment and staff have negotiated with him in an effort to end his food refusal.

"However the prisoner has signed a living will prohibiting any medical treatment." A doctor from a local hospital was monitoring his condition.

Horne's most high profile protest - at the government's refusal to announce a royal commission on vivisection in line with a pre-election pledge - ended in December 1998 without the government ceding any significant ground.

Horne also faced claims - fiercely denied by supporters - that he had been secretly taking orange juice and sugary tea throughout the hunger strike.

Horne is serving an 18-year sentence following an Animal Liberation Front firebomb attack in the Isle of Wight, which caused £3m damage.

Last year appeal court judges rejected his claim that the conviction was unsafe and the sentence too long.

Horne, twice-married with two children and a grandchild, has been at Full Sutton since January 1998.

fields.headline: Burglaries bring siege mentality
fields.trailText: The double-hit on Norwood Grove in central Leeds, mirrored next door where a lawyer, Patrick Stoddart, had two break-ins shortly after moving in, helps to account for the local police division's place at the top of the national burglary rate.
fields.body:
The burglars smashed their way into Simon Hopkins's house three weeks before Christmas, split the strengthened door, tried to rip out the clanging alarm bell, failed and ran off empty-handed.

But two weeks later they were back again, splintering the replaced door and grabbing a TV, video and Mr Hopkins's stereo player in the time it had taken them previously to wrestle with the alarm.

The double-hit on Norwood Grove in central Leeds, mirrored next door where a lawyer, Patrick Stoddart, had two break-ins shortly after moving in, helps to account for the local police division's place at the top of the national burglary rate. Despite massive publicity - neighbouring Chestnut Grove was named three years ago as "Britain's most burgled street" - residents in the redbrick terraces still have to assume that their turn is likely to come.

"It all looked very encouraging four years ago," said John Greenwood from the Burley and Hyde Park community safety project, digging out a clipping of eight smiling policemen from the Yorkshire Evening Post of January 4, 1996.

Following street violence in the area and bitter complaints about thieving, the initiative was warmly welcomed.

"But now," said Mr Greenwood, "we are back to just two 'beat managers'."

His task for the afternoon was to send a letter to West Yorkshire's chief constable, calling for more attention from Millgarth police station, which keeps an eye on 36,000 people in 13,000 households.

The packed streets recorded a tally of more than 36 burglaries per 1,000 households between April and September, three times the national average of 10.7.

West Yorkshire police warned that Millgarth's patch, just a step from Leeds's two universities, was vulnerable to high burglary figures because of the high student population. Since April new home office recording methods have changed a burglary like Mr Hopkins's from one incident into three, because belongings of three different students in the shared house were stolen.

But local people countered that government research only last autumn specifically warned that students were one of the top targets of sneak thieves. High risk should mean higher police priority, they said.

The grim architectural badge of Burley and Hyde Park - the wrought-iron metal grille over most front doors - is having a gradual effect.

Between the nadir of 1995 and last year, the overall burglary rate in Millgarth dropped by 45%, and initiatives such as free locks and door-braces for students are being copied by a "safety-twinning" scheme in Durban, South Africa.

webTitle: HRT 'aid' to sharp mind in later life

fields.headline: HRT 'aid' to sharp mind in later life
fields.trailText: British researchers are to study claims that hormone replacement therapy can keep women thinking faster in later life.
fields.body:
British researchers are to study claims that hormone replacement therapy can keep women thinking faster in later life.

The team, based at the Institute of Psychiatry in London, will investigate whether the female sex hormone oestrogen protects the brain from age-related mental decline and dementia. They have been given a £610,000 grant by the Medical Research Council for their survey.

Evidence from animal and laboratory studies suggests that the hormone has a powerful effect on the brain.

Cells of the hippocampus, a part of the brain closely associated with memory, survive oxidative stress much better when exposed to oestrogen.

The trial, led by Martin Prince from the Institute of Psychiatry, Felicia Huppert from Cambridge university and Marcus Richards from University College, London, should give definitive answers.

It will be an extension to the "Wisdom" trial (women's international study of long-duration oestrogen after menopause) which is looking at the health risks and benefits of HRT in 18,000 women. The new trial will investigate whether HRT can reduce the normal decline of cognitive ability with age in 2,000 British women aged 50 to 69.

Dr Huppert said if the effects were proved it would result in HRT being more widely prescribed to older women and possibly older men.

webTitle: Rise in offences sets alarm bells ringing

fields.headline: Rise in offences sets alarm bells ringing
fields.standfirst:
Fraud, violence and forgery up as police warn of cash shortfall
Crime figures: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The first rise for six years in the official recorded crime figures set the alarm bells ringing in Downing Street last night amid fears that the headline crime rate was on an upward trend, up to and beyond the next general election.
fields.body:
The first rise for six years in the official recorded crime figures set the alarm bells ringing in Downing Street last night amid fears that the headline crime rate was on an upward trend, up to and beyond the next general election.

Crime now threatens to join health and transport at the top of the list of political issues fuelling disenchantment among the voters. The 2% overall increase in the crime figures recorded by the police, for 12 months to September 1999, masks a 29% rise in fraud and forgery, which includes credit card crime on the internet, and a 19% rise in street robberies in Birmingham, Leeds, London and Manchester. While violent crime rose by 6.3%, crimes against property, including burglary, rose by just 2%. Drug offences, mainly possession, fell by 9%.

As Tony Blair met the incoming metropolitan police commissioner, John Stevens, the row erupted again over whether the police decision to scale down the use of stop and search powers, for fear of being labelled racist, was linked to the rise in street muggings.

The prime minister stressed his strong support for the proper use of stop and search powers as home office criminologists said it was "ludicrous" to draw a direct link between reduced use of such powers and the rising number of muggings on the street.

The overall 2% rise in recorded offences is a setback for the government's "crusade to cut crime". But home office statisticians repeated a warning yesterday that the booming economy, rising consumer spending and growing numbers of young men, are putting an immense pressure on the crime rate that is likely to continue to the general election.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has pinned hopes on his crime reduction strategy, and the publication in July of the first comparative league tables relating to each local police division, will also reveal the most ineffective forces.

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, said: "People will be quite right to demand an urgent explanation from [Mr Straw] as to why we are less and less safe on our streets and in our homes, under the party who promised to be tough on crime."

Last night, police leaders blamed the 6% rise in violent crime on underfunding and falling police numbers, and warned against "reading too much in to the raw figures".

Detailed figures published last night failed to draw comparisons between similar police forces and, in many cases, were made meaningless by being based on resident population figures. This meant that many city centres - where many work but few live - came top of the league tables for robbery, car thefts and sex offences. But the burglary rate per 1,000 households showed that the worst five areas for domestic break-ins in England and Wales were Leeds city centre (36 per 1,000), Birmingham city centre (36 per 1,000), north Manchester (30), Odsal in West Yorkshire (28), and north-east Lincolnshire (28). Newtown in Dyfed/Powys has the lowest burglary rate with 1.7 per 1,000 households.

Twenty-four forces mainly outside the big cities, recorded falls in the headline rate, while 19 forces showed increases. The largest rises in crime were in London (9%) and in the West Midlands (8%).

webTitle: BBC's voice of politics defects to ITN

fields.headline: BBC's voice of politics defects to ITN
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: John Sergeant, one of Britain's most respected political journalists, announced last night that he was quitting the BBC to join ITN.
fields.body:
John Sergeant, one of Britain's most respected political journalists, announced last night that he was quitting the BBC to join ITN.

Sergeant, who has worked for the BBC for 30 years, will replace ITN's present political editor, Michael Brunson, who is retiring at the end of March.

The BBC has faced a series of high-profile departures over the past year. Martin Bashir, the reporter who shot to fame when he interviewed Princess Diana, joined the ITV current affairs programme Tonight last winter, Des Lynam also left for ITV in the summer, and he was soon followed by the comedian Frank Skinner.

"We are absolutely delighted," said Steve Anderson, ITV's controller of news and current affairs. "This man pushes all the right political buttons."

Although Sergeant is highly regarded by Downing Street, he also has a reputation for prickly independence which goes down well with colleagues.

He was chosen to do the only interview with Ron Davies the day after the former Welsh secretary resigned following "a moment of madness" on Clapham Common.

Sergeant confronted Margaret Thatcher on the steps of the Paris embassy in 1990 on the night she discovered that she had failed to win the Conservative leadership contest on the first ballot.

The moment, which has passed into television news history, won Sergeant the British Press Guild award for the most memorable broadcast of the year.

His recent appearances on Have I Got News For You and Room 101 also revealed a comic timing said to be on a par with Paul Merton.

The ITN deal is believed to be worth in the region of £110,000 a year to Sergeant.
