webTitle: Dust off fusty image, museums told

fields.headline: Dust off fusty image, museums told
fields.standfirst: New supremo says heritage managers must embrace new technology or become 'Marks and Spencer of cultural world'
fields.trailText: Museums must embrace drastic change or risk becoming the Marks and Spencer of the cultural world, the government's new museums supremo said last night, in a speech fiercely criticising many aspects of his domain.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
Museums must embrace drastic change or risk becoming the Marks and Spencer of the cultural world, the government's new museums supremo said last night, in a speech fiercely criticising many aspects of his domain.

Matthew Evans, chairman of Faber and Faber publishers, has been appointed the first chairman of the new museums, libraries and archives commission, which officially comes into existence in April as the government's main adviser and grant giver. It replaces the present museums and galleries and libraries commissions, bringing the sectors together for the first time.

Mr Evans, who admitted he had no experience of museum management after a life spent in publishing, savaged his new flock last night and suggested moving collections out from behind museum walls and into pubs, schools and shops.

His attack came as a new survey found that the number of visits to British museums had dropped by 4% nationally.

Museum professionals from all over the country, at the annual Association of Independent Museums lecture, held at Sotheby's in London, heard their world damned as regressive, isolationist, afraid of change and ignorant of technical advances. Mr Evans said he had travelled the country to get to grips with his new responsibilities, and was shocked by many aspects of what he found.

"Those of us involved in managing cultural activities such as museums must fundamentally change what we do and the way we do it, if we are to remain relevant to politicians - and to the millions of ordinary people who not only directly or indirectly fund us but are our customers," he said.

Behind the times

"If we don't, we risk turning into a cultural version of Marks and Spencer - symbols of once great institutions that have failed to move with the times and are suffering as a result."

There were signs that this was already happening, he added. "Fifty nine million people live in these islands and yet, according to the latest Office of National Statistics report, around 80% of them - just under 50m - won't have visited a museum or gallery in the past three months. Apparently, museums are above funfairs in the popularity stakes, but below discos ...

"We need to break free from the idea that museums are constrained by physical walls. We need to demonstrate our relevance to local communities by taking collections out of museums and putting them into schools, shops and other locations. If visiting a pub is our favourite pastime, why not recognise that by exhibiting our collections in one?"

Information technology was changing the world beyond recognition, he said. "In my own field, book publishing, I can say that any print-based publisher who does not embrace the electronic revolution will be out of business in 10 years time."

Mr Evans warned that museums, if they were to continue to exist, must embrace change and work with one another and with other institutions in the sector.

"Some museum professionals live in outmoded professional boxes that sometimes prevent them from working with similar types of organisation. For example, there is in my view a quite ridiculous sniffiness among museums about recognising the contributions made by essentially similar bodies such as science centres or heritage trusts, let alone archives or libraries. There is little hope of a new future if these attitudes persist."

Mr Evans dynamic approach received a nervous welcome from many museum professionals, who nevertheless pointed out a few practical problems.

"We're there, we're doing it," Dr Simon Thurley, director of the Museum of London, said. "We haven't got a pub yet, but that's only a matter of time.

Daring displays

"We've got objects displayed, many at the sites where they were found, in London Bridge railway station, in offices, in schools, in the Royal Opera House - it's only a question of how daring you can be, in making excellent management arrangements and designing a case that somebody can't just come up and smash with a hammer.

"But apart from security considerations, I think the very best and most important objects are always going to be in the main museums, because that's where the big stories can be told. "

Maurice Davies, deputy head of the Museums Association, which represents the country's thousands of registered museums - but not heritage centres or science centres - said: "I'd like to throw the challenge back to Matthew Evans - what the sector is crying out for is clear, simple, coherent guidance and leadership from this new body. Small under-resourced museums are facing bewildering choices and possible changes of direction, and don't know where to turn, and they haven't been given enough help in the past."

"It's easy to criticise - now we want to see what he can do about it."

Mr Davies added: "As for Matthew's Marks and Spencer remark - I tried to get into their new year sale the other day and the shop was so crowded I couldn't."

Ironically, in one of its final publications, the museums and galleries commission yesterday issued figures which justified much of Mr Evans's gloom. Museum Focus 2, which looks at trends in museums between 1997 and 1998, found:

The number of visits to museums dropped by 4% nationally

The number of permanent full-time staff fell by 116, 2.5%, to 12,590 - though this was offset by a 20% increase in volunteer numbers, to 25,206.

Almost three quarters of museums feel that in-house conservation work is insufficient, and more than 90% contract out some conservation work.

Almost half of all museums, 49%, now charge for admission to core collections.

Only 51% of museums offer facilities or services for people with disabilities, though the number of museums with a disability policy increased by 8% to 29%.

On the more optimistic side:

80% of museums have shops and toilets and 35% a restaurant or cafe.

Opening hours are increasing; 40% open for more than 40 hours a week in summer, and 62% open for more than 10 months a year.

Although most of most museums' collections are in store, almost all, 98%, can now provide some access to stored material, either by opening stores to visitors or lending to other museums or exhibitions, or to schools and community centres.

'We know we have to move with the times'

Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery:

"The National Gallery has for many years aimed to find new ways of making its collection fully available to the public, wherever they may live.

"We maintain the importance of free admission and have pioneered access to the collection through new media. It was the first collection to be available on CD-rom, had the first ever touchscreen information room and has a website which received 21m hits in 1999."

Mark O'Neill, director Glasgow museums:

"I agree with everything Matthew Evans says, but he almost makes it appear that people in the industry don't know it. Of course you have to move with the times... you have to embrace information technologies, but you still have to stress the experience of visiting a museum.

"The combination of the building, the objects and the other visitors there to see them is unique and very important."

"Having said that, you have to reach out and we do that. We do 1,000 loans a year to non-museum venues such as community centres, prisons and shopping centres."

Dr Robert Anderson, director of the British Museum:

"Today museums must be dynamic organisations and respond imaginatively to audience expectations.

"The British Museum attracts some 6m visitors a year, but our activities are by no means confined to our London base. For example, last year more than 9,000 objects were lent to nearly 100 venues around the UK. Compass, our new multimedia collections database, which will be launched this year, is a prime example of how museums are harnessing modern technology."

Patrick Greene, president of the Museums Association, director of the Museum of Science and Industry in Manchester:

"I agree that there is a need for museums to reach out, to be as open and welcoming to visitors as possible, but I think Matthew Evans will find he's talking to the converted, or at least the semi-converted.

"At Manchester we've increased attendances by 28% through going out and putting on special events.

"In the last two years we've had a dinosaur exhibition and a show about the science of Star Trek, and they were crowd pleasers.

"These events are justified, providing they're well-researched and accurate, because once people come in for a particular show, they realise that we've got loads of other good exhibits."

Eddie Gershon, spokesman for the JD Wetherspoon pub chain:

"Having museum exhibits in pubs is a bit off the wall, but not impossible. We already commission more original works of art and sculpture from local artists and sculptors than any other pub company. We spend around £250,000 a year. We make a point of going to local artists, so why not do the same with local museums?"

Interviews by Paul Kelso

webTitle: New IVF rules 'will hit least fertile'

fields.headline: New IVF rules 'will hit least fertile'
fields.trailText: Changes to the rules on fertility treatment designed to stop multiple births will dash the chances of a baby for older women and the least fertile, the head of a Harley Street fertility clinic said yesterday.
fields.body:
Changes to the rules on fertility treatment designed to stop multiple births will dash the chances of a baby for older women and the least fertile, the head of a Harley Street fertility clinic said yesterday.

Tomorrow the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists is expected to recommend to the department of health a ban on more than two embryos being replaced in the womb. During standard fertility treatment, eggs removed from the woman's body are mixed with sperm from her partner in the laboratory. At present, up to three embryos are replaced in the womb and the rest are frozen for further attempts.

The college wants to cut the numbers of triplets born through IVF. Multiple births through IVF are also linked to birth defects, including cerebral palsy and spina bifida.

But Ian Craft, of the London Gynaecology and Fertility Centre, is strongly opposed to the expected limit of two embryos. He insisted that the college had got it wrong and was penalising the women who have greatest difficulties in conceiving.

"Why we always assume that all women are the same is beyond me," said Professor Craft yesterday. "We would like to see fewer embryos going into those at high risk of multiple birth and more into those who have repeatedly failed to get pregnant."

All women seeking IVF (in-vitro fertilisation) should be given a fertility score, he said, which would give a clear indication of their chances of having a multiple birth. Those at high risk should have just two embryos replaced. Those at low risk could have five or more.

He claimed his higher live birth rate (22.3%) than some other clinics such as the Hammersmith hospital (12.4%) or Aberdeen royal infirmary (17%) was due to the fact that he normally put back three rather than two embryos. In older women he often used a technique called GIFT, which mixed sperm and egg in the fallopian tube. There were no rules on the number of embryos that could be replaced in GIFT, and he sometimes put back as many as eight or nine.

His team at his Harley Street clinic have studied the risk of multiple birth in a sample of patients who underwent a total of 1,022 cycles of standard IVF treatment. In 87 cases (8.5%) there were multiple pregnancies. This was lower than the clinic's usual multiple birth rate of nearly 36% (with a 6% incidence of triplets) because the sample did not include women who became pregnant with eggs donated by younger women.

Their results showed that the chances of a multiple pregnancy depended on a number of factors, with the chances of having twins or triplets increasing the younger the woman, the more eggs she produced, the lower the dose of drug needed to stimulate her ovaries, and the higher the quality of the eggs and the percentage that fertilised.

In women under 35 the chances of multiple pregnancy were 20%-25%, said Geetha Venkat, the doctor at the clinic who analysed the results. By the age of 40, the chances had dropped to under 5% and were insignificant by age 45.

Multiple pregnancy rates among women who produced 10-15 eggs were around 10%. Among those who produced 20-25, they peaked at 27%. Where 80% of the eggs fertilised after being mixed with sperm, the multiple pregnancy rate was around 11%. Where only 40% fertilised, the rate was just 4%.

Professor Craft accepted that his was a small study. He urged the college not to come to a judgment until there had been further research.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What librarians are watching on television
fields.trailText: What librarians are watching on television
fields.body:
James Fisher: "I am that person who thinks Richard Whiteley's puns are actually funny, and I love the banter and anecdotes from the stars like Keith Baron and Martin Jarvis in Dictionary Corner. I think Byker Grove is the best and should be on at a peak-time evening slot. Do I think there should be more programmes with libraries in? No. not really. Fun, fun, fun, that's what I want from my television. That's not libraries."

Keith Cook: "Barbara Windsor - a class act. I've a lot of time for her because it's not just the acting with her, she is actually a very accomplished singer. And of course she still has that amazing chest after all these years, heheh. I detest Jamie Theakston. He's too tall and I don't like his eyebrows. Zoe Ball is just annoying. People seem to have just one basic talent these days. In fact, a lot of this current lot on television - they don't even have that."

Robin Pryor: "The repeats of Doctor Who see me swirling, lost in a world of 70s nostalgia, quarries full of adventure and mystery and a time where anything seemed possible. Jon Pertwee was so stylish. If I was controller of the BBC I would commission a new series straightaway, with Derek Jacobi as the Doctor."

Christopher McLay: "People say there are too many repeats on the telly but I would argue that it's just the wrong things they're repeating. There was Hi De Hi over the summer, only to lose interest after the first series. How can they leave Ted Bovis and the gang getting dusty on the archive shelves and then commission a show like Hale and Pace at the BBC? I don't think that Royle Family will last, do you?"

Carol Cooper: "I do like the fact you don't get any librarians on TV, there's none I can think of. No, not even detectives. What would I like to see? If they do real life then they should have people real-life murdering each other. That would give them a shock. Re-stage Stalin's life. Awful."

 Sin Pattenden spoke to librarians at Leeds Metropolitan University Library.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Ecological Design | P'Tang, Yang, Kipperbang | As Good As It Gets | Big Night
fields.body:
Ecological Design 8pm, Discovery Channel

This documentary traces the rise of ecological design in the 20th century, from the pioneering work of the 20s right up to the present-day global green movement. The show belongs to loopy designer R Buckminster Fuller who planned to solve New York's problems by encasing it in a giant geodesic glass dome.

P'Tang, Yang, Kipperbang (Michael Apted, 1982) 6pm, FilmFour

Schoolboy Alan (John Albasiny) is 14 in the summer of 1948: the atom bomb looms large, but he's much more interested in the England cricket team winning the Ashes, and getting to kiss Ann (Abigail Cruttenden), the prettiest girl in the class. In his screenplay Jack Rosenthal recalls his own postwar salad days; a funny and tender look at lads transformed by an invasion of raging hormones. Alison Steadman appears as Alan's teacher.

As Good As It Gets (James L Brooks, 1997) 8pm, Sky Premier

Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt won Oscars for this, which is pretty rich given that their relationship in Brooks's misfired romantic comedy is never remotely credible. He's a phobically challenged, ultra-fastidious irascible bastard of a writer; she's the waitress at the one restaurant in town that still serves him.

Big Night (Stanley Tucci, 1996) 2.10am, Sky MovieMax

The tale of brothers Primo and Secondo Pilaggi (Tony Shalhoub, director Tucci) struggling to make a success of their Italian restaurant in 50s New Jersey. Unfortunately, rival Pascal (Ian Holm) is making a killing down the road. Beautifully performed and life-affirming comedy.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
Nobody said blackmail was easy but there is one basic rule: contact your victim. Sound obvious? Apparently not, if the bizarre case involving New Zealand actor Russell Crowe, star of LA Confidential, is any indication.

A cunning plot was hatched after Crowe was involved in a punch-up at an Australian nightspot last November. Club owners Phillip Cropper and Malcolm Mercer discovered their security video had captured the fracas, and planned to extract $132,000 from Crowe in return for the tape. It seems, however, they never actually got in touch with the actor.

The budding criminal masterminds came unstuck when they were overheard discussing the plan with a rugby coach who they wanted to help "convince" Crowe to stump up the cash.

The pair's original brainwave, it seems, had been to sell the tape to the media, with Mercer optimistically suggesting it would "ruin Crowe's fuckin' credibility" in the run-up to the Oscars. The actor is tipped to receive a nomination for his role in the upcoming The Insider. Sadly, nobody thought to point out to Mercer that serial hell-raising is these days a virtual prerequisite for nomination hopefuls (as Sean Penn and Robert Downey Junior could confirm).

Both Cropper and Mercer are charged with conspiring to extort, conspiring to pervert justice and conspiring to hinder an investigation. Crowe has made no comment.

Meanwhile, back in the infinitely more civilised Los Angeles, Kelly LeBrock (best remembered from 1985's dire teen-sci-fi romp, Weird Science) has settled a lawsuit with her managers. Following the first rule of Hollywood - if at first you don't succeed, then sue - LeBrock issued a writ after an attempt to market her own line of homeopathic medicines went down the pan. As per usual in such cases, a settlement was reached before the case arrived in court, and LeBrock is presumably now free to resume her "acting career".

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Everybody Has A Dream | A Natural Woman - The Story Of Aretha Franklin
fields.body:
Michael Robinson completes his series about new business start-ups, Everybody Has A Dream (11.0am, Radio 4), with Elizabeth Nicholson and Dee Jones. They came together four years ago through a common interest in ways to relieve the lymph damage that can follow cancer treatments. Having decided to establish a clinic in Devon, the search was under way for NHS and private health funds. Then Dee Jones found that she had developed cancer herself.

Though many fans of Aretha Franklin regard her voice as one of the most magnificent in soul music, her long career has gone through some strangely arid patches. She began promisingly enough in the 1950s as a pupil of the splendid Mahalia Jackson. By 1967 Franklin had five records simultaneously in the American top ten but a succession of failed marriages and poor professional handling intervened. Charlie Gillett traces her switchback fortunes in A Natural Woman - The Story Of Aretha Franklin (9.0pm, Radio 2).

fields.headline: Unhealthy interest
fields.trailText: Children's Hospital | Castaway 2000 | Graham Greene: The Beginning Of The End Of The Affair
fields.body:
One of the greatest mysteries of modern broadcasting deepened last night as Children's Hospital (BBC1) strode into its umpteenth series with another collection of sick and injured kids and their shellshocked parents. It's easy to sneer at the show's success, but impossible to dismiss it: the last series drew audiences of seven million. This is no mean feat when you consider that most of us would do almost anything to avoid the circumstances depicted in the programme.

It was business as usual at Birmingham Children's Hospital: seven-year-old Nicole had sustained head injuries in a motorway accident, 12-year-old Lisa was waiting for a hole-in-the-heart operation, and tiny three-hour-old Sam had been born with his innards hanging out of a hole in his stomach, a knotty, livid mass. The surgeons got to work, the distraught parents wept, and the patients (at least those who were conscious) showed almost unbelievable pluck. As the programme wore on, one could only wonder why seven million people would voluntarily subject themselves to such harrowing viewing. This isn't, after all, a kid-glove handling of the subject, despite what the syrupy title music may suggest: the images of tiny children strapped into terrifying machines, with gloved hands manipulating their intestines, are the stuff of nightmare. The fact that this material is shown pre-watershed simply compounds the mystery.

It's impossible not to get caught up in so much suffering humanity, nor to fail to admire the health professionals who deal with this stuff every day of their working lives - but to watch it for enjoyment? Hopefully the hospital benefits from the publicity that a prime-time BBC1 slot generates, but other than that it's difficult to understand the show's raison d' tre. The success of Children's Hospital, Animal Hospital, Pet Rescue and any show in which vulnerable creatures suffer and die suggests that the nation is in the grip of a mass outbreak of Munchausen's syndrome by proxy.

There was more voluntary suffering after the news, as dozens of seemingly sane men, women and children volunteered to spend a year on a desolate Hebridean island in Castaway 2000 (BBC1). Four thousand people answered a recruitment advert; 200 of these were interviewed as potential residents for the windswept, storm-lashed island of Taransay. The bulk of last night's programme - the first of four covering the selection process - followed the wannabe Crusoes through a series of painful and disgusting exercises. Herding sheep proved beyond them, while emptying the compost sewage system (the "stuff" looked like anaemic Christmas pud) had them heaving in the bushes. A star was born in the handsome shape of Ben Fogle, a posh 25-year-old who emerged as an instant leader and all-round good guy. Happy the campers in his team; for the rest of them, the experience was a hideous blend of Lord Of The Flies and The Blair Witch Project. Three more shows (tonight and next week) complete the selection procedure; the "lucky" winners are now experiencing January on Taransay.

BBC2's Graham Greene: The Beginning Of The End Of The Affair delved into the murky personal circumstances behind the composition of Greene's 1951 masterpiece. The peg for this illuminating trot through the blasted heath of Greene's psyche is the forthcoming Neil Jordan film of the book, starring Ralph Fiennes and Julianne Moore as the writer and his lover. The story was closely based on Greene's own relationship with Catherine Walston, a beautiful, restless (and married) American woman; Greene conducted the affair and transmuted it into fiction simultaneously. Walston's son Oliver proved a strangely gung-ho guide to his mother's infidelities. More sensible reactions came from daughter Anne ("I don't like Greene's books") and Walston's sister Belinda, who chastised her nephew for his over-eagerness.

Greene emerged as an endlessly fascinating figure, a Christian who could only feel the full depth of his faith when he was deliberately sinning. The weak links in an otherwise engrossing slice of literary biography were the obligatory interviews with actors, whose opinions on Greene were neither informed nor enlightening. Julianne Moore announced that novelists often use real experiences as the basis for fiction, which came (to her, at least) as a surprise.

fields.headline: You couldn't make it up
fields.standfirst: Frank Skinner and David Baddiel's new TV show will be live, unscripted and unrehearsed. Are they being brilliant and daring or do they just have so much clout, they can flog the television companies any old idea? By  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: Frank Skinner and David Baddiel's new TV show will be live, unscripted and unrehearsed. Are they being brilliant and daring or do they just have so much clout, they can flog the television companies any old idea? By Danny Leigh
fields.body:
So, you're sitting on the sofa, shooting the breeze, small-talking with your mate about nothing in particular. Big deal. Except, while doing so - and here's the rub - you're live on national TV. Cameras point, producers huddle, and an audience of who knows how many lap up your every appalling faux-pas and failed one-liner. It's the stuff of nightmares.

And, in a strange echo of Jerry Seinfeld's fictional pitch for a "show about nothing", it's also the premise of David Baddiel and Frank Skinner's latest enterprise, an unrehearsed, unscripted half-hour of what the latter describes as "two blokes talking to a bunch of strangers about whatever comes up". That - to be broadcast this spring under the title Baddiel And Skinner Unplanned, after being bought by ITV for an indeterminate seven-figures - is that.

"Are we out of our minds? Are ITV out of their minds?" pondered Skinner as the network announced their purchase, and it's perhaps the second query which has provoked the most interest: after all, in the studiously choreographed world of primetime, winging it on-air is about as far as you can get from the done thing. Think of the potential for controversy, obscenity, for sheer unadulterated tedium.

Not, it must be said, that the onetime new lads' idea is quite as novel as it first sounds; pre-recorded though it was, Channel 5's confrontational-comedy The People vs Jerry Sadowitz took much the same High Concept (no script and the studio audience as guests) and ran with it back in 1997. The comparison isn't lost on Sadowitz himself, whose inimitably aggressive approach made him a far riskier proposition than either of his successors: "I'm slightly depressed," he admits, "because it basically sounds like it's my show. I just hope Channel 5 gets the credit for doing it first."

Mine hosts, moreover, are hardly strangers to the (non) format, having bumbled through the BBC's pointedly slapdash and hugely successful Fantasy Football League before abandoning the paper gags altogether during last year's Edinburgh Festival.

"I saw them do their unscripted show in Edinburgh," recalls Matt Lucas, comic actor and co-writer of last year's Channel 4 sitcom Boyz Unlimited, "and it was genuinely brilliant. They chatted to the audience, busked songs, took suggestions on what to talk about - it could have fallen flat at any point, but it was actually very, very funny."

Graham Linehan, co-creator of Father Ted, agrees that while the risk factor will never entirely disappear, hiring such old hands should mean the network is on safe ground: "Fantasy Football always had that nice, made-up-as-we-go-along quality," he remarks, "and although this is on a bigger scale, it's something they've already proved themselves capable of."

Where eyebrows have been raised, however, is in ITV's willingness to hand over yet more big money - after Skinner's £20 million departure from the BBC, and Baddiel's share in £5.5 million for a Sky sitcom co-written with The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw - and, more importantly, all practical control of what's actually being broadcast. Sure, the stars of the show have the track record and the chutzpah, but can you really trust anyone with three series' worth of live, entirely unstructured chit-chat?

Pete Sinclair, whose scriptwriting career "making other people funny" includes such mainstream staples as Have I Got News For You, is convinced Baddiel And Skinner Unplanned is proof of a star system gone haywire.

"It's no fault of the stars themselves," he explains, "but I do think it's symptomatic of commissioning editors going after the comfort of a big name no matter what the cost. The thing is, while having a well known face is no guarantee of success, it does insure against failure. From the commissioner's point of view, if a show with a star collapses, at least people will understand why they bought it."

All of which leaves young scriptwriters in the unenviable position of breaking into a business where prior celebrity increasingly outweighs good ideas.

"That's the problem," Sinclair continues. "If a show developed with a young writer flops, the commissioning editor knows everyone's going to ask them what they were thinking of in the first place. And so you get this situation where a star can essentially push through any idea they want. Which to be honest isn't good for either scriptwriters or the performers - successful shows are almost always very tightly structured and tightly written, which is a process that obviously needs both writers and performers."

So, while even the surprisingly emollient Sadowitz wishes them luck - "I've always thought Frank Skinner was an excellent stand-up, so he should make a decent fist of it" - the suspicion remains that Baddiel And Skinner Unplanned may, further down the line, end in someone else's tears.

"Personally I like both Baddiel and Skinner," muses Sinclair, "and I've got a feeling this show may well be a success - I'm just not sure how healthy it is for the industry. There's an awful lot of money about now, and performers are constantly encouraged to think they can do everything on their own."

He measures his words for a moment.

"And, at some point, they're going to see that they can't."

Are ITV out of their minds?" pondered Skinner as the network announced their purchase, and it's perhaps the second query which has provoked the most interest: after all, in the studiously choreographed world of primetime, winging it on-air is about as far as you can get from the done thing. Think of the potential for controversy, obscenity, for sheer unadulterated tedium. Not, it must be said, that the onetime new lads' idea is quite as novel as it first sounds; pre-recorded though it was, Channel 5's confrontational-comedy The People vs Jerry Sadowitz took much the same High Concept (no script and the studio audience as guests) and ran with it back in 1997. The comparison isn't lost on Sadowitz himself, whose inimitably aggressive approach made him a far riskier proposition than either of his successors: "I'm slightly depressed," he admits, "because it basically sounds like it's my show. I just hope Channel 5 gets the credit for doing it first." Mine hosts, moreover, are hardly strangers to the (non) format, having bumbled through the BBC's pointedly slapdash and hugely successful Fantasy Football League before abandoning the paper gags altogether during last year's Edinburgh Festival. "I saw them do their unscripted show in Edinburgh," recalls Matt Lucas, comic actor and co-writer of last year's Channel 4 sitcom Boyz Unlimited, "and it was genuinely brilliant. They chatted to the audience, busked songs, took suggestions on what to talk about - it could have fallen flat at any point, but it was actually very, very funny." Graham Linehan, co-creator of Father Ted, agrees that while the risk factor will never entirely disappear, hiring such old hands should mean the network is on safe ground: "Fantasy Football always had that nice, made-up-as-we-go-along quality," he remarks, "and although this is on a bigger scale, it's something they've already proved themselves capable of." Where eyebrows have been raised, however, is in ITV's willingness to hand over yet more big money - after Skinner's £20 million departure from the BBC, and Baddiel's share in £5.5 million for a Sky sitcom co-written with The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw - and, more importantly, all practical control of what's actually being broadcast. Sure, the stars of the show have the track record and the chutzpah, but can you really trust anyone with three series' worth of live, entirely unstructured chit-chat? Pete Sinclair, whose scriptwriting career "making other people funny" includes such mainstream staples as Have I Got News For You, is convinced Baddiel And Skinner Unplanned is proof of a star system gone haywire. "It's no fault of the stars themselves," he explains, "but I do think it's symptomatic of commissioning editors going after the comfort of a big name no matter what the cost. The thing is, while having a well known face is no guarantee of success, it does insure against failure. From the commissioner's point of view, if a show with a star collapses, at least people will understand why they bought it." All of which leaves young scriptwriters in the unenviable position of breaking into a business where prior celebrity increasingly outweighs good ideas. "That's the problem," Sinclair continues. "If a show developed with a young writer flops, the commissioning editor knows everyone's going to ask them what they were thinking of in the first place. And so you get this situation where a star can essentially push through any idea they want. Which to be honest isn't good for either scriptwriters or the performers - successful shows are almost always very tightly structured and tightly written, which is a process that obviously needs both writers and performers." So, while even the surprisingly emollient Sadowitz wishes them luck - "I've always thought Frank Skinner was an excellent stand-up, so he should make a decent fist of it" - the suspicion remains that Baddiel And Skinner Unplanned may, further down the line, end in someone else's tears. "Personally I like both Baddiel and Skinner," muses Sinclair, "and I've got a feeling this show may well be a success - I'm just not sure how healthy it is for the industry. There's an awful lot of money about now, and performers are constantly encouraged to think they can do everything on their own." He measures his words for a moment. "And, at some point, they're going to see that they can't."

fields.headline: Lost in space
fields.standfirst:
Nasa gives up on spacecraft sent to Mars
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Nasa scientists have given up their efforts to locate the Mars Polar Lander, the $165m (£100m) spacecraft that disappeared on December 3 as it started its descent to the surface of the red planet.
fields.body:
Nasa scientists have given up their efforts to locate the Mars Polar Lander, the $165m (£100m) spacecraft that disappeared on December 3 as it started its descent to the surface of the red planet.

Richard Cook, the Mars lander project manager at Nasa's jet propulsion laboratory in Pasadena, said in a statement released yesterday that the last commands were sent to the spacecraft on January 6.

"Since then we've had a series of relay communication sessions using Mars global surveyor to listen for the lander around the clock. These attempts have ended today [Monday], concluding our attempts to recover the spacecraft."

He said the Mars global surveyor would continue to take pictures of the landing site in hopes of spotting the lander or its parachute until February.

The lander was last heard of as it hit the Martian atmosphere near the planet's south pole on a mission to probe the surface for water. If found, it could provide vital clues on whether life existed there or could do in the future.

webTitle: The long list of Blair policies he opposes

fields.headline: The long list of Blair policies he opposes
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Over the last 18 months, Mr Livingstone has been anxious to build bridges with the Blair government. In an open letter to Tony Blair published in the Guardian in January 1999, he promised to "work with your government, not against it".
fields.body:
Over the last 18 months, Mr Livingstone has been anxious to build bridges with the Blair government. In an open letter to Tony Blair published in the Guardian in January 1999, he promised to "work with your government, not against it".

Mr Livingstone has said he has "no ideological conflict" with the government. He wrote in the Observer: "I am not an identikit of Tony Blair. We have differed on some issues, but nine times out of 10 we agree."

This claim only stands up if the one of 10 times he does not agree is permitted to encompass Mr Livingstone's opposition to the Blair government's economic policy, education policy, transport policy, foreign policy and managerial style.

Britain was, Mr Livingstone has said, running behind America "like a demented poodle"; he "totally disagrees" with education secretary David Blunkett's policies; "there are a lot of truly ghastly people around Blair, like lice on the back of a hedgehog."

He once said: "I assumed all that rubbish about New Labour was just something he said to win the election. I didn't think he believed in it," although he also told the Guardian in 1995 that "Blair is the most rightwing leader Labour has ever had".

But his ire has been most frequently directed at John Prescott, whose plans to involve private money in the London underground he opposes, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who he has said should be sacked.

He has said that Mr Blair committed "a major error of judgment" in giving Mr Brown control of economic policy; Mr Brown's first budget was "a tragic lost opportunity for Britain"; and the chancellor's economic policy was "precisely the opposite of what is needed"; the next slump would be the "Brown recession". He also inflamed ministers by using the phrase "stealth taxes", also used by the Tories, to attack Mr Brown.

fields.headline: MoD 'wastes £30m' on failed computer systems
fields.trailText: The ministry of defence has wasted nearly £30m on computer systems abandoned because they did not work or were out of date, parliament's financial watchdog discloses today.
fields.body:
The ministry of defence has wasted nearly £30m on computer systems abandoned because they did not work or were out of date, parliament's financial watchdog discloses today. The national audit office also reports serious weaknesses in the MoD's accounting system. It refers to charges against a civil servant who allegedly paid £470,000 into his personal bank account. Only £48,000 has been recovered.

The civil servant, whom the ministry declined to name yesterday, worked in the army's pensions department in Glasgow. He is due to appear in Glasgow high court next month.

An internal investigation unearthed what Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, described as "serious financial management and control weaknesses", including failing to monitor payments and establish whether pensioners were still alive.

A specially designed computer system bought by the RAF in 1989 for sending signals to 13 bases developed "unacceptable problems" by 1996.

In 1997 the RAF decided to abandon the system at a cost of £21m. A year later it bought a system off the shelf for just £1.3m.

The ministry also reveals how the navy bought a pay and pensions computer system in 1994 when it was estimated to cost £18.9m. A year later, its cost had risen to more than £40m and it was already estimated to be four years late. By 1996, the ministry decided to close down the project at a cost of £8.7m.

It is the seventh time in 10 years the audit office has criticised the MoD for overspending.

Sir John says today: "In 1998-99 the ministry of defence once again failed to keep their spending within the limits set by parliament. The loss of public funds through abortive expenditure on IT projects is clearly a cause for concern."

A ministry spokesman last night admitted that its financial management left a lot to be desired. But he said changes were being introduced and pointed to recent successes, including a new joint operation command system at Northwood in north-west London, which was used in the Kosovo war.

The MoD is also moving to a system of resource accounting along the lines of the private sector, with its assets and liabilities more clearly costed.

webTitle: Livingstone: Mayoral tactic could create power base as independent

fields.headline: Livingstone: Mayoral tactic could create power base as independent
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has been secretly approaching high-profile individuals in the capital to gauge their willingness to stand as independent candidates for the Greater London assembly in a bid to build a power base if he becomes mayor.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has been secretly approaching high-profile individuals in the capital to gauge their willingness to stand as independent candidates for the Greater London assembly in a bid to build a power base if he becomes mayor.

If he lost the Labour nomination to Frank Dobson, those individuals would clearly be seen as his allies if he mounted an independent challenge for the job.

But people approached by Mr Livingstone or intermediaries say that even if he wins Labour's endorsement, he is concerned about the amount of control that would be exerted on him by the Labour group - made up of Blairites chosen by Millbank - in the assembly. His calculation is that a group of independent but pro-Livingstone assembly members could hold the balance of power.

Under the new system of London government, the 25-strong assembly is designed to provide a check on the mayor. But, as Mr Livingstone told his biographer, John Carvel, he calculated it would be possible to be an effective mayor with the support of nine GLA members, because a two-thirds majority of assembly members is needed to veto the mayor's budget.

One of those sounded out, Tony Travers of the London School of Economics, said: "I talked to Ken in a way that he led me to believe that he was interested in testing out the idea of whether it would be possible to get individuals to stand as independents, to stand outside political parties as an independent group in the assembly."

Mr Travers said it would be "difficult not to infer" that he was being invited by Mr Livingstone to put his name forward, but he shrugged off the approach.

Mr Livingstone also suggested the names of Simon Jenkins, the former Times editor, and Sir Peter Hall, professor of planning at University College, London.

Mr Jenkins said last night: "In the course of conversations with Ken, I was aware that he was worried about his possible support in the assembly and he was floating the idea of a list of independents who would be kind of Ken Livingstone backers other than Blairite backers - in other words an alternative group in the assembly.

"I understood that I was one of a group of people who he mooted to others might be persuaded to stand and might not be unhelpful to him. He never asked me directly and I can't imagine myself standing."

Sir Peter Hall said that he had never been approached by Mr Livingstone. But he added: "Someone said to me months ago that Ken Livingstone was going around saying you might be an independent candidate for the GLA and I just found the whole thing fantastic that I discounted it. I've never had anything to do with Ken Livingstone and I'm certainly not a Ken Livingstone supporter."

Mr Livingstone last night denied that he had sounded out Mr Travers about running for the GLA. "What I said to Tony Travers was I hoped he'd come and be part of my administration and he declined." But Mr Jenkins confirmed the idea had been "strictly to do with the assembly".

The revelation casts further doubt on Mr Livingstone's public insistence - repeated yesterday - that "under no circumstances" would he run as an independent for mayor.

Ballot papers to select Labour's candidate go out next Wednesday and the result is expected to be announced a few days after the vote closes on February 16.

Nomination papers for Greater London assembly candidates will not be sent out by the returning officer until March, with the closing date in early April. The election proper is on May 4.

Downing Street yesterday seized on Mr Livingstone's comments to the Face magazine that he supported "direct action" and would put the World Trade Organisation in "vast stocks" so people could throw things at its officials. Frank Dobson called the remarks "irresponsible" and "disturbing".

Mr Livingstone yesterday dismissed the comments as "a series of one-line gags".

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Neil Kinnock, European commission vice-president, announced long-awaited measures to modernise the Brussels bureaucracy, get rid of the gravy train image and end the jobs for life culture in the EU civil service.

Bad day

Transport minister Lord Whitty faced a barrage of technical questions about London's millennium wheel. He did his best to field them, but when asked by Baroness Trumpington how people got out if it stuck ("is there a ladder long enough") he said there were "emergency exits".

Bad joke of the day

Tory MP Julian Lewis asked the speaker about the possibility of Sinn Fein MPs Martin McGuinness and Gerry Adams being offered use of facilities at Westminster, wondering "whether in future, instead of just checking members' cars for bombs on the way into the car park, there will checks for such devices on the way out of the car park".

Fact of the day
Culture secretary Chris Smith revealed that the Royal Opera House had cancelled nine performances since the opening season was announced last year, at a loss of £243,115.

Today

Prime minister's questions at 3pm. In the commons the remaining stages of the representation of the people bill and second reading of the fur farming (prohibition) bill.

fields.headline: Media protest fuels section 28 row
fields.trailText: Scotland's political leaders and gay rights campaigners are braced today for a fresh assault on plans to repeal section 28, the legislation which bans teachers from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality.
fields.body:
Scotland's political leaders and gay rights campaigners are braced today for a fresh assault on plans to repeal section 28, the legislation which bans teachers from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality.

Steps to erase the clause from the local government act 1988 are passing almost unnoticed through Westminster, but in Scotland the issue has pitted parent against teacher, thrown the churches into turmoil and generated an increasingly ugly war of words.

A media campaign to retain the clause will be launched in Edinburgh today by the Scottish school board association (SSBA), backed by £500,000 from Brian Souter, chairman of the Stagecoach bus and train company.

On Monday the head of the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland, Cardinal Thomas Winning, condemned homosexuality as a perversion and accused the first minister, Donald Dewar, of ignoring the "silent majority" who oppose repeal of the law.

The Scottish executive, which has described the clause as a badge of shame, said yesterday that 75% of those who responded during the consultation process were in favour of repeal. The clause bans local authorities from intentionally promoting homosexuality or promoting the teaching in schools of its acceptability.

Last October the Scottish communities minister, Wendy Alexander, announced that the clause would be repealed in the ethical standards in public life bill. She has since assured parents and teachers that the intention is not to promote homosexuality but to remove blatant discrimination from the statute books.

Supporters of repeal say the issue has been hijacked by extremists and say today's media launch will serve only to stir up further homophobia.

Jack Irvine, SSBA spokesman, said there had been no public debate on the issue, and "the Scottish public has been kept completely in ignorance. We don't think that's democratic".

fields.headline: Pierre Juillet
fields.standfirst: Gaullist champion whose power in France outlived the general
fields.trailText: For many, the French politician Pierre Juillet, who has died aged 78, was the most devoted of Gaullists. For others, he was an unwelcome influence who sought to be the power behind the throne. He was a Gaullist from June 1940, and he fought courageously in the resistance. When France was liberated, he was nearly shot by a group of communists, who mistook him for someone else - an incident that confirmed him in the belief that communists were not really French.
fields.body:
For many, the French politician Pierre Juillet, who has died aged 78, was the most devoted of Gaullists. For others, he was an unwelcome influence who sought to be the power behind the throne. He was a Gaullist from June 1940, and he fought courageously in the resistance. When France was liberated, he was nearly shot by a group of communists, who mistook him for someone else - an incident that confirmed him in the belief that communists were not really French.

Juillet joined the Gaullist party, the Rally of the French people, when it was formed in 1947. He became its representative in his department, the Creuse, where he had been born the son of a prefect, and where he raised cattle, as well as carrying out various surveys in south-west France. But he was never accepted as one of the "barons of Gaullism". In particular, he never got on friendly terms with the general himself, although he married one of his secretaries, Annick Mousnier. At times, he worked for a press agency in Brussels, but he held himself available for de Gaulle's return to power.

When this took place in 1958, Juillet was rewarded with an appointment in André Malraux's private cabinet. He accompanied his minister on overseas trips and made himself indispensable. When Georges Pompidou became prime minister of France in 1962, Juillet's task was to prepare for the 1967 elections. He saw many people, fed information to Pompidou - and was one of the few people to foresee the student unrest of 1968.

When Pompidou ceased to be prime minister, Juillet followed him, and, together with his associate Marie-France Garaud, established an office in the Boulevard Latour-Maubourg, where they defended themselves against scandal. In particular, there was the rumour, which de Gaulle did nothing to suppress, that Madame Pompidou was implicated in the mysterious death of a bodyguard working for the film-star Alain Delon.

Pompidou never forgot his friends - or his enemies. Consequently, when elected president of France, he installed Juillet in a magnificent office in the Elysée Palace, from where his influence was considerable.

Juillet disliked prime minister Jean-Jaques Chaban-Delmas, believing that his reforms would take France towards socialism, and he helped to get him dismissed in 1972. When Pompidou was suffering from his long and fatal illness, Juillet controlled those few who were admitted to see him. He approved of Jacques Chirac and helped his ministerial ascension through agriculture to the interior in 1974.

Juillet's last service to Chirac came after the latter's resignation as prime minister in August, 1976 - he helped him to create his own political party, the Rassemblement pour la Republique. In December 1978, with Chirac in the Cochin hospital after a motor accident, Juillet helped draft the "appel du Cochin", denouncing the forthcoming European parliamentary elections. The limit of his European beliefs, it was said, was his interest in cross-breeding Scottish and French cattle.

But this was the end of Juillet's role, and those who thought that the "appel du Cochin" was a mistake blamed him. He had always seen himself as the conscience of Gaullism, yet, in the end, he was forced to witness its decline.

He died in the village where he was born and is survived by his wife and two children.

Douglas Johnson

Pierre Juillet, politician, born July 22 1921; died December 23 1999

Pompidou never forgot his friends - or his enemies. Consequently, when elected president of France, he installed Juillet in a magnificent office in the Elysée Palace, from where his influence was considerable. Juillet disliked prime minister Jean-Jaques Chaban-Delmas, believing that his reforms would take France towards socialism, and he helped to get him dismissed in 1972. When Pompidou was suffering from his long and fatal illness, Juillet controlled those few who were admitted to see him. He approved of Jacques Chirac and helped his ministerial ascension through agriculture to the interior in 1974. Juillet's last service to Chirac came after the latter's resignation as prime minister in August, 1976 - he helped him to create his own political party, the Rassemblement pour la Republique. In December 1978, with Chirac in the Cochin hospital after a motor accident, Juillet helped draft the "appel du Cochin", denouncing the forthcoming European parliamentary elections. The limit of his European beliefs, it was said, was his interest in cross-breeding Scottish and French cattle. But this was the end of Juillet's role, and those who thought that the "appel du Cochin" was a mistake blamed him. He had always seen himself as the conscience of Gaullism, yet, in the end, he was forced to witness its decline. He died in the village where he was born and is survived by his wife and two children. Douglas Johnson Pierre Juillet, politician, born July 22 1921; died December 23 1999

fields.headline: Gene Harris
fields.trailText: Gene Harris, who has died aged 66, was a gifted and expansive self-taught jazz pianist, a master of a distinctive mainstream confection of swing, gospel, blues and boogie-woogie.
fields.body:
Gene Harris, who has died aged 66, was a gifted and expansive self-taught jazz pianist, a master of a distinctive mainstream confection of swing, gospel, blues and boogie-woogie.

He appealed often to listeners who otherwise might encounter very little jazz, and his performances frequently turned into parties, in which the audience would goad and cheer him to still more ecstatic heights. He often operated like a more bluesy and less pyrotechnical Oscar Peterson, and, like Peterson, he could play the daylights out of just about any jazz piano style, apart from free-jazz. The dynamics and amiable dramatics of his shows derived from knowing when to drop out and let the pulse do the work.

A Harris performance could be a fast-moving business, but any tendency to relentlessness was usually offset by the almost insolent ease with which he achieved the most dazzling effects. An unbroken flow of pieces would be launched off the back of each other without announcement, seething swing suddenly hurtling out of densely weaving unaccompanied arpeggios, dropping away into slow left-hand blues patterns hit so hard as to threaten the life of the piano frame - charging boogie-woogie turning abruptly into the caress of a ballad like Misty. Beneath all this would be Harris's exquisite control of tone, and his work's inspiration in the blues.

Born in Benson Harbor, Michigan, Harris taught himself boogie-woogie piano when he was nine years old, inspired by the hard-driving sound of the great pioneers of the the style, Albert Ammons and Pete Johnson. In the US 82nd Airborne Division's band from 1951 to 1954, he heard a wider range of styles and expanded his technique, and after demobilisation was offered regular touring work. In 1956, he formed his own band, the Three Sounds, with the bassist Andy Simpkins and the drummer Bill Dowdy, specialising in a repertoire rarely far from the blues, and working a circuit of venues around Michigan and Washington.

They moved to New York in 1958 and broadened their scope to take in a more general mainstream-to-bop jazz feel, playing standards and Broadway tunes - but their roots in the blues fitted a period in which jazz was under pressure from rock 'n' roll, and the ensemble offered commercial as well as musical attractions to the Blue Note record label during the 1960s. Harris also lent his piano muscle to recordings by Stanley Turrentine, James Clay, Milt Jackson and Benny Carter among others.

Dowdy and Simkins quit in the late 1960s, but Harris continued to run larger bands under the same name, and the raunchiness and openness of his music almost inevitably led him toward the funky jazz-rock style that was one of the few lucrative avenues for jazz musicians at that time. But he was a musical sophisticate for all his get-down rawness, and in 1977 - announcing his semi-retirement and moving to Boise, Idaho - he returned to more straight-ahead jazz playing.

In 1980, he performed as part of a regular quartet at the Hacienda, Las Vegas, but a transformation in his life occurred in the middle of that decade, with a resurgence of interest in the earlier acoustic forms of jazz resulting in a deal with Concord Records.

Retirement or no, 22 albums followed. Some of them featured all but interchangeable Harris characteristics, but some were sparkling performances, notably a devastating version of Take The A Train (on the 1993 live recording, A Little Piece of Heaven).

Harris's resurgence led not only to these lively small-band sessions - partnership with the bass virtuoso Ray Brown was a notable highlight - but to the emergence of an all-star Count Basie-like big band, the Gene Harris Superband, which toured extensively and was nominated for a Grammy in 1988 for its tribute to Basie himself.

Harris is survived by his wife Janie, two daughters and a son.

John Fordham

Eugene 'Gene' Harris, musician, born September 1 1933; died January 16 2000

fields.headline: Ulster's wake-up
fields.standfirst:
Today's announcement on the RUC's future marks the end of a political honeymoon - and brings the crunch on decommissioning closer
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: It was fun while it lasted, a euphoric honeymoon when the astonishing pace of political change left everyone a little flummoxed. Now it is time to wake up.
fields.body:
It was fun while it lasted, a euphoric honeymoon when the astonishing pace of political change left everyone a little flummoxed. Now it is time to wake up.

Today Peter Mandelson will implement Chris Patten's controversial report on the RUC, virtually in full. He is expected to announce a minor concession on the crown-and-harp badge and to signal an important brake on the proposed local policing boards, with the aim of averting paramilitary involvement. But the name will go. So too, eventually, will the Special Branch.

That will cut down Ulster Unionists' already limited scope for manoeuvre on that other spectre stalking the new dispensation. February 12 is the crunch date. That Saturday David Trimble, first minister, reconvenes his 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council to take stock of its decision to enter government immediately with Sinn Fein, in anticipation of quick IRA decommissioning. He has said he will resign if he is unable to report any such move on arms.

Back in November he calculated he would lose unless he made the promise. And there was a reason why he selected February. He believes he had a private deal with Sinn Fein that IRA decommissioning would start in January, so allowing General John de Chastelain, head of the Independent Commission on Decommissioning, to so report later this month.

The verbal assurances are said to have come in a meeting involving only five people toward the end of ex-US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday Agreement. Along with Mitchell, those present were Trimble, his lieutenant Sir Reg Empey and Sinn Fein's Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness. Sinn Fein vehemently denies any secret deal. But the clear belief among those who took part in the Mitchell review was that IRA decommissioning would come during January.

Opinion has swung around over the past two months. At meetings in the US, leading republicans Pat Doherty and Martin Ferris appeared to throw doubt that decommioning was imminent. Last month, Sunday papers claimed in stories apparently inspired by Downing Street that decommissioning would start by January 16. Ten days ago, they said the general had been invited to witness a symbolic destruction of some IRA weaponry, and would then oversee the sealing of arms dumps.

But sources close to General de Chastelain say he was left mystified by these tales: the IRA had given him nothing to support any such claim. He had already sounded cautious in his December 10 report, just after he first met the IRA go-between, suggesting he would lay down a start date if paramilitaries failed to do so. He is thought since to have had a second meeting with the IRA.

He also insists his mandate means destruction of weapons, and that the British and Irish governments would have to bring forward new legislation if "sealing" arms dumps was to be an option. The Northern Ireland Office disagrees and that will have to be settled.

Gerry Adams has adopted a belligerent tone recently, demanding David Trimble show leadership and berating him for setting his own deadline for decommissioning. That was to be expected, for republicans want to wring as much as possible from the Patten report and Peter Mandelson's expected announcement on cutting the army's presence.

Adams and McGuinness have adopted an analogy which throws doubt over the IRA's intentions. They say that the boat of inclusive democracy is only now setting sail with all on board; anyone who jumps off will surely drown.

David Trimble said Sinn Fein would attract worldwide condemnation if the IRA subsequently failed to decommission. The new metaphor indicates a real truth: that he will somehow be blamed if the executive collapses should the IRA refuse to play ball.

Sinn Fein is happy enough with the confusion. It improves its short-term negotiating position, and it also helps to reduce the likelihood of more defections from the IRA.

There has been none of the explicit conditioning of republican grassroots that there was ahead of the agreement; there is no information from the security forces suggesting that decommissioning is imminent. Yet there is a perception within mainstream republicanism that decommissioning is coming.

One senior provisional said there had been a deliberate policy of avoiding any internal debate, fostering the false impression that opposition was minimal. He felt those against decommissioning had been cleverly out-manoeuvred, with the leadership successfully pleading with them to stick with the peace process until it was too late to oppose it.

There is bitterness within the IRA. Some members feel the leadership is prepared to jettison many of them because Sinn Fein's electoral strength is now republicanism's real strength. Opponents of decommissioning appear to be left with nowhere to go. Most dismiss the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bombing, and agree there can be no return to war.

This all may point to IRA decommissioning taking place, but the only deadline republicans recognise is May, the aspirational date in the agreement for the completion of the Good Friday process. It seems highly unlikely a start will be made by February 12, with Sinn Fein and the IRA furious at what they see as Trimble's unilateral approach.

Last week in the Commons, the Northern Ireland secretary talked tough, saying an early move is necessary if decommissioning is to be completed in four months. He was careful to mention no deadline other than May's.

Unless General de Chastelain is able to break good news later this month, David Trimble is faced with little option but to make good his promises to his party. That would signal a return to the old certainty of uncertainty, and the demise of the now flourishing agreement. All over an issue which is about faith, not weapons.

John Mullin is the Guardian's Ireland correspondent

Decommissioning countdown
Good Friday 1998: timetable agreed
Today: future shape of Royal Ulster Constabulary announced
January 31/February 1: General de Chastelain due to report on arms removal
February 12: UUP's council meets to decide on staying in new executive
May 22: final date for "all paramilitaries" to decommission

fields.headline: Microsoft fights monopoly claim
fields.standfirst:
Biggest software company denies breaking law and puts success down to being 'popular product'
Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft came out fighting against judicial claims that it is a monopoly and abused its dominance of the personal computer industry last night in its first official response to the preliminary ruling of the landmark legal battle.
fields.body:
Microsoft came out fighting against judicial claims that it is a monopoly and abused its dominance of the personal computer industry last night in its first official response to the preliminary ruling of the landmark legal battle.

The world's largest software company said the preliminary findings of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson did not prove it had broken any law. The judge dealt Microsoft a severe blow in his first ruling two months ago, accusing it of harming consumers and stifling competition by bullying competitors and partners.

Jim Cullinan, a Microsoft spokesman, said last night that this judgment did not necessarily warrant legal remedy. "Just because it was not the best picture painted of the company, that doesn't add up to a violation of the law," he said.

The strength of Microsoft's denial confirms its uncompromising stance on the issue less than a week after Bill Gates, its founder, stepped back from the day-to-day running of the company. Mr Gates, the world's wealthiest man, was seen as instrumental in the group's almost intransigent approach to accusations brought by the US justice department and 19 US states.

Unable to deny the findings of fact decreed by the judge in November, Microsoft's chief argument rests with its belief that the government has failed to prove that it broke the law. In the filing lodged last night, Microsoft stated: "Even accepting the court's findings of fact, plaintiffs still have not satisfied their burden under the governing law on any of their claims."

The Seattle-based group denied that its behaviour had prevented Netscape, a key competitor, from entering the market for internet browsers. It also claimed that the government's case ignored "many of the most serious competitive threats faced by Microsoft's operating systems". Finally, the company argued that controlling more than 90% of the world's operating systems through its Windows service was not illegal. "Having an extremely popular product doesn't make a company a monopoly," it said.

Legal experts were unsurprised at the group's tactics last night and said Microsoft could do little else in spite of the settlement talks currently being carried out.

Ed Black, president of the Computer and Communications Industry Association which has campaigned against Microsoft, said: "I expected nothing less than a full court press to try to argue their case. They are going to pick on any point they can quibble with."

The independent mediator presiding over the talks has indicated that he wants to see some evidence of common ground by the end of this month.

But the talks could drag on until the next time Microsoft and the government are due to appear before Judge Jackson towards the end of February.

Although Microsoft reported better than expected earnings and record revenues, traders took fright at a relatively pes simistic forecast for the future. Earnings jumped 22% to 44 cents a share in the last three months of the year, above market expectations of 42 cents in spite of an exceptional charge to settle a far smaller anti-trust case.

Group revenues of $6.1bn benefited from strong demand for personal computers over the Christmas period.

fields.headline: Chamber musing
fields.standfirst:
Reform of the House of Lords must strengthen our democracy. Tinkering will not suffice
Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The Wakeham Commission's report on reform of the Lords is due out tomorrow. The prime minister's political opponents claim he will simply want to shelve it, letting us make do with a partly reformed house. Is there, in fact, an incentive for government to go any further?
fields.body:
The Wakeham Commission's report on reform of the Lords is due out tomorrow. The prime minister's political opponents claim he will simply want to shelve it, letting us make do with a partly reformed house. Is there, in fact, an incentive for government to go any further?

Last November's reform removed most hereditaries and left a "transitional" chamber, mostly of life peers. This ended the chamber's Conservative bias, which for Labour was a primary motivation for reform. The house now has 183 Labour members and 233 Conservatives. Despite Labour's slight disadvantage, it will be difficult for the Conservatives to inflict defeat, due to 54 Liberal Democrat and 163 non-party peers.

None the less, the new composition of the house will probably give it a renewed confidence. The "Salisbury convention", established under the 1945 Labour government, required that the Lords did not obstruct the implementation of government policy. But this was primarily due to its Conservative bias. Lord Strathclyde, for the Conservatives, has suggested that such conventions may now wither away. His logic is correct. The end of Conservative hegemony means there is now no reason why the opposition in the chamber should not go ahead and oppose.

If it does, the government's reaction is predictable. Elected to implement a programme and with a commanding majority in the Commons, such interference will surely cause irritation. Despite assurances that the transitional chamber will be more legitimate than the last - and so it is - this may mean little in practice. When the unreformed House of Lords attempted to amend the welfare reform and pensions bill last year, Alistair Darling referred to the interference as "a constitutional matter", saying: "The House of Lords has to accept that we are the elected chamber." Note that his criticism was not based on the presence of hereditary peers.

Just last week Jack Straw made similar comments about the transitional house in relation to trial by jury. The temptation to denigrate an unelected upper house standing in the way of government policy is too strong for ministers to resist.

The danger, of course, is that the standing of the transitional house sinks rapidly to match its hereditary predecessor. Any new found confidence may prove to be shortlived. The toothless Canadian senate (the only other appointed chamber in a western democracy) provides a clear precedent.

This explains why the Conservatives accuse Labour of wanting to stick to the status quo. Given the choice, would any government choose a powerful and combative upper house over a docile and compliant one, especially after 18 years in opposition?

However, the experience of those opposition years should also demonstrate the potential dangers of such a chamber. In the 80s the Tories had free rein to introduce policies such as the poll tax. The unelected Lords were also too cowed to block such measures as abolition of the GLC.

The proper role of an upper house should not be to rubber stamp government policy, but should include deterring governments from extreme and unpopular measures that are doomed to fail. While not being dominated by the opposition, the upper chamber should have the ability to ask government to think again .

Looking overseas, the second chambers which work combine three key factors. First, sufficient formal powers to challenge the lower house - the House of Lords' power to delay bills for a year would certainly qualify here. Second, a distinct composition to the lower house - in particular not being dominated by government. Third, and crucially, sufficient legitimacy in the eyes of the public to use their powers when necessary.

An example of one of these rare institutions is the Australian senate. It is elected by PR, in contrast to the lower house, which uses a similar system to our House of Commons. Thus a government majority in the lower house is balanced by an upper house where support by small centre parties and independents is required. In this environment it is inconceivable that a policy such as the poll tax could succeed. The upper house imposes a degree of consensus politics on the system, although this is combined with "strong government". Very Blairite, you might think.

The Labour party's debate over the candidate for London mayor has been dominated by calls for "no return to the 80s". The same might be said about the Lords. Although a party denied power for so long might understandably not want obstacles put in its way, this is a short-sighted approach. No government is in power forever, and Labour should contemplate the prospect of another period of Thatcherite government with a weak and ineffective upper house. Far better to leave behind them a second chamber which strengthens British democracy. Doing nothing should not be an option.

Meg Russell is the author of Reforming the Lords: Lessons from Overseas, published by OUP, and senior research fellow at the Constitution Unit, University College London

The danger, of course, is that the standing of the transitional house sinks rapidly to match its hereditary predecessor. Any new found confidence may prove to be shortlived. The toothless Canadian senate (the only other appointed chamber in a western democracy) provides a clear precedent. This explains why the Conservatives accuse Labour of wanting to stick to the status quo. Given the choice, would any government choose a powerful and combative upper house over a docile and compliant one, especially after 18 years in opposition? However, the experience of those opposition years should also demonstrate the potential dangers of such a chamber. In the 80s the Tories had free rein to introduce policies such as the poll tax. The unelected Lords were also too cowed to block such measures as abolition of the GLC. The proper role of an upper house should not be to rubber stamp government policy, but should include deterring governments from extreme and unpopular measures that are doomed to fail. While not being dominated by the opposition, the upper chamber should have the ability to ask government to think again . Looking overseas, the second chambers which work combine three key factors. First, sufficient formal powers to challenge the lower house - the House of Lords' power to delay bills for a year would certainly qualify here. Second, a distinct composition to the lower house - in particular not being dominated by government. Third, and crucially, sufficient legitimacy in the eyes of the public to use their powers when necessary. An example of one of these rare institutions is the Australian senate. It is elected by PR, in contrast to the lower house, which uses a similar system to our House of Commons. Thus a government majority in the lower house is balanced by an upper house where support by small centre parties and independents is required. In this environment it is inconceivable that a policy such as the poll tax could succeed. The upper house imposes a degree of consensus politics on the system, although this is combined with "strong government". Very Blairite, you might think. The Labour party's debate over the candidate for London mayor has been dominated by calls for "no return to the 80s". The same might be said about the Lords. Although a party denied power for so long might understandably not want obstacles put in its way, this is a short-sighted approach. No government is in power forever, and Labour should contemplate the prospect of another period of Thatcherite government with a weak and ineffective upper house. Far better to leave behind them a second chamber which strengthens British democracy. Doing nothing should not be an option. Meg Russell is the author of Reforming the Lords: Lessons from Overseas, published by OUP, and senior research fellow at the Constitution Unit, University College London

fields.headline: Unita 'sanctions busters' named
fields.trailText: The foreign office minister Peter Hain yesterday took the unique step of publicly naming three businessmen whom he claimed had been breaking UN sanctions on rebel forces in Angola.
fields.body:
The foreign office minister Peter Hain yesterday took the unique step of publicly naming three businessmen whom he claimed had been breaking UN sanctions on rebel forces in Angola.

Using parliamentary privilege, which carries immunity from libel action, he blamed a Belgian, a Portuguese South African and a former senior KGB officer. He yesterday referred all three to the UN sanctions committee, which has the power to prosecute them under international law.

He took the action after a discussion last month with Susan Rice, the US state department's assistant secretary for Africa, who endorsed the approach.

Mr Hain has been frustrated that the British and US governments have extensive intelligence in relation to almost daily breaches of the UN sanctions but have until now been unable to go public for fear of compromising their sources.

Mr Hain said he would make a priority of trying to end the Angolan civil war, which in its various phases has claimed hundreds of thousands of lives since 1975. The Unita forces, led by Jonas Savimbi, were heavily supported by South Africa, the CIA, and western governments such as Britain under Margaret Thatcher, for more than a decade.

Today the foreign office would like to see Mr Savimbi out of the picture as the best way of achieving peace.

Mr Hain also urged the Ukrainian government to tackle its arms dealers who had been active in Angola.

He was replying to a question from the Labour MP Joan Ryan, who said private companies, individuals and other countries were breaching UN sanctions by supplying fuel and other goods to Angola.

He told the Commons: "It is absolutely vital that private individuals and companies engaged in breaking the law by deliberately breaching UN sanctions on Unita must be stopped."

He named as a sanctions-buster Jacques "Kiki" Lemaire, a Belgian who he said was widely known to fly diesel fuel to Unita airstrips in either a Boeing 707 or a Caravelle. He had been based first in the former Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo), and then South Africa.

Mr Hain also named Tony Teixeira, a Portuguese South African who is chairman of the Central African Mining Company and was also accused of flying in diesel.

The third was a Ukrainian, Victor Bout, who, according to Mr Hain, ran the air transport company Cess, which has flown arms to Unita. A former senior KGB officer in Africa, Mr Bout formerly had the surname Boutov.

Mr Hain said it was widely believed that Mr Bout either owns or charters an aircraft impounded by Zambia en route to Angola last year.

Mr Hain told the UN security council last month that he planned to name and shame others involved in sanctions busting.
