fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Clinton seeks ballistics funds
fields.body:
Clinton seeks ballistics funds

President Bill Clinton was last night expected to ask the US congress for $280m (£170m) in additional funds to hire 500 firearms agents and inspectors and create a new programme to trace guns by comparing data on ballistics used in crimes.

The emphasis on law enforcement rather than legislation represents a subtle shift in the administration's efforts to curb gun violence. AP, Washington

Two-year-old 'not real monk'

The Reting Lama, a high-ranking Tibetan Buddhist monk, has not been reborn, and so the two-year-old boy installed by China cannot be the true reincarnation, officials at the Dalai Lama's office said yesterday.

Soinam Puncog was ordained as the 7th Reting Lama in Lhasa on Sunday at a ceremony attended by a Chinese government official. Beijing says only the government, and not the Dalai Lama, can recognise reincarnations. By naming the Reting Lama, Beijing would gain influence in naming the Dalai Lama's successor. AP, New Delhi

French couple seized in Yemen

A French couple have been kidnapped in Yemen and authorities are negotiating to secure their release, officials said yesterday.

The man and woman, along with a Yemeni driver and guide, were abducted on Monday by armed tribesmen from Imran, 31 miles north of the capital, San'a, said the official. They were taken to the northern province of al-Jawf. AP, San'a

Sentry's suicide at war memorial

A 22-year-old sentry shot and killed himself yesterday minutes after starting his early-morning watch at Italy's altar to its war dead in Piazza Venezia, Rome.

Authorities could find no immediate explanation for the suicide of the sailor, Nicola Farfagliaat, at the Victor Emmanuel II monument. AP, Rome

Maradona in Cuba for rehab

The Argentinian football star Diego Maradona arrived in Cuba yesterday to be treated for drug abuse after receiving hospital treatment in Buenos Aires for cocaine addiction.

Doctors have said that continued drug use could threaten Maradona's life. He opted for Cuba because he has been denied entry to the United States after testing positive for stimulants during the 1994 World Cup. AP, Havana

webTitle: Dare to be different, Japanese are urged

fields.headline: Dare to be different, Japanese are urged
fields.trailText: Japan must abandon its obsession with conformity and equality if it is to deal with its growing social problems.
fields.body:
Japan must abandon its obsession with conformity and equality if it is to deal with its growing social problems.

This judgment, a repudiation of many of the country's core values, was issued yesterday not by foreign critics, but by an advisory panel set up by the conservative prime minister, Keizo Obuchi.

The commission on Japan's goals in the 21st century, made up of experts including an astronaut and a playwright, was set up last year to plot a new direction for a country that has been racked by rising juvenile crime, a soaring suicide rate and record levels of bankruptcy and unemployment.

There had been speculation that the commission would try to reassert conservative "Asian values", but the surprisingly liberal report, which covers everything from education to politics and business, appears to be telling people to stop being so "typically" Japanese.

In a departure from the mura ishiki (village mentality) that is a feature of even urban Japanese society, it stressed the need for "individual empowerment". These are radical words in a country famous for the slogan "the nail that sticks up must be hammered down", and it echoes calls for change from the business community.

Until recently, salarymen were valued for loyalty, patience and hard work and rewarded with jobs for life and promotion based primarily on their years of service. This system was perfect for production line workers, but Japan is now desperate for spontaneity, innovation and ambition.

The panel suggests that the country shift away from its long-treasured egalitarianism - there is only a narrow gap between the salaries of executives and workers - in favour of a "fair disparity" to reward individual excellence.

They call for action to curb "the excessive degree of homogeneity and uniformity" in education. Instead of sticking closely to a national curriculum, the panel says compulsory subjects should be taught three days a week, with two days used for advanced lessons, review classes or music and language lessons.

The panel also argues for more lawyers; few disputes reach court, partly because of the desire to avoid a fuss. In the media, it proposes the abolition of the cosy press club ties between journalists and the subjects of their reports.

Insularity also comes under criticism. The report proposes adopting English as a second language and suggests increasing immigration in a country that has long prided itself on its ethnic "purity".

Mr Obuchi attended several of the group's meetings, but its recommendations are likely to be hard to swallow. He has promised to raise some of the issues in parliament, which is a step further than the last similar sweeping report, which has gathered dust since it was issued in the 1970s.

Tadashi Yamamoto, a member of the panel, said he hoped the new report would spark debate and be supported by the prime minister.

"He must feel that things are due to change. Japan cannot go on like this," he said.

Straitjacket society

Workers at big companies and public bodies all take summer and winter holidays at the same time, clogging up the roads and trains.

Foreigners make up only 1.5% of Japan's population. Many Koreans who have lived in Japan for generations adopt Japanese names to avoid discrimination.

Almost all schoolchildren aged up to 16 wear dark-blue sailor-style uniforms and follow the same rigid curriculum and textbooks.

Employees remain late at the office even if they have little to do because of the unspoken rule that they should not leave early.

The government pours money into barely used bridges and roads to try to maintain equality of wealth between regions.

webTitle: Karl Lagerfeld to sell off home comforts

fields.headline: Karl Lagerfeld to sell off home comforts
fields.standfirst: Fashion house supremo's array of 18th century furniture and art from his Paris mansion may fetch £30m
fields.trailText: Like everything else in his life, when Karl Lagerfeld decides to have a spring clean, he does it lavishly. Yesterday he became the latest celebrity to catch the downsizing bug when he put the contents of his Paris home up for sale for £30m.
fields.body:
Like everything else in his life, when Karl Lagerfeld decides to have a spring clean, he does it lavishly. Yesterday he became the latest celebrity to catch the downsizing bug when he put the contents of his Paris home up for sale for £30m.

The collection of 18th century French furniture, objets d'art and paintings with which he decorated his Louis XV house on rue de l'Université will go under the hammer at Christie's in April.

Like his friends Elton John and Barbra Streisand, who have recently unburdened themselves of vast collections of clothes and furniture, Lagerfeld, 61, is not selling out of necessity. Sources close to the master of the house of Chanel said he was merely "trying to simplify his life".

Lagerfeld's idea of the simple life, however, is not one of ascetic self-denial. Although he is also auctioning the contents of La Vigie, his home in Monaco, later this year, he still has three homes scattered across the globe and he is keeping some of his favourite Old Masters. The celebrated Japanese architect Ando is also building him a beach house in Biarritz.

As well as 400 pieces of furniture and ornaments, Lagerfeld is selling 150 paintings, including work by Fragonard, Boucher and Jacques de Lajoue.

Lagerfeld, who has described himself as "a passionate apostle of beauty", said last night that he had always wanted to "emulate the refinement " of Frederick the Great's palace of Sans-Souci at Potsdam just outside Berlin.

Like the Prussian king who walked the corridors of his palace with Voltaire, the Hamburg-born designer they call "the Kaiser" has been an ardent Francophile from an early age.

When he was five he claims he demanded his parents got him a French tutor. "Eighteenth century France represents the epitome of exuberance, youth, balance and harmony," he said. "And for me the way that life ought to be lived, an ideal that I have striven to achieve."

Bertrand du Vignaud, of Christie's, said Lagerfeld, whose fashion and perfume businesses are said to be buoyant, would be hanging on to a small number of 18th-century pieces. "However, the vast majority of the collection he has been gathering for more than 20 years will be sold."

Like his late friend Gianni Versace, Lagerfeld has long had a weakness for all things gilded, French and 18th century. The first things he bought when he moved to Paris as a teenager was a pair of gilt regency fauteuils and a Louis XVI commode.

He has also gone on buying expeditions with Elton John, who shares his taste for Sèvres porcelain. But like Elton John and Madonna, he is now diversifying into the photography market. "In the past he has also bought Memphis, Art Deco and Weimar era art, and later sold it on," said Mr du Vignaud. "He is now very interested in photography - he is a photographer himself - and architecture in particular. Even so, it is fair to say that French 18th-century has been the style he has been most associated with."

 Gucci Group NV announced yesterday that Tom Ford has taken over from Pierre Berge as creative director of Yves Saint Laurent Couture, in addition to his existing duties at Gucci. He will be responsible for the overall management of all creative activities for the house, as well as of YSL Parfums. "I wish Tom Ford lots of success at Yves Saint Laurent, which means lots of success for the house that bears my name," Yves Saint Laurent said in a statement.

webTitle: US Spanglish puts Spanish on the run

fields.headline: US Spanglish puts Spanish on the run
fields.trailText: Forget Esperanto and start mugging up on Spanglish, a mixture of Spanish and English spawned by the US Hispanic community which is, according to its American lexicographer, the language of the future.
fields.body:
Forget Esperanto and start mugging up on Spanglish, a mixture of Spanish and English spawned by the US Hispanic community which is, according to its American lexicographer, the language of the future.

"The Hispanic world will end up speaking Spanglish," predicts Ilan Stavans of Amherst College, Massachusetts, author of the Dictionary of Spanglish - a compilation of 6,000 words used on the streets of the US by its Spanish-speaking population.

Mr Stavans's team of researchers trawled the US's Hispanic areas, listened to Latino radio stations and analysed rap lyrics in their search for words such as brode (brother), culisimo (very cool), lonche (lunch) and rufa (roof).

Demographics show that Hispanics are expected to account for a third of the US population by the end of the century.

"We're talking about 40m Hispanics in the United States and a total of 400m Spanish-speakers in the world," said Mr Stavans, who was born in Mexico. "That's an awful lot.

"Where two languages co-exist it is natural for them to merge," he adds, and Spanglish is the result of the resilience of the Spanish language compared to other languages spoken by immigrants to the US.

An official grammar and spelling guide published by Spain's Academy of the Language last year took account of Latin American derivations but ignored Spanglish.

Meanwhile, Spain's conservative prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, has been seeking to promote Castilian Spanish as a cultural, political and economic force.

But a quarter of internet users worldwide already operate in Spanish using their own hybrid, accentless form.

"Latin Americans in general, and those of us who live in the United States in particular, are tired of the centralisation of Spanish by Spain," Mr Stavans said.

webTitle: Italians hold inquiry into immigrant boat deaths

fields.headline: Italians hold inquiry into immigrant boat deaths
fields.trailText: The discovery of a young woman's body attached to a deflated dinghy in the Adriatic has confirmed fears that about 59 illegal immigrants drowned on New Year's Eve.
fields.body:
The discovery of a young woman's body attached to a deflated dinghy in the Adriatic has confirmed fears that about 59 illegal immigrants drowned on New Year's Eve.

An inquiry has been opened into why the Italian coastguard ignored claims from relatives in Italy that the vessel had gone missing in rough seas after leaving Albania.

No search was launched and the claims were dismissed until the body was spotted about 11 miles from the Albanian island of Sazan on Monday.

Albanian authorities who had interviewed witnesses confirmed that the boat had contained three Albanian smugglers, a further 13 Albanians, four Moldavian teenage girls and 39 people of Chinese and Kurdish origin from Iraq and Turkey.

It is thought that the 12m (40ft) grey dinghy, designed to hold 30 people, broke apart.

webTitle: New York mom spends UN funds in costly blunder

fields.headline: New York mom spends UN funds in costly blunder
fields.trailText: Like many people of modest means and sizeable debts, all Susan Madakor wanted to do was win the lottery. So when $701,998.84 (about £430,000) appeared out of the blue in her bank account, the 40-year-old single mother believed her time had come.
fields.body:
Like many people of modest means and sizeable debts, all Susan Madakor wanted to do was win the lottery. So when $701,998.84 (about £430,000) appeared out of the blue in her bank account, the 40-year-old single mother believed her time had come.

True, it was strange that the international lottery for which she had bought tickets had not contacted her about her good fortune. But that did not stop her expressing gratitude.

"I was saying 'Thank you, Jesus.' I was blessed," she said. Nor did it stop her spending a large part of the money on transforming her life. She gave up her job, paid off $30,000 in credit card debts, set up a savings fund to send her 10-year-old son to college, furnished her publicly owned apartment and leased a mini-van.

"I wanted to secure my future," said the $23,000-a-year receptionist from Brooklyn, New York. "I wanted the money to work for me and work for my son."

She had started negotiations to buy an off-licence when it became clear the money had been mistakenly diverted from a United Nations environment fund to clean up the planet - a rather grander aspiration than Ms Madakor had in mind when she spent $100,000 on a laundry business.

The money started arriving in her bank account two years ago in 13 wire transfers, contributions intended for the UN environment programme which went to Ms Madakor because of one incorrect digit. The money came from countries including Italy, France, Belgium, Finland, Turkey, Uruguay and St Kitts-Nevis.

Her account - by now containing $450,000 - was frozen when Chase Manhattan and the UN discovered the mistake.

fields.headline: Supermarket isle
fields.standfirst:
Sainsbury's has a problem: it can't get enough high-quality organic fruit. Its solution? To take over the agricultural production of the entire island of Grenada and convert it to supplying health-conscious Britain. John Vidal on how one of the world's richest food chains plans to invade the Caribbean

What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's has a problem: it can't get enough high-quality organic fruit. Its solution? To take over the agricultural production of the entire island of Grenada and convert it to supplying health-conscious Britain.  John Vidal  on how one of the world's richest food chains plans to invade the Caribbean
fields.body:
In October 1983, several thousand US paratroopers, backed by helicopters, the navy and ground forces, invaded the idyllic 21-mile-long Caribbean island of Grenada to purge it of a few dozen revolutionaries who had killed a popular prime minister.

As invasions go, this was one of history's more lopsided. The choppers and the Stars and Stripes were flying over the capital, St George's, within hours. Hundreds of Cubans were quickly rounded up after a short fight, and something billed as democracy was restored. The 90,000 Grenadians mostly cheered and thanked their "liberators" and that, it was believed, was the last invasion the usually tranquil, sun-kissed island of bougainvilleas and palm trees, steep hills, blue sea and sandy beaches would ever know.

Not quite. Grenada has a long history of invasions and colonists. The French kicked out and killed the native Caribs, the British kicked out the French, the Americans invaded to kick out the commies and now the giant cruise ships and global corporations are moving in.

In the past few months, agents of Sainsbury's, one of the world's richest food empires (turnover £6bn a year) have been quietly poring over maps, scouting out the land, making sorties into the fields and plotting with the Grenadian government (turnover £200m). The plan, hatched peacefully and with the best intentions, is to take over the agriculture of the entire island and make it organic.

Sainsbury's problem is simple. It can't get enough high quality organic tropical fruit. British and, increasingly, American demand for healthily grown bananas, passion fruit, coconuts and mangoes is growing fast, but the quality is variable and importing it is notoriously difficult.

For the company generals at headquarters, scratching their heads over how to supply thousands of hungry outlets trying to keep up with the organic and ethical consumer revolution (and the £200m-a-year high-profit market it has created), the four eastern Caribbean Windward Islands looked ideal.

They have the right climate to grow perfect fruit (year-round sunshine, few hurricanes, lots of rain); the right image (former British colonies, picture of paradise); right governments (politically stable); right land (lots of disused plantations); all well-served by an old-style Anglo-Irish shipping company, Geest, which has long imported most of the tropical fruit Britain eats.

Over the past year, Sainsbury's executives have toured St Lucia, Grenada, St Vincent and Dominica. What they have seen is four very different islands all more or less on their agricultural knees, unable to compete in the cutthroat global farm economy. As in so many other areas of the world, the Caribbean small farmers are being driven off the land, rural communities are on the rocks and there's an alarming, and increasing, disparity of wealth.

High command at Sainsbury's finally settled on Grenada and St Lucia as its beachheads. The Grenadian government, for starters, offered Sainsbury's 440 prime acres of old plantations, and the St Lucians have proffered four large farms totalling 300 to 400 acres. Having got the Soil Association, which oversees organic standards in Britain, to check the suitability of the land for conversion to organic production, the supermarket has completed a six-month study and is now starting its pilot projects. The plan was backed by Dino Adriano, who has led the chain towards ethical and organic foods but was ousted last week.

So far so good. The first crops are now about to be planted. These, says Ian Merton, the company's commercial director, should be "the spearhead of organic fruit production" and the trials should be "a model to convert other land". If all goes well, Sainsbury's should be getting all their organic bananas, mangoes, coconuts and passion fruit from Grenada and St Lucia within three years. After that, Merton foresees Grenada going completely organic and Sainsbury's acting as an agent to sell the produce worldwide. Exactly how he would persuade all the other farmers in the country to turn organic is glossed over.

This is where the islands' governments catch their breath, having long been promised aid and assistance from richer countries that seldom appears. The plantation owners cut down most of the forests and introduced slavery; the British set up sugar and cocoa industries that failed and then encouraged tens of thousands of Windward Islanders to come to live in British cities; the Americans promised Grenada better roads, schools, housing and health after their invasion; more recently, Venezuela proposed that the whole island could be a model of "sustainability" and sent technicians and consultants. They have also had talks with Cuba, where most crops are now organic.

Sainsbury's says its initiative is not a new era of colonialism, and it isn't in the sense that the company will not own land and will not, as the old French and British colonial farmers did, farm it themselves. But as so many growers for supermarkets in Britain and elsewhere know, the relationship between a giant corporation and small farmers is often fraught, with the power balance very much in the supermarket's favour; the potential for the supermarket to pull out is always there.

But everyone we talked to in Grenada before Christmas was enthusiastic, in principle. The trouble was, hardly anyone knew anything. The local paper knew nothing. The island's nutmeg association shrugged. The banana growers had "heard a rumour" but were unsure. Robert Grant, a prominent farmer, hadn't a clue. Ditto the manager of the island's agricultural marketing board and the Agency for Rural Transformation, a local non-governmental organisation.

"This is news to me," says Lennox Purcell, one of the island's largest businessmen and estate owners. "I, personally, will sell Mr Sainsbury my best mangoes. I can produce 20,000 pounds of ginger. I'm willing, happy and ready to grow everything for him if he makes it interesting. He could have all my avocado crop, vanilla, nutmeg. I shall piggyback on him. I will meet him at the airport."

In the the brand new government buildings, Cecil Winsborough, Grenada's chief agronomist, was part of a team that met Sainsbury's before Christmas. He was cautious: "In the past, the people who controlled agriculture were colonists. Today people are more serious and farmers will look at all ideas. We've been told our island is ideal for a complete transformation of its approach to agriculture. Sainsbury's came shopping here because they see us as a good investment. They are buying the image. People will buy the fruit thinking, boy, this place is pristine.

"But we are scared that it will make farming harder. [They're] telling us 'go the other way', but we don't know how this will turn out. Who will pay for the changeover period? A lot of nice things have been waved about, but we want to be cautious. We want to ensure it is profitable these days to grow for the local market rather than jump through all the hoops of international trade." He makes out a good case that farmers could be better off growing for the local market rather than export.

Grenada (unemployment 16%, 65% of people dependent on farming) knows that it's getting harder than ever to compete in the global food market, which is being dominated by a few giant companies running huge plantations. It makes sense to diversify, especially after last year's World Trade Organisation ruling that Britain should not continue to give the island favoured terms of trade. When full-blown free trade eventually comes, the Windwards will be on a very sticky wicket.

But for all the talk about guaranteeing markets, being ethical, acting as a catalyst for "sustainable development", diversifying and helping the islands to reduce their dependency on a few crops, Sainsbury may be doing little to help the majority of farmers.

The islands want new markets, but also hi-tech assistance to make changes, and Sainsbury's will indeed help to teach some farmers how to go organic. But the supermarket wants, at least to start with, to work with the large farmers on land that is almost organic already and will cost little or nothing to convert. The vast majority of small growers live in virtual penury on land awash with the chemicals needed to produce the cosmetically appealing fruit that British supermarkets have insisted on for so long.

These people cannot convert to organic because they live from week to week and would lose their liveli hoods for several years during the transition. No one, least of all Sainsbury's, is going to pay for them to change. Sainsbury's says it will try to help get EU grants, but whether these materialise is anyone's guess.

The company has also chosen the most prosperous and diversified of all the Windward Islands. Neighbouring St Vincent is almost entirely dependent on selling bananas to British supermarkets, but the world price is low, the work gets harder than ever and there's so little profit that many are giving up. "Ideally Mr Sainsbury will come to St Vincent to talk to the farmers here and say we want this and that," says Julian Boyea, a banana grower. "We want Sainsbury's to come and speak to us at a church, a school or something. We would love Mr Sainsbury to come to St Vincent. Tell him to come and talk. He can have the best bananas in the world."

Renwick Rose, who runs the Windward Islands National Farmers Association, says: "Sainsbury's concern is that there are too many small fish in the sea, so it's easier to catch a whale [a country] than three million herring. I'm not sure of Sainsbury's strategy. Do they want to take over Grenada?"

He and many others are convinced the answer is "Fairtrade", an alternative trading system that would guarantee fruit prices in a volatile world market, cut out the middlemen and allow even the smallest farmers to have a say in their own future. Sainsbury's says publicly that it wants to foster this, but so far it has not been able to organise the system in the Windwards. On Monday, however, it sold its first Fairtrade bananas, but from Costa Rica.

"We in the Windwards are suffering. Yes, we need help. We need the supermarkets," says Rose. "But the terms of trade must be fair."

fields.headline: The runaway trainer
fields.standfirst:
He invented the Nike air bubble and sparked a revolution. As Tinker Hatfield
unveils a new model, Peter Lyle meets the former architect and athlete who
became the best sports shoe designer in the world
fields.trailText:
He invented the Nike air bubble and sparked a revolution. As Tinker Hatfield
unveils a new model, Peter Lyle meets the former architect and athlete who
became the best sports shoe designer in the world
fields.body:
Having spent the previous hour sitting still and engaging in calm conversation, Tinker Hatfield suddenly jumps off the sofa in his London hotel suite and shifts his weight on to the balls of his feet. The idea is to demonstrate how, with the right trainers, humans can be made to move like velociraptors. "For Jurassic Park," he explains, "we did shoes for the actors who were inside some of the dinosaur costumes. They had to be up on their toes like this, because that's sort of the shape of a dinosaur leg. So we designed special shoes to help them."

The prehistoric high heels came before the futuristic footwear 47-year-old Hatfield made for Jodie Foster in Contact, but after the hoverboarding boots he designed for Michael J Fox in Back to the Future II; after the bat boot in the first Batman movies, but before the shoe that has just been turned down for the new Superman movie. When you are universally regarded as The Man Who Invented The Trainer, you get asked to do these things all the time.

No one would contend that sports shoes did not exist before Hatfield began designing them for Nike 14 years ago. What is certain, though, is that he was the creative force behind the all-singing, all-dancing, deeply desirable trainer we now take for granted. He shifted the focus of sports shoe consumers from function to form, and from sport to street: "When I started designing shoes in late 1985, athletic shoes were just basic performance footwear. There was no romance, no tying in with athletic personalities, no design inspiration from outside. They were just done for sports. Then Nike came on the scene."

More to the point, Hatfield came on the scene. He revolutionised the design of trainers - and their desir ability. Much of Nike's success in the 90s has been down to his designs, especially the airbag technology that propelled Nike to the No 1 position in the market. Any new shoe he makes gets snapped up by devotees.

Hatfield, who is in London to promote his new Cross Trainer II, available next month, came to shoe design by an unorthodox route. In Oregon, as a teenager, he distinguished himself at basketball, hurdling and American football, then studied architecture at the University of Oregon. In 1981, he joined Nike, designing offices and showrooms, but always thought he could do shoes. "I understood them. I could tell Nike was starting to plateau and go down. Basically we ran out of consumers. Only so many people actually go running. So while the market it grew, it wasn't going anywhere. People were wearing them around because they were comfortable, not really for style so much." After four years, Hatfield became involved in designing the footwear itself, and made his mark with the "Air" bubble: a small plastic window in the sole of the shoe which allowed you to see the cushioning system inside.

"My first shoe of any note was the original Air Max," he recalls. "The Georges Pompidou centre in Paris changed architecture, because it took the skin off the building so you could see inside. With the airbag, that first Air Max was like the Pompidou centre. Nobody [had] even thought of that in athletic footwear. It was an immature field of design. It was more like engineers were doing it."

Hatfield let his imagination run wild. "I treated designing shoes like designing buildings. A church is a good example of a building that's more than a building. Churches need to evoke emotion. They make you feel small, make something else feel bigger, more glorious. There's a lot of tricks in architecture to do that, and that's what I brought to footwear."

Other events conspired to take the trainer beyond the orbit of athletic training. Nike signed up-and-coming basketball star Michael Jordan, and Hatfield worked on his shoes. This marked the beginning of the modern cult of the trainer: expensive, ornate and collectible. The mania reached a macabre peak in the early 90s when urban American schoolchildren were murdered for their shoes.

Hatfield says he and Nike were able to drastically reshape our perception of the trainer. "It added value to the whole idea of buying shoes. You're not really buying a piece of leather with some rubber and foam; you're buying a part of modern culture, a part of some personality. You're buying a thought, a way to express yourself. And the advertising really had a big impact. It made people lust after these things more than just needing a pair of shoes to go work out in."

In 1996, the brash green-and-grey Air Max 95 (£120) was adopted by designers to accompany their haute couture on the catwalks, as if they were conceding defeat to the superior styling of the mass-market sports shoe. Hatfield, too, has benefited from trainers' elevated status. In 1997, Forbes magazine named him one of the 20th century's 100 most influential designers. A new generation of product designers who grew up wearing his shoes have acknowledged his influence on their own work. "I'm contacted by museums all the time; people are collecting this stuff and there are articles and books being written about shoe design."

Unfortunately for Nike, this recognition has coincided with a general levelling out of sales and cultural excitement about trainers. Hatfield cites the decline in athlete worship and the fashion cognoscenti's return to simpler, old-fashioned designs as the most obvious explanations. It's why he's come to London to promote his new design, a shoe with Prada-esque clean lines outside, and all the technology hidden within. "It's like sorbet," he says. "It cleanses the palette after all these over-designed shoes. Until you have the Next Big Thing, maybe you should downplay it a little, go a little more sophisticated."

The sentiment will be enough to reduce those of us reared on huge, elaborate Tinker trainers to tears. Surely he's not saying there will never be another Big Thing, that the grand narrative of the trainer is over? "No," he says. "I think these things are cyclical. I think we're due for a leap."

That gives you plenty of time to start saving for the mould-breaking Air Jordan XXXVI.

The shoe must go on: Hatfield classics that kept the planet on its toes

Air Jordan IV, 1989 Huge, padded basketball boots in white, black and grey, with complex meshing, exterior ankle supports, and the jumping Jordan silhouette at the tongue - so comfortable that wearing shoes after them always felt masochistic. Version IV quickly became established as essential urbanwear in the UK, despite an unprecedented £70 price. The soles wore out quickly off the court, too, ensuring you were soon saving for a new pair.

Air Huarache, 1992 Light, weird-looking running shoes with asymmetrical support straps and important-looking technical tidbits. Huarache was a new synthetic fabric championed by runners for its snug fit. Never was Hatfield's inclination to have the insides on the outside so indulged. Crucial forerunners of the mid-90s boom in trainers that looked like climbing boots, they won Hatfield a design award. Popular with arty types who thought it looked weird, and with teenagers who thought it looked nice.

Air Max 95, 1995 The Air Max brand had become a reliable fixture in the Nike calendar: bright, big-soled and the-same-but-different. The 95 deconstructed the template using an all-the-way-round air bubble down below, and included a graded grey upper, lime green trimmings, and reflective details. At first, sales were sluggish then everyone got obsessed. They were on record sleeves, at catwalk shows, and fought over in Japanese shops. Variants remain one of the company's biggest sellers.

In Oregon, as a teenager, he distinguished himself at basketball, hurdling and American football, then studied architecture at the University of Oregon. In 1981, he joined Nike, designing offices and showrooms, but always thought he could do shoes. "I understood them. I could tell Nike was starting to plateau and go down. Basically we ran out of consumers. Only so many people actually go running. So while the market it grew, it wasn't going anywhere. People were wearing them around because they were comfortable, not really for style so much." After four years, Hatfield became involved in designing the footwear itself, and made his mark with the "Air" bubble: a small plastic window in the sole of the shoe which allowed you to see the cushioning system inside. "My first shoe of any note was the original Air Max," he recalls. "The Georges Pompidou centre in Paris changed architecture, because it took the skin off the building so you could see inside. With the airbag, that first Air Max was like the Pompidou centre. Nobody [had] even thought of that in athletic footwear. It was an immature field of design. It was more like engineers were doing it." Hatfield let his imagination run wild. "I treated designing shoes like designing buildings. A church is a good example of a building that's more than a building. Churches need to evoke emotion. They make you feel small, make something else feel bigger, more glorious. There's a lot of tricks in architecture to do that, and that's what I brought to footwear." Other events conspired to take the trainer beyond the orbit of athletic training. Nike signed up-and-coming basketball star Michael Jordan, and Hatfield worked on his shoes. This marked the beginning of the modern cult of the trainer: expensive, ornate and collectible. The mania reached a macabre peak in the early 90s when urban American schoolchildren were murdered for their shoes. Hatfield says he and Nike were able to drastically reshape our perception of the trainer. "It added value to the whole idea of buying shoes. You're not really buying a piece of leather with some rubber and foam; you're buying a part of modern culture, a part of some personality. You're buying a thought, a way to express yourself. And the advertising really had a big impact. It made people lust after these things more than just needing a pair of shoes to go work out in." In 1996, the brash green-and-grey Air Max 95 (£120) was adopted by designers to accompany their haute couture on the catwalks, as if they were conceding defeat to the superior styling of the mass-market sports shoe. Hatfield, too, has benefited from trainers' elevated status. In 1997, Forbes magazine named him one of the 20th century's 100 most influential designers. A new generation of product designers who grew up wearing his shoes have acknowledged his influence on their own work. "I'm contacted by museums all the time; people are collecting this stuff and there are articles and books being written about shoe design." Unfortunately for Nike, this recognition has coincided with a general levelling out of sales and cultural excitement about trainers. Hatfield cites the decline in athlete worship and the fashion cognoscenti's return to simpler, old-fashioned designs as the most obvious explanations. It's why he's come to London to promote his new design, a shoe with Prada-esque clean lines outside, and all the technology hidden within. "It's like sorbet," he says. "It cleanses the palette after all these over-designed shoes. Until you have the Next Big Thing, maybe you should downplay it a little, go a little more sophisticated." The sentiment will be enough to reduce those of us reared on huge, elaborate Tinker trainers to tears. Surely he's not saying there will never be another Big Thing, that the grand narrative of the trainer is over? "No," he says. "I think these things are cyclical. I think we're due for a leap." That gives you plenty of time to start saving for the mould-breaking Air Jordan XXXVI. The shoe must go on: Hatfield classics that kept the planet on its toes Air Jordan IV, 1989 Huge, padded basketball boots in white, black and grey, with complex meshing, exterior ankle supports, and the jumping Jordan silhouette at the tongue - so comfortable that wearing shoes after them always felt masochistic. Version IV quickly became established as essential urbanwear in the UK, despite an unprecedented £70 price. The soles wore out quickly off the court, too, ensuring you were soon saving for a new pair. Air Huarache, 1992 Light, weird-looking running shoes with asymmetrical support straps and important-looking technical tidbits. Huarache was a new synthetic fabric championed by runners for its snug fit. Never was Hatfield's inclination to have the insides on the outside so indulged. Crucial forerunners of the mid-90s boom in trainers that looked like climbing boots, they won Hatfield a design award. Popular with arty types who thought it looked weird, and with teenagers who thought it looked nice. Air Max 95, 1995 The Air Max brand had become a reliable fixture in the Nike calendar: bright, big-soled and the-same-but-different. The 95 deconstructed the template using an all-the-way-round air bubble down below, and included a graded grey upper, lime green trimmings, and reflective details. At first, sales were sluggish then everyone got obsessed. They were on record sleeves, at catwalk shows, and fought over in Japanese shops. Variants remain one of the company's biggest sellers.

fields.headline: No nanny state
fields.standfirst: News of Elle Macpherson's collapse  on the set of Friends will come as no  surprise to many working mothers.  But why does she refuse help,  wonders Luisa Dillner
fields.trailText:
News of Elle Macpherson's collapse
on the set of Friends will come as no
surprise to many working mothers.
But why does she refuse help,
wonders Luisa Dillner
fields.body:
Poor Elle Macpherson has collapsed on the set of Friends, claiming exhaustion. It's not an unusual complaint for the stars of the sitcom, some of whom are so thin that they must be teetering on the brink of unconsciousness. But Macpherson is The Body for goodness' sake - she is beauty and fitness rolled into one. Surely a part as a six-week love interest for Matt Leblanc can't be too overwhelming for a former supermodel?

Work is in fact only partly to blame. Her collapse is said to be due to interrupted nights with her two-year-old son. Macpherson does not employ a nanny and during her 14 hours a day on set, is also bringing up Flynn.

The initial reaction of many working mothers to the news from New York will have been a combination of sympathy and relief. Who hasn't felt exhausted and emotionally frazzled trying to combine a job with motherhood? I remember driving home from work when my baby was small and sticking my fingernails into my palms to keep awake. So there is something of a reprieve in discovering that even a superwoman like Macpherson can't manage it all.

How much worse if she was starring in a hit sitcom, looking healthy and luminous, able to do without sleep and still care full-time for her son. But Macpherson's swoon raises a more serious question. Why are an apparently increasing number of high-powered mothers choosing to do without a nanny? In Macpherson's case it's plainly not a question of money. She has diversified from her modelling career into underwear design, fitness videos and acting and is worth an estimated $26m.

It's not for lack of money that Victoria and David Beckham decided to go without paid help either, choosing to take their son Brooklyn to work (Beckham took him to a training session when Victoria was away), change nappies themselves and roping in family to help. Melanie Blatt from All Saints is also avoiding a nanny, taking both her baby and mother to the recording studios.

Three celebrities do not a trend make, of course, but their decisions do reflect a disconcerting school of thought that childcare is for wimps, and that we should be able to work and parent at the same time. It's a trend that starts as soon as you give birth in hospital. Once you stayed in for five days and everyone made a fuss of you as a new mother. Now you're out almost as soon as the umbilical cord is cut.

Once, having it all meant being a working mother. You went to work, rushed out to the supermarket at lunchtime for some pre-prepared microwaveable suppers and hurried home to start the evening's parenting job. Now, it seems to mean working and being a mother simultanously.

You are doing your job and being the sole carer for your baby. Geddit? Not only are you doing some urgent filing but you are teaching your baby the various noises that zoo animals make to ensure they get into a good school later in life.

Needless to say, it's a whole lot easier to pass up the nanny if you are Elle Macpherson. No one's going to give you grief for bringing the baby into work. Employers will happily provide a stream of minions to hold the baby when you need to do some actual work. Everyone will be enormously understanding if you need a break to breastfeed or tickle your baby's tummy. Try turning up for work with your sprog at a factory or a shop.

While it is vaguely irksome even to consider why celebrities may not want nannies when many parents spend most of their wages struggling to afford one, most mothers will identify to some degree with the reluctance of Macpherson and Co to subcontract their parenting responsibilities. A Martian dropping in on any middle-class urban dinner table might quickly deduce that childcare was the most fraught issue facing the planet.

Mothers may enjoy the business of work but torture themselves with worries that their child is not safe away from them. Regular documentaries showing nannies on hidden cameras using babies as punch-bags, send the guilt levels soaring. What mother doesn't ask herself if working is really worth it? And then there's the jealousy. That somone else will see your baby's first step, hear her first word. Some mothers, pitifully, ask their nanny to write copious notes describing their children's bowel movements. Everyone tells you that childhood is over in the twinkle of an eye; suddenly they're smelly teenagers who don't want to know you, let alone give you a cuddle.

In the employment market of the future, the line between work and home, we are told, will become increasingly blurred. The increase in net access at home should make office working at least less of a nine-to-five affair. So home-working mother will be able to attach her baby to her breast while using the keyboard with one hand and talking into the phone perched on her shoulder. She will work when the baby sleeps and do her maternal duties when the baby wakes, thus ensuring she has no time to sleep herself.

She will fret that she will not make a work deadline because today her baby was teething and will manage her two full-time jobs, as parent and employee, in a fugue state. Often she will forget to feed herself, shovelling up the remains of pureed carrot and potato (which she made herself because she wants to be a good mother and cook fresh foods). She will grunt to her partner who she will never see because she is using up all the hours in the day on work or parenting. Watch the birth rate continue to fall.

Having a baby is exhausting, going without sleep is torture. It is hard, verging on impossible, to work efficiently if you are woken six times a night. The most relaxed parents I know are the ones who have good childcare, not the ones who try to do it all themselves. Letting go of any of your responsibility as a parent is enormously difficult but if you are trying to work, without the support of an extended family, you need someone to help you. Most mothers feel physically and emotionally knackered. And Elle Macpherson, it seems, has joined us.

Mother knows best: the working mums who say no to nannies by Esther Addley

Caroline Quentin

Quentin gave birth to daughter Emily Rose in September, having spent the day of the delivery filming Jonathan Creek. She and partner Sam Farmer were resolved not to hire a nanny. "I don't want a nanny early on. I want Sam and I to have the baby to ourselves."

She has not ruled out the possibility of future help, but at present the two are dividing the childcare between them. "We share everything 50-50. Well, it's probably about 70-30 actually, he is so adept. Mind you, I'm not bad myself. I have taken to it."

Duchess of York

After going through three nannies in three years, in December 1994 the Duchess said she would not be employing another to look after her daughters Beatrice and Eugenie, then six and four. The arrangement was seen as unusual in royal circles, but with both children at school and her husband helping with the childcare, the famously cash-strapped Duchess may have seen a nanny as an unnecessary expense.

Patsy Palmer

EastEnders' Bianca left the soap last year to spend more time with her seven-year-old son. "Charley is my number one priority," she said at the time. "I think a lot of women feel this way and it is a question of being confident enough to go for it." Palmer, who is now expecting her second child, still lives just around the corner from her mother, who, along with a teacher, cares for her grandson while the actress is working.

Victoria Beckham

Despite a combined income running well into eight figures, Posh Spice and husband David Beckham insisted before the birth of baby Brooklyn that they would care for the imminent arrival themselves.

"I'll just take it into the studio with me," declared the expectant mother. Both Beckhams come from close families who lend a hand with childcare, but after recent kidnap threats security has been stepped up around the child, now 10 months.

Teri Hatcher

The star of the Superman TV series announced soon after her daughter's birth in 1997 that she would be taking a career break in order to be a full-time mother. Hatcher said that her decision was prompted by the Louise Woodward case.

"It reinforced my belief that the parents should be the caregivers. In a child's first years you should be doing the interacting. If you get a nanny, that's where the bond relationship goes. I just feel lucky I can afford to stay at home."

fields.trailText: We were mistaken in identifying one of the figures in a photograph accompanying our obituary of Reg Foster, page 22, January 12, as Foster's fellow journalist, Brendan Mulholland. The true identity of the figure is not known. Apologies to Mr Mulholland's relatives.
fields.body:
We were mistaken in identifying one of the figures in a photograph accompanying our obituary of Reg Foster, page 22, January 12, as Foster's fellow journalist, Brendan Mulholland. The true identity of the figure is not known. Apologies to Mr Mulholland's relatives.

In our article, How we fell in love with the web, page 2, G2, January 17, we described the bcc function in email but got it the wrong way round; bcc (standing for blind carbon copy) allows the writer of a message to copy it to someone without the main recipient(s) being aware that that has been done. The cc function enables the main recipient(s) to see who else is receiving it.

NHS Direct, the helpline referred to in our front page lead, Blair's £12bn pledge to NHS, January 17, allows patients to consult a nurse by phone, not a doctor.

Clwyd was spelt wrongly in a report about Toyota, page 2, yesterday. Also, it ceased to exist as an administrative area of Wales several years ago.

In a panel about correction fluid, page 3, Office hours, January 17, we said, "Fed up with having to rip up pages after her all-too-frequent typing slips, she simply hid the evidence with a blob of white tempura paint ..." Tempera, that would be.

It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: 1,350 more jobs to go in water and power

fields.headline: 1,350 more jobs to go in water and power
fields.trailText: Thames Water and Yorkshire Electricity yesterday joined the growing list of utilities resorting to job losses to meet new efficiency targets set by industry regulators last year.
fields.body:
Thames Water and Yorkshire Electricity yesterday joined the growing list of utilities resorting to job losses to meet new efficiency targets set by industry regulators last year.

Thames, the country's largest water company, is planning to shed 1,000 jobs over the next five years while Yorkshire Electricity intends to cut 350 jobs over the next 12 months. Both companies said they were having to cut jobs to meet the targets set by the water and electricity regulators in recent price reviews.

Bill Alexander, chief executive of Thames, said the number of jobs at the group's British water business would fall by about 200 a year over the next five years. "The majority of the reductions will be achieved through natural staff turnover," he said, though he admitted that there would probably have to be some compulsory redundancies.

The company is also hoping to switch employees from the British utility to its fast growing international business.

"Employees across the group now number some 14,000, up from 8,000 at the time of privatisation, and will continue to grow," Mr Alexander said.

Thames, which recently recruited former US senator and Northern Ireland peacemaker George Mitchell as an international adviser, is to concentrate on expanding its overseas operations.

Its chairman, Roger Carr, said the goal was to increase the proportion of profit coming from non-regulated - and largely overseas - activities from 15% to 30%.

Existing projects moving into more profitable phases are expected to account for the bulk of the improvement. Contributions from the recently acquired E'town water business in the United States and a stake in the Chilean water company Essel are expected to be more evident by the time of the next price review in five years' time.

The group, which already has a broad portfolio of overseas contracts, is currently bidding for new work in Brazil, Morocco, Portugal, Turkey, South Africa, Thailand and China.

Finance and planning director David Luffrum said Thames planned a 9% dividend rise this year followed by a "progressive dividend policy" of real increases thereafter.

The initial big cut in prices in 2000-01 was expected to reduce profits by about £110m. He said the group planned to spend up to £500m a year on acquisitions over the next five years using debt financing.

Yorkshire Electricity said it intended to cut the 350 jobs in an attempt to drive down bills. It also hoped to achieve the bulk of the reduction through voluntary redundancies.

The company said the job cuts, which would be in its distribution and supply operations, were a direct result of the new price caps imposed by the energy regulator, Callum McCarthy. Tudor Townsend, managing director of Yorkshire's distribution business, said: "We are looking to technology and new investments to increase efficiency."

fields.headline: US group with merger appetite
fields.trailText: Citigroup has a reputation for mergers. The American organisation became the world's biggest financial services company almost two years ago when the world's largest credit card company and one of its biggest insurers merged.
fields.body:
Citigroup has a reputation for mergers. The American organisation became the world's biggest financial services company almost two years ago when the world's largest credit card company and one of its biggest insurers merged.

The ground-breaking deal between Citicorp and Travelers in April 1998 did not end the group's ambitions, however.

It has since stated that it wants to expand its customer base around the world from 100m to 1bn by 2012, Citibank's 200th anniversary.

It aims to become a one-stop shop for the financial needs of all clients - from huge corporations to individuals. It launched a drive to expand further into European investment banking last year in order to fill a gap in its armour.

Yesterday's announcement recognised that it needed to act more quickly. The group faced some turmoil following the 1998 merger when there were repeated reports of tension between the co-chief executives - Sandy Weill, former head of Travelers, and John Reed, former head of Citibank.

Analysts also worried about combining the cultures of the groups. The merger combined a retail bank with an investment bank - a combination which contradicted US financial services legislation at the time - as well as two distinctly different investment banks. It brought together Salomon Brothers, known for its aggressive bond trading and for housing the original "Big Swinging Dicks" of the 1980s, with the patrician corporate financiers at Smith Barney.

It brought together Salomon Brothers, known for its aggressive bond trading and for housing the original "Big Swinging Dicks" of the 1980s, with the patrician corporate financiers at Smith Barney.
fields.bylineHtml: Jane Martinson in New York

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Fund managers turn bearish
fields.body:
Fund managers turn bearish

The proportion of fund managers who think UK equities are overvalued reached record levels in January.

Merrill Lynch's global fund manager survey, published yesterday, found 32% more British managers said equities were overvalued in their market than said they were undervalued, compared with 21% in December and 6% in November.

The balance of managers who are bullish on profits has also fallen from 87% in November to 75% in January. Trevor Greetham, global strategist at Merrill Lynch, said: "Earnings expectations are worsening but interest rates are not expected to to fall to cushion the blow. This may explain why fund managers saying UK equities are overvalued out number those saying they are undervalued by 32%, the highest figure since we started asking in February."

WTO remains deadlocked

There have been no fresh moves toward a new round of World Trade Organisation negotiations since the breakdown of the Seattle round last year, director general Mike Moore said in Brussels yesterday.

"I want a new round as soon as possible," he said before meeting members of the European Commission. "But I have yet to see movement of a substantial nature and cannot say we are any closer.

"Those who wanted social issues still want social issues. A certain number of members do not want reform." He did not expect a breakthrough at the WTO meeting in Davos this month.

Oftel to adopt lighter touch

Oftel yesterday signalled plans to loosen its grip on regulation of the telecommunications industry in response to the growing level of competition. David Edmonds, Oftel director general, described the intent to withdraw from many parts of the market as the "most significant change in Oftel's approach to regulation since 1984". The organisation will review various sectors, and where competition has been fully established will pull back. The focus will shift to preventing anti-competitive behaviour, using the powers Oftel gains in March when the competition act comes into force.

FoE shames 14 insurers

Environmental pressure group Friends of the Earth today "names and shames" 14 life insurance companies for "their feeble record on ethical investment".

An FoE report, Capital Punishment - the Insurance Industry and the Global Environment, says that while insurers such as Friends Provident, Axa Sun Life, Legal & General and Norwich Union market ethical or green unit trusts, their main investment funds hold stakes in oil, chemical, mining, and forest product firms.

L&G said: "Good environmental practice is good for business. We aim to focus activities to minimise environmental impact."

fields.headline: Hitting the Wall Street barrier
fields.standfirst: Sad end to Bischoff's battle
fields.trailText: It is 17 years since Win Bischoff was parachuted back into London to fix the Schroder family firm. The client base had been shot to shreds, the world of corporate finance was in a spin and everyone wondered whether things were moving too fast for an institution struggling to modernise under the weight of such history and tradition.
fields.body:
It is 17 years since Win Bischoff was parachuted back into London to fix the Schroder family firm. The client base had been shot to shreds, the world of corporate finance was in a spin and everyone wondered whether things were moving too fast for an institution struggling to modernise under the weight of such history and tradition.

Thomas Tilling, one of its biggest fee-payers at the time, under attack from the old BTR takeover machine, famously moved its business to rival War burg with the parting shot: "When you are fighting for your life you need the best."

As chief executive and then chairman, Mr Bischoff did a bit more than just fix things. Back then, the Schroder family stake was worth under £50m, with the whole shooting match valued at £100m. Today, as the sharp edge of the business is hived off to the Americans, Bruno Schroder and his sister, Charmaine, are sitting on stock worth £1.5bn.

In the process, Mr Bischoff has won himself the routine description of one of London's truly great investment bankers. But he has had to fight extraordinarily hard once again over the past couple of years and it seems the best he can now expect is by throwing in his lot with the transatlantic marauders. The Brits, and to a large extent European corporate financiers generally, have just been blown out of the water by the members of Wall Street's bulge bracket. It is really quite embarrassing. Mr Bischoff's rescue of the firm in the 1980s was built on the virtues of independence, specialist knowledge and international reach. It was often remarked that one reason Schroders never seemed to get into trouble was that it had too little capital to risk getting into trouble with.

So the move now to sell the glamourous wing of the firm to a parent with a great big balance sheet must be viewed as an admission of failure.

Schroders seems to have fallen at that hurdle which has tripped up so many of the City's finest: expansion into the United States itself. There was clearly always frustration that its Schroder Wertheim venture in New York never grew to punch-packing size. Last Autumn the business threatened to implode completely and so we have had the farce of the Great London Investment Banker scuttling across the At lantic just as Wall Street's hard-hitters were heading in the opposition direction - over here to pick off Mr Bischoff's client base.

But it would be wrong to infer that this man is somehow finished. There is little doubt that he will run the corporate finance show in Britain and the investment bank hirelings at Salomon, and those few still hanging on from Smith Barney, must now be staring at their brogues.

This is a great deal for Citigroup, but it begs the question as to why it should stop here. Schroders gives it muscle in Britain, but Europe remains very patchy. As for the Far East, Schroders managed to close down most of its investment banking operations in the region in the wake of the Asian panic.

While everyone is in the mood for carving up Britain's financial heritage, there is another family-controlled institution called Robert Fleming, where the owners might finally be ready to accept that the game is up. It has a grand investment banking presence in the Far East and has also been building up its business in central and eastern Europe. Schroder Fleming Salomon Smith Barney would be a mouthful, but there would be no shortage of strategic fit.

In fact, there is no reason why the Fleming family should not follow the Schroder example to the letter, retaining control of the asset management and private banking businesses and selling the rest. Then we could all get on chasing a new speculation: putting the two fund management firms together and then merging the families themselves.

Egging on

When the Prudential first aired those post-modern banking adverts to accompany the launch of its egg internet off spring 15 months ago, the immediate and widespread reaction was "huh?"

But the success of the concept is now showing through in hard numbers, with egg customers up another 100,000 during the last quarter of last year to 800,000 - despite tecnology faults.

Egg is proving to be a textbook example how new brands can be established on the back of old-trustworthy consumer names. It also shows the importance of the "first-to-market" rule of cyberspace, promoting a good product relentlessly.

There has been much discussion over whether Egg should be hived off as a separate entity, allowing the Pru's shareholders to see the value of their off-spring and also to provide some room to incentivise the staff, lest they decide to move nests. But there is a growing sense that this business, and the skills acquired in establishing it, are crucial to the future of the Prudential group.

webTitle: SFO chief orders inquiry at Versailles

fields.headline: SFO chief orders inquiry at Versailles
fields.standfirst: Accounts and shares sale under scrutiny
fields.trailText: Serious Fraud Office director Rosalind Wright last night ordered a full-scale criminal investigation into Versailles, the trading group at the centre of a £50m-plus accounting scandal.
fields.body:
Serious Fraud Office director Rosalind Wright last night ordered a full-scale criminal investigation into Versailles, the trading group at the centre of a £50m-plus accounting scandal. The inquiry is likely to torpedo plans to relist shares in the fallen stock market star by the end of this month.

Based on information supplied by the department of trade and industry last year, "there now appears to be sufficient reason ... to authorise an investigation into possible serious and complex fraud", Mrs Wright said.

Not only is the SFO investigating the company's accounts but it is bound also to look into the sale by founder Carl Cushnie of shares worth £29m - about 5% of the equity - in autumn last year when he knew, and the market did not, that the company was being examined by a DTI-mandated auditors' inquiry.

In recent days Versailles came close to recruiting a new, high-powered financial adviser to assist its return to a stock market listing. Two top names were on the shortlist, but last night's announcement will probably terminate such discussions.

Former advisers Raphael Zorn Hemsley and Teather & Greenwood refused to act further for Versailles in the wake of the December 8 statement in which the company first admitted that up to a third of turnover might have been illusory.

Two days later, Versailles said it had lied on December 8 when it claimed to have uncovered the problems itself. It had been the DTI that came across apparent gaps in the accounts of Versailles early last year when it investigated the books of an insolvent company, Telecom Manufacturing Ltd (TML), of Airdrie, Scotland.

Ironically, Versailles was a TML creditor, and thus a victim of its bankruptcy.

But, under the companies act, the DTI needed to inspect Versailles's books and in doing so cast doubt on the treatment of its MP product, by which it effectively finances a client's materials purchases. The nature of the product seemed to create double counting as a client's materials moved on and off the books of Versailles several times.

Confidentially, the DTI insisted Versailles commission a special audit to look at the problem.

The accountancy firm Baker Tilly took on the job, and when it was unable to give the books a clean bill of health Versailles asked for the shares to be suspended and made its December 8 statement.

But by then the chairman, Carl Cushnie, had sold £29m worth of shares into a market entirely unaware of the DTI-ordered investigation. This sale of 5% of the equity still left him with 53% of Versailles.

Versailles last night noted the SFO statement but said it would be inappropriate to comment further.

The company was one of the fastest-rising stars of the 1990s. Founded in 1989, Versailles has boomed in recent years, with particular success during the past 12 months. The shares have roared ahead from a few pence in January 1996 to about 150p in January this year.

On December 8, the shares were suspended at 250p.

Three banks - NatWest, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays - have lent about £65m to Versailles. They might now activate the "force majeure" clauses that will allow them to demand their money back. Accountancy firm PricewaterhouseCoopers is examining the books of Versailles on the banks' behalf.

Even before last night's announcement Versailles had been braced for a share price crash of up to 50% when it relisted.

webTitle: Dynasty: a tale of money and power

fields.headline: Dynasty: a tale of money and power
fields.trailText: Undoubted pain at surrendering complete control of Britain's largest independent merchant bank after almost two centuries will undoubtedly have been mitigated by the substantial financial gains for the Schroder family.
fields.body:
Undoubted pain at surrendering complete control of Britain's largest independent merchant bank after almost two centuries will undoubtedly have been mitigated by the substantial financial gains for the Schroder family.

The family, including descendants of the Hamburg Jew, Johann Heinrich Schroder, who founded the bank in 1818, own some 48% of the group.

One of their number, Bruno , a scion of a dynasty that with other German families, once dominated London merchant banking, has sat on the board as a non-executive since 1963. Philip Mallinckrodt, another family member, works at the bank. His father George joined the family in 1958 when he married Charmaine, daughter of Helmut, the then chairman, whom he succeeded. He is now president.

The bank's fortunes ebbed and flowed from the Victorian era into the more uncertain present of globalisation.

Schroders, anglicised in 1957, issued £3m bonds in 1863 for the Confederacy in the American civil war and raised £1m seven years later to finance the building of the Tokyo-Yokohama railway.

The Schroders were honoured by the German and British crowns: the founding father became a German baron, his son was knighted by Queen Victoria.

The family endured a crisis when war erupted in 1914. Baron Bruno, the chairman, was hastily naturalised. Sheer survival marked the period from the depression to 1945.

Post-war, the bank sought to regain pre-eminence by converting from a partnership into a private company in 1957 and, two years later, to a quoted public company. Gordon Richardson, later governor of the Bank of England, joined in 1957 and oversaw global expansion.

Schroders last year aborted an agreed takeover of US investment bank Deacon, whose head, Geoffrey Boisi, was touted as the next chairman. The family and board revolted; three months later they gave up a large part of their inheritance.

webTitle: Has the fat lady taken a poison pill?

fields.headline: Has the fat lady taken a poison pill?
fields.trailText: Game over? Well, not yet, as even the most callow students of Manchester United v Bayern in last year's champion's league final could have told the "experts" in the market who assumed Vodafone had all but clinched its bid for Mannesmann.
fields.body:
Game over? Well, not yet, as even the most callow students of Manchester United v Bayern in last year's champion's league final could have told the "experts" in the market who assumed Vodafone had all but clinched its bid for Mannesmann.

Yesterday those market-watchers suddenly recalled that a second-half substitution could turn the game around - and pronto, score two goals in injury time.

Vodafone, crowned the UK's biggest company last Friday on the surge in its shares, fell 13.25p to close at 338.25p as some investors got "frit" that its German prey would bring on an eleventh-hour substitute.

Mannesmann's saviour initially was thought to be Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, with whom it was allegedly in talks about offloading its 44% stake in France's second mobile phone operator, Cegetel. The fat lady had swallowed a poisoned pill.

Never mind that Mannesmann's advisers had already dismissed similar stories, arguing that while chief executive Klaus Esser would love to add France to the three European countries his firm controls, no sale was in the offing.

Vivendi denied the story again, but the feeling persisted that Mr Esser would turn to his French friends to escape the clutches of Vodafone's Chris Gent.

"Our deal with Orange took just five or six days to complete," one adviser said in a calculated tease.

Mr Gent piled on the pressure with Mannesmann investors, promising them manna if they accepted an offer that would give them 47.2% of an enlarged group.

Shares in Mannesmann fell 5.64% to close at €257.5 or a see-through price of €294.2, well below the €305 valuation on Vodafone's offer at Monday's close and the €350 propounded by Mr Esser.

The German group pointed out that the discount between the value of Vodafone's offer and its market price had widened to 12.2% at the end of play compared with just 9.7% on Monday.

Neuja, said Vodafone. The arbs' role had diminished in the volume of trading. But with the final whistle not due until February 7 it was not singing, being a little deflated.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: London shares closed down sharply yesterday led by Vodafone AirTouch and BT , which suffered at the hands of profit-takers and pressure from weak markets in the United States.
fields.body:
London shares closed down sharply yesterday led by Vodafone AirTouch and BT , which suffered at the hands of profit-takers and pressure from weak markets in the United States.

Further downward pressure came from the merger news between Glaxo Wellcome and SmithKline Beecham, as stronger than expected manufacturing data reinforced expectations of a further rate rise. The FTSE 100 index closed down 164.9 points at 6,504.6.

Smaller firms also took a hit. The FTSE 250 index was down 58.8 at 6,567.4 and the FTSE Small Cap index was off 8.1 at 3,255.7, although market turnover remained healthy, with 1.7bn shares changing hands.

Vodafone - which for a short time yesterday became London's biggest stock after reaching a new high - fell 13p to 338p as the market worried that the battle for Mannesmann was about to turn nasty.

BT was also weak, falling 51p to £12.82, as the profit-takers descended.

The muted response to the creation of the world's largest pharmaceutical company continued, with SmithKline Beecham declining 35p to 753p and Glaxo Wellcome easing 41p to £16.91.

Again disappointment at the projected costs savings - £1bn of which £250m will be reinvested into research and development - was behind the falls.

A weak performance from the financial sector on the back of weakness in the bond market and fears of higher domestic interest rates forced Halifax shares down 31p to 567p and Woolwich , down 18p at 276p.

Yet Schroders shone after the merchant bank announced plans for a radical shake-up. The ordinary shares closed 117 higher at £11.24, the best performing stock in the FTSE 100.

Reuters was another prominent riser as speculation of a bid for the news and information firm swirled. The shares had soared in late morning as talk circulated the market that a bidder was lining up an offer, with Thomson Financial and US-based rival Bloomberg mooted as potential predators.

Meanwhile tiny Coburg saw its shares leap 111% to 9p on the back of speculation that it planned to transform a loss-making coffee-roasting company into an internet stock.

Eidos , the creator of video game series Tomb Raider, saw its shares pummelled, falling £12.60 to £26.28 after warning that profits for the year to the end of March would be significantly lower than the £37m the company made last year.
