Again disappointment at the projected costs savings - £1bn of which £250m will be reinvested into research and development - was behind the falls. A weak performance from the financial sector on the back of weakness in the bond market and fears of higher domestic interest rates forced Halifax shares down 31p to 567p and Woolwich , down 18p at 276p. Yet Schroders shone after the merchant bank announced plans for a radical shake-up. The ordinary shares closed 117 higher at £11.24, the best performing stock in the FTSE 100. Reuters was another prominent riser as speculation of a bid for the news and information firm swirled. The shares had soared in late morning as talk circulated the market that a bidder was lining up an offer, with Thomson Financial and US-based rival Bloomberg mooted as potential predators. Meanwhile tiny Coburg saw its shares leap 111% to 9p on the back of speculation that it planned to transform a loss-making coffee-roasting company into an internet stock. Eidos , the creator of video game series Tomb Raider, saw its shares pummelled, falling £12.60 to £26.28 after warning that profits for the year to the end of March would be significantly lower than the £37m the company made last year.

fields.headline: Biotech sector finds new life
fields.standfirst: Mergers offset impact of scandals
fields.trailText: The biotechnology sector, which has been depressed for the past 18 months following a series of scandals - overhyped drugs, cover-ups and resignations - has leaped back to life with investors switching from internet and telecom stocks.
fields.body:
The biotechnology sector, which has been depressed for the past 18 months following a series of scandals - overhyped drugs, cover-ups and resignations - has leaped back to life with investors switching from internet and telecom stocks.

Interest will increase further next week with consummation of the sector's biggest UK merger: the £1.3bn tie-up between Celltech Chiroscience and Medeva.

Bloomberg's UK Biotech Index, which tracks 33 leading stocks, reached 77.74 yesterday, up from 62.36 on January 5 and a long way beyond the 50-point level where it languished for nearly 12 months.

The smaller healthcare companies have been out of favour since former front-runner British Biotech's shares dropped from £3 18 last year - they were below 35.5p yesterday. The collapse - and subsequent management bloodletting - came amid allegations that it misled the investment community about the chances of success for two of its lead products.

British Biotech's humiliation plus rivals' failure to live up to expectations led speculative investors, who traditionally favoured this sector, to pile into what appeared more lucrative bets: telecom and internet stocks which share the new Techmark index with biotech companies.

Now a range of factors - not least a feeling that telecom shares must soon end their run - have brought investors' attention back to biotech which, like the internet, trades on future expectations rather than current profits, which in both sectors tend to be scarce.

Erling Refsum, sector analyst with the securities house Nomura, says: "Since Christmas there has been huge interest, with prices forced up partly because the sector has been bombed out for so long many sellers have already left and the stocks are relatively illiquid."

Also driving the resurgence is excitement over developments in mapping the human genome such as the successful sequencing of chromosome 22. This has led investors to realise, too, that the US has been marking up its biotech companies for some time.

Cambridge Antibody was perceived to be valued at a third of the price of US peers such as Abjnix and Medarex.

Cambridge Antibody shares bumped along in the 200p range for most of last year. Since December they have caught fire, rising a further 13% at one stage yesterday to 872.5p.

Oxford BioMedica is another small company that has benefited from the share reratings. It fell yesterday on profit taking but had risen 73% on Monday to 78.5p as the husband-and-wife team that established it took advantage of the resurgence of interest in the sector to raise £5m of new cash by way of a rights issue.

The planned £107bn Glaxo Wellcome merger with SmithKline could trigger further interest in the sector. The chairman-designate of the new group, Sir Richard Sykes, said he planned to use some of the combined cash pile to buy new assets.

Glaxo Wellcome has made no major biotech acquisition since its $538m purchase of Affymax in 1995 and opinions are split as to whether big pharmaceutical firms and small biotech companies make good bedfellows anyway.

One sector analyst said: "All the signs are that, the bigger the company, the lower the research and development productivity. The kind of scientists who form biotech companies often get on very badly with the suits that run big bureaucracies."

But the same pressures that have driven the Glaxo-SmithKline merger are gripping the biotech sector: ever higher costs of research coupled with time-consuming regulatory delays and pressure on product prices.

This is one reason why Celltech Chiroscience plans to complete its takeover of Medeva next Wednesday, in the wake of last year's tie-up between Celltech and Chiroscience.

The deal is a coup for John Jackson, chairman of Celltech Chiroscience. Celltech is the grandfather of the British biotech sector and was given £5m launch money by the first Thatcher government on condition it raised £7m from the private sector.

It is not all plain sailing for the biotech sector, with recent warnings from players such as Powderject that profits might take longer to materialise than expected.

But such difficulties only whet the appetite of some investors who say they make further mergers and takeovers more likely.

fields.headline: But you're beautiful, Miss Jones
fields.standfirst: For decades Frances de la Tour has been denied the great classical roles that she covets. Tonight she finally gets her break. She talks to  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: For decades Frances de la Tour has been denied the great classical roles that she covets. Tonight she finally gets her break. She talks to Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
Back in the 60s the young Frances de la Tour asked the director Peter Hall if she could play Juliet. Hall's response was blunt. He said it would never happen because she was far too tall and gangly and didn't fit the public's perception of how Juliet should look.

Thirty years later the Royal Shakespeare Company announces that Frances de la Tour will be starring in Antony and Cleopatra opposite Alan Bates. A cruel little joke begins to go the rounds: which one of them will be playing the "serpent of the Nile" and which one Antony? It seems that preconceptions take a very long time to break down.

Journalists like to describe Frances de la Tour as having a mournful jolie laide face and an angular body. In fact, at 56, she is a strikingly attractive and confident woman. Like Marilyn Monroe she knows how to make her presence felt. I recently watched her from a distance at a film gala. There were plenty of far more obviously beautiful women present, but it was the red-headed de la Tour that people couldn't take their eyes off. "Who is that incredibly attractive woman?" asked the man next to me.

But she has never fitted the mould of the classically beautiful Shakespearean heroine. She joined the RSC in 1965, straight after graduating from the Drama Centre (the radical breakaway from the Central School of Speech and Drama), and although Peter Brook had the far-sightedness to cast her as Helena in his famous production of A Midsummer Night's Dream, de la Tour never really got the parts she deserved. She should have done brainy Rosalind for the RSC's As You Like It. Instead she was cast as the bumpkin Audrey.

So de la Tour left and went her own way, determined that she shouldn't be strait-jacketed as so many brilliant but not conventionally good-looking actresses had before her into constantly playing the comedienne.

"However insecure I was when I was young, I was certain that I wouldn't go down that route," she explains. "A lot of those women were great artists but they suffered the most limited casting and had to constantly repeat themselves."

Instead she stretched herself, playing Hamlet before such gender-bending experiments were fashionable, and finding a lasting although not always welcome fame for her superb performance playing the lovelorn spinster Miss Jones opposite Leonard Rossiter in Rising Damp, the 70s TV comedy considered by many to be one of the finest sit-coms of all time. That inevitably brought its own kind of strait-jacket.

De la Tour isn't bitter about the missed opportunities or the parts she never played. After all, she's had some great roles - the raw, big-boned Josie in Eugene O'Neill's A Moon for the Misbegotten and Stephanie, the violinist afflicted by a muscle-wasting disease, in Duet for One, the play that her then partner, Tom Kempinski, wrote especially for her. And it's not that she's tired of playing second fiddle to others, as she did to her ex-Workers Revolutionary Party colleague Vanessa Redgrave in When She Danced or Maggie Smith in Three Tall Women. In fact, she danced off with the best supporting actress award for the former.

No, what rankles is that de la Tour believes it is the great playwrights such as Shakespeare and Chekhov who offer an actor the chance to grow and she has done so little of them.

"I don't think acting is a question of becoming somebody else. It is a question of becoming your fullest self through the part," she says. "It is not an ego trip. You allow the character to enter you, but the moments when you are closest to it are the moments when you are most in touch with yourself. Whenever I give acting classes my approach is the opposite of what is regarded as Method acting. What the actor feels is important, but what the actor feels about the part is not."

But it can be a painful, revealing process - one that de la Tour agrees is almost like being in therapy. Playing Josie in Moon For the Misbegotten cured her of the anxiety attacks that had plagued her for years.

"I really wrestled with that part. I was really ashamed of my voice and I tried to compensate by acting big. It was only when I stopped and was myself that it all fell into place. It was like a revelation. The attacks went."

But she believes that the actor can't develop if he or she doesn't get the really good roles. "I've had a wonderful time and had some very nice things said about me for some parts that I've played. But a lot of those roles don't require you to go anywhere other than where you've already been. It is frustrating to have to put a full stop on a role because it doesn't have the breadth to allow you to take it further. However good an artist you are, if you don't fit into people's preconceptions, you won't be given the chance to do it."

Which brings us back to the question of why de la Tour hasn't always got those roles that she yearns for and could so obviously play. After all, even the chance to play Cleopatra was a result of her own efforts and her friendship with director Steven Pimlott. They've been talking about the project for 10 years.

"I didn't sit around on my haunches waiting for the RSC to call and say 'How about Cleopatra?' If I had, I'd still be waiting. Steven and I waited for the right moment to suggest it."

So why hasn't de la Tour got those roles? Was it her radical politics? Or the fact that she became associated with a particular kind of desperate woman, such as Violet in Tennessee Williams' Small Craft Warnings and Miss Jones in Rising Damp? Or was it simply that she wasn't conventionally good-looking enough?

Things get a touch frosty at this point. "I am so hostile to the question," she says politely, and fiercely points out that she has never had eight double chins and that there have been plenty of classical actresses both before her and since who haven't been raving beauties and that hasn't stopped them playing Shakespeare. So if she refuses to accept that she may not have got parts because of her looks, why does she think they escaped her? Her answer seems astonishing: "Maybe people didn't think I was talented."

I find it curious that anyone would prefer to believe people thought her untalented rather than not beautiful, but a straw poll among girlfriends reveals that, given the choice when younger, they'd all have plumped for being beautiful rather than being talented or clever. So maybe de la Tour isn't that different after all.

Certainly she has grown more and more attractive as the years have gone by. As other actresses have lost their looks, de la Tour has grown into hers, although she is still reluctant to be photographed. But when the conversation warms up again, she concedes that being told you're too gangly to play Juliet does feed your anxieties.

"You begin to believe that maybe you couldn't do it. So instead you long to play unusual parts, and you learn to do them very well, and that feeds the preconception. These are the lonely people, the misbegotten. Then you start not bothering to do your hair or make-up and you get more acclaim for showing these people warts and all, and less chance of getting the roles you really want.

"I've never understood all this talk about my looks. But Tom [Kempinski] once said something interesting to me. He said, 'Whatever nonsense people write about you, there is a truth in it somewhere. What they say about you is not about what you are giving out - it's about something inner about you that they've spotted.' Maybe without realising it I did exude something."

What she exudes now is confidence, and confidence is very sexy. This is a woman in her prime, a woman absolutely ready to play Cleopatra.

Many years ago when de la Tour was at drama school, a friend overheard the principal telling the new intake about the year above. "In that year," he said, "we have a girl called Frances de la Tour. She is very beautiful, but she doesn't know it."

She didn't, but she does now.

 Antony and Cleopatra opens at the Barbican, London EC2 (0171-638 8891), tonight.

fields.headline: Labyrinth of sound
fields.standfirst: Cinema for the ears
fields.trailText: It used to be a cliche in the music press to describe certain pop records as "movies for the ears". This usually meant the sort of singles that either had a clear narrative drive (the Shangri-Las) or were visually evocative because they alluded to the bombast of big Hollywood scores (MacArthur Park, Bohemian Rhapsody).
fields.body:
It used to be a cliche in the music press to describe certain pop records as "movies for the ears". This usually meant the sort of singles that either had a clear narrative drive (the Shangri-Las) or were visually evocative because they alluded to the bombast of big Hollywood scores (MacArthur Park, Bohemian Rhapsody).

This cliche ought to have become redundant. There's no longer any reason for a pop song to be cinematic in its own right, since it's bound to have a video attached, and any images evoked by the music will be eclipsed by those cooked up for MTV.

But "cinema for the ears" could be something else entirely, although it's something that few musicians or film-makers have dared imagine. One new CD release that genuinely qualifies as "listening cinema" is Jean-Luc Godard's Histoire(s) du Cinéma, which began as a series of eight video essays and is now a five-CD box set, complete with illustrated books, on the ECM label. This is an odd phenomenon for two reasons: one, because ECM rarely does soundtracks, but specialises in improvised and new classical music; and two, because this is not what we usually think of as a film soundtrack.

We get not just the music from Godard's Histoire(s), but the entire soundtrack: music, commentary in French, snatches of film dialogue, sound effects. If you listened to a similarly complete soundtrack from a conventional film, you could probably reconstitute the visuals more or less coherently - you'd know whether the setting were a stately home or a western saloon, and when the killer was going to jump out of the cupboard. But Histoire(s) is more abstract, a free-form collage-essay of voice and sound, stitched together in a stop-start mosaic.

Nor, despite the title, is this a conventional history of cinema, but a set of discontinuous observations and digressions. Sometimes the various voices (including Godard's own doom-laden rasp) make direct, provocative propositions about film history: the suggestion that Alfred Hitchcock succeeded where Hitler and Napoleon failed, in becoming master of the universe; or that cinema is really a branch of the cosmetics industry.

The Histoire(s) CDs are best described as radical musique concrète that flouts the boundaries between spoken-word and music recording. What's puzzling, however, is this soundtrack's status as a free-floating object separate from the films, all the more so in that the visual images in Histoire(s) are no mere illustration of the argument, but an argument in their own right. Just as Godard layers sound, he layers images and words on screen, flashing up slogans, cutting from one film clip to another, dissolving fiction footage into documentary, film into painting. The meaning of the whole isn't clear-cut; rather, the whole undertaking is, to quote one passage, "a saturation of magnificent signs bathed in the light of their absence of explanation".

A few years ago, ECM also released the soundtrack to Godard's 1990 feature Nouvelle Vague, an ostensibly more conventional film in that there are characters and a narrative. Not that the soundtrack will help you with either: it's an enigmatic pile-up of voices, birdsong, car doors slamming and occasional passages of Patti Smith or Schoenberg. Godard teasingly said about Nouvelle Vague, "My film without the sound will be improved. However, if you "see" the soundtrack without the images, it will have an even greater impact."

The extraordinary thing about both Godard CDs is that they encourage us to get lost in a labyrinth of sound and meaning, where soundtracks generally serve as safeguards against us losing our way. Few film-makers are willing to risk a disoriented audience, or to challenge the primacy of dialogue. (David Lynch is a rare exception - try Lost Highway with your eyes shut.) Though Godard's CDs only represent one half of the works they're taken from, it's by no means the inferior half: sound and image are on a strictly equal footing.

Unanchored by their images, these soundtracks reveal how precarious the traditional sound-image hierarchy is, and how rarely it's challenged. Experienced as listening cinema, Histoire(s) du Cinéma also reminds us of the other half of the equation. To wit, if sound and image aren't obliged simply to illustrate each other, then cinema should also be viewed as music for the eyes - which means not MTV but Schoenberg, or Lee Perry, or Alfred Hitchcock.

 Jean-Luc Godard's Histoire(s) du Cinéma five-CD box set is on the ECM New Series label, price £79.99.

Few film-makers are willing to risk a disoriented audience, or to challenge the primacy of dialogue. (David Lynch is a rare exception - try Lost Highway with your eyes shut.) Though Godard's CDs only represent one half of the works they're taken from, it's by no means the inferior half: sound and image are on a strictly equal footing. Unanchored by their images, these soundtracks reveal how precarious the traditional sound-image hierarchy is, and how rarely it's challenged. Experienced as listening cinema, Histoire(s) du Cinéma also reminds us of the other half of the equation. To wit, if sound and image aren't obliged simply to illustrate each other, then cinema should also be viewed as music for the eyes - which means not MTV but Schoenberg, or Lee Perry, or Alfred Hitchcock.  Jean-Luc Godard's Histoire(s) du Cinéma five-CD box set is on the ECM New Series label, price £79.99.

fields.headline: End of the revolution
fields.standfirst: No Alan McGee, no Oasis and now almost no staff... Creation Records is winding down.  Dave Simpson reports
fields.trailText: No Alan McGee, no Oasis and now almost no staff... Creation Records is winding down. Dave Simpson reports
fields.body:
The record company whose slogan was Form Is Temporary, Class Is Permanent is about to close its doors. Two months after the surprise announcement that founder Alan McGee was leaving, Creation Records, the label that spawned Oasis, has started to resemble a graveyard. Before Christmas, Creation's London office employed more than 40 people. Now there are only four. "No one's here," says Creation's head of art, Simon Corkin. "We're drowning in empty boxes; posters are lying everywhere. It's horrible. You can almost hear a pin drop. There's no music playing or anything. Boxes of records are just lying around with nowhere to go. Everything's finished, basically."

If McGee's exit shocked the music industry, the speed of Creation's demise astounded staff who thought that the 17-year-old label, which had survived near-bankruptcy (not to mention the excesses of rockers like the Gallaghers), was nigh-immortal. "When I first I heard the news, I took it with a pinch of salt," says Corkin. "I never thought it would actually happen."

He and his colleagues had better start believing it. The bulk of Creation staff had been told that their jobs were secure until July, the end of the campaign for Oasis's forthcoming album, Standing on the Shoulder of Giants. But everything has been thrown into a tailspin by this month's news that Oasis are to form their own label, Big Brother - and that Big Brother will be releasing the new album. McGee claims the new label was not due to start trading until at least March, but a leak speeded everything up.

All this is highly embarrassing for McGee, not least because the end of Creation means that a lifelong socialist and confirmed enemy of unemployment is being held responsible for putting people on the dole. However, former employees have been given a generous payoff of three months' money, and McGee is adamant that he is not personally to blame. Within the next few weeks McGee and his partner Dick Green will sell their 51% stake in Creation to Sony, which already owns the rest of the company. He insists that final responsibility for closing the label rests with its future owner.

"I gave people jobs for 17 years," he pleads. "I'm not their dad. If Sony want to put 30 people on the dole, it's up to them. I left. Sony could have carried on. If I walk off the football pitch and Sony close the label, is that my fault?"

Curiously, according to McGee, the label could still survive the redundancies: Sony is apparently unsure what to do with it. He says he hopes Creation doesn't end up "like Motown after Berry Gordy left, a 'cool' imprint for rubbish boy bands".

While the caustic, charming McGee hasn't got where he is today without a grasp of PR nous, it's hard to disagree with his logic. For McGee, walking away from Creation is a professional statement from someone who has managed to combine being maverick, millionaire, punk rocker and friend of the prime minister. Having famously given up drugs, he has become tired of being dependant on airplay, sharing the charts with "commercialised muck like S Club 7", and is planning new adventures (partly using the internet) which will "shock and surprise" the old music industry left impotent by merger after merger. "How long before Microsoft buys EMI?" he asks.

"I have been very disillusioned," he admits of Creation. "I started a label with my friends in 1983 and by 1999 we had a team of corporate technicians running the record label. I want to go back to putting out records I love. In a way, I've kinda gone back to where I came from."

Indeed. McGee's sudden exit displays exactly the kind of radical gesture upon which his label was founded. Creation never revolutionised pop packaging (as did Factory) or independent distribution (like Rough Trade) but gave birth to some of the most revolutionary pop records of the modern era. Formed by McGee and pals Dick Green and Joe Foster with a £1,000 bank loan, Creation was founded on McGee's vision of combining punk attitude and psychedelic sounds. For a glorious period well into the 90s, this madcap label launched terrorist raids from the independent sector into mainstream pop culture.

Jesus and Mary Chain, My Bloody Valentine, The House of Love and Primal Scream (and later on Sugar, Ride and Teenage Fanclub) captured a mood of anarchic, youthful exhilaration that conjured up the wildest party in history. The label wasn't exactly lovey-dovey: "At Motown, Marvin Gaye hated Smokey Robinson and Diana Ross," explains Ed Ball, Creation's original record plugger and later one of its artistes. "At Creation everybody hated everybody." Still, a wild party wasn't far from the truth. "In those days, a lot revolved around drugs," admits Andy Saunders, Creation's former head of communications.

After McGee's own coke habit escalated from one to seven grams a day and he almost died on a flight to Los Angeles, he spent eight months in rehab. Following his return, out went the office culture of wild parties and in came a new office staffed with corporate professionals, which coincided with the fact that his new signings - a bunch of surly Mancunians - had just hit number one. McGee was clean, Oasis had arrived. Life at Creation would never be the same again.

There was another critical development. After financial problems in 1991, McGee and Green had sold 49% of Creation to Sony. This Faustian pact saved the label from bankruptcy and meant they could invest heavily in Oasis but sowed the seeds of McGee's eventual disillusion.

Oasis's immediate global success changed the rules. Sure, there were triumphs that probably made McGee's wildest drug fantasies seem eminently respectable (Oasis at Knebworth, a £20m bank account, tea with the prime minister), but there was a price. As an indie, if Creation got a record into the top 40 it was a triumph. Now, anything less than top 10 was seen as a failure.

As Creation became part of the mainstream and Sony "demanded another superstar", McGee was increasingly chasing the market. He was signing boring bands and spending more and more money on them because the corporate marketing system demanded it. His last signing was disastrous. Kevin Rowland came back wearing a dress and sold a reported 500 or so copies, despite costing six figures. At least McGee went out in gloriously madcap style.

Already, rumours are spreading like wildfire, but McGee and associates are keen to stress that it really was McGee, not Sony, who decided that he should end his involvement with Creation.

"To be fair, they trusted Alan's judgment right till the end," says Saunders, who was made redundant on Christmas Eve but is now working with McGee on his new projects. "They always said 'Look, we never believed in five blokes from Manchester. We thought they were a dodgy Happy Mondays, and look what happened.' "

Ultimately, he says, the decision was not financial, and was as much of a shock to Sony as to anybody else.

In the next few months, McGee will make his next moves. Some Creation staff are going with him to his new internet label, Poptones. The rest ("major label people, nice people, but not my people") will have to fend for themselves. Primal Scream will stay contracted to Sony; McGee suspects Super Furry Animals will leave. The rest will probably fall by the wayside, but Creation is unlikely to be forgotten. "I hope people remember Creation as the truly great label it surely was," says Saunders. "I hope they don't think it was something really good that went crap."

"Ultimately," says McGee, "we failed. I wanted to be Motown or Stax; ultimately we were Stiff or something. Still, I think we will be remembered. We were the soundtrack to a lot of young people's lives."

As for Corkin, Creation's head of art for the past three years, he's "looking forward to not having to think about Oasis". This time next week, he signs on the dole.

fields.headline: Arkan
fields.standfirst:
Underworld boss of Milosevic's murder squad
Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Zeljko Raznatovic, who has been gunned down in Belgrade aged 47 and was known since the late 1970s as "Arkan", was the most able self-publicist in Serbia, revelling in his notoriety abroad and portraying himself as a warrior prince. He was also one of the most wanted men in Europe, indicted as a suspected war criminal by the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.
fields.body:
Zeljko Raznatovic, who has been gunned down in Belgrade aged 47 and was known since the late 1970s as "Arkan", was the most able self-publicist in Serbia, revelling in his notoriety abroad and portraying himself as a warrior prince. He was also one of the most wanted men in Europe, indicted as a suspected war criminal by the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

Born in Brezice, a small Slovenian town 12 miles west of Zagreb, the Croatian capital, he was the son of a senior officer in the Yugoslav airforce. As a teenager, he developed a reputation as a tearaway and delinquent, and by his early 20s had embarked on a life of criminality in northern Europe.

Yugoslavia's policy of allowing its citizens to work in western Europe, combined with labour shortages in West Germany and Scandinavia, led to the growth of huge Croat and Serb emigré communities during the 1960s. This was accompanied by a large criminal fraternity that dominated the Frankfurt underworld, and was linked to crime syndicates in Norway, Sweden and the Benelux countries, as well as in Italy to the south.

Raznatovic, who adopted the moniker Arkan from one of his false passports at this time, became notorious as a specialist in armed robbery. Goran Vukovic, a fellow gangster who was himself gunned down in Belgrade in 1994, recalled Arkan's early years: "Of all of us, Arkan robbed the most banks; he walked into them almost like they were self-service stores. No one can quarrel with that fact about him. I don't know about politics, but as far as robbery is concerned, he was really unsurpassed."

But Arkan did get repeatedly caught. He was first jailed in 1975, when a Brussels court sentenced him to 15 years in prison. He escaped after serving 42 months, establishing a remarkable pattern of break outs from western prisons. He fled jails in Holland and Germany, and evaded arrest in Sweden and Italy.

Such was his ability to slip through borders, and out of prison, that his colleagues began to suspect, correctly, that he was collaborating with the Yugoslav secret police. In any event, he was not arrested when he returned to Belgrade in 1986 to open his renowned cake and ice-cream shop, located opposite the stadium of Serbia's most successful football team, Red Star Belgrade.

Arkan soon became chairman of Red Star's fan club, Delije (the Warriors), where he naturally found plenty of aggressive young men from whom he could pick recruits for his criminal gang. By November 1990, he was already working with the Serbian authorities in their attempts to destabilise Croatia. He was arrested in the village of Dvorna Uni by Croatian police and charged with unauthorised possession of weapons. He returned to Belgrade after six months in custody. At home, he boasted he would soon "be back in Zagreb to open a cake shop on Republic Square."

The then Croatian interior minister, Josip Boljkovac, has revealed that the Belgrade authorities bought Arkan's freedom from imprisonment for 1m German marks, a trade-off which many Croats would later regret - though, at the time, the Croatian government was desperate for hard currency to purchase weapons. Viewed from another perspective, the deal also indicated how closely Arkan had become involved with President Slobodan Milosevic's Serbian government.

During 1991, Arkan's Serb Volunteer Guard, or "Tigers", became the most powerful paramilitary unit in eastern Slavonija, the part of Croatia that borders Serbia. In a massive operation of plunder and slaughter in the villages surrounding the besieged town of Vukovar, Arkan established a veritable corporation in Erdut, his local headquarters. This was to become the beginning of his criminal empire, which, at the time of his death, was the largest mafia operation in Serbia. He repeated this strategy in Bosnia and Hercegovina, driving out or murdering Muslims from eastern Bosnia, and then establishing strong commercial links with the wartime Bosnian Serb parastate.

Arkan's self-publicity was greatly enhanced by his marriage in 1995 to Ceca, one of Serbia's most glamorous "turbo-folk" stars, with whom he had two children to add to the seven he had fathered in previous relationships and marriages.

In stark contrast to President Milosevic, Arkan and his political movement, the Serbian Unity party, paid great homage to the Serbian Orthodox church and other symbols associated with the Chetnik tradition of Serbian nationalism. He was, however, invariably at odds with the other self-proclaimed Chetnik leader, Vojislav Seselj.

In the late 1990s, Arkan began to establish closer links with Milosevic's political enemies, notably Milo Djukanovic, the president of Montenegro. In April 1999, it was also revealed that he was on the list of indicted war criminals at the Hague tribunal, along with Milosevic himself.

For the last year, Arkan had been one of the most wanted men in Europe, but his mafia interests were clashing ever more frequently with those of gangs associated with JUL, the party run by Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic. It would be a great surprise to all in Serbia if the circumstances surrounding Arkan's murder were ever cleared up, but few in the remainder of the former Yugoslavia will be mourning him.

Misha Glenny

fields.headline: Philip Jones
fields.standfirst: Gifted trumpeter who opened the world of chamber music to brass instruments
fields.trailText: The stereotypical brass player - northern, overweight, blunt and beer-loving - is still the concertgoer's most cherished misconception. Philip Jones, who has died aged 71, lived elegantly in St John's Wood, London, and in Switzerland; he was slim, carefully spoken and immaculately dressed; and he fought against this caricature until his Philip Jones Brass Ensemble was playing the same venues, and receiving the same critical attention, as the finest string quartets.
fields.body:
The stereotypical brass player - northern, overweight, blunt and beer-loving - is still the concertgoer's most cherished misconception. Philip Jones, who has died aged 71, lived elegantly in St John's Wood, London, and in Switzerland; he was slim, carefully spoken and immaculately dressed; and he fought against this caricature until his Philip Jones Brass Ensemble was playing the same venues, and receiving the same critical attention, as the finest string quartets.

Occasionally appearing in front of the orchestra as soloists, brass instruments are generally assumed to be a backing act. Philip worked tirelessly to establish them as a medium that could hold centre stage, by themselves, for a whole evening.

Few brass players of recent generations can have escaped benefiting from his influence - whether by playing works he commissioned, studying at one of the three music colleges where he held senior positions, or enjoying the new credibility afforded to brass chamber music that he wrested out of the "posh" musical establishment. With his ensemble, he made more than 50 recordings and gave 87 world premieres. He had 71 works written especially for him.

Born in Bath and brought up in a London family of trumpeters, Philip won a scholarship to the Royal College of Music. During the next 25 years, he held the position of principal trumpet in six London orchestras - a unique achievement, but still not his real ambition. In 1947, he heard a performance of brass chamber music, rare at that time, by four players from the Concertgebouw Orchestra, which started him on the path he followed until retirement in 1986.

In 1951 he formed a quartet, the first group to bear the name of the Philip Jones Brass Ensemble, already with its first piece of specially commissioned music. At this time, a group of brass instruments, no matter how distinguished its members, was still seen as a "brass band", only to be considered for open-air music, accompaniments to singers, or ceremonial performances.

Philip's reaction to this was typical of him: not to bemoan it or rail against it, but over the years to acquire new repertory, promote his own concerts, seek out engagements and refine the group's performances into something that would persuade promoters and public to think again.

The group expanded in 1963 into a quintet of two trumpets, horn, trombone and tuba. As its prestige grew, Philip was able to employ in it the cream of Britain's brass soloists; two considerable musicians to join were Elgar Howarth, whose enthusiasm for 20th-century music had a great influence, and John Fletcher, tuba icon and musical polymath, whose loyalty and quirky humour lightened Philip's load immensely.

As performance opportunities multiplied through the 1970s, the ensemble grew in size until it settled on the combination of four trumpets, four trombones, horn and tuba. This particular grouping, rich and varied in sound, had a unique sonority, born of fastidious attention to the details of balance, intonation and nuance, immediately recognisable by brassmen and laymen alike. It achieved unprecedented popularity, performing nearly 100 engagements a year in the 1980s across Europe, the United States, Japan and Australia.

This acclaim was not derived wholly from polished performance standards. Philip was the master programme-planner, every minute being evaluated in terms of its demands on both players and audience (or "customers" as he preferred them to be called). "Middle of the road", often used disparagingly, would be unlikely to cause any offence to Philip, a pragmatist who knew exactly where his act was positioned. He was not drawn by instinct to the avant-garde, unless the music was carefully and idiomatically written for the instruments. Those of us who made his transcriptions of classical and romantic music sometimes had to rein back his enthusiasm - to convince him, for example, that a suite of Chopin piano pieces arranged for brass was not one of his better ideas.

He was adamant that instrumental pyrotechnics should not form a substantial part of his programme, content just to tease the audience with an encore that would highlight the brilliance of one of his team, but never himself. His willingness to push others to the fore makes even more remarkable his achievement of blending 10 top players into the "Philip Jones" sound. In fact, in the years before his retirement, he became much less prominent as soloist or front man, while the ensemble became even more stamped with his personality.

The huge amount of administration for concert tours and recordings was shared by Philip's wife, Ursula Strebi, but he shouldered all the musical preparation himself, leaving his players free to concentrate on their performance. While we were enjoying a pre-concert meal, Philip could always been found sitting alone on the stage, carefully positioning everyone's music, lining up the stands, and checking sight lines.

After retirement from playing, he continued a full life as teacher, administrator and adjudicator, a role that took him around the world. He was principal of the Trinity College of Music from 1988-94. Among his many honours were fellowships from several music colleges and the Royal Society of Arts, the Composers Guild Award, the CBE, and freedom of the City of London. He was a member of the Arts Council and chairman of the Musicians Benevolent Fund.

Philip leaves behind no musical foundation or playing method; he wrote no treatise or textbook, being content to let his music speak for itself. His legacy is to be heard on recordings, and in the sonorous elegance of the best of British brass playing.

He is survived by his wife and sister.

Christopher Mowat

Philip Mark Jones, musician, born March 12 1928; died January 17 2000
fields.bodyText: The stereotypical brass player - northern, overweight, blunt and beer-loving - is still the concertgoer's most cherished misconception. Philip Jones, who has died aged 71, lived elegantly in St John's Wood, London, and in Switzerland; he was slim, carefully spoken and immaculately dressed; and he fought against this caricature until his Philip Jones Brass Ensemble was playing the same venues, and receiving the same critical attention, as the finest string quartets. Occasionally appearing in front of the orchestra as soloists, brass instruments are generally assumed to be a backing act. Philip worked tirelessly to establish them as a medium that could hold centre stage, by themselves, for a whole evening. Few brass players of recent generations can have escaped benefiting from his influence - whether by playing works he commissioned, studying at one of the three music colleges where he held senior positions, or enjoying the new credibility afforded to brass chamber music that he wrested out of the "posh" musical establishment. With his ensemble, he made more than 50 recordings and gave 87 world premieres. He had 71 works written especially for him. Born in Bath and brought up in a London family of trumpeters, Philip won a scholarship to the Royal College of Music. During the next 25 years, he held the position of principal trumpet in six London orchestras - a unique achievement, but still not his real ambition. In 1947, he heard a performance of brass chamber music, rare at that time, by four players from the Concertgebouw Orchestra, which started him on the path he followed until retirement in 1986. In 1951 he formed a quartet, the first group to bear the name of the Philip Jones Brass Ensemble, already with its first piece of specially commissioned music. At this time, a group of brass instruments, no matter how distinguished its members, was still seen as a "brass band", only to be considered for open-air music, accompaniments to singers, or ceremonial performances. Philip's reaction to this was typical of him: not to bemoan it or rail against it, but over the years to acquire new repertory, promote his own concerts, seek out engagements and refine the group's performances into something that would persuade promoters and public to think again. The group expanded in 1963 into a quintet of two trumpets, horn, trombone and tuba. As its prestige grew, Philip was able to employ in it the cream of Britain's brass soloists; two considerable musicians to join were Elgar Howarth, whose enthusiasm for 20th-century music had a great influence, and John Fletcher, tuba icon and musical polymath, whose loyalty and quirky humour lightened Philip's load immensely. As performance opportunities multiplied through the 1970s, the ensemble grew in size until it settled on the combination of four trumpets, four trombones, horn and tuba. This particular grouping, rich and varied in sound, had a unique sonority, born of fastidious attention to the details of balance, intonation and nuance, immediately recognisable by brassmen and laymen alike. It achieved unprecedented popularity, performing nearly 100 engagements a year in the 1980s across Europe, the United States, Japan and Australia. This acclaim was not derived wholly from polished performance standards. Philip was the master programme-planner, every minute being evaluated in terms of its demands on both players and audience (or "customers" as he preferred them to be called). "Middle of the road", often used disparagingly, would be unlikely to cause any offence to Philip, a pragmatist who knew exactly where his act was positioned. He was not drawn by instinct to the avant-garde, unless the music was carefully and idiomatically written for the instruments. Those of us who made his transcriptions of classical and romantic music sometimes had to rein back his enthusiasm - to convince him, for example, that a suite of Chopin piano pieces arranged for brass was not one of his better ideas. He was adamant that instrumental pyrotechnics should not form a substantial part of his programme, content just to tease the audience with an encore that would highlight the brilliance of one of his team, but never himself. His willingness to push others to the fore makes even more remarkable his achievement of blending 10 top players into the "Philip Jones" sound. In fact, in the years before his retirement, he became much less prominent as soloist or front man, while the ensemble became even more stamped with his personality. The huge amount of administration for concert tours and recordings was shared by Philip's wife, Ursula Strebi, but he shouldered all the musical preparation himself, leaving his players free to concentrate on their performance. While we were enjoying a pre-concert meal, Philip could always been found sitting alone on the stage, carefully positioning everyone's music, lining up the stands, and checking sight lines. After retirement from playing, he continued a full life as teacher, administrator and adjudicator, a role that took him around the world. He was principal of the Trinity College of Music from 1988-94. Among his many honours were fellowships from several music colleges and the Royal Society of Arts, the Composers Guild Award, the CBE, and freedom of the City of London. He was a member of the Arts Council and chairman of the Musicians Benevolent Fund. Philip leaves behind no musical foundation or playing method; he wrote no treatise or textbook, being content to let his music speak for itself. His legacy is to be heard on recordings, and in the sonorous elegance of the best of British brass playing. He is survived by his wife and sister. webTitle: Donnelly spots the way out of gridlock

fields.headline: Donnelly spots the way out of gridlock
fields.trailText: After a delayed kick-off caused by traffic delays, these two sides became congested in their own gridlock last night. This FA Cup fourth-round replay had been taken into extra-time before the Premiership side Sheffield Wednesday won 4-3 in a penalty shoot-out, the substitute Simon Donnelly striking the final decisive spot kick.
fields.body:
After a delayed kick-off caused by traffic delays, these two sides became congested in their own gridlock last night. This FA Cup fourth-round replay had been taken into extra-time before the Premiership side Sheffield Wednesday won 4-3 in a penalty shoot-out, the substitute Simon Donnelly striking the final decisive spot kick.

A side notoriously prone to bouts of travel sickness, the 20-minute hold-up clearly did Sheffield Wednesday few favours and their display typified why they should get used to visiting First Division stadia.

The gulf in status was rarely evident and Danny Wilson's side was somewhat fortuitous to emerge unscathed after coming off second best in their pursuit for poetic justice.

Only an astonishing error of judgment had denied Wednesday entry into the fifth round when a trigger-happy linesman got his angles horribly wrong and erroneously awarded Steve Sedgley a headed "goal". But the ball had clearly never crossed the line.

Hence Wilson's players trundled down congested motorways to Molineux bristling with indignation and with the manager wondering whether Joe Ashton and his fellow government conspirators had recruited Lady Luck in their plot to have him removed from office.

The midfielder Alan Quinn appeared particularly intent on exacting some personal retribution with an aerial challenge that poleaxed Sedgley in the opening exchanges.

Wednesday's irritation was almost compounded midway through a rumbustious first half when Andy Sinton's left-wing cross was headed against the inside of the right-hand post by Ade Akinbiyi before being belted away by a grateful Steven Haslam. This time, however, the linesman's flag stayed by his side. The sight of Sinton in such impressive form provoked memories of happier times for Wednesday and his supply line from the left flank posed constant problems for his former club during long spells of concerted pressure from the home side.

The visitors provided a few incisive moments of their own, most notably when the Belgian striker Gilles De Bilde manoeuvred a shooting opportunity inside the first few minutes only to arrow his left-foot drive narrowly wide.

But it was not difficult to establish why Wednesday had failed to muster a single victory away from home all season, scoring in only four matches on their travels.

Wilson attempted to increase his side's attacking enterprise by introducing Donnelly for Philip Scott after the interval and the former Celtic player forced the first save of note from Michael Oakes within 30 seconds of the re-start, but there was precious little else from the visiting side as the game continued to stagnate. The contingent from Gillingham will have returned south optimistic about their chances of progressing into the sixth round.

fields.headline: What a load of rubbish
fields.trailText: A powerful anti-litter message was issued by London Underground last week, when trains on the Piccadilly line ground to a halt in the path of an errant sandwich wrapper. No ordinary disposable this, but a strain of tin foil with the constitution to short circuits, blow signal boxes and ultimately foul up the traffic between Hatton Cross and Heathrow. The authorities were quick to turn the incident to their advantage. Within minutes of calculating the likely extent of the delay, a notice went up in the entrance of Hatton Cross station, placing the origins of the problem firmly in the public's lap. "Delays will occur following an earlier interruption due to foil on the line," read the handwritten text, with the sort of compressed causality for which we have come to love London Underground. "Please take your litter home with you. Thank you."
fields.body:
A powerful anti-litter message was issued by London Underground last week, when trains on the Piccadilly line ground to a halt in the path of an errant sandwich wrapper. No ordinary disposable this, but a strain of tin foil with the constitution to short circuits, blow signal boxes and ultimately foul up the traffic between Hatton Cross and Heathrow. The authorities were quick to turn the incident to their advantage. Within minutes of calculating the likely extent of the delay, a notice went up in the entrance of Hatton Cross station, placing the origins of the problem firmly in the public's lap. "Delays will occur following an earlier interruption due to foil on the line," read the handwritten text, with the sort of compressed causality for which we have come to love London Underground. "Please take your litter home with you. Thank you."

On interrogation, a spokesman for London Underground delivered himself of the opinion that passengers, disgruntled by the 90-minute suspension of services which hit at peak rush hour, between 7.45am and 9.20am, had only themselves to blame. "These things happen because people are careless and drop litter," he said irritably. "These things are not down to us. They are down to Joe Public."

Joe Public? This, presumably, is the most palatable of the terms London Underground staff use in private reference to "customers" and one can only imagine what other evils they ascribe to him. Perhaps Joe Public has influence over Jack Frost, at large in the trees over rural Britain, blowing gently on the most stubborn leaves. In this instance, however, whoever the offending snacker was, his sin is surely mitigated by the lesson it has taught us: that it is wise to pack sandwiches for a journey on London Underground, since you never know how long your journey might take or where you will find yourself when you get there.

webTitle: How the net has helped my career

fields.headline: How the net has helped my career
fields.standfirst:
Jobs Unlimited
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText:
Simon Jones, 47 strategic planner
I work from home for a food company based in North America and for me, the advantages of email are enormous: I can send loads off when I finish work and the time difference means there'll be replies in the morning. But the real benefit of the internet is it has cut research time. I can look at publicly-available files and in one day go from no information to having a pretty clear idea of what a company does. I used to have to pay a researcher; now it costs virtually nothing.
fields.body:
Simon Jones, 47 strategic planner
I work from home for a food company based in North America and for me, the advantages of email are enormous: I can send loads off when I finish work and the time difference means there'll be replies in the morning. But the real benefit of the internet is it has cut research time. I can look at publicly-available files and in one day go from no information to having a pretty clear idea of what a company does. I used to have to pay a researcher; now it costs virtually nothing.

Andrea Evans, 41 charity fund-raiser
Not everyone in the charity sector is up-to-speed with the internet. A lot of people still use libraries and annual reports, but I go to the websites of companies I want to know about. The internet is particularly useful when you're doing a bit of industrial espionage - you can bypass phoning and asking for a brochure to be sent to your home address, so they don't know where you're calling from. The internet is much more anonymous in terms of getting information.

Yasmeen Zia, 29 advertising sales executive
I got my job from the internet. I couldn't afford to buy a newspaper every day, so I would scroll through the employment webpages. I found my job on a site where you could click on a link that gave you a profile of the company. It put me at an advantage because I knew more about them when I applied. I went for another job at the same time and I think they were impressed I used the internet and sent my CV by email. Applying for jobs this way shows you are up to date with technology.

A lot of hotel companies think they can put their brochure on a webpage and that will be enough. I run a hotel marketing company where we offer VIP treatment to company directors at the world's top privately-owned hotels. I'm investing a lot of money to boost our website. I think the internet is the marketplace of the future, especially in luxury goods. We're offering a service where clients will be able to view our hotels in 3D and book through our website.

Caitlin Walker, 30 communications consultant
I'm about to go into a small business to do some consultancy and there's a lot of background work to do. I've got a nine-month-old baby and I work from home, so normal office hours aren't feasible. I have to get up at 2am, so I can send emails while I'm breastfeeding. Emails are much better than phone calls during the day, too, because people can't hear the baby screaming in the background. Sometimes it's hard to concentrate when someone is talking on the phone, but you can re-read emails at your leisure.

 Interviews by Cayte Williams

webTitle: Hands up who wants to be hands-on

fields.headline: Hands up who wants to be hands-on
fields.standfirst: You've been promoted? Great! Or is it? Last week, Microsoft boss Bill Gates announced that he is giving up running the company to go back to his real love: programming the computers. And he is not alone:  Anita Chaudhuri meets the managers happy to take a step back down the career ladder
fields.trailText: You've been promoted? Great! Or is it? Last week, Microsoft boss Bill Gates announced that he is giving up running the company to go back to his real love: programming the computers. And he is not alone: Anita Chaudhuri meets the managers happy to take a step back down the career ladder
fields.body:
It is hard not to love Bill Gates. No, really. In one swift move, the billion-dollar geek has admitted what the rest of us have suspected for years: that it's dull at the top. Gates has just swapped his day job, running Microsoft, to return to what he loves best, messing around with computers, and now he wants to be addressed by the far groovier title of Chief Software Architect.

The real reason for his new job title may be far from groovy, however. In six weeks' time, Microsoft faces an investigation into whether it has breached American anti-trust laws and Gates may be removing himself in the nick of time from what could prove a protracted battle. But whatever his reasons, managers across the world must be rubbing their hands with glee. Gates has acknowledged an increasingly common dilemma in the 21st-century workplace: how is it possible to speed up the corporate ladder while hanging on to the bits of your old job that made you a star in the first place?

"When my boss offered me promotion, I instinctively wanted to turn it down," says Jane Charles, who works in sales. "At the time, I was on the sales team of a large cosmetics firm. I loved the job - there was lots of fieldwork, going out on the road selling, and lots of bonding with the team in the pub afterwards. I used to get a real high from meeting my targets."

Against her better judgment, she took the new post of sales manager, an office-bound job which involved lots of paperwork. "I felt isolated from my former colleagues. Suddenly they viewed me as the enemy. I was the one who had to tell them off if they didn't perform well, but worse was that, overnight, I had ceased to do what I loved best, which was selling."

Charles finally worked up the nerve to tell her boss things weren't working out. "He was sympathetic up to a point but when I suggested going back to my old job he was horrified and said management would consider such a move only if someone were forced to slow down on health grounds. In the end I found a sales job with another firm but there were awkward questions at the interview about why on earth I wanted to take a step down the career ladder."

Andrew Ferguson, who runs Breakthrough, an organisation that manages changes in the workplace, is not surprised by this story. "Turning down promotion is a bit like being picked for the First 11 at school and saying: 'No, thanks, I don't fancy it.' It makes you look a bit wet."

Ferguson should know: he was that rare schoolboy who did turn down a coveted First 11 place and he has been downshifting ever since. "Hardest of all is taking promotion, then admitting it hasn't worked out," he says. "Companies don't like people making career reversals because it smacks of failure. The culture of the modern office is becoming increasingly macho and any admission of weakness doesn't go down well. Having said that, it is possible to avoid promotion if you can make yourself appear indispensable to the team."

Psychiatrist Sarah Bell found herself grappling with these issues last year when she realised that the demands of a new job were taking away most of her job satisfaction. "I was seeing far too many patients, combining a heavy caseload with on-call work and ward rounds, and there was pressure to write papers and keep up with research. After a while I became very depressed. I realised what I loved about the job - taking time to talk to patients and understand their histories - was disappearing. I began to see that a lot of career psychiatrists have no empathy for patients because there isn't time."

To her colleagues' amazement, Bell took a part-time job at another hospital. "A lot of them thought I was out of my mind. But my new job is 20 hours per week, with no on-call work, and it lets me get back to the aspects of the profession that inspire me. It also gives me time to develop interests outside what is still a very stressful job. I am now earning considerably less, but that's a small price to pay."

Career experts agree that going for the big money is not always the best policy. Occupational psychologist Ros Taylor interviewed 80 chief executives for her business self-help book Transform Yourself! (published by Kogan Page this week). "When it comes to promotion, people imagine money is the only motivator, but that is a mistake. There are other values that enhance our working lives, such as power and influence, creativity and affiliation with colleagues."

She points out that career reversals are not impossible but says the person involved needs to work out what it is they want from their job. "Often people come to see me suffering from stress due to overwork. Usually it isn't overwork, but feeling they are no longer doing the right work for them."

Chris Fowler, a PR executive with the Burson-Marsteller Agency, is someone who has successfully negotiated a career change with his firm. "In PR, there is a classic career progression that takes you away from pitching stories to the press and working on media campaigns, to dealing with client billing and staff resources. That started happening to me and after a lot of thought I went to my boss and asked if I could just get on with what I did best - dealing with the press."

He was fortunate enough to be given a new job title, Media Manager, and was allowed to specialise in his chosen area. "It was very forward-thinking of the company," he says, but admits it has changed relations with some colleagues. "They have different challenges from mine - trying to control budgets, for example. I'm at the same level of seniority but because my job is so different, colleagues can lack empathy."

One person who may experience a similar lack of empathy is Bill Gates. He might be returning to grassroots level but, cleverly, he is still hanging on to the reins of power, with the new title of Chairman. True, he's going back to doing what he loves, but the workforce at Microsoft must be quaking in their Nike trainers. Now their boss will have a ringside view of the office slackers.

fields.headline: Technology boom boosts factory output
fields.trailText: Britain's hi-tech boom powered the biggest gain in manufacturing output for four-and-a-half years in November but the strong pound is still handicapping many more traditional industries, according to official figures published yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's hi-tech boom powered the biggest gain in manufacturing output for four-and-a-half years in November but the strong pound is still handicapping many more traditional industries, according to official figures published yesterday.

Overall output leapt 0.6% in the month - twice as high as expected in the City - taking it 2.2% above the level of a year ago, and the biggest annual increase since June 1995.

Analysts said the surprising strength of the data from the office for national statistics reinforced expectations of further interest rate rises in the wake of last week's 0.25% increase to 5.75%.

"Although it is other data, such as the labour market, service sector and the housing market which is driving rates higher, the strength of this report should help seal another 0.25% increase at the next MPC meeting on February 10," said Deutsche Bank economist Ciaran Barr.

November's surge produced a 1.1% increase in manufacturing output over the past three months, illustrating a dramatic turnaround in the sector's fortunes from early last year, when it was in recession.

But analysis by industrial sub-sector reveals a patchy performance with only five out of 14 recording significant growth - chemicals, electrical and optical equipment, transport equipment, food, drink and tobacco, and base metals.

Leading the way between September and November was the chemicals sector, where output rose 4.3% compared to the previous three months.

ONS officials said the pharmaceuticals industry was do ing particularly well, benefiting from robust demand for new treatments for baldness and irritable bowel syndrome.

In joint second place, recording an output growth of 2.5%, were electrical and optical equipment and transport equipment. Production volume of mobile telephones increased by 11% in the quarter and output of TV receivers - including digital set-top boxes - by 7%. Firms manufactur ing equipment for linking homes and businesses to the internet also did well, as did the semiconductor industry.

The latter picked up business lost by storm-damaged factories in Taiwan.

Sectors suffering declines in output included textiles and leather - underwear production was down almost 4% in the last three months - and machinery and equipment.

Dharshini David, an economist at HSBC, said the figures indicated that the manufacturing recovery has shifted up a gear, due to robust demand.

But Neil Parker of the Royal Bank of Scotland said the strength of the data may have been exaggerated by manufacturers rebuilding stock before the millennium. "We should not read too much into these figures, but they certainly suggest a more positive outlook for manufacturing," he said.

Eddie George, the Bank of England governor, yesterday denied that the Scottish economy was suffering from high interest rates designed to cool overheating in the south-east.

In a speech to the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce, he said monetary policy was set to curb inflation in the economy as a whole and that there was no evidence that growth and employment were suffering. He said that employment in Scotland was around its all-time high and that the Scottish economy had grown by an average of 2.6% over the past seven years or so, compared to 2.8% for the economy as a whole.

fields.headline: Salomon wins Schroders
fields.standfirst: One of the last blue-blooded banks falls to US group for £1.3bn
fields.trailText: One of the last of the City's blue-blooded banks fell into foreign hands yesterday when Schroders sold its investment banking business to Salomon Smith Barney.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor and Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
One of the last of the City's blue-blooded banks fell into foreign hands yesterday when Schroders sold its investment banking business to Salomon Smith Barney.

The £1.3bn deal with part of the world's largest financial firm Citigroup will land a £360m windfall for the Schroder family - already the eighth richest in the country - and promises hefty "golden handcuffs" for the Schroders investment bankers who will join the US firm.

While the sale immediately evoked fears of large scale jobs cut in the City, the worst of the pain is expected to be felt on Wall Street where Schroders employs 1,800 bankers whose franchise is being consigned to the history books.

The two groups, which said they were creating a "powerful new force" in in vestment banking, however, tried to play down job cuts pointing to the complementary nature of the businesses.

Schroders, which is in the FTSE 100 index, will retain its troubled investment management arm and remain listed. It intends to invest £450m of the sale proceeds, which are not being returned to shareholders, to beef up its fund management business and launch a new private banking operation.

The firm insisted that the new-look company had the backing of the Schroder family - led by Bruno - who will retain almost 50% in the slimmed-down entity. It was unclear last night whether the family would take their 40% share in the £90m being distributed to shareholders in cash - and face a tax bill - or take loan notes or shares in Citigroup, Salomon Smith Barney's parent company. City sources said the transaction - which surprised many in the City yesterday - leaves just Robert Fleming, still con trolled by the Fleming family, as the an "independent" investment bank. The independent tag could also be applied to Cazenove, the highly regarded broking firm, and Rothschilds and Lazards whose roots both lie outside Britain. "On a combination, this is a very compelling case not just for shareholders but for staff and clients," said Sir Win Bischoff, the chairman of Schroders, who will become chairman of Citigroup in Europe.

The deal, which both sides called a "merger of equals", ends months of speculation about the future of Schroders, which had been struggling to boost its presence in the United States, where the bank has failed to make much headway since taking over Wertheim, a New York-based boutique.

Salomon Smith Barney first approached Schroders about the deal at the end of last year after it failed to cement a takeover of Beacon, a privately owned US investment bank.

The new investment bank - which will be known as Schroders Salomon Smith Barney in Europe but will lose the Schroders tag in the US - would be catapulted up to seventh in the all-important mergers and acquisitions league tables.

Neither had a reputation for advising on the biggest deals in Europe and this gap in their arsenal had become particularly important as such deals are expected to flourish over the next year as a result of increased globalisation and the introduction of the single currency.

Citigroup hopes that the acquisition will enable the combined group to be taken seriously as a "bulge bracket" investment bank along with Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

Diane Glossman, banking analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "This is certainly something that Salomon needs, especially in the European context." Citigroup had been "looking to bolster their franchise in Europe for some time", she said.

fields.headline: Focus  FTSE 100
fields.trailText: It used to be that the FTSE 100 could be succinctly described as the index of top British companies, but it is fast becoming no more than an indicator charting a small handful of truly global companies which happen to be registered in Britain.
fields.body:
It used to be that the FTSE 100 could be succinctly described as the index of top British companies, but it is fast becoming no more than an indicator charting a small handful of truly global companies which happen to be registered in Britain.

Best Investment, a private client investment adviser, yesterday joined the growing professional lobby arguing that things have got to change since the craze for mega-mergers has led to an insufferable distortion.

"A great many of the companies dominating the UK indices are truly global," said Best's deputy managing director Jason Hollands. "They happen to be quoted in London for historical reasons.

"Indexation and increasing requirement for investment managers to benchmark funds mean that investors who believe they are buying British are largely being steered into a random set of global companies concentrated around the pharma, oil, banking and telecoms sectors. They are ignoring other global leaders such as Microsoft - which happen to be listed in the US."

He pointed to a worrying paradox: while tracker funds were developed as a low-risk way of following market trends, these funds are now on a collision course with rules designed to protect investors from risky positions in individual companies.

Unit trust regulations state no fund should have more than 10% invested in any one stock. But once the Glaxo Smith-Kline deal is cemented, this company will be worth 9% of the Footsie, while BP Amoco is already at this figure before the takeover of Arco. If Vodafone succeeds in bagging Mannesmann, its Footsie weighting will stand at 14%.

There is a general suspicion that the rules will bend before fund managers modernise their thinking. There is already a host of international indexes fighting for recognition, but much re-education will be required before the BBC starts running, say, the Eurotop 300.

webTitle: Viglen makes Sugar £115m in a day

fields.headline: Viglen makes Sugar £115m in a day
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Sir Alan Sugar yesterday made a paper profit of more than £100m when the value of shares in Viglen Technology, the computer software and hardware company he took over 15 months ago, almost doubled.
fields.body:
Sir Alan Sugar yesterday made a paper profit of more than £100m when the value of shares in Viglen Technology, the computer software and hardware company he took over 15 months ago, almost doubled.

The stock, worth 24p when Sir Alan bought it outright in October 1998, rose 185p to close at 366p after Viglen confirmed it was setting up a subsidiary to invest in e-commerce companies.

The Spurs chairman, who was knighted in the new year's honours, owns 73% of Viglen's equity and calculated he had made £115m on the day. "Well, it was £163m during one hour, but then I lost £450m on one day in the October 1987 crash on that basis," he said. "You don't make any money until you crystallise it."

Sir Alan - "Mr Sugar, I can't get used to being knighted" - said the purpose of the new unit was to take strategic shareholdings in existing e-commerce companies rather than to support start-ups.

In the first year the new unit will invest anything from £3m to £20m in half a dozen such companies. But the founder and chairman of the consumer electronics group Amstrad said : "We are not to be viewed in this initiative as being simply venture capitalists with too much money who will invest in anything with a dot.com.

"We will thoroughly scrutinise the companies which need our infrastructure expertise and the synergies to the technology businesses we are already in."

One analyst said of Viglen's star performance among large numbers of fallers in the FTSE small cap index: "You just have to mention e-commerce with these stocks and off they go."

Sir Alan said the aim could be to float off Viglen Internet as a separate entity but for now the goal was to build on the expertise developed by its parent in expanding the business from making and directly selling PCs into offering services such as installation, networks and training.

Viglen is now said to be knee-deep in applications to run the unit which was originally due to be unveiled with the half-year results on February 24.

The subsidiary, according to Sir Alan, will put in cash to help new e-commerce and internet-related companies pay their staff and acquire equipment.

"About 15 or 20 years ago, investment in hi-tech, growing companies meant a massive spend on capital and now it's in the salaries of employees who are developing and writing the systems," he said. Others would get help to buy capital equipment.

Sir Alan added: "Viglen has the financial resources to deal with up to five or six of these in phase one - that is, the first year." He had no intention of taking control of the new companies but nurturing them to the point when they could go to market.

Viglen, once worth £17m after a disastrous year in the run-up to Sir Alan's assuming full control, last year declared £4.3m pre-tax earnings while Amstrad surged back into the black with £9.08m.

Amstrad, which is 29% owned by Sir Alan, was dragged back into profit last year on the back of strong demand for digital television set-top boxes.

Sir Alan bought Viglen through his private company, Amshold, last October when he topped a purchase of 10m shares for £2.4m with an offer worth a further £17m.

Viglen was demerged from Amstrad in July last year after which shares fell to 14p.

With Spurs back in the top flight of the Premiership - and his knighthood - Sir Alan, written off more than once in his career, says it has been a good new year. "So far."

fields.headline: Piper and poet in tune
fields.standfirst:
Seamus Heaney/ Liam O'Flynn
The Glasgow Royal Concert Hall
****
fields.trailText: This was the great Irish poet Seamus Heaney in a unique context: in concert, alongside the renowned uilleann piper, Liam O'Flynn, in a live collaboration of words and music. It was the perfect embodiment of the Celtic Connections Festival which, in its sixth year, and with over 200 concerts across Glasgow in the next fortnight, is now the biggest winter arts festival in the country.
fields.body:
This was the great Irish poet Seamus Heaney in a unique context: in concert, alongside the renowned uilleann piper, Liam O'Flynn, in a live collaboration of words and music. It was the perfect embodiment of the Celtic Connections Festival which, in its sixth year, and with over 200 concerts across Glasgow in the next fortnight, is now the biggest winter arts festival in the country.

Even so, the appearance of Heaney and O'Flynn was something of a coup for the festival. Their show wasn't so much a honed act as an informal attempt to capture a moment of spiritual history, and at first Heaney's poems and O'Flynn's music seemed unrelated. But as the stately imagery and keening wash of the pipes progressed, it was clear that writer and musician were drawing from the same well - the darkness and light of personal experience and Irish history.

Heaney recited an early poem, from the 1966 collection Mid-term Break, about the death of a young brother. It seemed to glide into the shivering beauty of O'Flynn's Music of the Spirits - and it all began to make sense, Heaney's complex simplicity and sinewy detail serving as introductions to the laments and jigs. The six magnificent stanzas of Heaney's Keeping Going, about retaining inner freedom amid the 30-year hell of the Troubles, was a tribute to human dignity followed, appropriately, by O'Flynn's epic version of the ancient pipe tune, The Fox Chase, ending with a haunting lament for the fox and its lost freedom.

Celtic Connections may have over-reached themselves here, the pungent intimacy of this extraordinary performance sometimes lost in the vast hall. But the poet and the piper won through with the clarity and grandeur of their language.

Until January 30. Details: 0141 287 5511
