fields.headline: Rhapsodic and mature
fields.standfirst:
Freddy Kempf
Wigmore Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: The Bechstein Hall was always intended as a showcase venue for piano and chamber recitals. So if there were any Bechstein ghosts present in the Wigmore Hall for this recital, they must have been jumping for joy. Freddy Kempf is a truly remarkable player, and piano recitals don't get much more involving than this.
fields.body:
The Bechstein Hall, built nearly a century ago by the firm of piano-makers, was always intended as a showcase venue for piano and chamber recitals. So if there were any Bechstein ghosts present in the Wigmore Hall, as it now is, for this recital, they must have been jumping for joy. Freddy Kempf is a truly remarkable player, and piano recitals don't get much more involving than this.

Eight years ago Kempf became the youngest ever BBC Young Musician of the Year. It's one thing to be a child prodigy and quite another to realise all that promise, but Kempf, still in his early 20s, has blossomed into a mature and intelligent performer. Two years ago he went down a storm at the Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow. There was an outcry when he was awarded only third place, and since then Kempf has built up the kind of following in Russia that has critics struggling for superlatives and legions of female fans loitering outside his dressing room.

Not that Kempf has been aggressively marketed. He records on the BIS label rather than for one of the giants, and his next disc, released this April, will be only his second. It will include the Rachmaninov Etudes-tableaux Op 39, five of which (numbers five to nine) were performed here. Kempf launched expansively into these, capturing the differing moods and character of each.

The clangorous cathedral bells of the seventh reverberated around the hall, while the racing crescendos of the ninth surged freely, giving the impression that the music was leading the pianist and might break free at any moment.

The Rachmaninov was preceded by Beethoven's Sonata Op 110. Kempf's performance of this wistful, rhapsodic work was well thought through, sensitive and unselfconscious. The opening melody of the first movement was tenderly drawn out of the instrument; later he would be almost pawing at the keyboard to bring an insistent crescendo out of a string of repeated notes.

Kempf plays frequently as part of a piano trio, and it shows; his solo playing can sound almost like chamber music. Each inner voice has its own life and impulse, and each melodic line is picked out clearly and expressively.

Chopin's Sonata No 3, Op 58 is a lengthy work, but in Kempf's performance it seemed to fly by. The delicate semiquaver figures of the Largo, light as air, had the audience holding their breath; minutes later they were holding on to their chairs, swept along by the dazzlingly fast runs of the finale.

Kempf has a sure grasp of a mature repertoire, but with such open and generous musicianship one suspects that he could play through the Associated Board's Scales and Arpeggios book and make even that sound fascinating.

webTitle: Fund management arm vulnerable to takeover

fields.headline: Fund management arm vulnerable to takeover
fields.trailText: The decision by Schroders to sell its investment banking arm could leave the fund management division vulnerable to a takeover bid from a predator, according to industry observers last night.
fields.body:
The decision by Schroders to sell its investment banking arm could leave the fund management division vulnerable to a takeover bid from a predator, according to industry observers last night.

Schroders is Britain's biggest retail fund manager in terms of assets under management and is the country's second-largest pension fund manager, but in recent years has been hit by poor performance in its main UK funds.

Schroders stressed that selling off the investment banking operations would release cash which could be used to build up the fund management business and turn it into a much more focused asset management and private banking concern.

But, while some City observers agree with this analysis, others said the deal could leave it dangerously exposed at a time when there is no shortage of predators keen to acquire an established fund manager.

One industry commentator described Schroders as a "tasty morsel," adding: "You no longer have to worry about how to get rid of the corporate banking side because they have done it for you.

"It could enhance their attractiveness as an acquisition target for any of the zillions of predators out there."

There was also speculation that the company might be planning to attempt to buy a fund management group, such as Gartmore.

Schroders has assets under management of £14.2bn, according to figures from the Association of Unit Trusts and Investment Funds.

It is estimated to have about £65bn under management in its pension funds, putting it in second place after Mercury Asset Management.

Its investment management division was formed in 1922 and now has £132bn under management, a presence in 26 countries and 240 fund managers.

On the pensions front it has come under fire in recent years, however, for failing to keep pace with the stock market, and it has lost a number of lucrative mandates, including that of the Corporation of London.

In the year to July 1999 it lost mandates of £694m and won £700m.

One of its best-known unit trusts, the £582m Schroder Income fund, will this weekend have to endure the humiliation of appearing in discount broker Best Investment's latest "Spot the Dog" guide to Britain's worst-performing funds.

The fund is ranked 71st out of 84 funds in its sector over three years.

The company admitted last year that its British funds had underperformed over the past two years and that this had fed into its three- and five-year performance rankings, thereby discouraging financial advisers from recommending them to clients.

webTitle: Fillip for Microsoft before court struggle resumes

fields.headline: Fillip for Microsoft before court struggle resumes
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft was expected to report strong second quarter results last night, despite recent turmoil at the company, after benefiting from heavy demand for software around the world.
fields.body:
Microsoft was expected to report strong second quarter results last night, despite recent turmoil at the company, after benefiting from heavy demand for software around the world.

Shares were up more than 2% at noon as traders anticipated buoyant second quarter earnings to be published after New York markets closed.

The group was also expected to issue a strong defence of its business practices in its official rebuttal of the judge's preliminary findings in the anti-monopoly case brought by the United States government.

Legal experts said yesterday that Microsoft was likely to argue that it had not breached competition law despite the criticism from Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in his ruling two months ago.

Professor William Kovacic, of the George Washington University Law School, said: "I think we are going to see them say damn the torpedoes, full speed ahead. The substance of the document will be completely uncompromising."

Microsoft is expected to continue its aggressive stance in spite of the settlement talks being conducted by an independent mediator and the decision by the software company's founder, Bill Gates, to stand back from the day to day management of the company.

However, lawyers argued yesterday that Microsoft's stance in public may not reflect its efforts to reach a settlement; one said he would be "shocked" if Microsoft seemed to kowtow to the judge's finding that it had abused its monopoly position and harmed consumers in spite of the fact that "everybody wants this case to settle".

Prof Kovacic said the group was likely to argue that the law does not prohibit strong-arm tactics for a company, even if it is dominant in a sector.

The dominant position of the software company in the world market has helped make it a stock market darling, and analysts yesterday were discounting the impact of this stage in the long-running legal battle.

Michael Kwatinetz, head of research at CSFB's technology group, said "solid" demand for PCs and the Office word processing package could mean that Microsoft would beat his $6.1bn revenue target for the second quarter.

On average, analysts expected Microsoft's earnings to increase by about 17% from 36 cents a year ago to about 42c. Few had changed their earnings forecasts as a result of last week's management upheaval.

fields.headline: Son may achieve terminal velocity
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report

Korea Web Weekly
Democratic People's Republic of Korea
fields.trailText: It has been a typically hectic week in the life of Masayoshi Son, the Korean-Japanese tycoon who has his finger in more internet pies than anyone else on the planet.
fields.body:
It has been a typically hectic week in the life of Masayoshi Son, the Korean-Japanese tycoon who has his finger in more internet pies than anyone else on the planet.

On January 11 he announced the establishment of a $100m fund to invest in start-up internet firms in Latin America. The next day came a $300m joint venture to establish Japan's first net supermarket.

Then on Monday he held a press conference to tell the world that his company, Softbank, was hooking up with Vertical Net to create a $4m business-to-business portal.

It is business as usual for Mr Son, who claims that Softbank holds more than 7% of the publicly listed value of the world's net firms. "If people say I have expanded too fast then I am delighted, and I hope it's true, because I've always been frustrated with myself for not moving fast enough. So many new players are coming in that we cannot stand still. This year we are going to accelerate rather than slow down," Mr Son told the Guardian.

But the vast web he is spinning - Softbank has a capitalisation of one trillion yen (£60bn) - has also threatened to unravel in the past week amid signs of resentment about his influence in South Korea and doubts elsewhere about his ability to manage a rapidly expanding empire.

The unease in South Korea has been stirred up by newspaper advertisements placed by a local rival comparing Softbank, a Tokyo-based company, to the Japanese forces which tried to invade their far-eastern neighbour in the 16th century. They were placed in response to Softbank's plan to invest $100m in South Korean net start-ups.

Competition is likely to come from a group of five Korean technology companies threatening to set up their own fund to lure local firms away from Mr Son's clutches.

Softbank has responded by saying it would almost double its stake in a local investment unit. The move prompted speculation of disquiet among Softbank's Korean partners.

The comparison with colonial oppressors is a bitter irony for Mr Son. Although he was born in Japan, he has emphasised his Korean background to the point of discarding the Japanese name his family adopted.

This made him something of an outsider in the conservative old Japanese economy. But in the United States - where he studied at Berkeley - it has given him the reputation of a rebel, which has gone down well in Silicon Valley.

Since establishing Softbank in 1981, Mr Son's links - including the friendship of Bill Gates - have been his strongest suit in winning over a sceptical Japanese public. "No other Japanese venture capitalist has such connections. That is his strongest factor," says Hiroshi Yamashina of Goldman Sachs.

Softbank took off as an internet company after taking a 30% stake in Yahoo for $105m in 1995. The stocks are now worth more than $8.5bn.

Since then Mr Son has taken a slice of anything that might sell on the web. Softbank is a major shareholder in huge net groups such as GeoCities and E*Trade, and is reported to have stakes in about 120 other unlisted companies.

It was Mr Son who is credited with Rupert Murdoch's conversion to the net. NewsCorp's chief had famously claimed that the net "would destroy more businesses than it would create". Six months after that Mr Murdoch had signed a deal with Softbank.

Mr Son has also linked with the National Association of Security Dealers, who operate the Nasdaq, to set up similar markets in Japan and Europe.

Despite its success Japanese opinion is divided over Softbank. For its fans, it is a revolutionary force for the change needed to bring the country kicking and screaming into the information age.

The most symbolic change may still be to come. Softbank is part of a consortium which has applied to take over the failed Nippon Credit Bank and make it the hub of a new web finance company.

Critics say Mr Son is merely pumping air into the net bubble. Analysts say it is hard to assess Softbank holdings as most are unlisted. "He's certainly a big noise," says one sceptic, Ben Wedmore of HSBC. "But I wouldn't give Softbank 15p."

The overall direction of Softbank shares, however, has been upward, and Mr Son seems in no mood to ease the pace.

fields.headline: Dandies v puritans
fields.standfirst:
A Woman of No Importance
Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester
****
fields.trailText: "Epigrams engulf it like the sea," wrote Lytton Strachey of Oscar Wilde's 1892 play. But, while it is true it has something quotable to say about everything from fox-hunting to the House of Lords, it is also an impassioned work about sexual hypocrisy and the Victorian contest between puritanism and dandyism - something vividly realised in Marianne Elliott's vigorous, full-blooded, perfectly balanced production.
fields.body:
"Epigrams engulf it like the sea," wrote Lytton Strachey of Oscar Wilde's 1892 play. But, while it is true it has something quotable to say about everything from fox-hunting to the House of Lords, it is also an impassioned work about sexual hypocrisy and the Victorian contest between puritanism and dandyism - something vividly realised in Marianne Elliott's vigorous, full-blooded, perfectly balanced production.

The plot sounds, indeed is, melodramatic; but Wilde, like Shaw, proved that melodrama could be a vehicle for ideas. In this case we are in country-house England where the rakish Lord Illingworth has fastened on Gerald Arbuthnot to be his private secretary only to discover, when Mrs Arbuthnot appears, that the young man is the son he casually sired a generation ago. The piously possessive Mrs A is torn between protecting her son and her own reputation; and, when the truth emerges, the situation is saved only by a convenient American heiress who loves the lad to distraction.

Wilde's plot, however, is simply the clothes-horse on which he can drape his ideas. And what makes the play so fascinating is that it reveals the endless contradictions of its author. Wilde's charity and justice make him side with the wronged Mrs Arbuthnot and even with the pietistic American who roundly attacks the double standards of English life by which women are shamed and men acclaimed for their sexual indiscretions. But Wilde's aesthetic sympathies are much more engaged by the stylishly amoral Lord Illingworth and by his female counterpart, Mrs Allonby, with her mocking contempt for marriage and for "poor, awkward, reliable, necessary man". Wilde's heart lies with the puritans but his head, and his dress-sense, are with the dandies.

But the whole play is best enjoyed as a running debate, not least about relations between the sexes. Wilde is palpably on the side of women who risk death in childbirth, social obloquy in their sex lives and boredom in marriage. In one exhilarating scene the women sit down after dinner to air their discontent with the male gender. Yet Wilde also punctures their world of aristocratic privilege and highlights the bizarre comedy of married life. On one level, there is the posturing MP who preaches family values while despatching his wife and eight children to the seaside. Even funnier is the archdeacon whose unseen wife, clearly a close cousin to Lord Bracknell, is a martyr to every ailment known to man or woman.

You forgive the sentimental conclusion for the intellectual sparkiness that precedes it. Marianne Elliott's production also neatly combines style with passion. Jonny Phillips's sinisterly smooth Lord Illingworth and Diana Hardcastle's artful Mrs Allonby bat persuasively for the dandies while Geraldine Alexander's impressive Mrs Arbuthnot is all clenched virtue in black velour. Paul Chequer as her bank-clerk son has a hollow-cheeked sincerity reminiscent of the young Tom Courtenay. Richenda Carey as an unflappable hostess and Gaye Brown as a domineering aristo add greatly to the gaiety of a production that reminds us that Wilde's magnetism - in the centenary year of his death - rests on the insoluble paradox of his nature.

Until February 26. Box office: 0161-833 9833

fields.headline: Line of fire
fields.standfirst:
Connex tries to stifle criticism with £1bn plans
More about transport
fields.trailText: Commuters at London's Charing Cross gazed at the departures board last night after Connex, one of the country's poorest performing train companies, unveiled a £1bn plan to win a new franchise.
fields.body:
Commuters at London's Charing Cross gazed at the departures board last night after Connex, one of the country's poorest performing train companies, unveiled a £1bn plan to win a new franchise.

The company was accused by the leader of the train drivers' union, Aslef, of not being fit to run a public service at all, however. Mick Rix, Aslef's general secretary, challenged the conduct of the company, which is facing a series of six one-day stoppages this month and during February. They are due to start on Tuesday.

Mr Rix warned of safety problems if managers were drafted in to drive trains. "I don't believe they are a fit company to hold a franchise," he said. "Their trains are crammed full of people packed in like sardines, which Connex thinks is acceptable."

Connex chairman, Antoine Hurel, said he was not sure that either passengers, or the Strategic Rail Authority, which will have to decide on whether Connex will be granted a new franchise from 2003 stretching over 20 years, would agree.

Asked whether he thought the strikes were "politically motivated", a senior Connex manager, Geoff Harrison-Mee, said that it was no coincidence that they had been called at a time when the company was applying for a new franchise.

Under the company's plans two routes between London and the south coast will be upgraded to main lines and £500m of the £1bn spent on new rolling stock. Creches would be set up at Brighton and London Victoria.

webTitle: What the other Mr Murdoch did next

fields.headline: What the other Mr Murdoch did next
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Simon Murdoch, the man who launched Amazon.com's UK website, is to make his expertise available to British internet entrepreneurs through a new $100m venture capital fund.
fields.body:
Simon Murdoch, the man who launched Amazon.com's UK website, is to make his expertise available to British internet entrepreneurs through a new $100m venture capital fund.

He is partnering Chase Manhattan Bank to form Chase Episode-1 which is to launch what is believed to be Britain's largest dedicated internet start-up fund.

The bulk of the funding is coming from the US bank's Chase Capital Partners business, which has about $15bn (£9.3bn) under management.

Mr Murdoch set up an internet bookshop, Bookpages, in 1996 and became a multi-millionaire when he sold it two years later to Amazon.com. He was managing director of Amazon.co.uk when it launched in October 1998 and subsequently became Amazon's vice-president Europe.

He left Amazon last year and set up Episode-1 with Richard Tahta, another former Amazon executive. Episode-1's first employee was Perry Blacher, former business development manager at Microsoft UK.

The new venture will offer fast-track funding and advice to seedbed and early stage internet ventures.

"Targets for the investment will be UK start-ups with European or global aspirations who intend to use the internet in innovative ways, especially in business-to-business e-commerce," a spokesman said.

Mr Murdoch said Chase Capital Partners would provide the money and Episode-1 would inject the expertise.

"Creating a valuable internet company takes much more than a good idea and some money," he said. "You have to know how to grow at hundreds of per cent a year and yet still provide a great service for customers."

fields.headline: Brief encounters
fields.standfirst: An industrial tribunal lawyer writes
fields.trailText: An industrial tribunal lawyer writes
fields.body:
I have been living through my own personal ground hog day this week. Mr L and I meet in this way once every few months. Mr L applies for jobs with Large Public Utility plc, jobs for which he is manifestly unsuited. He applies for these jobs all over the country and each time he gets turned down he makes an application to an employment tribunal, usually alleging race discrimination.

So Mr L and I encounter each other in tribunals everywhere - London, Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds. We exchange pleasantries, then I cross-examine him again about the cases he has brought and lost, and then he loses again. There is a certain satisfying rhythm about these encounters, predictable, courteous.

Or there was. Recently, Large Public Utility plc has begun asking for and getting costs orders against Mr L. Mr L has responded with a fiendish change of strategy: he is now bringing sex discrimination cases (not usually a great ploy if you are a man). Which led us this week to this wearying exchange, in an employment tribunal up north:

Me: Now, we've been through the job description and you've agreed that you did not meet seven out of 10 of the essential criteria. So, Mr L, why do you say the fact that Mr Male Manager appointed Miss Appropriate Qualifications to this post in preference to yourself constituted sex discrimination?

Mr L: He wanted a girlfriend.

The tribunal did not have a great deal of difficulty booting this one into touch. Nor, when they heard about Mr L's campaign against Large Public Utility plc, did they have much hesitation in awarding costs against Mr L. Things turned ugly when we tried to quantify the costs. Mr L took a look at the list and emitted a squawk. He poked a finger at the modest three-figure sum that represented my brief fee. "What is this?"

I explained that it represented my payment for preparing the case and appearing on behalf of Large Public Utility plc, and covered my costs at the Executive Travel Lodge (including breakfast but excluding involvement with the minibar).

Indignation possessed Mr L. He turned an anguished face to the tribunal: "I have been against this woman SIX TIMES. She said the SAME THINGS each time. A PARROT could have done her job."

I do not think our relationship will recover. The strange inchoate rage Mr L has been directing against Large Public Utility plc has reached out and embraced me, too. And I have to confess to being a little hurt. It is not, after all, my fault that Mr L brings the same case repeatedly. Anyhow, I reckon there are some parrots who couldn't do my job.

So Mr L and I encounter each other in tribunals everywhere - London, Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds. We exchange pleasantries, then I cross-examine him again about the cases he has brought and lost, and then he loses again. There is a certain satisfying rhythm about these encounters, predictable, courteous. Or there was. Recently, Large Public Utility plc has begun asking for and getting costs orders against Mr L. Mr L has responded with a fiendish change of strategy: he is now bringing sex discrimination cases (not usually a great ploy if you are a man). Which led us this week to this wearying exchange, in an employment tribunal up north: Me: Now, we've been through the job description and you've agreed that you did not meet seven out of 10 of the essential criteria. So, Mr L, why do you say the fact that Mr Male Manager appointed Miss Appropriate Qualifications to this post in preference to yourself constituted sex discrimination? Mr L: He wanted a girlfriend. The tribunal did not have a great deal of difficulty booting this one into touch. Nor, when they heard about Mr L's campaign against Large Public Utility plc, did they have much hesitation in awarding costs against Mr L. Things turned ugly when we tried to quantify the costs. Mr L took a look at the list and emitted a squawk. He poked a finger at the modest three-figure sum that represented my brief fee. "What is this?" I explained that it represented my payment for preparing the case and appearing on behalf of Large Public Utility plc, and covered my costs at the Executive Travel Lodge (including breakfast but excluding involvement with the minibar). Indignation possessed Mr L. He turned an anguished face to the tribunal: "I have been against this woman SIX TIMES. She said the SAME THINGS each time. A PARROT could have done her job." I do not think our relationship will recover. The strange inchoate rage Mr L has been directing against Large Public Utility plc has reached out and embraced me, too. And I have to confess to being a little hurt. It is not, after all, my fault that Mr L brings the same case repeatedly. Anyhow, I reckon there are some parrots who couldn't do my job.

fields.headline: Jobless figure hits 20-year low
fields.standfirst: Download the national labour market statistics
fields.trailText: Dole queues fell to a 20-year low today as government figures showed a record number of people in work.
fields.body:
Dole queues fell to a 20-year low today as government figures showed a record number of people in work.

The number claiming benefits dropped by 21,900 in December to 1,164,400 - the lowest figure since January 1980.

The rise in employment continued to be driven by service industries. Supermarket giant Tesco today announced 7,000 new jobs under a huge expansion of its home shopping service.

The employment boom is not spread among the regions. The total fell by 7.2% in London but grew by over 9% in the north east and 7.5% in Wales.

International labour organisation figures, which include people not eligible for benefit, show that unemployment increased by 1,000 between September and November to 1,726,000.

This puts the UK jobless rate at 5.9% of the population aged between 16 and 64, nearly 2% higher than the official government figure of 4% though still at its lowest since records began in 1984.

Employment Minister Tessa Jowell today welcomed the figures.

"There are more people in jobs than ever before," she said. "Employment levels are continuing to set new records."

Average earnings are also up - increasing by the 4.9% in the year to November, unchanged from the October figure. They grew by 3.9% in the public sector compared with 5.1% in private firms.

There were fears in the City that this may lead to a further round of interest rate rises.

Employment figures by region

 North east 108,000, up 1,000 (+9.1%)
 North west 203,000, down 23,000 (-6.2%)
 Yorkshire and the Humber 156,000, down 13,000 (-6.3%)
 East midlands 119,000, up 12,000 (+5.6%)
 West midlands 175,000, up 2,000 (+6.6%)
 East 117,000, down 7,000 (-4.3%)
 London 256,000, down 7,000 (-7.2%)
 South east 164,000, down 12,000 (-4.0%)
 South west 105,000, down 10,000 (-4.2%)
 Wales 101,000, up 5,000 (+7.5%)
 Scotland 175,000, down 18,000 (-7.1%)
 Northern Ireland 50,000, down 6,000 (-6.7%)

fields.headline: Best laid plans
fields.standfirst: It's always important to have something in reserve for when the work dries up...but does it really have to involve exotic nurses, endangered animals and brushed aluminium?
fields.trailText: Barristers are a volatile and pessimistic crowd.
fields.body:
Barristers are a volatile and pessimistic crowd.

Every month or so, someone predicts the Death of the Bar and anyone whose case has settled sits around fretfully in chambers wondering what other work we might be fit for (not a lot in most cases). Then the work picks up and we all forget, griping about being overworked until the next scare.

But it's important to have a back-up plan. Tony, my client this week, has many. He brought a disability discrimination case after losing his job as a chef. Tony, who is in his late forties, has a bad back which rendered him unable to work about 68% of the time (employers' calculation).

Tony's Big Idea Number 1: "What were the two big growth industries of the late nineties?"

Me: "Umm, New Labour and the Spice Girls?"

Tony: "Ha ha. No, food and the internet. So my idea, right, is why not combine the two? I'd have this great site; you get home in the evening, hungry, don't know what to have for dinner, don't feel like going out. Solution? You just log on to Tonynet and there'd be, like, recipes you could make with what's in your cupboard or a direct link to any kind of takeaway you want; share of the proceeds to Tonynet. And there'd be loads of other stuff."

Me: "Like what?"

Tony: "Well, uhh, hampers and that."

Tony's Big Idea Number 2: (Prefaced by: "I don't know if I should share this one with you, you're probably a feminist, right?"): "When I was in hospital I got to thinking. A lot of those nurses are very attractive young girls; all sorts too, Irish, exotic. But they're making a pittance. What if someone set up a really high-class escort service, just nurses? Men would love it and those girls would probably jump at the chance to make a bit more cash."

Me: "I quite liked your internet idea."

There were lots more ideas where those came from, but after the one about gourmet dinners for jaded millionaires made out of animals from endangered species ("that had died naturally right, but weren't actually ill or anything") I stopped listening.

Tony is going to have to look elsewhere for start-up money in any event, since we lost the case. "A lot of barristers have a bit of spare cash about the place I expect," said Tony hopefully as we parted.

Me: "Times are a bit hard at the Bar."

Tony (looking suddenly anxious): "Oh well, as long as you don't go nicking any of my ideas."

Back in chambers, my roommate is making use of a slack period to redecorate our room and is holding up paint samples to the winter light.

Me: "I think we might get a bit tired of Tomato Sunset."

Roommate: "It would go quite well with our new conference table."

Me: "What new conference table?"

Roommate (flourishing sketch): "The one I've designed. The top's this incredible coloured linoleum and the legs are a sort of brushed aluminium."

The sketch shows a circle resting on four lines. An arrow pointing to the circle is neatly labelled "linoleum" and another pointing to the lines says "brushed aluminium".

Me: "Yeah, amazing. Maybe you should consider a career in furniture design."

Too late, I see the flicker of excitement in his eyes and realise that he too has a business plan to show me.
